question: Where 2.1(3) applies to a group, how must a relevant insurance group undertaking treat a parent undertaking that is an insurance holding company without its head office in the UK or Gibraltar (or a third country insurance or reinsurance undertaking) when calculating group solvency for the purpose of 20.1, and how does that treatment align with the fact that modules 4 to 14, 16 to 19 and External Audit 2 to 4 apply at the level of that parent undertaking (unless an exception applies)?
gold_answer: In a group to which 2.1(3) applies, a relevant insurance group undertaking must, solely for the purpose of calculating group solvency for 20.1, treat the parent undertaking as if it were a UK Solvency II firm to which 2.1(1)(a) applies, even where that parent is an insurance holding company without its head office in the UK or Gibraltar, or is a third country insurance undertaking or third country reinsurance undertaking. [#SRC:9faaabced2ba31fb] This calculation-only re-characterisation sits alongside the separate rule that, when 2.1(3) applies, modules 4 to 14, 16 to 19 and External Audit 2 to 4 apply (with necessary changes) at the level of that same type of parent undertaking, unless an exception applies. [#TGT:4b76a4f92f32f4d8] Practically, this means the group solvency computation for 20.1 is performed on the basis that the parent is treated as within the UK Solvency II firm perimeter for that computation, while the broader set of specified modules and external audit provisions are also applied at the parent level (subject to the stated “unless” carve-out). [#SRC:9faaabced2ba31fb] [#TGT:4b76a4f92f32f4d8]

question: If 2.1(3) applies and the parent is an insurance holding company with no head office in the UK or Gibraltar (or a third country insurance/reinsurance undertaking), what do you do in the group solvency calculation for 20.1, and how does that connect to which rule blocks (4–14, 16–19 and External Audit 2–4) apply at the parent level unless there’s an exception?
gold_answer: When 2.1(3) applies, the group solvency calculation for the purpose of 20.1 must be done by having the relevant insurance group undertaking treat the parent undertaking—where it is an insurance holding company without its head office in the UK or Gibraltar, or a third country insurance undertaking or third country reinsurance undertaking—as a UK Solvency II firm to which 2.1(1)(a) applies, but only for that calculation. [#SRC:9faaabced2ba31fb] At the same time, the framework for what applies at the parent level is that, when 2.1(3) applies, modules 4 to 14, 16 to 19 and External Audit 2 to 4 apply with any necessary changes at the level of that parent undertaking, unless an exception applies. [#TGT:4b76a4f92f32f4d8] So you link the two by (i) using the “treat as a UK Solvency II firm” approach to run the 20.1 group solvency computation, and (ii) recognising that the parent-level compliance baseline includes those specified modules and external audit provisions (subject to the “unless” carve-out), even though the solvency treatment is expressly limited to the calculation context. [#SRC:9faaabced2ba31fb] [#TGT:4b76a4f92f32f4d8]

question: In a firm subject to the Senior Managers and Certification Regime, how should the identified Senior Management Function (SMF) oversee compliance with Article 6(2) in relation to treating on-balance-sheet originator assets as comparable to assets to be transferred to the SSPE, including what timing point must be considered and when escalation is expected?
gold_answer: A firm subject to the Senior Managers and Certification Regime is expected to designate a relevant individual performing a Senior Management Function (SMF) to provide effective oversight of securitisation issuance, and that oversight should explicitly cover how the firm applies Article 6(2) when assessing whether certain originator assets can be treated as comparable to assets intended for transfer to the SSPE. [#SRC:ecf215575f4bdc6c] For Article 6(2) purposes, the SMF’s oversight should focus on the firm’s determination that assets held on the originator’s balance sheet, which the securitisation documentation indicates meet the eligibility criteria, are only deemed comparable where the required conditions are satisfied at the time the assets are selected. [#TGT:de53496f24c9e07b] In practice, this means the SMF should ensure the firm has a process to check (i) that the documentation of the securitisation supports that the on-balance-sheet assets meet the eligibility criteria, and (ii) that the Article 6(2) conditions are evaluated at the selection point rather than later in the transaction lifecycle. [#TGT:de53496f24c9e07b] Where appropriate, the SMF is expected to escalate issues identified in this oversight of securitisation issuance to the board or a relevant sub-committee. [#SRC:ecf215575f4bdc6c]

question: In the period between a section 178 notice being submitted and the occurrence of the change in control, what ongoing monitoring is a UK domestic firm expected to perform regarding the controller or proposed controller, and what immediate notification to the PRA is required if the firm identifies potential issues with the information provided in the notice?
gold_answer: A UK domestic firm must both (i) actively monitor relevant developments about the controller or proposed controller connected to the notification and (ii) promptly alert the PRA if it discovers a potential integrity problem in what was submitted. Specifically, during the period referred to in 3.6, the firm is required to take reasonable steps to keep itself informed about the circumstances of the controller or proposed controller to which the notification related. [#SRC:e4f64412bd209979] In addition, for the period between a section 178 notice being submitted and the occurrence of the change in control, the firm must notify the PRA immediately if it becomes aware, or has information reasonably suggesting, that the person submitting the notice has or may have provided information to the PRA that was or may have been false, misleading, incomplete, or inaccurate, or that the information has or may have changed in a material particular. [#TGT:adb285c8c0a8613e] Read together, the “reasonable steps” monitoring obligation supports timely detection of changes or defects in the submitted information, while the separate duty sets the trigger and timing for escalation: once awareness or reasonable suggestion exists within that interim window, notification must be immediate. [#SRC:e4f64412bd209979] [#TGT:adb285c8c0a8613e]

question: How should institutions perform risk-category mapping for a derivative transaction when applying the rule that mapping is based on the primary risk driver, but the transaction has more than one material risk driver across one or multiple risk categories?
gold_answer: Institutions must reconcile the instruction to map on the basis of the primary risk driver (which is defined as the only material risk driver) with the derogation that addresses transactions with more than one material risk driver. [#TGT:7c541aa6ba03b9a1] Specifically, the mapping approach in the derogation applies when a derivative transaction has more than one material risk driver, requiring mapping to more than one risk category. [#SRC:28d975e9bccdd9ad] If all material risk drivers for that transaction fall within a single risk category, the institution maps the transaction only once to that category, using the most material risk driver within that category as the basis for the mapping. [#SRC:28d975e9bccdd9ad] If the material risk drivers span different risk categories, the institution maps the transaction once to each risk category in which the transaction has at least one material risk driver, and for each such category uses the most material risk driver in that category to determine the mapping. [#SRC:28d975e9bccdd9ad] In contrast, where mapping is conducted on the basis of the primary risk driver, the mapping is based on that primary risk driver and the primary risk driver is treated as the only material risk driver of the derivative transaction. [#TGT:7c541aa6ba03b9a1]

question: If a derivative has more than one material risk driver, when do institutions map it once versus mapping it to multiple risk categories, and how does that fit with the idea that mapping is based on the primary risk driver (the only material risk driver)?
gold_answer: Institutions must apply the special mapping approach for derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver, while also recognizing that mapping is otherwise performed using the primary risk driver, which is defined as the only material risk driver of the transaction. [#TGT:7c541aa6ba03b9a1] When the transaction has more than one material risk driver, institutions map it to more than one risk category. [#SRC:28d975e9bccdd9ad] The “map once” outcome happens when all of the transaction’s material risk drivers sit in the same risk category: in that case, the institution maps the transaction only a single time to that category, using the most material of those risk drivers as the basis. [#SRC:28d975e9bccdd9ad] The “map multiple times” outcome happens when the material risk drivers belong to different risk categories: then the institution maps the transaction once to each risk category for which the transaction has at least one material risk driver, and in each category the mapping is based on the most material risk driver within that category. [#SRC:28d975e9bccdd9ad] Separately, where mapping is conducted on the basis of the primary risk driver, the mapping is anchored to that primary risk driver and treats it as the only material risk driver. [#TGT:7c541aa6ba03b9a1]

question: For a firm that has not elected monthly reporting of changes in close links under 3.1, what form must be used for the notification, what content must it include, who may submit it, and by when must it be made once the firm becomes aware it has begun to have or ceased to have close links with any person?
gold_answer: A firm that has not elected to report changes in close links on a monthly basis under 3.1 must ensure a notification is made using the Close Links Notification Form, and it must be submitted as soon as reasonably practicable and in any event no later than one month after the firm becomes aware that it has begun to have, or ceased to have, close links with any person. [#TGT:a5839d75335755c9] The firm may either make the notification itself or procure that another firm in its group makes it, but in either case the notification must be made by completing the Close Links Notification Form. [#TGT:a5839d75335755c9] In addition to using that form, the notification must include all relevant information specified in the Close Links Notification Form, meaning the submission is not complete unless it contains the information the form requires. [#SRC:d6fa5c79c4012dd5] Practically, this means the firm should treat the awareness date as the trigger for the one-month backstop, while also acting promptly rather than waiting until the end of the month, and should verify that every required field or item in the form has been populated with the relevant information before submission. [#TGT:a5839d75335755c9] [#SRC:d6fa5c79c4012dd5]

question: If a firm is not using monthly reporting under 3.1 and it learns it has started or stopped having close links with someone, what form does it have to use, what information has to be included, and how quickly does it need to send the notification (including the latest deadline)?
gold_answer: If the firm has not elected monthly reporting under 3.1, it must make a notification (or arrange for another firm in its group to make it) when it becomes aware it has begun to have, or ceased to have, close links with any person. [#TGT:a5839d75335755c9] That notification must be made by completing the Close Links Notification Form, and it must be sent as soon as reasonably practicable, with an absolute deadline of no later than one month after the firm becomes aware of the start or end of the close links. [#TGT:a5839d75335755c9] Using the correct form is not enough on its own: the submission must also include all the relevant information that the Close Links Notification Form specifies, so the firm should ensure the form is completed with the required details rather than leaving required items blank. [#SRC:d6fa5c79c4012dd5] Taken together, the firm should (i) identify the awareness date as the trigger, (ii) complete the Close Links Notification Form with the relevant information required by that form, and (iii) submit it promptly and in any case within one month, whether the firm submits directly or via another group firm. [#TGT:a5839d75335755c9] [#SRC:d6fa5c79c4012dd5]

question: If the data needed for 4.13(4) isn’t available or isn’t reliable, can a firm make up data when setting the stressed FS floor, and what limits apply so the floor still meets the PRA’s minimum expectations?
gold_answer: Yes, a firm can use constructed data when some of the data referred to in 4.13(4) is missing or unreliable, but it must do so within specific limits and still meet the PRA’s expectations for the stressed FS floor. [#TGT:5f5585242ebb290e] The constructed data must be built on prudent assumptions and must be based on available and reliable data relating to the previous 30 years, so the firm cannot construct inputs without grounding them in that historical, reliable dataset. [#TGT:5f5585242ebb290e] At the same time, the PRA expects firms to maintain a floor (a minimum FS level at the appropriate point in the calculation) based on long-term average spreads as part of modelling stressed FS, and at a minimum to reapply the floor methodology and calibration described in Matching Adjustment 4.11 to 4.15. [#SRC:c25a4960dc77cc1d] If the firm changes the floor (including because it used constructed data), the firm should be able to justify those changes. [#SRC:c25a4960dc77cc1d] The firm also should not allow the change to reduce the calibration below what would have been produced by reapplying the methodology and calibration used to calculate the TPs, so the constructed-data approach must not be used to push the floor lower than that baseline. [#SRC:c25a4960dc77cc1d]

question: If a credit union has more than £10 million in total assets and also does additional activities that involve more complex investments (like supranational bonds or money market funds), what does it need to do about its investment policy, and what does the PRA expect about concentration limits (including any exception mentioned)?
gold_answer: In this situation, the credit union is expected to address both internal governance and portfolio concentration, because the passages describe expectations that apply to (a) credit unions over £10 million in assets and (b) credit unions investing in more complex investments or undertaking additional activities. [#SRC:183eb2475d6b7e0c] [#TGT:6cdd849d0a0503ce] On governance, credit unions undertaking additional activities are expected to keep an investment policy that has been approved by the board. [#SRC:183eb2475d6b7e0c] On concentration, the PRA expects credit unions with more than £10 million in total assets to comply with the concentration limits it sets out for that group, and it also applies that expectation to any credit union holding investments that fall under Rules 6.4(7) and 6.4(8) of the Credit Unions Part of the PRA Rulebook. [#TGT:6cdd849d0a0503ce] When applying those concentration limits, the PRA notes an exception for the investments listed in paragraph 11.2. [#TGT:6cdd849d0a0503ce] The additional expectations tied to the £10 million threshold and to more complex investments are indicated as being located in Chapters 11 and 14, respectively, which frames where the credit union should look for the detailed expectations. [#SRC:183eb2475d6b7e0c]

question: If an institution is working out its risk-weighted exposure amounts for trade exposures with CCPs (for Article 92(3)), what steps does it follow, and which sections/chapters tell it how to calculate the exposure values before it applies the risk weight?
gold_answer: To calculate risk-weighted exposure amounts for trade exposures with CCPs for Article 92(3), an institution must start by calculating the exposure values for its CCP trade exposures, then add those exposure values together, and then multiply the total by the relevant risk weight. [#SRC:99cd1305ee2e0e40] The exposure values used in that total must be calculated using the specified framework: Sections 1 to 8 of the Chapter and, where applicable, Section 4 of Chapter 4. [#TGT:325217a9dca51ff6] The source text also makes clear that, for this risk-weighted exposure amount calculation, the exposure values are those calculated under the paragraph-based method referenced for exposure values (paragraphs 2 and 3), and the risk weight applied is the one determined under the referenced paragraph 1. [#SRC:99cd1305ee2e0e40] Putting these together, the institution should not skip directly to applying a risk weight; it must first compute exposure values under the required Sections/Chapter approach (and the referenced paragraph method), sum them across its CCP trade exposures, and only then apply the risk weight to that sum to arrive at the risk-weighted exposure amounts. [#SRC:99cd1305ee2e0e40] [#TGT:325217a9dca51ff6]

question: When calculating group solvency, how should a participating Solvency II undertaking treat own funds of a related Solvency II undertaking that are not effectively available to cover the group SCR, given the TARGET’s assumption about which items of a related undertaking are not effectively available?
gold_answer: In calculating the group solvency for a participating Solvency II undertaking, own funds from a related Solvency II undertaking that cannot effectively be made available to cover the participating undertaking’s SCR (for which group solvency is calculated) must be excluded from the group solvency calculation, except to the limited extent those own funds are eligible to cover the related undertaking’s own SCR. [#SRC:cbb5ec092d926613] This exclusion logic is applied in the context that certain items of a related undertaking are to be treated as not effectively available to cover the group SCR, and that assumption applies across related undertakings that are Solvency II undertakings as well as related undertakings that are third country insurance undertakings, third country reinsurance undertakings, insurance holding companies, or mixed financial holding companies. [#TGT:03e8a5e9bd172697] Practically, the compliance step is to identify the relevant related undertaking and determine whether the own funds in question fall within the category of items assumed not effectively available for group SCR coverage; if they do, they are not counted toward group solvency unless (and only insofar as) they remain eligible for covering the related undertaking’s SCR. [#SRC:cbb5ec092d926613] The result is a constrained inclusion approach: effective availability for group SCR is the gatekeeper, and eligibility for the related undertaking’s SCR is the only stated basis for any residual inclusion. [#SRC:cbb5ec092d926613]

question: If a related undertaking’s items are treated as not effectively available to cover the group SCR (including when the related undertaking is a third country insurance undertaking or an insurance holding company), what does that mean for whether the related Solvency II undertaking’s own funds can be counted in the group solvency calculation?
gold_answer: If items of a related undertaking are assumed not to be effectively available to cover the group SCR, that assumption frames the availability assessment for group SCR coverage across several types of related undertakings, including Solvency II undertakings, third country insurance undertakings, third country reinsurance undertakings, insurance holding companies, and mixed financial holding companies. [#TGT:03e8a5e9bd172697] Where, in that setting, certain own funds eligible for the SCR of a related Solvency II undertaking cannot effectively be made available to cover the SCR of the participating Solvency II undertaking for which group solvency is calculated, those own funds must not be included in the group solvency calculation. [#SRC:cbb5ec092d926613] The only stated exception is narrow: the own funds may be included only if, and only to the extent that, they are eligible for covering the SCR of the related undertaking itself. [#SRC:cbb5ec092d926613] Operationally, you would (1) confirm the entity is a “related undertaking” within the types listed for the non-availability assumption, and (2) treat any own funds that are not effectively available for group SCR as excluded unless they still qualify for the related undertaking’s SCR coverage. [#TGT:03e8a5e9bd172697] This ensures group solvency reflects only own funds that are effectively available for group SCR purposes, with limited carry-through based on the related undertaking’s SCR eligibility. [#SRC:cbb5ec092d926613]

question: If a firm is working out its Class A tariff base, what SCV information does it have to use (and to what standard at the valuation date), and what kinds of account balances must it still include even if the account holder is not absolutely entitled—plus what can it leave out?
gold_answer: For the Class A tariff base, the firm must calculate using covered deposits taken from the SCV file, and it must use information that matches what the firm would have to include in its single customer view. [#SRC:95405e3eada2b4e1] [#TGT:cd1f61ae71a25acf] The information used for the calculation must also meet the extent and standard that would apply if the firm were preparing the single customer view in line with the SCV requirements as at the valuation date for the tariff base. [#TGT:cd1f61ae71a25acf] Alongside that SCV-based method, the firm must include the total balance of deposits in any account holding funds where the account holder is not absolutely entitled, and it must also include safeguarded funds under the rules when building the tariff base figure. [#SRC:95405e3eada2b4e1] Even with those inclusions, the firm is allowed to exclude any funds that it has confirmed are not covered deposits, meaning the SCV-based covered-deposit population can be reduced only where the firm has made that confirmation. [#SRC:95405e3eada2b4e1] [#TGT:cd1f61ae71a25acf]

question: For a large institution whose non-performing loans and advances ratio is at least 5%, when must it begin making the additional annual disclosures using templates UK CR2a, UK CQ2, CQ6, UK CQ8, and columns b and d of UK CQ4 and UK CQ5, and how does the “two consecutive quarters during the four quarters prior to the reference date” condition affect the first disclosure reference date?
gold_answer: A large institution with a non-performing loans and advances ratio equal to or above 5% is required to make the specified additional disclosures on an annual basis using templates UK CR2a, UK CQ2, CQ6, UK CQ8, and columns b and d of Templates UK CQ4 and UK CQ5 (with the related Annex XV templates and Annex XVI instructions). [#TGT:f4069472e0482e37] The point at which it must commence that disclosure is when it has reached or exceeded the 5% threshold in two consecutive quarters within the four quarters preceding the disclosure’s reference date. [#SRC:d188f8c0946e8de1] For the first disclosure reference date, the institution must disclose the templates that are subject to the 5% threshold if it meets the threshold on that first disclosure reference date, even as the commencement trigger is framed by the prior two-consecutive-quarters test. [#SRC:d188f8c0946e8de1] In practice, this means the institution should (i) determine whether it is a large institution and whether its ratio meets or exceeds 5%, which establishes that the annual template set applies, and (ii) check the prior four quarters to confirm two consecutive quarters at or above 5% to identify when disclosure must start, while ensuring that on the first reference date it discloses the threshold-subject templates if it is at or above 5% on that date. [#TGT:f4069472e0482e37] [#SRC:d188f8c0946e8de1]

question: If a large institution’s non-performing loans and advances ratio is 5% or more, what extra templates does it have to publish each year, and when does it have to start publishing them based on the rule about two back-to-back quarters in the last four quarters before the disclosure reference date?
gold_answer: When a large institution has a non-performing loans and advances ratio that is at least 5%, it must make the additional disclosures (linked to points (c) and (f) of Article 442 of the CRR) using templates UK CR2a, UK CQ2, CQ6, UK CQ8, and columns b and d of Templates UK CQ4 and UK CQ5, following the Annex XV templates and Annex XVI instructions, and it must do so annually. [#TGT:f4069472e0482e37] The institution must begin making disclosure in line with the 5% threshold rule once it has reached or exceeded 5% in two consecutive quarters during the four quarters before the disclosure reference date. [#SRC:d188f8c0946e8de1] For the first time it discloses, the institution must include the templates that are subject to the 5% threshold if it meets the threshold on that first disclosure reference date. [#SRC:d188f8c0946e8de1] Putting these together, the annual obligation to use the specified UK templates applies when the ratio is at or above 5%, and the start point is determined by checking whether the institution hit or exceeded 5% in two back-to-back quarters in the prior four-quarter window, while also ensuring the first disclosure reference date includes the threshold-subject templates if the ratio is at or above 5% on that date. [#TGT:f4069472e0482e37] [#SRC:d188f8c0946e8de1]

question: Where a firm has established a specific, independent and autonomous internal channel for disclosure of reportable concerns, what must the firm do to ensure that workers in a third country firm’s UK establishment can use that channel, and what information must be provided to the third country firm in the UK?
gold_answer: The firm must both (i) have an internal disclosure channel that meets the required characteristics and (ii) ensure that this channel is operationally extended to the relevant UK establishment of the third country firm, with appropriate information provided to enable use. [#TGT:e1060de75b1384d6] Specifically, the firm is required to establish, implement and maintain arrangements that allow a person (including a firm’s employee) to disclose reportable concerns internally via a channel that is specific, independent and autonomous. [#TGT:e1060de75b1384d6] In addition, the firm must provide information to the third country firm in the UK about the channel identified in 2A.2, and it must make that channel available to workers in the third country firm’s UK establishment. [#SRC:ac7d95fab418408e] Taken together, this means the firm cannot treat the internal channel as limited to its own direct employees: it must ensure the channel is available for use by workers in the third country firm’s UK establishment and must communicate the necessary channel information to the third country firm in the UK so that disclosures of reportable concerns can be made through that internal channel. [#SRC:ac7d95fab418408e] [#TGT:e1060de75b1384d6]

question: When a firm seeks to include an asset with cash flows that are not fixed in its relevant portfolio of assets under regulation 4(9) of the IRPR regulations, what specific evidential showing must it make about predictability and materiality, and how does the interpretive limitation in the related guidance constrain when such assets can be treated as not creating material risks to the quality of matching?
gold_answer: To include an asset with cash flows that are not fixed in a firm’s relevant portfolio of assets under the regulation 4(9) condition, the firm must be able to demonstrate two linked points: (1) that the non-fixed cash flows are highly predictable, and (2) that the risks to the quality of matching are not material. [#SRC:1865ea7a3f01fff9] The interpretive limitation clarifies how these points fit together for regulation 4(9): such assets are only capable of being included without giving rise to material risks to the quality of matching if the non-fixed cash flows are highly predictable. [#TGT:d2e8a1f59f1408cf] In practice, this means the firm’s evidence on predictability is not merely supportive but is the gating criterion for treating the asset as not creating material matching risk under regulation 4(9). [#TGT:d2e8a1f59f1408cf] Accordingly, the evidential package should explicitly address the predictability of the non-fixed cash flows and separately confirm that, on that basis, any residual risks to matching quality are not material. [#SRC:1865ea7a3f01fff9] If the firm cannot substantiate that the non-fixed cash flows are highly predictable, the interpretive limitation indicates the asset cannot be treated as includable on the basis that it does not give rise to material risks to the quality of matching. [#TGT:d2e8a1f59f1408cf]

question: When explaining Pillar 2B to a firm, how should the PRA describe (i) what the PRA buffer is intended to do within the capital stack relative to the TCR and combined buffer, and (ii) how Section II frames the PRA’s use of Pillar 2B in relation to weak governance and risk management and group risk (including RFB group risk)?
gold_answer: A compliant explanation should present Pillar 2B as both a defined capital layer in the PRA’s capital framework and as a supervisory tool whose determination and application are discussed in Section II, including its linkage to governance and group-risk considerations. [#SRC:1399703aeb306995] Specifically, the PRA buffer (Pillar 2B) is an amount of capital firms are expected to hold on top of their total capital requirement (TCR) and the combined buffer, and it is designed to absorb losses that could occur under a severe stress scenario while avoiding overlap with the combined buffers. [#TGT:37bcd95fb7b21224] In describing how it fits in the capital stack, the explanation should make clear that the PRA buffer, the combined buffer, and the TCR together constitute the PRA’s capital framework (as depicted by the capital stack). [#TGT:37bcd95fb7b21224] To connect this capital-stack description to Section II’s supervisory framing, the explanation should also note that Section II sets out the purpose of the PRA buffer, how it is determined, and how it relates to the CRD buffers, and it further describes the PRA’s approach to addressing weak governance and risk management under Pillar 2B as well as group risk, including RFB group risk. [#SRC:1399703aeb306995]

question: If you’re writing a short internal note on Pillar 2B, what should you say about where the PRA buffer sits compared with the TCR and the combined buffer, and how Section II links Pillar 2B to weak governance/risk management and group risk (including RFB group risk)?
gold_answer: Your note should combine (1) the capital-stack placement and function of the PRA buffer and (2) the Section II topics that explain how Pillar 2B is determined and used in supervision. [#SRC:1399703aeb306995] On placement and function, state that the PRA buffer (Pillar 2B) is an additional capital amount firms should maintain on top of their total capital requirement (TCR) and the combined buffer, and that it is intended to absorb losses that could arise in a severe stress scenario without duplicating what the combined buffers are meant to cover. [#TGT:37bcd95fb7b21224] Also state that the PRA buffer, the combined buffer, and the TCR together form the PRA’s capital framework (shown as a capital stack). [#TGT:37bcd95fb7b21224] Then link this to Section II by noting that Section II explains the purpose of the PRA buffer, how it is determined, and how it relates to the CRD buffers, and it provides the PRA’s approach to dealing with weak governance and risk management under Pillar 2B as well as group risk, including RFB group risk. [#SRC:1399703aeb306995]

question: If someone has two different life events that create temporary high balances at the same authorised entity, how do you apply the THB limit for each event, and what changes if one of the balances comes from a payment linked to personal injury or incapacity?
gold_answer: You should treat THB protection as applying to each depositor on a per-event, per-authorised-entity basis, so separate life events can be claimed separately rather than being merged into one combined cap. [#SRC:9452d37938f9afef] This approach is intended to apply to natural persons (individuals), and where a trust is involved the relevant person is the underlying beneficiary who must be an individual (with trustees able to claim for the trust as a whole where beneficiaries have less than an absolute beneficial interest, including discretionary trusts). [#SRC:9452d37938f9afef] For the amount payable, the maximum compensation sum for a THB is £1,400,000. [#TGT:b5fbb2a524d9ce87] However, if a THB arises from a payment in connection with personal injury or incapacity, there is no maximum limit for that THB compensation. [#TGT:b5fbb2a524d9ce87] Putting these together, if a depositor has two qualifying life events, you would assess compensation for each event separately, applying the £1,400,000 maximum to each event unless one event is personal-injury/incapacity-related, in which case that event is not capped. [#SRC:9452d37938f9afef] [#TGT:b5fbb2a524d9ce87]

question: When an insurer is setting up its risk monitoring metrics and determining any liquidity buffer(s) it holds, how do the investment and liquidity expectations described for UK Solvency II firms (and related entities) and for non-Directive insurers shape what that liquidity buffer is intended to achieve, including the conditions under which it is expected to operate?
gold_answer: In establishing the insurer’s risk monitoring metrics and determining any liquidity buffer(s) it holds, the liquidity buffer should be framed as a stock of liquid assets designed to support meeting liabilities as they fall due, and the monitoring metrics should be capable of tracking that buffer and related liquidity characteristics. [#SRC:9c279e6bff2a8352] For a UK Solvency II firm, the Society and managing agents, the investment approach is described as needing to ensure the liquidity of the investment portfolio and to include consideration of whether assets are appropriate to meet obligations as they fall due. [#TGT:69f861caa7c533e0] In addition, the described guideline expectations indicate the insurer should consider total liquidity needs (including an appropriate liquidity buffer), the level and monitoring of liquid assets, and potential haircuts that could apply on sale of those assets—elements that can be reflected in the design of risk monitoring metrics. [#TGT:69f861caa7c533e0] For a non-Directive insurer, the stated standard is to maintain adequate liquidity so there is no significant risk that liabilities cannot be met as they fall due, which aligns the purpose of any liquidity buffer(s) with that outcome. [#TGT:69f861caa7c533e0] Finally, the liquidity buffer is expected to be sufficient under both benign and stressed conditions, which should be incorporated into how the insurer calibrates and monitors the buffer within its metrics. [#TGT:69f861caa7c533e0]

question: If a firm’s recovery plan has to cover severe stress scenarios (including system-wide events and stress affecting individual legal persons and groups), what should a TWD firm be able to do with sensitivity analysis so senior management can see the range of capital and liquidity outcomes, and how many scenarios must G-SIIs and O-SIIs analyse at a minimum?
gold_answer: The recovery plan should cover a range of severe macroeconomic and financial stress scenarios that fit the firm’s own conditions, including system-wide events and stress that is specific to individual legal persons and to groups. [#TGT:b05c0e996e2dafa2] For a TWD firm, sensitivity analysis should be used as a practical tool within that planning to quantify how different key assumptions (compared with those used in the TWD scenario) would change results. [#SRC:b6ce98b0d799fd2f] The firm should be able to use those sensitivity results to set upper and lower bounds for its key assumptions, so senior management can understand the plausible range of impacts on the firm’s capital and liquidity projections after the TWD option is executed. [#SRC:b6ce98b0d799fd2f] The sensitivity analysis capability should also be able to analyse at least the minimum baseline set of factors that are part of the TWD scenario, while also being able to consider other factors. [#SRC:b6ce98b0d799fd2f] Separately, if the firm is a global systemically important institution (G-SII) or an O-SII, SS9/17 indicates it should include analysis of at least four scenarios in its recovery plan. [#TGT:b05c0e996e2dafa2]

question: How should a firm structure its booking governance so that (i) it has a clear booking taxonomy covering remote booking, split desks/shared desks, and branch bookings, and (ii) each individual booking can be traced to a responsible individual while maintaining segregation between trade entry and independent checking?
gold_answer: A firm should implement booking governance that combines a documented booking taxonomy with clear accountability for who may book and who is responsible for the correctness of each booking. The firm should first identify and classify the booking types it uses and maintain a clear, comprehensive taxonomy that defines key terms such as remote booking (in both legal-entity and geographic senses), split desks, shared desks, and the classification of branch bookings. [#TGT:670172cefe48eb87] In parallel, the firm should define and record who is permitted to book and what constitutes a booking, including whether the trader is solely responsible, and it should articulate any distinctions between traders, sales, and sales traders. [#SRC:03d5f6afa7925703] The governance should also cover individuals booking into legal entities and branches, including traders based overseas booking into UK branches, and align those scenarios to the taxonomy’s treatment of remote and branch bookings. [#SRC:03d5f6afa7925703] The PRA expects the correctness of any given booking to be traceable to at least one (and preferably only one) responsible individual, usually the trader, which should be reflected in the firm’s booking definitions and controls. [#SRC:03d5f6afa7925703] Finally, the firm should ensure trade entry is distinct from independent checking and is performed in line with segregation of duties controls, so that the taxonomy and responsibility model do not blur execution/entry with verification. [#SRC:03d5f6afa7925703]

question: When determining the amount by which the firm is exposed to assets of each description by adjusting values under 19 to 23, how must the firm treat assets of that description that it has transferred by way of initial margin, and how does this interact with the baseline requirement for ascribing a value to assets of each description (including where no valuation provision exists)?
gold_answer: In determining the firm’s exposure to assets of each description, the firm must start by ascribing a value to assets of each description as an amount determined under the applicable rules in this Part, or—if there is no valuation provision for that description—an amount that would reasonably be paid for an immediate assignment or transfer of those assets. [#TGT:596695fe437c2dff] The firm must then determine the amount of exposure by adjusting that ascribed value in accordance with 19 to 23. [#TGT:596695fe437c2dff] As part of those adjustments, the value ascribed under 18 to 20 for assets of each description must be increased by an amount representing the value of any assets of that same description that the firm has transferred by way of initial margin. [#SRC:b5aade12a934b433] This means that, even where the initial ascribed value is derived from the Part’s valuation method (or a reasonable immediate-transfer consideration where no method is provided), the exposure calculation must incorporate an uplift reflecting initial-margin transfers for the relevant asset description when applying the 18 to 20 valuation steps within the 19 to 23 adjustment framework. [#SRC:b5aade12a934b433] [#TGT:596695fe437c2dff]

question: If the firm is working out its exposure to a type of asset by adjusting values under 19 to 23, what extra amount has to be added for assets of that type that were transferred as initial margin, and what starting value should the firm use for that asset type (especially if there is no specific valuation rule for it)?
gold_answer: To calculate exposure for each asset description, the firm must first assign a value to that asset description using the amount determined under this Part’s valuation rules, or—if there is no valuation provision for that asset description—using an amount that would reasonably be paid for an immediate assignment or transfer. [#TGT:596695fe437c2dff] The firm then determines how much it is exposed to that asset description by adjusting the ascribed value in line with 19 to 23. [#TGT:596695fe437c2dff] When applying the valuation steps under 18 to 20 within that adjustment process, the firm must increase the value ascribed for assets of the relevant description by an amount representing the value of any assets of that description that the firm has transferred by way of initial margin. [#SRC:b5aade12a934b433] In practical terms, the initial “starting value” comes from the Part’s valuation approach (or a reasonable immediate-transfer price where no approach exists), and the exposure figure must reflect an added amount for initial-margin transfers of the same asset description when the 18 to 20 valuation is used as part of the 19 to 23 adjustments. [#SRC:b5aade12a934b433] [#TGT:596695fe437c2dff]

question: If a firm gets staff from an intragroup service company and treats that as outsourcing, what written contract is expected for critical or important operational functions or activities, and does outsourcing change who is responsible for meeting PRA rules and FSMA-related obligations for UK Solvency II firms?
gold_answer: Where staff provision through an intragroup service company is treated as outsourcing, the firm should pay close attention to that relationship and, if the arrangement involves outsourcing critical or important operational functions or activities, the firm should put in place a written agreement with the service provider that clearly defines the rights and obligations of both parties. [#SRC:699d49de3bdbcc6a] However, outsourcing does not shift the firm’s accountability: if the firm outsources a function or any insurance or reinsurance activity, it still remains fully responsible for discharging all of its obligations under the PRA rules, FSMA, and other laws, rules, regulations, and administrative provisions deriving from FSMA that apply to UK Solvency II firms. [#TGT:c0c1ed2e69073245] The practical linkage is that the contract can allocate tasks and clarify expectations with the intragroup service company, but it cannot be relied on to reduce the firm’s own regulatory responsibilities. [#SRC:699d49de3bdbcc6a][#TGT:c0c1ed2e69073245] Separately, the firm should also consider whether entering into this kind of written agreement creates a need under IAS 19 to recognise the pension scheme on the authorised firm’s balance sheet. [#SRC:699d49de3bdbcc6a]

question: When preparing the notice of a society meeting and the related scrutineers report, how should the society treat (i) people who turn 18 after the notice date but on/before the meeting date and (ii) people who become shareholding or borrowing members after the notice date but before the final proxy-form receipt date, and how should the “accidental omission/non-receipt does not invalidate” principle be applied where management errors affect notice distribution?
gold_answer: The society should plan its notice process on the basis that certain individuals who join or become eligible after the notice date may still need to be sent notice, and the scrutineers report may take account of the statutory protection for genuinely accidental omission or non-receipt, while recognizing that some management-driven failures fall outside that protection. [#SRC:89ce33483e37159d] [#TGT:f23025bd819d81c5] Operationally, notice must also be given to (a) any person who will reach age 18 after the notice date but on or before the meeting date, and (b) every person who becomes a shareholding or borrowing member after the notice date but before the final date for receipt of proxy voting forms, where in either case the person would be eligible to vote at the meeting if they remained a member until then. [#SRC:89ce33483e37159d] The Schedule 16 Statement must be sent in or with the notices. [#SRC:89ce33483e37159d] For validity and reporting, accidental omission to give notice (and, in the scrutineers report context, non-receipt of notice) does not invalidate the meeting proceedings. [#SRC:89ce33483e37159d] [#TGT:f23025bd819d81c5] However, the scrutineers report should not treat as “accidental/non-receipt” cases where the society’s error reflects an erroneous management decision not to send notices to particular persons or groups, or a systemic failure such as omitting new members or excluding a class of members due to a computer-program fault. [#TGT:f23025bd819d81c5] [#SRC:89ce33483e37159d]

question: If a firm is below its combined buffer and needs to work out how much it can pay out, what percentage of its last four quarters’ profits can it distribute in each combined buffer quartile, and why shouldn’t it plan to use the combined buffer in normal business?
gold_answer: If a firm does not meet its combined buffer, it faces limits on distributions and becomes subject to a maximum distributable amount (MDA), so it cannot simply pay out profits without applying that cap. [#SRC:f0d7eff2798e540b] The MDA uses a percentage that depends on which quartile of the combined buffer the firm is in, multiplied by the sum of the last four calendar quarter profits (as defined in the referenced capital buffers provision), net of certain deductions. [#SRC:f0d7eff2798e540b] The quartile percentages set the maximum share of such profits that can be distributed: in the first quartile (where the firm meets between 75% and 100% of its combined buffer), 60% can be distributed; in the second quartile, 40%; in the third quartile, 20%; and in the fourth quartile, 0%. [#TGT:f7a8dbc40adc919d] Separately, the combined buffer is described as something firms may use in times of stress, and firms are told not to use it in the normal course of business or build a plan that assumes they will enter into it. [#SRC:f0d7eff2798e540b] Putting these together, the quartile-based MDA limits are a practical consequence of being below the combined buffer, consistent with the expectation that the buffer is not a routine funding source for distributions. [#SRC:f0d7eff2798e540b]

question: When structuring a society’s transfer scheme, how should the society identify the Qualifying Day for purposes of determining entitlement to the Statutory Cash Bonus, and which specific class of shareholders must receive the section 100(2)(b) and (4) bonus based on that Qualifying Day?
gold_answer: For a transfer scheme, the society should designate a single Qualifying Day as the controlling date for determining who must be given the right to the Statutory Cash Bonus under section 100, and it should ensure that this Qualifying Day is clearly separated from any other “reference dates” the society may use for other transfer-scheme purposes. [#SRC:1efdcc3c346d1b8a] Using that one Qualifying Day, the society must pay the bonus required by section 100(2)(b) and (4) to every shareholder of the society who (i) held shares on the Qualifying Day and (ii) was not eligible to vote on the requisite shareholding members’ resolution. [#TGT:ede0da8a1461e0fc] In practical terms, the Qualifying Day selection is not merely administrative: it is a determining factor for identifying which members must have the bonus right conferred, and it may also affect which members may receive certain rights under a proposed distribution of funds or shares in the successor company. [#SRC:1efdcc3c346d1b8a] Accordingly, the society should avoid treating multiple dates as “Qualifying Days,” because the Commission’s view is that only one Qualifying Day can apply for these purposes, and that single date then anchors the shareholder class described above for payment of the section 100(2)(b) and (4) bonus. [#SRC:1efdcc3c346d1b8a] [#TGT:ede0da8a1461e0fc]

question: If a society picks dates for its transfer scheme, what does it need to do about the Qualifying Day (compared with other reference dates), and who exactly gets the section 100(2)(b) and (4) cash bonus based on that Qualifying Day?
gold_answer: The society needs to treat the Qualifying Day as a single, specific date that drives who must be given the right to the Statutory Cash Bonus under section 100, and it must keep that Qualifying Day clearly distinct from any other “reference dates” it may choose for other parts of the transfer scheme. [#SRC:1efdcc3c346d1b8a] Once that one Qualifying Day is set, the cash bonus required by section 100(2)(b) and (4) must be paid to every shareholder of the society who held shares on the Qualifying Day and who was not eligible to vote on the requisite shareholding members’ resolution. [#TGT:ede0da8a1461e0fc] This means you cannot decide bonus eligibility by switching between different dates used elsewhere in the scheme, because the Commission’s view is that there can be only one Qualifying Day for these bonus-related purposes. [#SRC:1efdcc3c346d1b8a] The same Qualifying Day may also matter for identifying which members may receive certain rights under a proposed distribution of funds or shares in the successor company, but the bonus payment class is still defined by shareholding on the Qualifying Day plus ineligibility to vote on the requisite resolution. [#SRC:1efdcc3c346d1b8a] [#TGT:ede0da8a1461e0fc]

question: If a firm is working out surplus funds and checking whether something counts as Tier 1 own funds, what does it need to look at in Own Funds 3A and 3B, and when does it have to treat certain basic own funds items as Tier 1 (using the 3.5 and 3.6 references)?
gold_answer: The firm should connect its surplus-funds calculation work with the PRA Rulebook’s Own Funds structure, and then apply the rule that forces Tier 1 classification for certain basic own funds items when the full 3B feature set is met. [#SRC:e91fa3d6305dd52e] Specifically, the firm should use the Surplus Funds and Own Funds Parts of the PRA Rulebook when calculating surplus funds and when deciding whether it meets the criteria for Tier 1 own funds. [#SRC:e91fa3d6305dd52e] Within that, Own Funds 3A is the place to identify the relevant own funds items, while Own Funds 3B is the place to check the features that determine whether an item is classified as Tier 1. [#SRC:e91fa3d6305dd52e] For the “basic own funds items” described, the firm must treat those items as substantially having the characteristics in 3.5, assessed by taking into account the features in 3.6, and it must classify them as Tier 1 own funds when the items display all of the features set out in 3B. [#TGT:6b2cbcf4cc3413b4] So the practical sequence is: identify the item in 3A, test it against the Tier 1 feature set in 3B, and if it is one of the basic own funds items and it meets all 3B features (with the 3.5/3.6 framing), classify it as Tier 1. [#SRC:e91fa3d6305dd52e][#TGT:6b2cbcf4cc3413b4]

question: If a composite firm keeps separate accounts for its long-term insurance business and its general insurance business, what does it have to write up from those accounts about eligible own funds and the notional MCR for each business?
gold_answer: Where a composite firm maintains separate accounts for its long-term insurance business and its general insurance business so that the results and sources for each activity are shown separately, it must also produce a statement that uses those accounts as its foundation. [#TGT:eac60971cab72fc0] In that statement, the firm must identify the eligible own funds that cover the notional long-term insurance MCR and, separately, the eligible own funds that cover the notional general insurance MCR. [#SRC:0b09948a10ceade3] In practical terms, the separation of accounts across the two activities should be reflected in the statement’s structure: it should clearly distinguish the long-term insurance side from the general insurance side rather than blending them into one combined presentation. [#TGT:eac60971cab72fc0] The minimum required elements are therefore two distinct identifications—one for eligible own funds covering the notional long-term insurance MCR and one for eligible own funds covering the notional general insurance MCR—each prepared on the basis of the accounts. [#SRC:0b09948a10ceade3]

question: When a society establishes or reviews its corporate governance arrangements, how should it decide whether to have regard to the UK Corporate Governance Code or the Combined Code, and what specific scope limitation applies to the Combined Code referenced in the materials?
gold_answer: A society that is not publicly quoted is expected, when setting up and when reassessing its corporate governance arrangements, to take into account an appropriate governance code, choosing between the UK Corporate Governance Code and the Combined Code depending on which is suitable in the circumstances. [#SRC:1da93b3de3471f0b] Where the society looks to the Combined Code, the relevant Combined Code is the version on Corporate Governance that was developed by the Corporate Governance Committee of the Financial Reporting Council and is expressly tied to accounting periods that begin before 29 June 2010. [#TGT:a3566db56919a9f0] In practical terms, this means the society’s “have regard to” exercise for the Combined Code is anchored to that identified Combined Code and its stated accounting-period applicability, rather than an unspecified or open-ended version. [#TGT:a3566db56919a9f0] The trigger for considering these codes is the society’s act of establishing and reviewing its corporate governance arrangements, and the society’s non-publicly-quoted status does not remove the expectation to consider the codes; it frames the context in which the society should select the appropriate one. [#SRC:1da93b3de3471f0b]

question: If a society isn’t publicly quoted and is setting up or checking its corporate governance arrangements, what code(s) should it look at, and if it uses the Combined Code, which time period does that Combined Code cover?
gold_answer: When a society that is not publicly quoted is putting in place its corporate governance arrangements, or later reviewing them, it should take into account a recognised governance code—either the UK Corporate Governance Code or the Combined Code—whichever is appropriate for its situation. [#SRC:1da93b3de3471f0b] If the society chooses to have regard to the Combined Code, the Combined Code being referred to is the Combined Code on Corporate Governance that was developed by the Corporate Governance Committee of the Financial Reporting Council. [#TGT:a3566db56919a9f0] That referenced Combined Code is also limited by timing: it applies to accounting periods that begin before 29 June 2010. [#TGT:a3566db56919a9f0] So, the society’s decision about which code to consider happens in the context of establishing or reviewing its governance arrangements, and the Combined Code option is specifically the Financial Reporting Council committee’s version with the stated accounting-period start-date boundary. [#SRC:1da93b3de3471f0b] This links the society’s governance-review activity to a clearly identified Combined Code and its defined time scope. [#TGT:a3566db56919a9f0]

question: When assessing whether Articles 30–32 of MODR and Conditions Governing Business 7 in the PRA Rulebook apply to a firm’s arrangement with an external organisation, how should the firm distinguish between (i) an arrangement that is ‘outsourcing’ and (ii) a non-outsourcing third‑party arrangement, and what role does the ‘recurrent or ongoing basis’ consideration play in that determination?
gold_answer: Articles 30–32 of MODR and Conditions Governing Business 7 in the PRA Rulebook apply only where the arrangement meets the applicable definition of “outsourcing”; they do not apply to other firm–third party arrangements that fall outside that definition. [#SRC:ae60277c11940928] To make that distinction, the firm should start from the PRA Rulebook definition: outsourcing is any arrangement (with a service provider, supervised or not) under which the provider performs a process, service, or activity—directly or via sub-outsourcing—that the firm would otherwise carry out itself. [#TGT:b7ac6dbd1a20206b] The firm should then use the “recurrent or ongoing basis” consideration as a practical test when deciding whether an arrangement with a third party falls within that outsourcing definition, i.e., whether the third party will perform the relevant function or service (or part of it) on a recurrent or ongoing basis. [#TGT:b7ac6dbd1a20206b] Separately, the SS defines a “third party” broadly as an organisation that has entered into a business relationship or contract with a firm to provide a product or service, but that label alone does not determine whether the arrangement is outsourcing for purposes of the MODR/PRA Rulebook requirements. [#SRC:ae60277c11940928]

question: For a credit union providing a subordinated loan, how do the requirements to assess the financial implications before providing the loan and to retain a written record for five years after the date of the loan interact, and what must be documented and kept?
gold_answer: A credit union must both (i) complete an assessment of the financial implications before it provides a subordinated loan and (ii) keep a written record of that assessment for a defined period after the loan is made. [#TGT:070e1e95885eea3e] The precondition is that the credit union is in the process of providing a subordinated loan; in that case, the assessment must occur prior to provision, meaning it should be performed and finalized before the loan is made available. [#TGT:070e1e95885eea3e] Once the subordinated loan has been made, the credit union must retain a written record of the assessment referenced in 3.14, and the retention period runs for five years following the date of the subordinated loan. [#SRC:33b846227c3ca9b2] Practically, this means the credit union should ensure the assessment exists in written form (or is captured into a written record) so it can be retained for the full five-year period measured from the loan date. [#SRC:33b846227c3ca9b2] The combined effect is a before-and-after control: the assessment is required as a prerequisite to providing the loan, and the written record must then be preserved for five years after the loan date to evidence that the pre-provision assessment was carried out. [#TGT:070e1e95885eea3e] [#SRC:33b846227c3ca9b2]

question: For the agreement required by section 97(4)(b) of the 1986 Act between a society and its successor company, what termination and decision-making provisions are expected if flotation does not occur as planned, and what additional material does the PRA expect to review in that context?
gold_answer: The agreement required by section 97(4)(b) of the 1986 Act—i.e., the agreement between a society and its successor company on the terms of the transfer—should be drafted to manage the risk that flotation does not occur as anticipated. [#TGT:cf8d8f23b7b8b22d] In particular, the Transfer Agreement 52 is expected to contain an express mechanism allowing termination if, for any reason, flotation does not take place within a specified period after confirmation. [#SRC:f867fbae8f1ee6d7] Alongside that termination right, the agreement should also provide for the board to decide not to proceed where market conditions or other developments make it unreasonable to continue, taking into account the basis on which the board obtained approval of the members. [#SRC:f867fbae8f1ee6d7] These provisions together align the transfer terms agreed between the society and its successor company with the practical possibility of delay or changed circumstances affecting flotation. [#TGT:cf8d8f23b7b8b22d] In addition to the contractual provisions themselves, the PRA expects to see the society’s contingency plans, indicating that the society should be prepared to present planning materials that address how it would respond if flotation is delayed or does not occur within the specified post-confirmation period. [#SRC:f867fbae8f1ee6d7]

question: The TARGET points to “Paragraph 4.6, The Bank’s SoP on FiR.” If a Firm follows that reference, how quickly should it be able to provide its liquidity analysis, and what does it need to have in place so the analysis can be updated and adjusted during stress?
gold_answer: For the reference to “Paragraph 4.6, The Bank’s SoP on FiR,” a Firm is expected to be able to produce liquidity analysis quickly and keep it reliable and usable even when conditions deteriorate. [#TGT:6a4f41448caac1c1] On timing, the Firm should be able to make the liquidity analysis available on a T+1 basis, and it should be capable of providing it even faster when that is both necessary and appropriate. [#SRC:29dd29593feaede6] On maintaining the analysis, the Firm should be able to refresh the relevant liquidity analysis as necessary, and it should do so at the level of material entities (not only at a consolidated level). [#SRC:29dd29593feaede6] To make these outputs dependable, the Firm’s mechanism for collecting and compiling the information should be robust and should comply with the relevant data quality processes within the firm. [#SRC:29dd29593feaede6] The analysis also needs to be adaptable so it can be readily adjusted to reflect the circumstances of a stress, supporting decision-making when the stress scenario changes. [#SRC:29dd29593feaede6]

question: Where a firm holds accounts on behalf of beneficiaries (including client accounts and trust accounts) that contain or may contain eligible deposits, what must the firm do to ensure immediate identification, and what additional capability and timeframe applies if the PRA or the FSCS requests information about eligibility status?
gold_answer: A firm must ensure that beneficiary-held accounts—including client accounts and trust accounts—that contain or may contain eligible deposits are marked so they can be identified immediately. [#TGT:68113e9f6b9da4d1] In addition to applying that marking approach, the PRA expects the firm to be able to provide the PRA or the FSCS with account details that distinguish eligible accounts from ineligible accounts, so that the eligibility status is separately identifiable in what is provided. [#SRC:abfeb4bf0c334fbc] The information must be made available in a format that aligns with the relevant rule and the PRA’s statement, and it must be deliverable quickly enough to support immediate identification in practice when a request is made. [#SRC:abfeb4bf0c334fbc] Specifically, the firm must be able to produce and provide those separately identified details within twelve hours starting from the time the PRA or the FSCS makes the request. [#SRC:abfeb4bf0c334fbc] Taken together, this means the marking obligation applies to the relevant beneficiary-held accounts, and the firm must also have operational readiness to extract and supply eligibility-separated account data to the PRA or FSCS on request within the stated twelve-hour window. [#TGT:68113e9f6b9da4d1] [#SRC:abfeb4bf0c334fbc]

question: In a transfer to a specially formed successor company, how must the terms of the transfer address the society’s holding of shares by the time the society dissolves, and how does that requirement interact with the society’s ability to notify a later dissolution date in its vesting-date notice (including any limits on business activity after the vesting date)?
gold_answer: The transfer documentation must be drafted so that it ensures the society will no longer hold any shares in the specially formed successor company by the date on which the society is to dissolve. [#SRC:6b46a0ab65f37c08] In parallel, once the PRA has confirmed the transfer it will notify the FCA and the society, and the society must itself notify the PRA and the FCA of the vesting date no later than seven days before that date. [#TGT:44f3b2962ff383a8] Unless the society gives a notice that specifies a later dissolution date, the society is dissolved on the vesting date; however, if it is necessary to facilitate disposal of the society’s shares in its successor, the society may include in the vesting-date notice a later dissolution date, and dissolution then occurs on that later date. [#TGT:44f3b2962ff383a8] The share-disposal linkage is that the transfer terms must still secure that the society ceases to hold any shares by the (possibly later) dissolution date identified through this notice mechanism. [#SRC:6b46a0ab65f37c08] If the society uses the later-dissolution option, it must stop transacting business from the notified vesting date, except business needed to dispose of its shares in its successor. [#TGT:44f3b2962ff383a8]

question: If a society plans to dissolve after a transfer to a specially formed successor company, what must the transfer terms achieve about the society’s shares by the dissolution date, and what notices and timing rules apply for telling the PRA and the FCA the vesting date (including when dissolution happens and what the society can do after the vesting date if it sets a later dissolution date)?
gold_answer: The transfer terms must include a mechanism that makes sure the society will stop holding any shares in the specially formed successor company by the date the society is due to dissolve. [#SRC:6b46a0ab65f37c08] After the PRA confirms the transfer, it will notify the FCA and the society, and the society must also notify both the PRA and the FCA of the vesting date at least seven days before that date. [#TGT:44f3b2962ff383a8] If the society does not give a notice specifying a later dissolution date, dissolution happens on the vesting date. [#TGT:44f3b2962ff383a8] If disposing of the society’s shares in its successor requires more time, the society may include in its vesting-date notice a later dissolution date, and dissolution then occurs on that later date. [#TGT:44f3b2962ff383a8] This matters for the transfer terms because the “no shares held” outcome must be achieved by whatever dissolution date applies (whether the vesting date or a later date notified to facilitate share disposal). [#SRC:6b46a0ab65f37c08] When a later dissolution date is notified, the society must stop doing business from the vesting date except what is needed to dispose of its shares in its successor. [#TGT:44f3b2962ff383a8]

question: For a derivative transaction that is mapped to the commodity risk category and has more than one material risk driver (including transactions referred to in Article 277(3)), how must an institution determine (i) whether the transaction is mapped once or multiple times across risk categories, and (ii) which risk driver basis is then used to assign the transaction to a hedging set within the commodity risk category?
gold_answer: An institution must first decide how many risk-category mappings are required for the derivative transaction, and then—once the transaction is mapped to the commodity risk category—assign it to a commodity hedging set using the appropriate risk-driver basis. [#SRC:820ffbb74005c855] For derivatives with more than one material risk driver, the institution must map the transaction to more than one risk category as a derogation from paragraph 2. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] If all material risk drivers fall within a single risk category, the transaction is mapped only once to that category, using the most material of those risk drivers as the basis for that single mapping. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] If the material risk drivers span different risk categories, the transaction is mapped once to each relevant risk category for which it has at least one material risk driver, and the mapping within each category is based on the most material risk driver in that category. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] After the transaction is mapped to the commodity risk category (including for transactions referred to in Article 277(3)), it must be assigned to one of the commodity hedging sets based on the nature of its primary risk driver, or—where applicable—the most material risk driver in the commodity risk category. [#SRC:820ffbb74005c855]

question: If a derivative has several important risk drivers and at least one of them puts it in the commodity risk category, when do you map it to more than one risk category, and how do you then pick the risk driver to place it into a commodity hedging set (including for transactions referred to in Article 277(3))?
gold_answer: You must handle the mapping step first, and then use the commodity-specific rule to place the transaction into a hedging set once it is in the commodity risk category. [#SRC:820ffbb74005c855] If the derivative has more than one material risk driver, you generally map it to more than one risk category. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] However, if all of its material risk drivers are within the same risk category, you only map it once to that single category, and you base that mapping on the most material of those risk drivers. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] If its material risk drivers sit in different risk categories, you map it once to each risk category where it has at least one material risk driver, and for each category you use the most material risk driver within that category as the basis for the mapping. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] Once the transaction is mapped to the commodity risk category (including transactions referred to in Article 277(3)), you must assign it to one of the commodity hedging sets based on the nature of its primary risk driver, or (for those Article 277(3) transactions) the most material risk driver in the commodity risk category. [#SRC:820ffbb74005c855]

question: Where an institution acts as a clearing member and, in that capacity, serves as a financial intermediary between a client and a CCP, how should it align (i) the calculation of own funds requirements for CCP-related transactions with that client and (ii) its internal assessment of whether own funds held against CCP exposures are adequate, including exposures arising from contractual arrangements referred to in Article 304?
gold_answer: An institution acting as a clearing member and, in that capacity, as a financial intermediary between a client and a CCP must calculate the own funds requirements for its CCP-related transactions with that client using the specified framework (Sections 1 to 8 of the Chapter, Section 4 of Chapter 4 of the Title, and Title VI, as applicable). [#TGT:44da4c43fe9df94e] In parallel, it must assess—using appropriate scenario analysis and stress testing—whether the level of own funds it holds against its exposures to a CCP adequately reflects the inherent risks of those exposures. [#SRC:a3a91a063d2c4fd0] This adequacy assessment must cover not only general CCP exposures and potential future or contingent credit exposures, but also exposures arising from default fund contributions. [#SRC:a3a91a063d2c4fd0] Additionally, because the institution is a clearing member, the assessment must also include exposures that result from contractual arrangements as laid down in Article 304, ensuring those contractual-arrangement exposures are captured in the stress/scenario-based evaluation of own-funds sufficiency. [#SRC:a3a91a063d2c4fd0] Practically, the institution should ensure that the own-funds amounts produced by the required calculation approach for the client-facing CCP-related transactions are then tested for risk-adequacy against the full set of CCP exposure types identified for clearing members, including the Article 304 contractual-arrangement exposures. [#TGT:44da4c43fe9df94e] [#SRC:a3a91a063d2c4fd0]

question: When the Prudential Regulator is considering whether to confirm a merger under the criteria prescribed by section 95(4) of the 1986 Act (the Three Criteria), how does section 95(6) operate if defects mean the PRA would otherwise be precluded from confirming, and what are the possible outcomes depending on whether the defects are substantially remedied?
gold_answer: When deciding whether to confirm a merger, the Prudential Regulator must consider the criteria prescribed by section 95(4) of the 1986 Act (the Three Criteria). [#TGT:f876d164651d21b2] If the PRA would be unable to confirm because of defects that fall within those Three Criteria, section 95(6) allows the PRA to direct a society to remedy the defects rather than immediately refusing confirmation. [#SRC:8ba3cc430698d0ee] A direction under section 95(6) can require procedural steps such as calling a further meeting, including to hold a new vote after issuing a revised Schedule 16 Statement that includes material information previously omitted, or after fixing defects in the systems used to send meeting notices and Statements and to validate votes. [#SRC:8ba3cc430698d0ee] After the society has acted, the PRA assesses whether the defects have been substantially remedied, based on evidence furnished by the society. [#SRC:8ba3cc430698d0ee] If the PRA is satisfied on that evidence that the defects have been substantially remedied, it must confirm the merger (i.e., the Three Criteria no longer preclude confirmation). [#SRC:8ba3cc430698d0ee] If the PRA is not satisfied, confirmation must be refused. [#SRC:8ba3cc430698d0ee]

question: When an institution is calculating exposure values for OTC derivatives under the methods in Sections 3, 4 and 5, how should it treat two perfectly matching OTC derivative contracts that are in the same netting agreement, and how does that treatment interact with whether the institution may calculate a single exposure value for all transactions within a contractual netting agreement or must calculate exposures separately per transaction?
gold_answer: An institution can, when applying the exposure-calculation methods in Sections 3, 4 and 5, combine two OTC derivative contracts that are both (i) included in the same netting agreement and (ii) perfectly matching, by treating them as though they were one contract with a notional principal of zero. [#SRC:14f4743e51835715] In parallel, the institution’s ability to compute one exposure value for all transactions within a contractual netting agreement depends on whether all conditions in Article 274(1) are satisfied; if they are, a single exposure value may be calculated for the whole agreement, and if they are not, an exposure value must be calculated separately for each transaction and each such transaction is treated as its own netting set. [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c] Read together, the “perfectly matching” treatment is a specific calculation approach available within the Section 3–5 methods for two matching OTC derivatives in the same netting agreement, while the broader question of whether exposures are aggregated across the contractual netting agreement or split by transaction turns on meeting (or not meeting) the Article 274(1) conditions. [#SRC:14f4743e51835715] [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c]

question: If you’re writing a short note on SEC-SA and SEC-IRBA, how do you explain (1) what “non-neutrality” usually does to total RWAs compared with the underlying portfolio, and (2) why that doesn’t mean the methods fully pick up non-credit risks—especially given the STS/non-STS floors and the “p” factor?
gold_answer: You should say that “non-neutrality” usually means the total RWAs for the securitisation tranches come out higher than the RWAs that would have been calculated for the underlying portfolio if it had stayed unsecuritised. [#TGT:dbb9be39416dec17] You should then connect that to how SEC-SA and SEC-IRBA work: they can only recognise a defined number of items in their capital calculation and are mainly focused on credit risk, so they may fail to recognise non-credit risks. [#SRC:b660733416fb3965] The linkage is that some additional non-credit risks from securitisation are reflected to an extent through this non-neutrality, but the size of that effect is driven by pre-defined inputs such as STS status rather than a broad capture of all non-credit risks. [#SRC:b660733416fb3965] To make the mechanism concrete, explain that in SEC-SA and SEC-IRBA the non-neutrality is introduced mainly by applying a risk weight floor—10% for STS positions and 15% for non-STS positions—together with the supervisory “p” factor. [#TGT:dbb9be39416dec17] This shows why higher tranche RWAs can occur while still leaving gaps in recognising non-credit risks. [#SRC:b660733416fb3965]

question: If the Merger Notification Statement has to be approved by the PRA before it goes to members, what does the board need to say about any financial changes since the financial period ended, and what compensation details must be included for directors or other officers of the transferor society?
gold_answer: The Merger Notification Statement cannot be sent to members until it has been approved by the PRA, and it must then be sent within the specified time limit. [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc] Because the financial information used will cover a period ending before the date the Schedule 16 Statement is approved, the board must tell members whether there have been any material changes to the financial position in the period between the financial information’s end date and the approval date. [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1] Where a material change has been identified but cannot be measured in numbers, the board must still explain the change in words so members know it has been identified and is relevant to their decision on the proposed merger. [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1] Separately, the Merger Notification Statement must set out particulars of any compensation payable to directors or other officers of the transferor society where the PRA has consented to that compensation under paragraph 2(1) of Schedule 8A to the 1986 Act. [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc] The board should also be aware that not disclosing interim material changes will matter to the PRA when it later considers the society’s application for confirmation of the merger. [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1]

question: For a firm that is a UK ISPV, who must sign the record referred to in 5.4 (including each updated version), given that 5.4 applies with a modified meaning for “key function holder”?
gold_answer: For a firm that is a UK ISPV, the signature requirement for the 5.4 record applies, but the person described as the “key function holder” is treated as a PRA senior management function holder for this purpose. [#SRC:72db45975ca3958c] Accordingly, the record in 5.4 and every updated version must be signed by (i) the relevant PRA senior management function holder (standing in for the key function holder) and (ii) an appropriate representative of the firm.
