[#TGT:8e03ecfaf3ea1715] This means the firm should ensure that, whenever the 5.4 record is created or updated, the required two signatories are obtained: one being the PRA senior management function holder (because the UK ISPV modification changes who counts as the key function holder), and the other being an appropriate representative of the firm. [#SRC:72db45975ca3958c] The obligation extends to each updated version, so the firm must repeat the signing process on updates rather than relying only on the original signatures. [#TGT:8e03ecfaf3ea1715]

question: When adjusting the value ascribed to assets under 18 to 19, in what circumstances must a firm treat assets as being deemed acquired or disposed of pursuant to an option, and how does that deemed treatment affect the increase or decrease applied for assets of the relevant description?
gold_answer: A firm must adjust the value ascribed under 18 to 19 for each asset description by adding or subtracting the value of assets of that description that the firm is treated as having acquired or disposed of under an option. [#TGT:edaf68ec91a76124] For the purposes of 20.1, that deemed acquisition or disposal arises only where, at the relevant date, the firm is a party to an option and it is prudent to assume the option will be exercised, and the option is of the type described in the rule. [#SRC:bd531cb4e2558157] In practice, this means the firm first identifies whether, at the relevant date, it meets the option-party and prudent-assumption conditions that trigger deemed acquisition/disposal under 20.1. [#SRC:bd531cb4e2558157] If those conditions are met, the firm must then reflect the resulting deemed position directly in the 18 to 19 valuation by increasing or decreasing the value ascribed for the corresponding asset description by the value of the assets deemed acquired or disposed of. [#TGT:edaf68ec91a76124] The direction of the adjustment (increase versus decrease) follows whether the firm is deemed to have acquired or to have disposed of assets pursuant to the option. [#TGT:edaf68ec91a76124]

question: If a firm has an option, when does it count as having acquired or disposed of assets for valuation purposes, and what does it then do to the values it has worked out under 18 to 19 for that type of asset?
gold_answer: The firm only treats itself as having acquired or disposed of assets because of an option when, at the relevant date, it is a party to the option and it is prudent to assume the option will be exercised, and the option is one that fits the rule’s description for 20.1. [#SRC:bd531cb4e2558157] Once that deemed acquisition or disposal applies, the firm must adjust the value it has ascribed under 18 to 19 for each asset description by incorporating the value of the assets of that same description that are deemed acquired or disposed of under the option. [#TGT:edaf68ec91a76124] Concretely, the firm should (i) determine whether the relevant-date conditions for being deemed to have acquired or disposed of assets pursuant to an option are met, and (ii) if they are, increase or decrease the 18 to 19 value for that asset description by the value of the assets deemed acquired or disposed of. [#SRC:bd531cb4e2558157] [#TGT:edaf68ec91a76124] The adjustment is made at the level of “assets of each description,” so the deemed option effect is applied to the matching category rather than being treated as a general, undifferentiated change. [#TGT:edaf68ec91a76124]

question: How should a firm reconcile the requirement to complete the investigation referred to in 2.1 for the first financial year ending on or after 1 January 2017 with the separate requirement that an investigation into the firm’s financial condition (in respect of its insurance business) be made every third financial year by the appropriate actuary?
gold_answer: A firm must treat the first financial year ending on or after 1 January 2017 as a mandatory completion point for the investigation referred to in 2.1, and it must also ensure that investigations into its financial condition for its insurance business occur on a recurring every-third-financial-year cycle and are carried out by the appropriate actuary. [#SRC:fbe9526d072301c2] [#TGT:3caa12ffd3bf3daf] In practice, this means the firm cannot defer the 2.1 investigation beyond that first qualifying year-end, even if its “every third financial year” cadence would otherwise place the next investigation later. [#SRC:fbe9526d072301c2] [#TGT:3caa12ffd3bf3daf] The firm should therefore (i) identify the first financial year that ends on or after 1 January 2017 and ensure the 2.1 investigation is completed for that year, and (ii) separately track the ongoing third-financial-year schedule for investigations into the firm’s financial condition in respect of its insurance business, ensuring each such investigation is made by the appropriate actuary. [#SRC:fbe9526d072301c2] [#TGT:3caa12ffd3bf3daf] Where the first qualifying year-end also happens to fall on a third-financial-year point, the firm can satisfy both requirements in that same year provided the investigation made by the appropriate actuary covers the firm’s financial condition in respect of its insurance business and is completed for that financial year. [#SRC:fbe9526d072301c2] [#TGT:3caa12ffd3bf3daf]

question: If a firm has to finish the investigation for the first financial year ending on or after 1 January 2017, how does that fit with the rule that an appropriate actuary must investigate the firm’s financial condition for its insurance business every third financial year?
gold_answer: The firm has two linked duties: it must complete the investigation referred to in 2.1 for the first financial year that ends on or after 1 January 2017, and it must also make sure an appropriate actuary carries out an investigation into the firm’s financial condition for its insurance business every third financial year. [#SRC:fbe9526d072301c2] [#TGT:3caa12ffd3bf3daf] The first duty sets a specific initial deadline tied to a particular year-end, so the firm must not let the “every third financial year” pattern push that first completion past the first qualifying financial year-end. [#SRC:fbe9526d072301c2] [#TGT:3caa12ffd3bf3daf] After meeting that initial completion requirement, the firm should continue to ensure that, on the recurring schedule, an investigation is made every third financial year and that it is performed by the appropriate actuary and focuses on the firm’s financial condition in respect of its insurance business. [#TGT:3caa12ffd3bf3daf] If the first financial year ending on or after 1 January 2017 also happens to be one of the “every third financial year” points, the firm can align the work so that the investigation completed for that year is also the actuary-led investigation into the firm’s financial condition for its insurance business. [#SRC:fbe9526d072301c2] [#TGT:3caa12ffd3bf3daf]

question: If an institution wants to use the Section 4 method to work out the exposure value of its derivative positions, what size measure must it use for its on- and off-balance-sheet derivative business, and how often (and using what date’s data) must it check that size against the thresholds?
gold_answer: To use the Section 4 method for calculating the exposure value of derivative positions, the institution must check whether the size of its on- and off-balance-sheet derivative business stays within the required limits, because the permission to use Section 4 depends on that size being no more than both thresholds set for the test. [#TGT:a1884bd4d42120b2] The size figure used for this test is not left open-ended for institutions using the methods in Sections 4 to 5 of Chapter 6 of Title II Part Three: it must be the size calculated in line with Article 273a(1) or Article 273a(2), whichever applies to the institution. [#SRC:afa72c2dcedc6ca1] The institution must perform the threshold assessment monthly, and it must use data as of the last day of each month when doing so. [#TGT:a1884bd4d42120b2] Put together, this means the month-end, monthly eligibility check for Section 4 must be based on the Article 273a calculation of derivative-business size that is tied to institutions using Sections 4 to 5 methods. [#SRC:afa72c2dcedc6ca1] The institution must also recognize that the ability to use Section 4 is stated to be subject to a restriction referenced in Article 273b(2). [#TGT:a1884bd4d42120b2]

question: How should a firm determine the permitted asset exposure limit for an asset by reference to the range 28.2 to 28.23, and what limit applies where the asset is not covered by 28.2 to 28.22 (excluding derivatives)?
gold_answer: A firm should determine the permitted asset exposure limit by using the limits specified in the referenced set of provisions, and it must also apply a specific default outcome for certain assets that fall outside most of that range. The general rule is that permitted asset exposure limits are the ones contained in provisions 28.2 through 28.23, so the firm’s starting point is to identify whether the asset is addressed within that span and then apply the corresponding limit. [#SRC:4a2c6b4a1519f187] However, there is an explicit treatment for an asset that is not covered by 28.2 through 28.22: if the asset is outside those provisions and it is not a derivative, the permitted asset exposure limit is zero (nil). [#TGT:15448cfaa68fe315] Read together, this means the firm must (i) look to 28.2–28.23 for the applicable permitted limit where the asset is covered there, and (ii) apply a nil limit for any non-derivative asset that is not covered by 28.2–28.22, even though the broader set of limits is described as 28.2–28.23. [#SRC:4a2c6b4a1519f187] [#TGT:15448cfaa68fe315]

question: If you’re checking an asset’s permitted exposure limit, where do you look for the limits, and what happens if the asset isn’t covered by 28.2 to 28.22 and it’s not a derivative?
gold_answer: You determine the permitted asset exposure limit by referring to the limits set out in the specified rule range, and you also need to apply a special “default” limit for certain assets that are not covered by most of that range. Specifically, the permitted asset exposure limits are the ones contained in 28.2 through 28.23, so you should check those provisions to see whether the asset is covered and what limit is stated there. [#SRC:4a2c6b4a1519f187] If the asset is not covered by 28.2 through 28.22 and it is not a derivative, then the permitted asset exposure limit is nil, meaning the exposure limit is zero for that asset. [#TGT:15448cfaa68fe315] Putting these together, your process is: first, look within 28.2–28.23 for an applicable limit; second, if you cannot find coverage for the asset in 28.2–28.22 and the asset is not a derivative, you must treat the permitted limit as nil rather than trying to infer a limit from elsewhere in the 28.2–28.23 range. [#SRC:4a2c6b4a1519f187] [#TGT:15448cfaa68fe315]

question: When applying Chapter 4 of the Matching Adjustment Part of the PRA Rulebook (including Rule 4.6), how should a firm treat the fundamental spread component—specifically the portion reflecting risks retained by the firm—given that the fundamental spread is calculated under rules 4.10 to 4.17?
gold_answer: A firm must exclude from the matching adjustment any fundamental spread element that reflects risks retained by the firm, even where the fundamental spread itself is determined using the calculation approach in rules 4.10 to 4.17. [#TGT:9bbf6a9cc239d53c] This exclusion is framed within Chapter 4 of the Matching Adjustment Part of the PRA Rulebook, where Rule 4.6 (restating relevant IRPR provisions) establishes that the matching adjustment is not permitted to include the fundamental spread to the extent it represents risks the firm keeps. [#SRC:9242ee9283fd69c0] In practice, the firm may still calculate the fundamental spread in accordance with 4.10 to 4.17, but it must ensure that the matching adjustment outcome does not incorporate the part of that fundamental spread that corresponds to retained risks. [#TGT:9bbf6a9cc239d53c] The compliance focus is therefore on the composition of the matching adjustment (what it includes or excludes), not on altering the prescribed method for calculating the fundamental spread under 4.10 to 4.17. [#SRC:9242ee9283fd69c0]

question: In a merger where a bonus is proposed to equalise reserves between a transferor society and a transferee society (and potentially also to pay a bonus to members of the transferee society), how should the societies determine which Merger Resolutions must include member approval of the bonus payments, taking into account the prudence condition and the prescribed-limit test based on total gross cost?
gold_answer: Member approval for any proposed bonus payment(s) must be obtained through the Merger Resolutions, and the resolution(s) that must carry that approval depend on which society’s funds are being distributed and whether the total gross cost is within the prescribed limit. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] Where a bonus is used to address differing capital ratios—such as paying members of a transferor society that has a higher capital ratio than the transferee society to help equalise the reserves brought into the combined society—the proposal still needs to be structured so that any equalisation (including any decision to also pay a bonus to members of the transferee society) is only taken forward if it is prudent to equalise reserves at a level below the transferee society’s capital ratio. [#SRC:b67dac575cd27cc6] Operationally, the Merger Resolutions should be drafted as follows: - Calculate the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es) without adjusting for prospective corporation tax recovery, and compare it to the prescribed limit. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] - If the total gross cost is within the prescribed limit, include the bonus-approval wording only in each Merger Resolution of the society whose funds are to be distributed (i.e., the paying society). [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] - If the total gross cost exceeds the prescribed limit, include the bonus-approval wording in each Merger Resolution of each participating society. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] - Ensure the rationale for any reserve equalisation (including paying both sets of members) aligns with the prudence constraint described for setting the combined society’s reserve level. [#SRC:b67dac575cd27cc6]

question: If the PRA is checking whether a home state supervisor is “equivalent,” what does it mainly look at (including what it gives extra weight to), and how is that different from the advice the PRA might give to HM Treasury under Regulation 4 of SI 2019/541?
gold_answer: For the PRA’s own purposes, the equivalence check is an overall, outcomes-based assessment used for PRA authorisation and supervision, and it is separate from any HM Treasury equivalence determinations made for other purposes. [#TGT:b4c97c646d738581] In that PRA assessment, the PRA considers whether the home state supervisor is sufficiently equivalent and whether the home state regime is consistent with the UK regulatory framework in producing appropriate outcomes that meet the PRA’s objectives. [#SRC:8e5451c44f63e11a] The PRA looks at the relevant factors together, but it places considerable weight on how extensive and high-quality co-operation is with the home state supervisor. [#SRC:8e5451c44f63e11a] It also takes into account supervision of individual firms (including branches) and the consolidated group, and it considers the nature and scale of the firm’s activities in the UK as part of that overall judgement. [#SRC:8e5451c44f63e11a] Separately, the PRA may give advice to HM Treasury under Regulation 4 of SI 2019/541, but that advice is distinct from the PRA’s own equivalence assessment for authorisation and supervision. [#TGT:b4c97c646d738581]

question: When making an application to the PRA for approval of a Schedule 16 Statement, how should the board’s declaration address other merger or takeover proposals, and how does that interact with the requirement to notify members of prescribed particulars when a proposal has been received (including the timing relative to AGM and special meeting notices for Merger Resolutions)?
gold_answer: In applying to the PRA for approval of a Schedule 16 Statement, the application must be in writing and should include a declaration made on behalf of the board stating that the Statement is complete and contains all material information that, in the directors’ opinion, members should know. [#SRC:b23ef312764c9a50] That declaration should also explicitly state whether any other merger or takeover proposals exist (confidential or otherwise) and confirm that the information provided about those proposals is correct. [#SRC:b23ef312764c9a50] Where a proposal of either kind has been received, the society must also ensure members receive a notification containing the prescribed particulars, sent to every member entitled to notice of a meeting. [#TGT:e13932686034a534] This notification may be delivered as a standalone communication or bundled with each notice of the society’s annual general meeting. [#TGT:e13932686034a534] In addition, if the prescribed-particulars notification has not already been provided, it must be included with every notice of the special meeting at which Merger Resolutions are to be moved. [#TGT:e13932686034a534] Practically, the board’s declaration about other proposals supports completeness and accuracy in the PRA submission, while the member-notification duty governs how and when prescribed particulars about received proposals must be communicated around AGM and special-meeting notices. [#SRC:b23ef312764c9a50] [#TGT:e13932686034a534]

question: If the society has received a merger or takeover proposal, what does the board need to say about proposals in the declaration that goes with the written PRA application for a Schedule 16 Statement, and when must members be sent the prescribed particulars (AGM notice vs special meeting notice for Merger Resolutions)?
gold_answer: If the society is applying to the PRA for approval of a Schedule 16 Statement, the application must be made in writing and should include a declaration made on behalf of the board. [#SRC:b23ef312764c9a50] In that declaration, the board should confirm the Statement is complete and includes all material information that, in the directors’ opinion, members should be aware of. [#SRC:b23ef312764c9a50] The declaration should also cover whether there have been any other merger or takeover proposals (including confidential ones) and confirm that the information given about those proposals is correct. [#SRC:b23ef312764c9a50] Separately, once a proposal of either kind has been received, the society must notify every member who is entitled to notice of a meeting by sending the prescribed particulars. [#TGT:e13932686034a534] That notification can be sent on its own or included with every notice of the society’s annual general meeting. [#TGT:e13932686034a534] Also, if the prescribed particulars have not already been sent, they must be included with every notice of the special meeting where Merger Resolutions will be moved. [#TGT:e13932686034a534] Together, this means the board’s declaration addresses proposal existence and accuracy for the PRA submission, while the member-notification rule controls the timing and packaging of prescribed particulars around AGM and special-meeting notices. [#SRC:b23ef312764c9a50] [#TGT:e13932686034a534]

question: For a firm or FMI using the SoP’s links to EIOPA Guidelines and Recommendations, how should it determine which materials remain relevant after the end of the transition period, including how to treat predecessor committee materials and later changes or replacements?
gold_answer: A firm or FMI should treat the SoP’s EIOPA links as a fixed reference set limited to EIOPA Guidelines and Recommendations that were in place at the end of the transition period, and should not treat post-transition EIOPA updates or new issuances as relevant for SoP purposes. [#TGT:6e9c30ab0bba7980] At the same time, the firm or FMI should not assume the linked lists are complete, because the appendices are expressly non-exhaustive and may omit certain materials (including Guidelines and Recommendations made by predecessor committees to the ESAs). [#SRC:fa6efa5299a687b0] In practice, this means the firm or FMI should (i) use the SoP links as the authoritative source set for end-of-transition EIOPA materials, as acknowledged by the Bank and PRA, and (ii) separately consider whether any omitted predecessor-committee Guidelines and Recommendations remain applicable “where relevant.” [#TGT:6e9c30ab0bba7980] [#SRC:fa6efa5299a687b0] The continuation expectation for those predecessor materials applies unless they have been revoked or superseded by later Guidelines and Recommendations or by other legislation, which provides the condition for when they no longer need to be followed even if they are not in the SoP-linked set. [#SRC:fa6efa5299a687b0] This combined approach aligns the SoP’s time boundary (end of transition period) with the separate rule that non-listed predecessor materials may still require compliance unless displaced. [#TGT:6e9c30ab0bba7980] [#SRC:fa6efa5299a687b0]

question: When giving notice of an application under the Business Transfers Regulations, how should the firm(s) structure the accompanying statement and summary so recipients can understand the scheme’s effect, and what must be made available on request (including whether the internet may be used), given that the notice must go to specified categories of policyholders and certain reinsurers and should explain how and when representations are to be made to the court?
gold_answer: The firm(s) should treat the application notice as a package that both reaches the required recipients and equips them to understand the scheme and participate effectively in the court process. The notice must be sent to all policyholders of the parties and to reinsurers (or a person acting on its behalf) whose reinsurance contracts are proposed to be transferred, unless the court directs otherwise. [#TGT:c99af11004d99259] Alongside that notice, it would normally be appropriate to include a statement setting out the scheme’s terms and summarising the scheme report, drafted so that each recipient can grasp in broad terms how the scheme is likely to affect them; this is best achieved by a clear, concise summary that still contains enough detail, avoiding an overly long or hard-to-understand summary. [#SRC:763120bb6b209201] The notice and related communications should also explain how and when affected parties’ representations should be made so the court can consider them. [#TGT:c99af11004d99259] In addition, the Business Transfers Regulations require the scheme report, the notice, and the statement to be made available to anyone who requests them, and the internet may be used to provide access where it is suitable for the person making the request. [#SRC:763120bb6b209201]

question: When a firm validates its internal credit assessment methodology and criteria for Matching Adjustment purposes, how must that validation connect (i) identification and allowance for all sources of credit risk and (ii) the requirement that internal credit assessment outcomes fall within a CRA’s plausible range and show broad consistency and no bias at asset-type and portfolio levels?
gold_answer: A firm’s validation should be designed to demonstrate both methodological soundness and outcome comparability, so that the PRA can be satisfied the internal credit assessment process is appropriately validated and produces results consistent with the CRA-based benchmarks described for Matching Adjustment. The PRA expects validation to cover the firm’s internal credit assessment methodology and criteria, including how the firm has identified and allowed for all sources of credit risk, whether using qualitative or quantitative approaches. [#SRC:4f0228446ac0d767] In addition, the validation should ensure the internal credit assessment outcomes meet the relevant outcome-focused expectations, which include being within the plausible range of issue ratings that could have resulted from a CRA and showing broad consistency and no bias versus CRA issue ratings at both the asset type and portfolio level. [#TGT:5fd5739308652721] Practically, this means the firm should not treat validation as only a model-governance exercise; it must also test whether outputs align with the plausible CRA range and are broadly consistent and unbiased across assets and the portfolio. [#TGT:5fd5739308652721] The PRA also expects the validation to ensure outcomes satisfy the points referenced in paragraph 2.4, linking the validation work to those outcome checks. [#SRC:4f0228446ac0d767] While CRA sample assessments can help evidence broad consistency, the firm should avoid solely or mechanistically relying on credit ratings when assessing creditworthiness. [#TGT:5fd5739308652721]

question: When a firm is applying the MA within the calculation of the SCR for illiquid assets, how should it treat the Chapter 4 expectations on risk identification and internal model calibration/validation, including the example expectations for Income Producing Real Estate (IPRE) loans, and what must it do if it decides those expectations are not applicable to other assets with similar features?
gold_answer: A firm applying the MA within the calculation of the SCR should treat the PRA’s Chapter 4 expectations as the relevant framework for conducting the risk identification exercise and for calibrating and validating internal models for illiquid assets. [#SRC:19764d3f3782ec08] In that context, the example expectations described for Income Producing Real Estate (IPRE) loans should be used as a reference point, and the firm should actively assess whether those example expectations are suitable for other relevant illiquid assets in its portfolio given the heterogeneity of such assets. [#TGT:4abb726bc4a4f4e9] If the firm concludes that the IPRE-related expectations are not applicable to assets that have similar features to IPRE, it must be able to provide a justification explaining why they are not applicable, and it must provide that justification upon request. [#TGT:4abb726bc4a4f4e9] The PRA’s approach to seeking assurance against these expectations is described as proportionate and is linked to using similar criteria to those discussed in paragraph 2.6 of this SS, which informs how the firm should anticipate supervisory review of its Chapter 4 work. [#TGT:4abb726bc4a4f4e9] Overall, the firm should align its MA/SCR internal model work for illiquid assets with these Chapter 4 expectations and be prepared to evidence applicability decisions and any non-applicability rationale. [#SRC:19764d3f3782ec08]

question: If a firm values a financial liability using UK-adopted international accounting standards, can it change the value later because its own credit standing changes, and how does that compare to the rule for an insurance or reinsurance undertaking in Valuation 10.1?
gold_answer: No: once the financial liability has been initially recognised, the firm is not allowed to change the valuation later just because its own credit standing has changed, and that matches the Valuation 10.1 position for an insurance or reinsurance undertaking. [#TGT:f26605efb3832de6] For context, the target rule applies where the firm is valuing financial liabilities that fall under UK-adopted international accounting standards, and it specifies that the valuation at initial recognition must be done in line with the referenced “5” requirement. [#TGT:f26605efb3832de6] The key restriction then applies after initial recognition: the firm must not make a subsequent adjustment that reflects changes in its own credit standing. [#TGT:f26605efb3832de6] The source text expresses the same outcome in the insurance/reinsurance setting by stating that there must be no valuation adjustment that takes account of a change in the own credit standing of the insurance or reinsurance undertaking. [#SRC:d6c3553c96db7f71] Putting both together, the practical compliance result is that own-credit changes are not a permitted reason to adjust the valuation after the initial recognition step, including for an insurance or reinsurance undertaking. [#TGT:f26605efb3832de6] [#SRC:d6c3553c96db7f71]

question: When a firm maintains the required record of each key function holder’s statement of responsibilities, who must sign that record, and does the signing requirement also apply to later updates to the record?
gold_answer: A firm must maintain a current record covering the statement of responsibilities for each key function holder, and that record is not complete for compliance purposes unless it is properly executed. [#TGT:1d05aec0b357c9ba] Specifically, the record referred to in 5.4 must be signed by two parties: the key function holder and an appropriate representative of the firm. [#SRC:8e03ecfaf3ea1715] This signing requirement is not limited to the initial version of the record; it also extends to every updated version, meaning that whenever the firm updates the record to keep it up to date, the updated version must again bear both signatures. [#SRC:8e03ecfaf3ea1715] In practical terms, the firm should treat “keeping an up-to-date record” as an ongoing obligation that triggers re-execution whenever the record is revised, so that the current version on file is signed by the key function holder and an appropriate firm representative. [#TGT:1d05aec0b357c9ba] This linkage ensures the firm’s up-to-date recordkeeping duty is met with a signed current record and signed updates, rather than an unsigned or partially signed document. [#SRC:8e03ecfaf3ea1715]

question: When the PRA assesses an internal model application or a firm’s continued compliance with calibration standards 22 and internal model requirements 23 for internal model permissions, how should the firm incorporate the PRA’s requested EVT-in-stress test into its regular cycle of internal model validation (including sensitivity testing and performance monitoring) so as to support assurance that the MA in stress is not overstated?
gold_answer: A firm should embed the PRA-requested EVT-in-stress test within its regular internal model validation cycle so it functions as a recurring validation tool that supports the firm’s ability to demonstrate appropriate capital requirements and provides assurance that the MA in stress is not overstated. [#SRC:197d09dc7abf48b4] [#TGT:5b30ae70a80bf3bb] In practice, the EVT-in-stress exercise should be treated as part of the firm’s ongoing validation toolkit, because the PRA indicates it will ask firms to apply a test based on the EVT in stress when assessing internal model applications and continued compliance with the relevant calibration standards and internal model requirements for permissions. [#SRC:197d09dc7abf48b4] To integrate it into the required validation cycle, the firm should align the EVT-in-stress test with the cycle elements that already must exist: monitoring internal model performance and reviewing whether the model specification remains appropriate; testing model results against experience; operating an effective statistical validation process that enables the firm to demonstrate to the PRA that capital requirements are appropriate; and testing sensitivity of results to changes in key underlying assumptions (which can be informed by stressed comparisons of economic value and Effective Value). [#TGT:5b30ae70a80bf3bb] [#SRC:197d09dc7abf48b4] The firm should also ensure the data used for the EVT-in-stress work is assessed for accuracy, completeness, and appropriateness as part of the same validation cycle. [#TGT:5b30ae70a80bf3bb]

question: If the PRA asks a firm to run a test based on EVT in stress to check that the MA in stress is not overstated, what parts of the firm’s regular internal model validation cycle should that test be tied to (like monitoring, statistical validation, sensitivity testing, and data checks)?
gold_answer: The EVT-in-stress test should be built into the firm’s regular internal model validation cycle as a repeatable check that helps the firm give the PRA assurance that the MA in stress is not overstated. [#SRC:197d09dc7abf48b4] This linkage matters because the PRA states it will ask firms, when assessing internal model applications and ongoing compliance for internal model permissions, to apply a test based on EVT in stress to support that assurance. [#SRC:197d09dc7abf48b4] To fit the test into the required validation cycle, the firm should connect it to the cycle components it must already maintain: (a) ongoing monitoring of internal model performance, review of whether the model specification remains appropriate, and testing results against experience; (b) an effective statistical validation process that allows the firm to demonstrate to the PRA that the resulting capital requirements are appropriate; (c) stability analysis, especially sensitivity testing of results to changes in key underlying assumptions (which can be informed by the stressed comparison work described for EVT in stress); and (d) checks on the accuracy, completeness, and appropriateness of the data used by the internal model. [#TGT:5b30ae70a80bf3bb] [#SRC:197d09dc7abf48b4] Using the EVT-in-stress test as part of this cycle also aligns with the PRA’s view that reassessing EVT in stress can be a helpful validation exercise for meeting internal model requirements. [#SRC:197d09dc7abf48b4]

question: When a competent authority requests information on hedging sets per risk category, how should an institution determine and report the relevant risk driver(s) for those hedging sets in light of the rule that certain derivative transactions with more than one material risk driver must be mapped to one or more risk categories?
gold_answer: An institution should respond by aligning its hedging-set reporting per risk category with the way it maps derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver across risk categories. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] Specifically, when the competent authorities request the number of hedging sets established for each risk category, the institution must make available that count together with the primary risk driver (or, for the relevant transactions, the most material risk driver in the given risk category) or, where applicable, the pair of risk drivers for each hedging set, and the number of transactions in each hedging set. [#SRC:83d0ae2a5dfdf3ce] To ensure the reported “most material risk driver in the given risk category” is coherent, the institution should use the mapping approach for multi-driver derivative transactions: if all material risk drivers fall within a single risk category, the transaction is mapped once to that category based on the most material risk driver; if material risk drivers span different risk categories, the transaction is mapped once to each relevant risk category based on the most material risk driver within that category. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] The institution’s disclosure of hedging sets and their risk driver(s) should therefore reflect the risk-category mapping outcomes and the associated transaction counts within each hedging set. [#SRC:83d0ae2a5dfdf3ce]

question: If a derivative transaction has more than one material risk driver, what does an institution need to do so it can correctly provide the competent authorities (on request) the number of hedging sets per risk category and the risk driver information for each hedging set?
gold_answer: To be able to provide the requested hedging-set information, the institution needs to map multi-risk-driver derivative transactions to risk categories in the way required, and then report hedging sets consistently with that mapping. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] When the competent authorities ask, the institution must make available (for each risk category) the number of hedging sets it has established, plus the relevant risk driver information for each hedging set (the primary risk driver or, for the relevant transactions, the most material risk driver in that risk category, or the pair of risk drivers), and also the number of transactions in each hedging set. [#SRC:83d0ae2a5dfdf3ce] For transactions with more than one material risk driver, the institution must map them to more than one risk category, except that if all material risk drivers are in the same risk category it maps the transaction only once to that category using the most material risk driver. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] If the material risk drivers fall into different risk categories, it maps the transaction once to each relevant risk category using the most material risk driver within each category, which then supports reporting the “most material risk driver in the given risk category” alongside the hedging-set counts and transaction counts. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] [#SRC:83d0ae2a5dfdf3ce]

question: Under what circumstances may a managing agent allow a single syndicate it manages to carry on both general insurance business and long-term insurance business, and how should the managing agent approach applying the Composites Part requirements in that situation?
gold_answer: A managing agent is generally prohibited from allowing both general insurance business and long-term insurance business to be carried on together through any syndicate it manages, but this prohibition is expressly framed as subject to an exception (“except where”). [#TGT:022fa162b8d30cb6] In the Composites framework, the baseline expectation is separate management of general insurance business and long-term insurance business, which in practice means separately managing syndicates that carry on general insurance business from syndicates that carry on long-term insurance business. [#SRC:112b43b1150a4cf8] Where, notwithstanding that baseline, a single syndicate carries on both types of business under the exceptions referred to at Composites 6.2, the managing agent should use the guidance in paragraphs 3.1–3.3 of SS8/15 on Composites to help determine how the requirements of the Composites Part apply to the managing agent in that mixed-business syndicate scenario. [#SRC:112b43b1150a4cf8] Accordingly, the managing agent’s compliance approach is: treat combined general and long-term business within one syndicate as permissible only within the scope of the stated exception, and then apply the Composites Part by reference to the SS8/15 paragraphs identified for that purpose. [#TGT:022fa162b8d30cb6] [#SRC:112b43b1150a4cf8]

question: If a managing agent is thinking about running both general insurance business and long-term insurance business in the same syndicate, what is the default rule, and what extra material is meant to help work out how the Composites Part applies when an exception allows it?
gold_answer: The default position is that a managing agent must not allow both general insurance business and long-term insurance business to be carried on together through any syndicate it manages, unless an exception applies. [#TGT:022fa162b8d30cb6] Consistent with that, the Composites requirements expect composite firms to keep the management of general insurance business separate from the management of long-term insurance business, which in practical terms means the managing agent should manage syndicates carrying on general insurance business separately from syndicates carrying on long-term insurance business. [#SRC:112b43b1150a4cf8] If the managing agent is in the specific situation where a single syndicate carries on both types of business under the exceptions referred to at Composites 6.2, then paragraphs 3.1–3.3 of SS8/15 on Composites are identified as intended to help determine how the Composites Part requirements apply to managing agents in that mixed syndicate case. [#SRC:112b43b1150a4cf8] So, the agent should treat “one syndicate doing both” as only possible within the stated exception, and then use the SS8/15 paragraphs to guide how to apply the Composites Part in practice. [#TGT:022fa162b8d30cb6] [#SRC:112b43b1150a4cf8]

question: When assessing how liquidity stresses at counterparties and other market participants could adversely affect an insurer, how should the insurer treat “sleeper collateral,” and what specific counterparty action involving sleeper collateral is identified as a potential stress transmission channel?
gold_answer: In evaluating how liquidity stresses at counterparties and other market participants could harm the insurer, the insurer should treat “sleeper collateral” as an unposted but contractually committed collateral amount that may become payable if and when the counterparty calls it. [#TGT:17e755beec91fb74] This matters because the passage identifies “recalling sleeper collateral” as a concrete counterparty action that can occur under stress and that could adversely affect the insurer’s liquidity position. [#SRC:4fbd64abc69cb404] The combined implication is that the insurer’s assessment should not view sleeper collateral as irrelevant simply because it has not been posted; instead, it should recognize it as a contingent liquidity demand embedded in contractual obligations that can be activated by counterparty behavior. [#TGT:17e755beec91fb74] In the same stress context, the insurer should consider that counterparties may take other actions—such as selling similar assets affecting market prices, not posting collateral required, or opening valuation disputes—that can compound liquidity pressures alongside a sleeper-collateral recall. [#SRC:4fbd64abc69cb404] Overall, sleeper collateral should be incorporated as a potential call-driven outflow risk specifically linked to the identified recall action under liquidity stress. [#SRC:4fbd64abc69cb404] [#TGT:17e755beec91fb74]

question: When a firm is determining whether an outsourcing or third party arrangement is a “material outsourcing” for PRA purposes, how should it reconcile the PRA’s use of “material outsourcing” (including its relationship to “critical or important outsourcing”) with the expectation to apply the Table 5 criteria, particularly where the arrangement involves an ICT product or service such as cloud?
gold_answer: A firm should treat the PRA’s term “material outsourcing” as the operative classification for its assessment, recognising that the PRA views it as covering what other frameworks describe as “critical or important outsourcing.” [#SRC:c6da983dfd07933b] In practical terms, that means the firm’s materiality assessment should be performed by having regard to all applicable criteria in Table 5, considering those criteria both individually and together, for any outsourcing or third party arrangement that is not already addressed by paragraphs 5.8 and 5.9. [#TGT:1899b72a48748aa1] The firm should also understand that the PRA’s approach is intended to align, in substance, with the criteria used to identify “critical or important outsourcing arrangements” under the EBA Outsourcing GL, while allowing for some justified exceptions (including exceptions that reference the PRA’s operational resilience requirements). [#SRC:c6da983dfd07933b] When the arrangement involves ICT products or services (for example, cloud), the firm should not treat the mere presence of ICT as determinative; instead, it must still apply the Table 5 criteria to decide whether the arrangement is material. [#TGT:1899b72a48748aa1] Overall, the firm’s conclusion on materiality should come from applying the Table 5 criteria within the PRA’s “material outsourcing” framing, rather than assuming ICT involvement or alternative terminology automatically sets the outcome. [#SRC:c6da983dfd07933b] [#TGT:1899b72a48748aa1]

question: When adjusting the value ascribed under 18 for assets of each description, how must a firm treat assets it is deemed to have acquired or disposed of under (i) an option and (ii) a futures contract, and how does this relate to the adjustment described as occurring from 18 to 19?
gold_answer: A firm must adjust the value ascribed under 18 for each asset description by reflecting deemed acquisitions or disposals arising under both options and futures contracts, and it must apply those adjustments in the manner described for the movement from 18 to 19. [#SRC:edaf68ec91a76124] Specifically, the value ascribed under 18 to 19 for assets of each description is required to be increased or decreased by the value of assets of that description that the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of pursuant to an option. [#SRC:edaf68ec91a76124] In parallel, the value ascribed under 18 for assets of each description is required to be increased or decreased by the value of assets of that description that the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of pursuant to a futures contract. [#TGT:ff6fa125bd63370d] Read together, these provisions mean the firm’s adjustment mechanism for values ascribed under 18 must capture deemed transactions under both instrument types, with the option-based deemed acquisitions/disposals explicitly framed as affecting the value ascribed “under 18 to 19,” while the futures-based deemed acquisitions/disposals are framed as affecting the value ascribed “under 18.” [#SRC:edaf68ec91a76124] [#TGT:ff6fa125bd63370d] The practical effect is that, for each description of assets, the firm must increase or decrease the relevant ascribed value by the corresponding value of assets deemed acquired or disposed of under either an option or a futures contract, applying the adjustment consistently with the referenced 18/19 ascription context. [#SRC:edaf68ec91a76124] [#TGT:ff6fa125bd63370d]

question: If a firm is working out the value under 18 for each type of asset, what changes does it have to make for assets it is treated as buying or selling under an option and under a futures contract, and where does the text mention the step from 18 to 19?
gold_answer: The firm has to adjust the value it assigns under 18 for each type of asset by adding or subtracting the value of assets it is treated as having acquired or disposed of under both an option and a futures contract, and the option rule is explicitly tied to the move from 18 to 19. [#SRC:edaf68ec91a76124] For options, the requirement is that the value ascribed under 18 to 19 for assets of each description must be increased or decreased by the value of assets of that description that the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of pursuant to an option. [#SRC:edaf68ec91a76124] For futures contracts, the requirement is that the value ascribed under 18 for assets of each description must be increased or decreased by the value of assets of that description that the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of pursuant to a futures contract. [#TGT:ff6fa125bd63370d] Putting these together, the firm’s calculation for each asset description must incorporate deemed acquisitions/disposals from both instruments by adjusting the relevant ascribed value upward or downward by the corresponding asset values. [#SRC:edaf68ec91a76124] [#TGT:ff6fa125bd63370d] The linkage to “18 to 19” appears in the option provision, which frames the adjustment as part of the value ascribed under 18 to 19, while the futures provision frames the adjustment as part of the value ascribed under 18. [#SRC:edaf68ec91a76124] [#TGT:ff6fa125bd63370d]

question: For a general insurer in run-off proposing a scheme of arrangement under Part 26 of the Companies Act 2006, how should the insurer integrate its PRA Rulebook obligations (including ORSA) with the PRA’s stated approach in SS3/14, and what specific SS3/14 document identification details must be used to ensure the correct supervisory statement is being applied?
gold_answer: A general insurer in run-off proposing a scheme of arrangement under Part 26 of the Companies Act 2006 should treat its PRA Rulebook duties—specifically the Risk Management chapter in the Conditions Governing Business Part, including the requirement to carry out an Own Risk and Solvency Assessment (ORSA)—as continuing compliance obligations, while also applying the PRA’s supervisory approach set out in SS3/14, because the two supervisory statements are intended to be read together for that population. [#SRC:23f45218074bd197] To ensure the correct supervisory statement is being applied, the insurer should identify SS3/14 by its full title and publication details: “The Prudential Regulation Authority’s (PRA’s) approach to schemes of arrangement proposed by PRA-authorised insurers under Part 26 of the Companies Act 2006,” issued as PRA Supervisory Statement 3/14 in April 2014, with the referenced web location provided for that statement. [#TGT:8d6a107327860924] In practice, this means the insurer should not treat the scheme process as displacing PRA Rulebook expectations (including ORSA), but instead align scheme planning and execution with the PRA’s scheme-focused supervisory approach described in SS3/14, using the specified SS3/14 identification details to avoid applying the wrong document. [#SRC:23f45218074bd197] [#TGT:8d6a107327860924]

question: When calculating the solvency of a group, how must the proportional share held by the participating undertaking be applied to data from related undertakings linked by a common management relationship, and how does this interact with the instruction that this inclusion applies notwithstanding point (4) of 11.1A and must follow points (1), (3), (4), (5) or (6) of 11.1A?
gold_answer: In calculating the solvency of a group, the calculation must reflect the proportional share held by the participating undertaking in its related undertakings, and that proportional-share approach is also the basis for including data from related undertakings that are linked by a common management relationship. [#TGT:acc84032d208c7bc] [#SRC:477b207547388eb5] Practically, this means that where the group’s solvency calculation needs to take account of related undertakings, the participating undertaking’s proportional share is the measure used to determine the extent to which those related undertakings are reflected in the group calculation. [#TGT:acc84032d208c7bc] For related undertakings linked by a common management relationship, their data must be included using that proportional-share basis, and the inclusion is to be carried out in line with points (1), (3), (4), (5) or (6) of 11.1A rather than being excluded or altered due to point (4) of 11.1A. [#SRC:477b207547388eb5] The linkage is that the group solvency calculation’s requirement to take account of proportional share is implemented, for common-management related undertakings, through the specific instruction to include their data proportionally and to do so under the specified points of 11.1A even where point (4) of 11.1A might otherwise be relevant. [#TGT:acc84032d208c7bc] [#SRC:477b207547388eb5]

question: If you are working out the solvency of a group, what do you do with the participating undertaking’s proportional share in related undertakings, and how do you treat related undertakings that are linked by a common management relationship given the rule that this applies despite point (4) of 11.1A and must follow points (1), (3), (4), (5) or (6) of 11.1A?
gold_answer: You must build the group solvency calculation so it reflects the proportional share held by the participating undertaking in its related undertakings. [#TGT:acc84032d208c7bc] When the related undertakings are linked by a common management relationship, their data must be brought into the calculation on that same proportional-share basis. [#SRC:477b207547388eb5] In addition, the common-management inclusion is not blocked or changed just because point (4) of 11.1A exists; instead, the data is included notwithstanding point (4) of 11.1A and by applying one of the specified routes in points (1), (3), (4), (5) or (6) of 11.1A. [#SRC:477b207547388eb5] Putting the two passages together: the proportional share is the required measurement for taking related undertakings into account in the group solvency calculation, and the common-management rule tells you exactly how to operationalize that measurement—include the relevant data proportionally and do it under the listed points of 11.1A even where point (4) might otherwise be thought to affect inclusion. [#TGT:acc84032d208c7bc] [#SRC:477b207547388eb5]

question: When a TWD firm writes its recovery plan, what does it need to say about the TWD option (including the active and passive wind-down periods and the cost/capital/liquidity impacts), and how do the firm’s TWD capabilities fit in for carrying out the recovery plan and BRP in real-life situations?
gold_answer: In its recovery plan, a TWD firm should describe the TWD option in a way that makes it easy to carry out in a stress, and it should back that plan with TWD capabilities that let it develop and execute the option in real-life circumstances, including for the BRP. [#SRC:e73d3db81c430c67] [#TGT:896c93bcd423e6b8] The plan should explain the TWD option and, where relevant, include the playbook so implementation in stress is straightforward. [#SRC:e73d3db81c430c67] The plan should also quantify the costs of the wind-down and set out the impacts on the TWD firm’s projected capital and liquidity resources across the wind-down period, which runs from the moment the TWD option is executed until the firm’s trading activities have been wound down. [#SRC:e73d3db81c430c67] For clarity and execution, the wind-down period should be split into: (1) an active wind-down period, ending when the firm has exited all positions it can exit without undue costs; and (2) a passive wind-down period, when the firm hedges exposures of remaining rump positions where possible until they expire. [#SRC:e73d3db81c430c67] Separately, the firm should maintain TWD capabilities that enable it to develop and execute the TWD option in a variety of real-life circumstances, and it should use those capabilities to help develop and execute both its recovery plan and its BRP. [#TGT:896c93bcd423e6b8]

question: When submitting the Merger Document (including the Schedule 16 Statement) and the related explanations of change, comparability and commitments, what interim financial-position disclosure must the board make because the financial information period ends before approval of the Schedule 16 Statement, and what is the stated regulatory consequence of failing to disclose such changes?
gold_answer: In preparing and submitting the Merger Document that includes the Schedule 16 Statement (together with the explanations of change, comparability and commitments referenced alongside it), the board must address the fact that the financial information necessarily covers a period ending before the Schedule 16 Statement is approved. [#SRC:f1c8b930cd8f5ee1] Specifically, the board is required to state whether there have been any material changes to the financial position in the interim between the end of that financial-information period and the approval date. [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1] If a material change has occurred and its effect cannot be quantified, the board must still describe the change so that members understand it has been identified and is relevant to their consideration of the proposed merger. [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1] This interim-change disclosure is therefore a necessary complement to the Merger Document package (including the Schedule 16 Statement and the associated explanations) being put forward. [#SRC:f1c8b930cd8f5ee1] A failure to disclose such interim material changes is not treated as immaterial: it will be relevant to the PRA’s later consideration of the society’s application for confirmation of the merger. [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1]

question: For a firm with a TMTP permission that decides to apply less than the maximum transitional deduction, what must it disclose and how should it determine the “maximum amount,” including how that maximum is derived under the TMTP method or a legacy approach in its permission?
gold_answer: Where a firm with a TMTP permission chooses to apply less than the maximum transitional deduction, it should treat the “maximum amount” as the upper bound of the permitted range (with the applied amount falling between zero and that maximum) and then disclose both figures. [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c] The “maximum amount” for this purpose is the maximum number produced either by the TMTP method in Transitional Measures on Technical Provisions 5 or by the legacy approach described in the firm’s relevant permission, so the firm must identify which of those two bases applies to it when determining the maximum. [#TGT:f321e44c98b40d33] In terms of transparency and supervisory engagement, when applying less than the maximum, the PRA expects the firm to include both the maximum amount and the actual TMTP amount in the notes to market disclosures and to share the same information with its supervision team. [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c] The firm should also maintain a transparent, consistently applied approach to determining the TMTP benefit it applies, and the PRA expects that approach to be followed across all Solvency II reporting (including QRTs) and reflected in the firm’s ORSA and risk management framework. [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c]

question: If a firm has a TMTP permission and uses less than the maximum TMTP amount, what numbers does it need to show and share, and how do you work out what counts as the “maximum amount” (TMTP method vs the legacy approach in the permission)?
gold_answer: If a firm with a TMTP permission applies less than the maximum transitional deduction, it should treat the applied TMTP amount as a figure that must sit between zero and a defined maximum, and it should be able to explain how it chose that applied amount. [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c] The “maximum amount” it is comparing against is not an arbitrary cap: it is the maximum number calculated either using the TMTP method in Transitional Measures on Technical Provisions 5 or using the legacy approach set out in the firm’s relevant permission, so the firm must determine which calculation basis applies to it. [#TGT:f321e44c98b40d33] When it applies less than that maximum, the PRA expects the firm to (1) include both the maximum amount and the actual TMTP amount in the notes to market disclosures and (2) share those same two numbers with its supervision team. [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c] The firm should also keep its method for determining the TMTP benefit transparent and apply it consistently across Solvency II reporting (including QRTs), and ensure the same approach is reflected in its ORSA and risk management framework. [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c]

question: How must institutions map a derivative transaction that has more than one material risk driver when the primary (or most material, within a given risk category) risk driver is a climatic conditions variable, and the other material risk driver(s) fall into different risk categories?
gold_answer: Institutions must treat the climatic conditions variable as requiring mapping to the commodity risk category, while also applying the multi-risk-driver mapping approach for derivative transactions with more than one material risk driver. [#SRC:d444b5b1871ca35e] [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] In practice, this means the transaction is not mapped to a single category only; instead, it is mapped across all relevant risk categories that contain at least one material risk driver, including commodity where the climatic conditions variable is the primary or most material driver in a given risk category. [#SRC:d444b5b1871ca35e] [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] For the commodity mapping specifically, the climatic conditions variable is the basis for mapping the transaction to the commodity risk category. [#SRC:d444b5b1871ca35e] For the other risk categories implicated by the remaining material risk drivers, the institution must map the transaction once to each such risk category, using the most material risk driver within each category as the basis for that category’s mapping. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] If, however, all material risk drivers happen to fall within the same risk category, the institution maps the transaction only once to that category based on the most material driver—while still recognizing that a climatic conditions variable, when it is the primary or most material driver, points to commodity as the relevant category. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] [#SRC:d444b5b1871ca35e]

question: If a third country branch and its outsourcing service provider are in the same group, what can the branch take into account about control or influence for the purposes of 8.6 to 8.8 and 8.10 and 8.11, and what information does it need to be ready to give the PRA (or another relevant competent authority) if asked about the outsourced work?
gold_answer: When the third country branch and the service provider are members of the same group, the branch may consider how much it controls the service provider or can influence what the provider does, but only for the specific purposes of 8.6 to 8.8 and 8.10 and 8.11. [#SRC:ba066540a6b4af47] That group-based control or influence is the relevant factor the branch is permitted to take into account in that context. [#SRC:ba066540a6b4af47] Even with that group connection, if the PRA or any other relevant competent authority requests it, the branch should make available all information needed so those authorities can supervise whether the outsourced activities are being performed in line with the requirements of the regulatory system. [#TGT:5c89c9f008f3d8f1] So the branch should be able to (1) describe its control/influence over the service provider for the purposes of the listed sections, and (2) provide the necessary information about the outsourced activities so supervisors can assess compliance performance. [#SRC:ba066540a6b4af47] [#TGT:5c89c9f008f3d8f1]

question: For a firm with a matching adjustment permission, how should the firm treat uncertainty in the timing and amount of cash-flows from assets with highly predictable cash-flows when determining the risks to which the MA portfolio is exposed and reflecting those risks in the SCR calculation, including any stress-driven changes to the FS and MA?
gold_answer: A firm with a matching adjustment permission should treat uncertainty in the timing and amount of cash-flows from any asset in the relevant portfolio of assets with cash-flows that are highly predictable as a risk source that must be identified and then assessed for its effect on the FS and MA within the SCR framework. [#TGT:e9d53c2edcdb5a35] The SCR should capture all material and quantifiable risks to which the firm is exposed, and the SCR calculation should allow for changes to the FS and MA following a stress event. [#SRC:c6705600c498e9a1] In practice, the firm should determine the risks to which the MA portfolio is exposed (including the identified cash-flow timing/amount uncertainties), evaluate how those risks could affect the FS and MA, and assess how that impact is captured within the SCR calculation. [#SRC:c6705600c498e9a1] The firm should also ensure that stress-condition changes to the FS include changes to any additions made to the FS used to calculate the TPs, including additions made as part of the attestation process. [#SRC:c6705600c498e9a1] For assets with highly predictable cash flows, the SCR should specifically allow for changes to the expected cash flow pattern on these assets and any changes to FS additions made in line with Matching Adjustment, linking the identified uncertainty to the stress impacts modelled in the SCR. [#SRC:c6705600c498e9a1]

question: If a firm has a matching adjustment permission, what does it need to do about uncertainty in the timing and amount of cash-flows from assets with highly predictable cash-flows, and how should that feed into its SCR stress calculation for changes to the FS and MA?
gold_answer: The firm must first identify every source of uncertainty about the timing and amount of cash-flows from any asset in the relevant portfolio of assets whose cash-flows are highly predictable. [#TGT:e9d53c2edcdb5a35] Those identified uncertainties should then be treated as part of the risks to which the MA portfolio is exposed when the firm builds its SCR, because the SCR should capture all material and quantifiable risks the firm faces. [#SRC:c6705600c498e9a1] The SCR calculation should be constructed so it can reflect how a stress event could change the FS and MA, meaning the firm should assess how the cash-flow uncertainties could affect the FS and MA and ensure that effect is captured in the SCR calculation. [#SRC:c6705600c498e9a1] When modelling stress conditions, the firm should include changes to additions made to the FS used to calculate the TPs, including additions made through the attestation process. [#SRC:c6705600c498e9a1] In addition, for assets with highly predictable cash flows, the SCR should explicitly allow for changes to the expected cash flow pattern and for changes to any FS additions made in line with Matching Adjustment, so the uncertainty identification is linked to the stress impacts reflected in the SCR. [#SRC:c6705600c498e9a1]

question: In the relatively rare case that a firm considers including complex feature(s) in its CET1 instruments, what advance steps are expected internally and with the PRA, and how should the firm address the PRA’s expectation to discuss eligibility-impacting complexity in advance despite any post-notification treatment for other instruments?
gold_answer: If a firm considers it necessary to include complex feature(s) in its CET1 instruments, the PRA expects the relevant Senior Management Function (SMF) to inform the firm’s board in advance of the issuance and to evidence why the instrument cannot be issued without the proposed complex feature(s). [#TGT:acd7b7086471f868] The relevant SMF is also expected to evidence that, notwithstanding the proposed complexity, they consider the instrument compliant with the objective of the Own Funds (CRR) Part. [#TGT:acd7b7086471f868] In parallel, where a firm proposes new or complex features that could affect eligibility, the PRA expects the firm to raise and discuss those features with its usual supervisory contact in advance, and to do so as early as possible once the relevant terms and conditions (including any side agreements) are drafted, with a clear explanation of how the features comply with PRA rules and supervisory expectations. [#SRC:cd48a3e0ac792741] This advance-discussion expectation applies even though Tier 2 instruments are described as subject to post-notification, because the PRA still expects pre-issuance discussion when complexity could affect eligibility. [#SRC:cd48a3e0ac792741] Overall, the firm should align board-level pre-issuance governance led by the relevant SMF with early supervisory engagement on the eligibility implications of the complex features. [#TGT:acd7b7086471f868] [#SRC:cd48a3e0ac792741]

question: For a shareholding members resolution, how should a society determine the relevant qualifying shareholding date when the voting date is after the society’s AGM in that financial year, and what limitations apply to using an overdrawn share account to satisfy any shareholding or membership condition on that date or during any required period?
gold_answer: Where the voting date is after the society’s AGM in the same financial year, the qualifying shareholding date is set by reference to the period tied to the meeting: it is the first day of the period that starts 56 days before the meeting date (rather than the last day of the preceding financial year). [#TGT:8b090799d8ee6d60] This timing point matters because any entitlement test that requires holding shares on a specified date or over a specified period must be met through actual shareholding, not by pointing to a share account that is overdrawn. [#SRC:5292b5d19dc62407] In addition, if the entitlement test includes being a member on a given date (for example, a membership condition like the one referenced at paragraph 3.111(a)), that membership condition likewise cannot be satisfied by relying on an overdrawn share account. [#SRC:5292b5d19dc62407] Accordingly, when applying the society’s Rules that include the shareholding and continuity concepts described in paragraph 3.110 to determine whether a person is entitled to vote on a shareholding members resolution after the AGM, the society should (i) anchor the assessment to the qualifying shareholding date defined by the 56-day lookback from the meeting, and (ii) disregard any attempt to meet shareholding or membership-on-a-date requirements via an overdrawn share account. [#TGT:8b090799d8ee6d60] [#SRC:5292b5d19dc62407]

question: If the voting date is after the society’s AGM that year, what date should be used as the qualifying shareholding date for a shareholding members resolution, and can someone use an overdrawn share account to count as holding shares or being a member on that date?
gold_answer: If the voting date happens after the society’s AGM in that financial year, the qualifying shareholding date is not the prior year-end; it is the first day of the period that begins 56 days before the meeting date. [#TGT:8b090799d8ee6d60] Once that date (and any related period-based test) is identified, the person must meet any “hold shares on a given date” or “hold shares during a given period” condition through genuine shareholding, because an overdrawn share account cannot be used to satisfy a shareholding requirement for a specific date or period. [#SRC:5292b5d19dc62407] The same restriction applies to any requirement to be a member on a given date (such as the kind of membership-on-a-date condition referenced at paragraph 3.111(a)): holding an overdrawn share account does not count as meeting that membership condition. [#SRC:5292b5d19dc62407] Put together, for a shareholding members resolution where the voting date is later than the AGM and the society’s Rules include the shareholding/continuity provisions described in paragraph 3.110, the society should (i) set the qualifying shareholding date using the 56-day lookback rule and (ii) reject overdrawn share accounts as a basis for meeting either shareholding or membership-on-a-date tests tied to that qualifying date. [#TGT:8b090799d8ee6d60] [#SRC:5292b5d19dc62407]

question: When an institution is calculating the own funds requirement for its pre-funded contributions to the default fund of a QCCP using the approach in Article 308, how should it determine the exposure value of that pre-funded contribution, including any reduction for amounts already applied by the QCCP after a clearing member default?
gold_answer: In calculating the own funds requirement for its pre-funded contributions to the default fund of a QCCP, the institution must apply the approach specified in Article 308, and that calculation must be based on an exposure value determined under the rule for DFi. [#SRC:b21669d5cc795148] The exposure value for the institution’s pre-funded contribution to the QCCP default fund (DFi) is the amount the institution has paid in, or alternatively the market value of assets it has delivered, and this starting amount must be reduced by any portion of that contribution that the QCCP has already used to absorb losses that arose after the default of one or more of the QCCP’s clearing members. [#TGT:5b56ca243fc390af] Accordingly, the institution should (i) identify whether its contribution was made as cash paid in or as assets delivered and, if assets were delivered, use their market value, and (ii) subtract any amount of that same contribution that has already been applied by the QCCP to cover losses in the specified default scenario. [#TGT:5b56ca243fc390af] This reduced DFi exposure value is the relevant measure to feed into the Article 308 approach when calculating the own funds requirement for the institution’s pre-funded default fund contribution. [#SRC:b21669d5cc795148]

question: If an institution has put money or assets into a QCCP default fund, what number should it use as the “exposure value” for that contribution when it works out its own funds requirement under Article 308, and when does that number get reduced?
gold_answer: For the institution’s own funds requirement calculation for its pre-funded contributions to the default fund of a QCCP, the institution must perform the calculation using the approach in Article 308 and therefore needs an exposure value for the contribution as an input to that approach. [#SRC:b21669d5cc795148] The exposure value (DFi) is set as the amount the institution paid into the QCCP default fund, or, if it delivered assets instead of paying cash, the market value of those delivered assets. [#TGT:5b56ca243fc390af] That exposure value is not always the full paid-in amount or full market value: it must be reduced by any part of the institution’s contribution that the QCCP has already used to absorb losses, but only where those losses followed the default of one or more of the QCCP’s clearing members. [#TGT:5b56ca243fc390af] Practically, the institution should determine whether the contribution was cash or assets, measure it accordingly, and then subtract any amount already applied by the QCCP for loss absorption in the specified default context before using the resulting figure in the Article 308 own funds requirement calculation. [#SRC:b21669d5cc795148]

question: If a firm has assets where the cash-flow timing is uncertain but still bounded (like callable bond final redemption payments), what are the two ways the firm can try to include them in the MA portfolio, and what is the cap on how much HP cash flows can contribute to the MA benefit?
gold_answer: For assets whose cash-flow timing is uncertain but limited within contractual bounds (including examples like callable bond final redemption payments or bonds where the start of repayments can vary within a bounded period), the firm has two routes to present for MA portfolio inclusion. [#SRC:e9aa8247582c38d4] First, the firm can apply to treat the assets as meeting the fixed cash flow requirement, recognising that the PRA will assess that request on a case-by-case basis. [#SRC:e9aa8247582c38d4] Second, the firm can assess whether the assets meet the criteria for HP cash flows (as referenced in paragraphs 2.12A and 2.12D) and, if they do, include them in the MA portfolio within the limited proportion allowed for such assets. [#SRC:e9aa8247582c38d4] Under the SS terminology, assets meeting the criteria referred to in paragraph 2.12A are called assets with HP cash flows, and firms can demonstrate these do not present a material risk to the quality of matching (as discussed in Chapter 4). [#TGT:b4a5a68f305c3fd1] If the firm uses the HP cash flow route, the aggregate limit is that HP cash flows may create only 10% of the MA benefit for the MA portfolio, and the PRA may also apply additional safeguards to address the extra risks they introduce. [#TGT:b4a5a68f305c3fd1]

question: When preparing a write-down plan that aims to respect the creditor hierarchy, how should the treatment of liabilities secured by floating charges be explained in light of FSMA section 377B’s excluded-liability carve-out for amounts secured on property other than those secured by a floating charge?
gold_answer: A write-down plan should explain that, although FSMA section 377B treats most amounts secured on property as excluded liabilities, it expressly carves out amounts secured by a charge that was created as a floating charge, meaning those floating-charge-secured liabilities are not excluded on that basis and can be written down. [#TGT:8a41e3fa3a9296cc] Consistent with the PRA’s expectation that write-down plans broadly follow the creditor hierarchy to improve outcomes for policyholders and other creditors overall, the plan should then set out how any write-down of floating-charge-secured liabilities will be sequenced relative to other liabilities. [#SRC:3ab0329fffa4af96] In particular, the PRA recognises that floating charges are often granted to inward reinsurance creditors who are contractually subordinated to rank alongside direct policyholders (who have a statutory priority), and it indicates that allowing write-downs of floating-charge-secured liabilities is intended to avoid giving those inward reinsurance creditors an inappropriate and unintended priority. [#SRC:3ab0329fffa4af96] Accordingly, where a floating-charge-secured liability is not contractually subordinated in that way, the plan should generally describe it as expected to be written down only after lower-ranking liabilities, aligning the write-down order with the creditor hierarchy. [#SRC:3ab0329fffa4af96]

question: When applying to the PRA for approval of a Merger Notification Statement before sending it to members within the specified time limit, what written application content and board-level declaration is expected, and how should the statement address any compensation payable to directors or other officers of the transferor society?
gold_answer: The applicant should treat the approval request as a written submission to the PRA that both supports timely member communication and demonstrates completeness and transparency, while ensuring the Merger Notification Statement contains the required compensation particulars. [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc] Specifically, the Merger Notification Statement must be approved by the PRA before it is issued to members and it must be sent within the specified time limit. [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc] In making the application, it must be in writing and should include a declaration made on behalf of the board stating that the Statement is complete and contains all material information that, in the directors’ opinion, members should know. [#TGT:b23ef312764c9a50] That declaration should also state whether there have been any other merger or takeover proposals (confidential or otherwise) and confirm the accuracy of the information about them. [#TGT:b23ef312764c9a50] In addition, the Merger Notification Statement itself must include particulars of any compensation payable to directors or other officers of the transferor society where the PRA has consented to that compensation under paragraph 2(1) of Schedule 8A to the 1986 Act. [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc] The application should also be accompanied by documents, and (for Merger Notification Statements) the final draft should be accompanied by the relevant documents listed for that purpose, adapted to the case and the less extensive information required in the statement. [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc] The application for a Schedule 16 Statement is likewise described as being accompanied by documents. [#TGT:b23ef312764c9a50]

question: When a firm plans an increase in remote trading that may relocate traders to an overseas office or entity managing risk into the UK, what governance and control outcomes must it ensure for remote bookings received in the UK, including how it should treat 100% remote booking arrangements and desks with a mix of local and remote traders?
gold_answer: A firm increasing remote trading in a way that could relocate traders overseas to manage UK risk should design its remote booking model so that UK oversight and desk design remain credible and controllable, with heightened challenge where the UK is fully remote-booked.
