gold_answer: A PRA-regulated firm must notify the PRA when it is entering into, or significantly changing, a material outsourcing arrangement, and the PRA expects the notification to be made before the firm enters into the outsourcing arrangement [#SRC:4feca3a835842f71]. In applying that obligation, “material outsourcing” should be interpreted by reference to whether the outsourced services fall within scope of OCIR, because where a firm outsources services to which OCIR applies, the arrangement will generally constitute material outsourcing [#TGT:460ccc4d06705d20]. Even where OCIR does not apply, an outsourcing or non-outsourcing third party arrangement may still be material outsourcing if it could affect the PRA’s objectives outside an OCIR context, including where it involves personal or sensitive data or carries high reputational risk [#TGT:460ccc4d06705d20]. The PRA also expects firms to submit notifications before an outsourcing arrangement that was not initially deemed material is expected or planned to become material, and it will consider the timeliness of notifications when assessing compliance with Fundamental Rule 7 [#SRC:4feca3a835842f71].

question: If someone has responsibility for keeping the compliance function independent and for overseeing how it performs (including an FCA-approved person doing compliance oversight for the firm), what must the firm put in place to make sure the firm and its managers, employees and appointed representatives (or tied agents) follow regulatory obligations and reduce financial crime risk?
gold_answer: Where responsibility is assigned for safeguarding the independence of, and overseeing the performance of, the compliance function—including overseeing the performance of a person approved by the FCA to perform the compliance oversight function on behalf of the firm—the firm must back that oversight with a working compliance framework [#SRC:ee565fa3af708789]. Concretely, the firm must establish, implement and maintain adequate policies and procedures that are sufficient to ensure compliance of the firm with its obligations under the regulatory system, and also to ensure compliance by its managers, employees and appointed representatives (or where applicable, tied agents) [#TGT:5ca4886f7aeb4304]. Those policies and procedures must also address countering the risk that the firm might be used to further financial crime [#TGT:5ca4886f7aeb4304]. Taken together, this requires the firm to set up clear internal arrangements so the compliance function can act independently, its performance can be overseen effectively, and the firm can demonstrate that compliance expectations are implemented and maintained across relevant people and distribution channels, including appointed representatives or tied agents, rather than being only a documented intention.

question: When setting assumptions about future management actions, how shall an undertaking ensure those assumptions are realistic while also identifying and addressing any relevant deviations from those assumptions referenced in the technical provisions?
gold_answer: An undertaking shall build its assumptions about future management actions on a realistic basis and treat that realism requirement as the baseline standard for the full set of assumptions it uses [#TGT:21a461da99c417d7]. In parallel, it must explicitly identify the relevant deviations from those assumptions that are referenced in the technical provisions and ensure those deviations are not overlooked or treated as immaterial simply because they differ from the central assumption set [#SRC:10677cafcf3c727c]. Practically, this means the undertaking should (i) articulate the assumed future management actions in a way that can be assessed for realism, and (ii) document where and how actual or contemplated outcomes could deviate from those assumptions, focusing on the deviations that are specifically called out as relevant in the referenced technical provisions. The undertaking should then reconcile the two: if a deviation indicates that an assumption is not realistic, the assumption should be revised; if the assumption remains realistic, the deviation should still be captured and explained as a relevant departure from the assumed path. This approach ensures both compliance with the realism obligation and proper treatment of the referenced deviations.

question: When composing the relevant portfolio of insurance or reinsurance obligations, a firm must not split an insurance contract’s obligations into parts except for an eligible element. In that context, when may a component of a with-profits annuity contract be treated as eligible for inclusion in an MA portfolio, and what limits apply to ensure the firm is not using impermissible splitting?
gold_answer: A firm is prohibited from splitting the insurance or reinsurance obligations of an insurance or reinsurance contract into different parts when composing the relevant portfolio, unless the split is limited to an “eligible element” [#TGT:80ba42a4e7626379]. Within that constraint, a component of a with-profits annuity contract may be eligible for inclusion in an MA portfolio only where the component is legally established and identifiable as guaranteed within the insurance contract, is capable of being organised and managed separately, and otherwise meets the MA eligibility conditions [#SRC:0bace533be32cdc7]. To demonstrate that the permitted treatment is not an impermissible fragmentation of obligations, the PRA expects the firm to provide a detailed assessment showing that the only elements included in the MA portfolio are contractually guaranteed and are not dependent on future premiums or future investment performance [#SRC:0bace533be32cdc7]. The PRA also expects the firm to set out a clear policy on whether future attaching bonuses are added within the MA portfolio or elsewhere, supporting disciplined boundary-setting around what is included as the eligible element [#SRC:0bace533be32cdc7].

question: You must not break an insurance contract’s obligations into separate parts when building the relevant portfolio, unless it is an eligible element. So when can a with-profits annuity contract component go into an MA portfolio, and what must the firm do to show it is not splitting the contract in a prohibited way?
gold_answer: When composing the relevant portfolio of insurance or reinsurance obligations, the contract’s obligations must not be split into different parts, except where the split relates to an eligible element [#TGT:80ba42a4e7626379]. A component of a with-profits annuity contract may be eligible for inclusion in an MA portfolio only if it is legally established and identifiable as guaranteed within the insurance contract, can be organised and managed separately, and otherwise meets the MA eligibility conditions [#SRC:0bace533be32cdc7]. To support that this is a permitted eligible-element treatment rather than prohibited splitting, the PRA expects the firm to provide a detailed assessment demonstrating that the only liabilities included in the MA portfolio are contractually guaranteed and are not dependent on future premiums or future investment performance [#SRC:0bace533be32cdc7]. The PRA also expects the firm to set out a clear policy on the addition of future attaching bonuses in the MA portfolio or elsewhere, so that any future bonus treatment does not blur the boundary of what is included as the eligible element [#SRC:0bace533be32cdc7].

question: When an Institution is permitted to compute one exposure value across transactions under a contractual netting agreement (subject to the relevant conditions), what must it do in terms of notifying the competent authorities about the calculation method it uses or ceases to use for determining exposure values for derivative positions?
gold_answer: Where Institutions choose to calculate exposure values for derivative positions using a particular method, they have a notification duty: they shall notify the competent authorities of the methods they use, or cease to use, to calculate the exposure value of their derivative positions [#SRC:7085c26bac1b91bb]. That obligation applies alongside the permission in the netting context: Institutions may calculate a single exposure value for all transactions within a contractual netting agreement only where the specified conditions are met; if those conditions are not met, Institutions must instead calculate an exposure value separately for each transaction, treating each transaction as its own netting set [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c]. Practically, this means that whenever an Institution adopts (or stops using) a method to support either (i) a single exposure value approach for transactions within a contractual netting agreement, or (ii) separate exposure value calculations per transaction, it must notify the competent authorities of the relevant method change or continued use. The notification requirement is framed around the methods used to calculate exposure values, not around the netting permission itself, so Institutions should ensure their notifications align with the method(s) actually applied to the exposure value calculations in either scenario.

question: When performing its self-assessment of operational resilience, how must a CRR firm ensure that the assessment is informed by work undertaken by the CRR consolidation entity, and how does that link to the CRR consolidation entity’s obligation to assess whether each member of its consolidation group can stay within impact tolerance for each important group business service during a severe but plausible disruption?
gold_answer: A CRR firm must conduct its self-assessment in a way that identifies any additional risks to its ability to deliver important business services within impact tolerances that arise from elsewhere in its group, and—because it is a CRR firm—must ensure that this self-assessment is informed by any work the CRR consolidation entity has undertaken regarding important group business services and whether each relevant group member could remain within impact tolerance [#SRC:525172756112897c]. In parallel, the CRR consolidation entity has a specific obligation to assess, for each important group business service, whether each member of the CRR consolidation entity’s consolidation group that provides that service could remain within the impact tolerance set for that service in the event of a severe but plausible disruption to its operations [#TGT:4e1aaf4d13ad6adb]. Read together, the CRR firm’s self-assessment should not be limited to its own operations; it should incorporate the CRR consolidation entity’s group-level assessment outputs so the firm can reflect group-derived vulnerabilities and dependencies that may affect staying within impact tolerances, including under severe but plausible disruption scenarios.

question: For a CRR firm doing its self-assessment, what does it need to take into account from the CRR consolidation entity’s work, and what must the CRR consolidation entity assess about each group member’s ability to stay within impact tolerance if there is a severe but plausible disruption?
gold_answer: A CRR firm’s self-assessment must look beyond the firm itself and identify any additional risks to its ability to deliver important business services within impact tolerances that come from elsewhere in its group. Because it is a CRR firm, that self-assessment should also be informed by any work the CRR consolidation entity has undertaken about important group business services and whether each member of the CRR consolidation entity’s consolidation group could remain within impact tolerance [#SRC:525172756112897c]. Separately, the CRR consolidation entity must carry out a specific assessment: for each important group business service, it must assess whether each member of its consolidation group that provides that service could remain within the impact tolerance set for that service if there were a severe but plausible disruption to its operations [#TGT:4e1aaf4d13ad6adb]. In practice, the CRR firm should use the CRR consolidation entity’s group-level assessment to inform its own view of group-driven risks and the likelihood of remaining within impact tolerances during disruption.

question: For a firm that is an international bank or a UK trading bank, how must the bank address resolution-related risks created by a global booking model—particularly where a multiple-point-of-entry strategy is relevant—given the PRA’s expectations on booking arrangements and proportional application based on the firm’s investment banking or sales and trading activity?
gold_answer: The PRA’s expectations on booking arrangements apply across the population of international banks and UK trading banks, and the PRA applies those expectations proportionately to the level of investment banking or sales and trading activity the firm undertakes [#SRC:8a9b8ceafce61236]. Within that scope, a bank using a global booking model should treat the model as a potential source of resolution friction: even if it is not a direct impediment under a single point of entry approach, it can increase complexity in post-resolution group restructuring, and under a multiple-point-of-entry strategy the inter-connectivity between the UK authorised firm and the wider group associated with global booking could be an impediment that the bank should address [#TGT:9fcb3c210c05859d]. In addition, because contingency plans to wind down trading books in a solvent and orderly fashion are important to orderly exit, recovery, or resolution, the PRA expects the bank’s chosen booking model to be fully taken into account in those plans [#TGT:9fcb3c210c05859d].

question: If firms are updating TMTP after a transfer event, what must they do to keep Transitional Measures on Technical Provisions complied with, and what must not happen to the total TMTP claimed by the firms involved in the transfer (even if they adjust inputs or have a waiver/modification)?
gold_answer: Firms must ensure that Transitional Measures on Technical Provisions is adhered to, unless they have been granted a waiver or modification under the relevant permissions statement; the PRA expects this can be achieved by adjusting the value for ‘Z B ’ or ‘C 0 ’ [#SRC:b34bb4d4e11aa3c7]. However, when the firms that are parties to the transfer event apply the relevant updates, those updates must not lead to any increase in the aggregate amount of TMTP claimed by those firms [#TGT:1e44705117d023b6]. In practice, this means firms can make the adjustments the PRA expects (or rely on a waiver/modification where applicable) to keep the transitional measure properly applied, but they must do so in a way that does not raise the combined TMTP claimed across all firms involved in the transfer event. The compliance approach therefore needs to balance two constraints: maintaining adherence to the transitional measure framework while ensuring the update process does not create an aggregate uplift in TMTP for the transfer-event parties.

question: When determining FS additions, how must firms address additional risks arising from cash flow variability while also deciding whether to apply an advanced methodology or retain the standard approach across different assets with HP cash flows, and what justification must be available for any mixed approach?
gold_answer: Firms must actively consider additional risks that arise from sources of cash flow variability and ensure those risks are sufficiently captured through the required FS additions, rather than assuming the base calculation is complete without that assessment [#SRC:b728c6d47d520ce6]. At the same time, firms must apply a practical methodology choice that reflects the PRA’s recognition that not all sources of variability can be modelled using an advanced approach (for example, where data are scarce) [#TGT:2b8c7b6afe728f9d]. Accordingly, firms may pursue advanced calculation methodologies for some assets with HP cash flows while retaining the standard approach for others, but they must be able to justify why an advanced approach is proposed for certain exposures and not for others [#TGT:2b8c7b6afe728f9d]. In practice, this means the firm’s approach to capturing additional variability-driven risks in FS additions should be consistent with its modelling capability and data availability, and the firm should be prepared to explain how the selected mix of advanced and standard approaches still results in those additional risks being sufficiently captured [#SRC:b728c6d47d520ce6].

question: If a firm cannot model every source of cash flow variability with an advanced method, what must it do to make sure the extra risks are still covered in FS additions, and what must it be able to explain if it uses advanced methods for some HP cash flow assets but not others?
gold_answer: A firm must look for additional risks that come from sources of cash flow variability and make sure those risks are sufficiently captured by the required FS additions, rather than overlooking them [#SRC:b728c6d47d520ce6]. The PRA also recognises that some sources of variability cannot be modelled using an advanced approach, such as when there is not enough data [#TGT:2b8c7b6afe728f9d]. Because of that, a firm may use advanced calculation methodologies for some assets with HP cash flows and keep the standard approach for other assets [#TGT:2b8c7b6afe728f9d]. However, the firm must be able to justify why it chose an advanced approach for some exposures but not others [#TGT:2b8c7b6afe728f9d]. Put together, the firm’s process should both (i) identify and address extra variability-related risks through FS additions and (ii) document the reasons—such as data limitations—behind any split between advanced and standard methods, while still showing that the FS additions capture the extra risks it identified [#SRC:b728c6d47d520ce6].

question: Where a group is within the scenario in which the relevant provisions apply at the level of an insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company that is not UK/Gibraltar‑headquartered, or at the level of a third country insurance undertaking or third country reinsurance undertaking, how must a relevant insurance group undertaking characterise the parent undertaking for group solvency calculation purposes, and how does that characterisation interact with the scope of requirements applied at that level?
gold_answer: When the group is one to which the relevant trigger applies, the framework extends specified requirements to operate “at the level of” an insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company that does not have its head office in the UK or Gibraltar, or at the level of a third country insurance undertaking or third country reinsurance undertaking, subject to stated exceptions in that scope statement [#TGT:4b76a4f92f32f4d8]. In that same situation, for the specific task of calculating the solvency of the group, a relevant insurance group undertaking has a distinct obligation regarding how it must treat the parent undertaking: it must treat the parent undertaking—where the parent undertaking is an insurance holding company without a UK/Gibraltar head office, or a third country insurance undertaking, or a third country reinsurance undertaking—solely for the purposes of that solvency calculation as a UK Solvency II firm to which the referenced application condition applies [#SRC:9faaabced2ba31fb]. The interaction is therefore purpose- and level-specific: the scope provision determines that the listed requirements apply with necessary changes at the parent-level entity, while the calculation obligation requires a UK Solvency II firm treatment only for the solvency calculation, without asserting that re-characterisation for all other purposes.

question: If MCR has to be read as both the issuer’s third-country capital requirement and an extra minimum (depending on the method used), can a basic own funds item still be written to allow repayment or redemption in under five years, and what limits apply?
gold_answer: Yes, the texts address two different but related compliance points. First, where the Own Funds rules refer to MCR, that term must be interpreted as a combined concept: it includes the capital requirement set by the relevant third country supervisory authority for the undertaking that issued the own funds item, and it also includes one of two minimums depending on whether method 1 is used or a combination of method 1 and method 2 is used [#SRC:c2928ea45b24dce6]. Second, even though there is an Own Funds requirement that would otherwise restrict early repayment or redemption, the rules expressly permit a basic own funds item to allow repayment or redemption before five years after issuance as an exception, provided that the specified conditions for that exception are met [#TGT:e6ebc5bbbac42735]. So, the MCR definition controls how you read MCR references, while the permission controls whether early repayment/redemption language can be included in the instrument, subject to conditions.

question: Where more than one SMF holds PR Q, the firm must ensure that all such SMFs provide the required attestation; in doing so, must the firm also avoid treating assets as eligible for the matching adjustment where the asset’s cash flows could be altered by early redemption or termination rights that are entirely at the discretion of the issuer or a third party (subject to any stated exception)?
gold_answer: The firm must organise its governance so that the senior manager(s) holding PR Q are responsible for the attestation, and where more than one SMF holds PR Q, the PRA expects all of those SMFs to attest, reflecting their ultimate governance responsibility for the calculation of the FS and MA even where tasks are delegated [#SRC:60350a1cc8a674eb]. In parallel, when determining whether assets support fixed cash flows for matching adjustment purposes, the firm must not treat as eligible those assets whose cash flows could be changed by early redemption or termination rights that are entirely at the discretion of the issuer or a third party, except where the stated exception applies [#TGT:d5964c3fc12fead2]. Read together, this means the attesting SMF(s) should ensure the attestation process and underlying calculations do not rely on assets with prohibited discretionary redemption/termination features, because such features would undermine the fixed cash flow eligibility condition that the firm’s MA calculation depends on. If governance arrangements suggest a different SMF should attest, the firm should approach its usual supervisory contact in the first instance [#SRC:60350a1cc8a674eb].

question: How must a firm demonstrate to the PRA that the methods and assumptions used in its internal model adhere to the Statistical Quality Standards principles, while also ensuring the internal model’s probability distribution forecast calculation meets the required compliance scope?
gold_answer: A firm must do two linked things: (1) ensure its internal model—specifically including the calculation of the probability distribution forecast generated by it—meets the defined compliance scope, and (2) be able to demonstrate to the PRA that it complies with the relevant Statistical Quality Standards (SQS) principles governing the methods and assumptions used in the internal model. The operational compliance requirement is that the internal model and, in particular, the probability distribution forecast calculation, complies with 11.2 to 11.13, which sets the concrete compliance span the firm must satisfy and be able to point to in its governance and model operation [#TGT:3ed819cc35a6fc9d]. In parallel, the SQS for internal models set out requirements on the principles that the methods and assumptions used in the internal model must adhere to, and the firm’s compliance with those requirements must be evidenced to the PRA, meaning the firm must maintain and provide appropriate evidence demonstrating adherence rather than relying on unsupported assertions [#SRC:f9ebadff53a4bf82].

question: During the period between a section 178 notice being submitted and the occurrence of the change in control, what must a UK domestic firm do to stay appropriately informed about the controller or proposed controller, and what immediate action must it take if it becomes aware (or has information reasonably suggesting) that the person submitting the notice has provided information that was or may have false, misleading, incomplete or inaccurate, or has or may have changed materially?
gold_answer: A UK domestic firm must actively monitor and investigate, on a reasonable-steps basis, the circumstances of the controller or proposed controller that are relevant to the notification, so that it keeps itself informed throughout the relevant period [#SRC:e4f64412bd209979]. That ongoing duty to remain informed is not passive: it is intended to ensure the firm can identify developments in the controller/proposed controller’s circumstances that bear on the notification and the information provided to the PRA. If, during the period between submission of a section 178 notice and the change in control, the firm becomes aware, or has information that reasonably suggests, that the person submitting the notice has or may have provided information to the PRA that was or may have been false, misleading, incomplete or inaccurate, or has or may have changed in a material particular, the firm must notify the PRA immediately [#TGT:adb285c8c0a8613e]. Read together, the reasonable-steps monitoring obligation supports timely detection, and the immediate notification obligation governs the required escalation once such concerns arise.

question: While a section 178 notice is pending (after it is submitted but before the change in control happens), what does a UK domestic firm have to do to keep up to date on the controller or proposed controller, and what must it do right away if it learns or has reasonable indications that the notice submitter’s information to the PRA may be wrong or has materially changed?
gold_answer: In the period after a section 178 notice is submitted and before the change in control occurs, a UK domestic firm must take reasonable steps to keep itself informed about the circumstances of the controller or proposed controller that the notification relates to [#SRC:e4f64412bd209979]. This means the firm should not simply rely on what was initially submitted; it must stay alert to relevant developments in those circumstances during the pending period. If, in that same period, the firm becomes aware, or has information that reasonably suggests, that the person submitting the notice has or may have provided the PRA with information that was or may have been false, misleading, incomplete or inaccurate, or has or may have changed in a material particular, the firm must notify the PRA immediately [#TGT:adb285c8c0a8613e]. The two requirements work together: the ongoing reasonable-steps duty helps the firm detect issues, and the immediate notification duty sets the required response once such an issue is identified.

question: When applying the derogation that requires institutions to create separate individual hedging sets by risk category for specified transactions, how must an institution reflect those hedging sets in the index used for a netting set that denotes all credit risk hedging sets established under the relevant framework?
gold_answer: Where institutions apply the derogation that obliges them to establish separate individual hedging sets in each risk category for the relevant transactions, those newly created hedging sets form part of the population of “credit risk hedging sets” that must be captured for the netting set. The index “j” is defined as the index that denotes all the credit risk hedging sets established in accordance with the specified establishment framework for the netting set [#SRC:8837142e47055ac2]. Accordingly, once institutions are required to create separate individual hedging sets by risk category under the derogation [#TGT:a3cc17fc347e6b59], they must ensure that the index “j” denotes (i.e., enumerates or references) all such established credit risk hedging sets for that netting set, including those arising from the derogation. In practice, this means institutions should not treat the derogation-created hedging sets as outside the indexing scheme; instead, they should be incorporated into the complete set of hedging sets that “j” denotes for the netting set, consistent with the definition’s “all … established” scope [#SRC:8837142e47055ac2] and the obligation to establish separate sets by risk category [#TGT:a3cc17fc347e6b59].

question: When a derivative transaction presents more than one material risk driver, how shall institutions determine whether to map it to a single risk category or to multiple risk categories, and how does that obligation interact with the requirement to base mapping on the transaction’s primary risk driver as the only material risk driver?
gold_answer: Institutions must apply two linked requirements. Under the TARGET obligation, institutions must conduct mapping on the basis of the primary risk driver of a derivative transaction, and that primary risk driver is defined as the only material risk driver of the transaction [#TGT:7c541aa6ba03b9a1]. In parallel, the SOURCE sets out how institutions shall map derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver: they must map to more than one risk category, unless all material risk drivers fall within the same risk category, in which case the transaction is mapped only once to that category based on the most material risk driver; if the material risk drivers span different risk categories, the transaction is mapped once to each relevant risk category based on the most material risk driver within each category [#SRC:28d975e9bccdd9ad]. Read together, institutions should first identify whether the transaction is treated as having a single material risk driver (the primary risk driver) for mapping purposes under the TARGET, and where the SOURCE scenario of multiple material risk drivers applies, they must follow the SOURCE’s single- versus multi-category mapping logic and the “most material” basis within the applicable category or categories.

question: If a derivative transaction seems to have more than one important risk driver, what must institutions do to map it to risk categories, and how does that fit with the rule that mapping is based on the primary risk driver as the only material risk driver?
gold_answer: Institutions have to align the mapping approach across both texts. The TARGET requires institutions to do the mapping based on the primary risk driver of the derivative transaction, and it also states that the primary risk driver is the only material risk driver of that transaction [#TGT:7c541aa6ba03b9a1]. The SOURCE addresses the situation where a transaction has more than one material risk driver and sets the mapping outcome: institutions must map the transaction to more than one risk category, except where all material risk drivers are in the same risk category, in which case the transaction is mapped only once to that category using the most material risk driver; where the material risk drivers fall into different risk categories, the transaction is mapped once to each such category, using the most material risk driver within each category [#SRC:28d975e9bccdd9ad]. Taken together, institutions must ensure their mapping is driven by the relevant risk driver basis (primary/most material) while applying the SOURCE’s rules on whether mapping occurs once or across multiple risk categories.

question: For the future version of the disclosure framework on exposure to market risk applicable after 01/01/2027, when Institutions calculate their own funds requirements using the approaches referenced for market risk, what disaggregation must they provide in their public disclosure, and how must they treat the specific interest rate risk of securitisation positions?
gold_answer: Under the future version of the disclosure framework addressing exposure to market risk after 01/01/2027, Institutions that calculate their own funds requirements using the specified approaches for market risk are required to present those own funds requirements in a risk-by-risk manner rather than as a single aggregated figure. Concretely, where Institutions calculate their own funds requirements in accordance with the referenced approaches, they must disclose the resulting own funds requirements separately for each risk that is covered by those approaches, ensuring that users can distinguish the contribution of each relevant risk category to the total requirement. In addition to that general separation by risk, Institutions must also provide a distinct, standalone disclosure for the own funds requirements attributable to the specific interest rate risk of securitisation positions, rather than including it within a broader risk line item. This obligation applies within the future disclosure regime for market risk exposure after 01/01/2027 [#SRC:b7e47ffae39566a1] and is expressly required for Institutions meeting the stated calculation condition [#TGT:acd7395abbe27295].

question: When institutions have to identify the relevant credit reference entities in a netting set, how do they pick the correlation factor for a specific credit reference entity k, and what are the two possible factor values depending on how k was established?
gold_answer: When institutions carry out the required step of establishing the relevant credit reference entities of the netting set, they must also ensure that each credit reference entity k is associated with the correct correlation factor based on how that entity k was established [#TGT:e31e1c31e024509b]. The correlation factor is defined in a conditional way: it is 50% where the credit reference entity k has been established in accordance with one specified establishment approach, and it is 80% where the credit reference entity k has been established in accordance with the other specified establishment approach [#SRC:731e149dd5302c90]. This means the institution cannot choose the factor independently; it must first determine which establishment approach was used for credit reference entity k and then apply the corresponding fixed percentage. As a result, the establishment process for relevant credit reference entities in the netting set should be performed with enough clarity and traceability to support the correct selection between the two defined correlation factor outcomes for each entity k.

question: If a firm is reapplying the floor method and calibration for stressed FS, can it use constructed data when some data is missing or not reliable, and what does it still have to do about keeping the floor at a minimum level?
gold_answer: Yes, a firm may use constructed data when part of the relevant data is not available or when the available data is not reliable, but only if the constructed data is based on prudent assumptions and is built from available and reliable data relating to the previous 30 years [#TGT:5f5585242ebb290e]. At the same time, the PRA expects firms to maintain a floor (a minimum level of FS at the appropriate point of the calculation) based on long-term average spreads, and as a minimum expects firms to reapply the methodology and calibration of the floor as previously set out [#SRC:c25a4960dc77cc1d]. If the firm makes any changes to the floor while doing this, those changes are expected to be justified, and they should not result in a calibration below what would have been obtained by reapplying the methodology and calibration used to calculate the TPs [#SRC:c25a4960dc77cc1d]. So, constructed data is allowed to fill gaps, but it must be used in a way that supports—rather than undermines—the required minimum floor outcome.

question: If an institution has to stop calculating exposure values for its derivative positions within six months after something happens, can it still use one exposure value for all transactions under a contractual netting agreement, and what must it do if the netting conditions are not met?
gold_answer: An institution has an obligation to stop calculating the exposure values of its derivative positions using the specified approach within six months after a triggering event occurs [#SRC:e840f5f94a52b4e7]. Separately, institutions are allowed to calculate a single exposure value for all transactions within a contractual netting agreement, but only if all the required conditions for that treatment are satisfied [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c]. If those conditions are not satisfied, the institution must not combine the transactions and instead must calculate an exposure value separately for each transaction, treating each transaction as its own netting set [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c]. Putting these together: the netting rule tells the institution when it may use one combined exposure value versus when it must use separate exposure values per transaction, while the other rule imposes a deadline to cease the specified exposure‑value calculation method for derivative positions after a trigger [#SRC:e840f5f94a52b4e7] [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c].

question: How must a third country branch ensure that its arrangements, processes and mechanisms for identifying and managing risk are effectively implemented, given that the level of compliance by the third country branch and its relevant persons with those adopted arrangements must be considered?
gold_answer: A third country branch must not only put in place effective arrangements, processes and mechanisms to identify and manage the risk relating to its activities, processes and systems, but it must also ensure those measures are actually followed in practice by the third country branch and its relevant persons. The risk framework should be designed and operated in the light of the branch’s level of risk tolerance, so that the adopted controls are proportionate to the risks arising from the branch’s activities, processes and systems [#TGT:de747f0b5eff8a04]. In parallel, the branch should assess and take into account the level of compliance by the third country branch and its relevant persons with the arrangements, processes and mechanisms that have been adopted, so that implementation effectiveness is evidenced through adherence rather than mere documentation [#SRC:6c8856b99608b6ca]. Practically, this means the branch should align its risk identification and management measures with its risk tolerance and then monitor whether the branch and its relevant persons comply with those measures, using that compliance level as an input to judging whether the arrangements remain effective and fit for purpose.

question: If a firm trades products like cash equities or cash bonds that can create settlement risk but do not attract counterparty credit risk, when can the PRA push back on a zero capital requirement and make the firm hold extra capital?
gold_answer: The products in scope include those (for example, cash equities and cash bonds) that can lead to settlement risk even though they do not attract counterparty credit risk, so the settlement-risk issue can arise without a corresponding counterparty credit risk charge [#TGT:5059cf1db1f509c9]. For settlement risk arising from products outside the scope of an advanced CCR model, the PRA may challenge whether it is appropriate for the firm to apply a zero capital requirement if the firm does not adequately manage that settlement risk [#SRC:6c6326c6d1c86320]. The passage indicates what “adequately manage” can involve, such as pre-deal checking, defined limit frameworks, and appropriate reporting. Where those kinds of controls are not sufficient for the settlement risk created by the relevant products, the PRA can require the firm to hold additional capital under Pillar 2, rather than allowing the firm to rely on a zero capital requirement for that risk.

question: When an institution determines the risk-weighted exposure amounts for its trade exposures with CCPs, how must it first calculate the underlying exposure values for those trade exposures with a CCP, and how are those exposure values then used to produce the final risk-weighted amount?
gold_answer: An institution must start by calculating the exposure values for its trade exposures with a CCP using the applicable calculation framework specified for those exposure values, i.e., in accordance with the relevant parts of the Chapter and, where applicable, the referenced part of Chapter 4 [#TGT:325217a9dca51ff6]. Those exposure values are then the building blocks for the institution’s risk-weighted exposure amounts for its trade exposures with CCPs: the institution must take the sum of the exposure values of its trade exposures with CCPs (as calculated under the applicable exposure-value methodology) and multiply that summed exposure value by the risk weight determined under the relevant risk-weight determination approach [#SRC:99cd1305ee2e0e40]. In other words, the target obligation governs how the institution must compute the exposure values for trade exposures with a CCP, while the source obligation governs how those exposure values must be aggregated and transformed into risk-weighted exposure amounts through application of the appropriate risk weight, for the stated prudential purpose.

question: When calculating the group solvency of the group, how must the participating Solvency II undertaking treat certain own funds eligible for the SCR of a related Solvency II undertaking where those own funds cannot effectively be made available to cover the SCR of the participating Solvency II undertaking, and how does the definition of items assumed not to be effectively available to cover the group SCR for a related undertaking affect that treatment?
gold_answer: In calculating the group solvency of the group, the participating Solvency II undertaking must exclude from the calculation any certain own funds that are eligible for the SCR of a related Solvency II undertaking but cannot effectively be made available to cover the SCR of the participating Solvency II undertaking for which the solvency of a group is calculated [#SRC:cbb5ec092d926613]. The only permitted inclusion is a limited one: those own funds may be included solely to the extent that they are eligible for covering the SCR of the related undertaking, and no further [#SRC:cbb5ec092d926613]. The definition in the paired text reinforces how “cannot effectively be made available” is operationalised by specifying that particular items of a related undertaking are to be assumed not to be effectively available to cover the group SCR, and it applies across related undertakings that are a Solvency II undertaking, third country insurance undertaking or third country reinsurance undertaking, insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company [#TGT:03e8a5e9bd172697]. Where an item falls within that assumed-not-available category, it triggers the prohibition on including it for group coverage purposes, subject only to the limited eligibility-for-the-related-undertaking carve-out [#SRC:cbb5ec092d926613] and the definitional scope of related undertakings [#TGT:03e8a5e9bd172697].

question: If certain own funds belong to a related Solvency II undertaking and they cannot really be used to cover the SCR of the participating Solvency II undertaking, do you leave them out of the group solvency calculation? How does the rule that some items of a related undertaking are assumed not to be effectively available to cover the group SCR change what you do?
gold_answer: Yes. Where certain own funds eligible for the SCR of a related Solvency II undertaking cannot effectively be made available to cover the SCR of the participating Solvency II undertaking for which the solvency of a group is calculated, those own funds must not be included in the calculation of the group solvency of the group [#SRC:cbb5ec092d926613]. There is a narrow exception: they may be included only if, and only to the extent that, they are eligible for covering the SCR of the related undertaking itself [#SRC:cbb5ec092d926613]. The paired definition helps you identify when “not effectively available” must be assumed, because it states that certain items of a related undertaking are assumed not to be effectively available to cover the group SCR [#TGT:03e8a5e9bd172697]. It also clarifies the types of related undertaking to which that assumption applies, including a related undertaking that is a Solvency II undertaking, third country insurance undertaking or third country reinsurance undertaking, insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company [#TGT:03e8a5e9bd172697]. So, if an item is within that assumed-not-available set, you treat it as unavailable for group SCR coverage and exclude it from group solvency, except for the limited inclusion allowed for the related undertaking’s own SCR eligibility [#SRC:cbb5ec092d926613].

question: When performing the class A tariff base calculation, how must a firm determine the covered-deposit basis from the SCV file while also ensuring the calculation is supported by the same information content and quality that would be required for its single customer views as at the valuation date, including the treatment of accounts holding funds to which the account holder is not absolutely entitled or that are safeguarded funds and any exclusion of confirmed non-covered deposits?
gold_answer: A firm must calculate the FSCS tariff base for deposit-takers (the Class A tariff base) using covered deposits drawn from its SCV file, and it must do so using information that is of the same extent and standard as would be required if the firm were preparing its single customer view in line with the SCV requirements as at the valuation date for the tariff base [#SRC:95405e3eada2b4e1] [#TGT:cd1f61ae71a25acf]. In practice, this means the firm’s tariff base computation should be traceable to the data elements it would have to include in its single customer views, and those data must meet the required completeness and quality benchmark at the relevant valuation date [#TGT:cd1f61ae71a25acf]. When identifying the deposit amounts to include, the firm must include the total balance of deposits in any account holding funds to which the account holder is not absolutely entitled, or which are safeguarded funds, as required under the rules, because those balances form part of the covered-deposit basis used for the calculation [#SRC:95405e3eada2b4e1]. However, the firm may exclude funds it has confirmed are not covered deposits, ensuring exclusions are limited to confirmed non-covered amounts [#SRC:95405e3eada2b4e1].

question: What must a firm use to calculate the class A tariff base, and what information standard must it meet at the valuation date—especially for accounts with safeguarded funds or funds the account holder is not absolutely entitled to, and for any funds the firm has confirmed are not covered deposits?
gold_answer: A firm must calculate the Class A tariff base using covered deposits from the SCV file, and it must base that calculation on the information it would have to include in its single customer views [#SRC:95405e3eada2b4e1] [#TGT:cd1f61ae71a25acf]. The information used cannot be a reduced or informal dataset: it must be of the extent and standard that would be required if the firm were preparing the single customer view in accordance with the SCV requirements as at the valuation date for the tariff base [#TGT:cd1f61ae71a25acf]. When assembling the deposit balances that feed into the covered-deposit calculation, the firm must include the total balance of deposits in any account that holds funds to which the account holder is not absolutely entitled, or that are safeguarded funds, because those balances must be included under the rules for the calculation basis [#SRC:95405e3eada2b4e1]. At the same time, the firm may leave out funds only where it has confirmed that those funds are not covered deposits, so exclusions must be limited to confirmed non-covered amounts rather than assumptions [#SRC:95405e3eada2b4e1].

question: When a firm is putting in place the documented framework for managing model risk, how must the board of directors and senior management sequence the assignment of responsibilities so that senior management functions are aligned to the relevant prescribed responsibilities in the PRA Rulebook, while also ensuring roles and responsibilities are designated to model owners, model users, and control and compliance functions?
gold_answer: The board of directors must first ensure that a framework for the management of model risk is established and that it is adequately documented, because this sets the baseline against which responsibilities can be allocated and evidenced [#SRC:d4070cd7428fcd33]. Senior management must then take responsibility for executing and maintaining that framework and, as part of that execution, designate roles and responsibilities to model owners, model users, and control and compliance functions so the framework is operational rather than merely documented [#SRC:d4070cd7428fcd33]. When the firm assigns the responsibilities for managing model risk to senior management functions, it should explicitly consider the relevant prescribed responsibilities under the PRA Rulebook’s Allocation of Responsibilities, to ensure the senior management function mapping is consistent with those prescribed responsibilities and avoids gaps or overlaps [#TGT:51ea2b168d63b6d3]. In practice, this means documenting (i) the board-established framework, (ii) the senior management execution and maintenance accountabilities, and (iii) the linkage between those accountabilities and the prescribed responsibilities considered, alongside the downstream role designations to model owners, model users, and control and compliance functions [#SRC:d4070cd7428fcd33] [#TGT:51ea2b168d63b6d3].

question: When must institutions begin making the additional annual disclosures tied to a 5% non-performing loans and advances ratio, and what threshold-testing conditions govern the start of disclosure and the first reference date templates?
gold_answer: Institutions must commence disclosure once the 5% threshold condition is met under the commencement test in the SOURCE, and, where applicable, they must also satisfy the TARGET’s requirement for large institutions to provide specified additional annual disclosures when their ratio of gross carrying amount of non-performing loans and advances to total gross carrying amount of loans and advances is equal to or higher than 5%. Under the SOURCE, institutions start disclosure where they have reached or exceeded the 5% threshold in two consecutive quarters during the four quarters prior to the disclosure reference date, and for the first disclosure reference date they must disclose the templates subject to the 5% threshold if they comply with the threshold on that reference date [#SRC:d188f8c0946e8de1]. In parallel, the TARGET imposes an annual disclosure obligation on large institutions meeting the 5% ratio test, requiring the disclosures required in specified points of Article 442 of the CRR to be made also in accordance with the listed templates and related annex instructions [#TGT:f4069472e0482e37]. Read together, commencement timing and first-reference-date template inclusion follow the SOURCE’s threshold mechanics, while the content and annual cadence for large institutions meeting the ratio test follow the TARGET.

question: When constructing a relevant portfolio, an insurer must not split an insurance contract’s obligations into parts unless an eligible element exception applies. How does that prohibition interact with the PRA’s position that in-payment elements of income protection contracts may be included in a matching adjustment portfolio when they are separately identifiable and managed separately, and what limits does the PRA place on using recovery time risk to justify inclusion?
gold_answer: The general rule is that, when composing the relevant portfolio of insurance or reinsurance obligations, the insurance or reinsurance obligations of a contract must not be split into different parts, except where the split is within an “eligible element” [#TGT:80ba42a4e7626379]. The PRA’s matching adjustment material indicates a circumstance in which a component of a broader income protection contract can be treated distinctly: in-payment elements of income protection contracts may be eligible for inclusion where they are separately identifiable and can be organised and managed separately in accordance with the referenced regulatory requirement [#SRC:aa234508c5cb946b]. Read together, the prohibition means a firm cannot carve up obligations merely for portfolio construction convenience; it needs the eligible-element basis, and the PRA’s eligibility conditions for in-payment elements help define when that basis may be available. The PRA also frames the underwriting risk context: permitted underwriting risks connected to the portfolio may include recovery time risk for policyholders in receipt of income protection payments, with no restriction on exposure to that risk in MA portfolios, but the PRA does not expect recognition of recovery time risk to expand inclusion beyond income protection claims in payment, and it notes inclusion where claims are not subject to future premiums [#SRC:aa234508c5cb946b].

question: You must not split a contract’s insurance obligations into separate parts when building the relevant portfolio, unless it is an eligible element. If you want to include only the in-payment part of an income protection contract in a matching adjustment portfolio, when is that allowed and what is not allowed, especially around recovery time risk?
gold_answer: The rule for building the relevant portfolio is that you must not split the insurance or reinsurance obligations of a contract into different parts, unless the split is within an “eligible element” [#TGT:80ba42a4e7626379]. The PRA’s matching adjustment guidance describes when an in-payment portion of an income protection contract may fit within that kind of exception: in-payment elements may be eligible for inclusion where they are separately identifiable and can be organised and managed separately in line with the referenced regulatory requirement, and the PRA expects this to allow in-payment claims under group and individual income protection policies to be permitted within MA portfolios where the claims are not subject to future premiums [#SRC:aa234508c5cb946b]. The PRA also explains the underwriting risk angle: permitted underwriting risks connected to the portfolio may include recovery time risk (the risk that policyholders in receipt of income protection payments take longer to recover than expected), and unlike mortality risk there is no restriction on exposure to recovery time risk in firms’ MA portfolios [#SRC:aa234508c5cb946b]. However, the PRA does not expect that recognising recovery time risk should be used to bring in liabilities other than income protection claims in payment, so splitting cannot be used to widen the portfolio beyond that scope [#SRC:aa234508c5cb946b].

question: Where an institution is permitted to calculate the exposure value of its derivative positions using the method available only if its on- and off-balance-sheet derivative business stays within specified thresholds based on a monthly assessment, what must the institution do if a triggering event occurs that requires it to stop using the relevant exposure-value calculation approach, and by when?
gold_answer: An institution may calculate the exposure value of its derivative positions using the specified method only subject to a stated restriction and only where, based on a monthly assessment using data as of the last day of the month, the size of its on- and off-balance-sheet derivative business is at or below the applicable thresholds [#SRC:76ff5419b175628d]. However, that permission is not open-ended: if one of the specified triggering events occurs, the institution has a mandatory transition requirement. In that case, the institution shall cease calculating the exposure values of its derivative positions in accordance with the relevant approach (as applicable) within six months of the triggering event [#TGT:e840f5f94a52b4e7]. Read together, the framework means the institution must both (i) monitor eligibility for the permitted method through the required monthly assessment and (ii) be prepared to discontinue the applicable exposure-value calculation approach within the six-month period once a trigger occurs, even if it previously met the thresholds and could use the method.

question: If a firm is mapping and testing its important business services, how does that help it meet the requirement to stay within impact tolerances, and how should boards and senior management use those tolerances to set priorities for investment and recovery/response during disruptions?
gold_answer: Mapping and testing the delivery of important business services equips a firm to establish whether and how it can remain within impact tolerances, supporting the requirement to ensure those services can be delivered within tolerances in severe but plausible scenarios [#TGT:0f14e9411e03a950]. Boards and senior management should use impact tolerances as a standard for prioritising investment and for making recovery and response arrangements, so the results of mapping and testing should translate into clear decisions on where to strengthen resilience and how to organise recovery and response actions [#SRC:51a4e8e33523d5d5]. When an operational disruption happens, impact tolerances may be helpful in informing decision-making, but they should be considered alongside other information relevant to managing the incident effectively, meaning leaders should use tolerances as a guide while also taking account of the broader incident situation [#SRC:51a4e8e33523d5d5]. This connects the firm’s testing-led understanding of what is achievable with governance-led choices about investment and response needed to stay within tolerances [#TGT:0f14e9411e03a950] [#SRC:51a4e8e33523d5d5].

question: How must an insurer align the establishment of its risk monitoring metrics with the obligation to maintain and monitor a liquidity buffer so that liabilities can be met as they fall due under both benign and stressed conditions?
gold_answer: An insurer must design and use its risk monitoring metrics in a way that directly supports how it determines, maintains, and evidences any liquidity buffer(s) it holds, because those metrics are part of the framework used to size and track liquid resources against expected outflows [#SRC:9c279e6bff2a8352]. In parallel, the insurer is required to invest in assets that ensure the liquidity of its investment portfolio and to consider whether its assets are appropriate to meet obligations as they fall due, which includes considering total liquidity needs and the level and monitoring of liquid assets [#TGT:69f861caa7c533e0]. Practically, this means the insurer’s metrics should be capable of monitoring liquid assets and informing decisions about an appropriate liquidity buffer, including under stressed conditions, so the insurer can demonstrate it maintains an adequate stock of liquid assets sufficient to meet liabilities as they fall due [#TGT:69f861caa7c533e0]. The linkage is that the metrics are not standalone reporting; they are used to support the establishment and ongoing adequacy of the liquidity buffer(s) held by the insurer [#SRC:9c279e6bff2a8352].

question: What must an insurer do to make sure its risk monitoring metrics help set and track any liquidity buffer(s), so it can still pay liabilities when due in normal and stressed conditions?
gold_answer: An insurer must ensure its risk monitoring metrics are used to support how it sets up and maintains any liquidity buffer(s) it holds, because those metrics are intended to underpin the establishment of the buffer and related monitoring [#SRC:9c279e6bff2a8352]. At the same time, the insurer has to hold and manage assets so its investment portfolio remains liquid and so it can meet obligations as they fall due, which includes considering total liquidity needs and monitoring the level of liquid assets [#TGT:69f861caa7c533e0]. This requires the insurer to maintain an adequate stock of liquid assets (a liquidity buffer) that is sufficient to meet liabilities as they fall due, and to be able to do so in both benign and stressed conditions [#TGT:69f861caa7c533e0]. Therefore, the metrics should be structured to track liquid assets and inform whether the liquidity buffer remains adequate over time, rather than being separate from liquidity management, because they are used to support the establishment of the insurer’s risk monitoring metrics and any liquidity buffer(s) held [#SRC:9c279e6bff2a8352].

question: When the PRA’s booking-arrangements expectations apply to a ‘UK trading bank’, how must the firm evidence senior management accountability for oversight of booking arrangements, and what approval consideration arises for parent or group-entity individuals who materially influence the firm’s UK regulated activities?
gold_answer: Where the PRA’s booking-arrangements expectations apply to a firm that falls within the described scope—namely, a PRA-authorised bank or designated investment firm that is headquartered in the UK or part of a UK-based group and that conducts investment banking or sales and trading activities in both the UK and overseas (referred to as ‘UK trading banks’)—the firm should treat those expectations as applicable in line with the stated delineation between expectations that apply to international banks alone and those that apply to international banks and UK trading banks [#SRC:a3ab5e4ef313b90a]. In that context, the PRA expects the firm to allocate responsibility for overseeing the firm’s booking arrangements to an SMF and to record this appropriately in the firm’s Statement of Responsibilities, so that accountability for booking-arrangements oversight is clearly documented [#TGT:a696590f07b39032]. Separately, where individuals in the parent or in group entities exercise significant influence over the management or conduct of one or more aspects of the firm’s UK regulated activities, the firm should assess whether it may be appropriate for those individuals to be approved as a Group Entity Senior Manager (SMF7), recognising that firms have applied for SMF7 approval for individuals performing a range of functions [#TGT:a696590f07b39032].

question: For firms covered by the PRA’s booking-arrangements expectations (including ‘UK trading banks’), who should be made responsible for overseeing booking arrangements, where must that responsibility be recorded, and when might someone in the parent or group entities need SMF7 approval?
gold_answer: For firms within the scope of the PRA’s booking-arrangements expectations—including PRA-authorised banks and designated investment firms that meet the ‘UK trading bank’ description (UK-headquartered or part of a UK-based group, with investment banking or sales and trading activities in both the UK and overseas)—the expectations apply as described, with the text also indicating that the PRA distinguishes between expectations that apply to international banks alone and those that apply to international banks and UK trading banks [#SRC:a3ab5e4ef313b90a]. Where applicable, the PRA expects the firm to allocate responsibility for overseeing the firm’s booking arrangements to an SMF and to record this appropriately in the firm’s Statement of Responsibilities [#TGT:a696590f07b39032]. In addition, if individuals in the parent or in group entities exercise significant influence over the management or conduct of one or more aspects of the firm’s UK regulated activities, the firm should consider whether it may be appropriate for those individuals to be approved as a Group Entity Senior Manager (SMF7), recognising that firms have sought SMF7 approval for individuals performing a range of functions [#TGT:a696590f07b39032].

question: Where a firm that accepts deposits under multiple brands or trading names must communicate information in a way that best brings it to depositors’ attention, can the firm satisfy that obligation by placing the required disclosures prominently on the front page of its website or mobile application, or via a pop-up box on login, and on what basis?
gold_answer: For a firm that accepts deposits under multiple brands or trading names, the firm must communicate the relevant information in a way that best brings it to depositors’ attention [#TGT:ff1653a69f0caf02]. In applying that obligation, the PRA indicates that the firm is permitted to rely on certain prominent digital placements as meeting the “best brings” standard, provided the content is the information required to be disclosed under the relevant depositor protection disclosure requirements. Specifically, if the required information is displayed prominently on the front page of the firm’s website or mobile application, or is presented in a pop-up box upon logging on to the website or mobile application, the PRA expects that the requirement to communicate in a way that best brings the information to depositors’ attention will have been satisfied [#SRC:06cb6758ebf841c4]. Accordingly, the obligation in the multi-brand/trading-name context can be met through these website/app presentation methods, so long as the firm is in fact displaying the required depositor protection information and doing so prominently in the specified locations or at login.

question: If a firm that accepts deposits under multiple brands or trading names has to make sure depositors notice the information, can it do this by putting the required disclosures prominently on the front page of its website or app, or by showing a pop-up when someone logs in?
gold_answer: Yes, in the situation where a firm that accepts deposits under multiple brands or trading names must provide information in a way that best brings it to depositors’ attention [#TGT:ff1653a69f0caf02], the PRA indicates that certain prominent online placements can satisfy that “best brings” requirement. The PRA’s expectation is that, if the information that is required to be disclosed under the depositor protection disclosure requirements is displayed prominently on the front page of the firm’s website or mobile application, that will meet the standard. The same applies if the required information is shown in a pop-up box when a user logs on to the website or mobile application [#SRC:06cb6758ebf841c4]. In other words, the firm can use these website/app methods to meet the obligation to draw depositors’ attention, as long as the content is the required depositor protection information and it is presented prominently in one of the specified ways.

question: When a firm is permitted not to follow certain compliance-related requirements because doing so would be disproportionate given the nature, scale and complexity of its business and the nature and range of the relevant services and activities, what must the firm still ensure so that the compliance function can discharge its responsibilities properly and independently?
gold_answer: A firm may be permitted not to comply with certain requirements where, in view of the nature, scale and complexity of its business and the nature and range of the relevant services and activities, compliance would not be proportionate, provided that the firm’s compliance function is, and continues to be, effective [#SRC:029ad42316e71977]. Even where that permission applies, the firm remains subject to an overarching obligation to ensure that the compliance function is able to discharge its responsibilities properly and independently [#TGT:56dd025c30f9e7e2]. Read together, this means the firm cannot treat the proportionality-based non-compliance as a relaxation of the need for an effective compliance function; rather, it must maintain arrangements that support proper and independent performance of the compliance function’s responsibilities while also ensuring the function remains effective on an ongoing basis. The firm should therefore assess proportionality in light of its business and activities, and only rely on the permission if it can demonstrate continuing effectiveness of the compliance function alongside the required ability for that function to operate properly and independently [#SRC:029ad42316e71977] [#TGT:56dd025c30f9e7e2].

question: When an institution is required to set up hedging sets for a netting set and allocate transactions to them, how must it treat the index that denotes all interest risk rate hedging sets established for that netting set, and how does that index relate to the institution’s obligation to establish the relevant hedging sets for each risk category?
gold_answer: Institutions must operationalise their obligation to establish hedging sets and allocate transactions by ensuring that, for each netting set, the interest risk rate hedging sets they establish are captured under the defined index “j”, which denotes all such interest risk rate hedging sets established for that netting set [#SRC:73f861950b2825dc]. In practice, this means that when Institutions establish the relevant hedging sets for each risk category of a netting set and assign each transaction to those hedging sets [#TGT:618dbcc272a2044a], they should treat “j” as the complete identifier set for the interest risk rate hedging sets within that netting set, so that transaction assignment can be performed against a clearly delimited universe of interest risk rate hedging sets. The definition of “j” is netting-set specific and is tied to hedging sets “established in accordance with” the referenced establishment conditions, so Institutions should ensure that the hedging sets they create for interest risk rate are the ones encompassed by that index and that transaction allocation is made to those established sets rather than to any ad hoc or undefined groupings. This aligns the definitional scope of the index with the required establishment-and-assignment process.

question: How must a firm structure its booking governance so that it both maintains a clear taxonomy of booking types (including remote, split, shared, and branch bookings) and documents which individuals are permitted to book into legal entities or branches, with accountability for the correctness of each booking traceable to a responsible individual?
gold_answer: A firm should implement booking governance that links “who can book” to “what kind of booking is being used.” It should first identify and classify the types of booking it employs and develop a clear, comprehensive taxonomy that defines key terms such as remote booking (in both legal-entity and geographic senses), split desks, shared desks, and branch bookings [#TGT:670172cefe48eb87]. In parallel, the firm should define and record who is permitted to book and what constitutes a booking, including whether the trader is solely responsible, and it should articulate any distinctions between traders, sales, and sales traders, as well as cover individuals booking into legal entities and branches (including traders based overseas booking into UK branches) [#SRC:03d5f6afa7925703]. The PRA expects the correctness of any given booking to be traceable to at least one, and preferably only one, responsible individual—usually the trader—so the firm should align its taxonomy and permissioning/recordkeeping so each booking type and location can be mapped to a clearly accountable person [#SRC:03d5f6afa7925703] and consistently described using the firm’s taxonomy [#TGT:670172cefe48eb87].

question: What must a firm do to clearly set out who is allowed to make bookings and, at the same time, classify the different booking types it uses (including remote, split, shared, and branch bookings) so each booking can be tied back to a responsible person?
gold_answer: A firm should do two connected things: define permissions and define categories. On permissions, it should define and record who is permitted to book and what counts as a booking, including whether the trader is solely responsible, and it should explain any differences in roles between traders, sales, and sales traders. It should also cover people booking into legal entities and branches, including traders based overseas booking into UK branches, and ensure the correctness of any given booking can be traced to at least one (preferably only one) responsible individual, usually the trader [#SRC:03d5f6afa7925703]. On categorisation, it should identify and classify the types of booking it employs and develop a clear and comprehensive taxonomy, clearly defining terms such as remote booking (both legal-entity and geographic senses), split desks, shared desks, and ensuring branch bookings are included in the classification [#TGT:670172cefe48eb87]. Taken together, the firm’s records of who may book should align with its taxonomy so that each booking type and booking location is consistently described and can be linked back to a clearly accountable individual [#SRC:03d5f6afa7925703] while using the firm’s own taxonomy approach [#TGT:670172cefe48eb87].

question: If Institutions have to make the required CRR disclosures, what do they need to say about risk management objectives and policies for each risk category, and what tables and instructions must they use to present it?
gold_answer: Institutions must include, within their required disclosure package, information describing their risk management objectives and policies for each separate category of risk, and this must also cover the risks referred to in the relevant Title [#TGT:dedbe720c755ba15]. At the same time, Institutions are not free to choose any format: they must make those required disclosures using the Tables UK OVA and UK OVB in Annex III and in line with the relevant instructions in Annex IV [#SRC:8d2b55c152b8188b]. In practice, this means Institutions should treat the risk-management objectives and policy content as mandatory disclosure material and then place it into the required table-based structure, completing the tables as directed and following the associated instructions for how the information should be set out. The combined effect is that both the subject matter (risk management objectives and policies by risk category) and the method of disclosure (the specified tables and instructions) are compulsory elements of the same disclosure obligation.

question: When the firm determines its exposure to assets of each description by adjusting the ascribed value, how must it treat assets of that description that the firm has transferred by way of initial margin—specifically, must the ascribed value be increased to reflect those transferred assets before the exposure amount is calculated?
gold_answer: In determining the amount by which the firm is exposed to assets of each description, the firm must start from a value ascribed to those assets and then determine exposure by adjusting that value under the applicable valuation approach described in the rules [#TGT:596695fe437c2dff]. Where, for a given description of assets, the firm has transferred assets of that same description by way of initial margin, the value ascribed for that description must be increased by an amount that represents the value of the transferred initial margin assets [#SRC:b5aade12a934b433]. Read together, this means the firm cannot calculate exposure using only the on-hand assets’ ascribed value; it must incorporate an uplift that captures the value of any same-description assets already transferred as initial margin, so that the adjusted value used for exposure determination reflects both the assets held and the value impact of those transferred assets. This increase applies at the level of each asset description and is tied to the value of the assets transferred by the firm as initial margin, ensuring the exposure calculation is based on an appropriately adjusted ascribed value across each description.

question: What steps should a society take to ensure it is appropriately informed about the statutory framework governing its electronic and website communications, given that the relevant provisions are inserted into the 1986 Act by later legislation?
gold_answer: A society should ensure it is actively aware of, and checks its practices against, the provisions in the 1986 Act that deal with electronic communications, because the SOURCE explicitly flags that societies should be aware of those provisions and points readers to the “Electronic communications” discussion for context [#SRC:07e2e50f8d1fdd53]. In parallel, the society should recognise that the TARGET identifies where the website-communications rules come from: the provisions were inserted into the 1986 Act by paragraphs in Schedule 9 to the Financial Services (Banking Reform) Act 2013, and those paragraphs contain provisions relating to website communications by a society [#TGT:bda17b6313ea65ca]. Read together, this means a society’s compliance approach should not treat “electronic communications” as a generic topic; it should specifically map its website communications to the inserted provisions now forming part of the 1986 Act, and ensure internal guidance and controls reflect that legislative lineage. Practically, the society should use the SOURCE’s signpost to locate the relevant electronic-communications discussion and then align it with the TARGET’s indication that the inserted provisions address website communications by a society, so staff understand both the obligation to be aware and the scope (website communications) of the provisions.

question: When a society is required to give meeting notice not only to existing members but also to persons who will become eligible to vote by turning 18 or by becoming shareholding or borrowing members within the relevant window, how should the society and the scrutineers treat an accidental failure to notify one of those entitled persons when assessing whether the meeting proceedings remain valid, and what kinds of notice failures fall outside that protection?
gold_answer: The society’s notice process must extend beyond the initial mailing to cover additional categories of persons who become entitled to receive notice after the notice date but before the relevant cut-offs, including those who will attain 18 by the meeting date and those who become shareholding or borrowing members before the final proxy receipt date, where they would be eligible to vote if they remained members until then [#SRC:89ce33483e37159d]. If, despite that obligation, notice is accidentally omitted to a person entitled to receive it (or the person does not receive it), that omission does not, of itself, invalidate the proceedings at the meeting, and the scrutineers report may properly take that principle into account when considering the notice position [#TGT:f23025bd819d81c5]. However, the protection is limited: it does not extend to systemic failures to send notices (such as omitting new members or a group/class due to a faulty mailing list or computer programme) or to all management errors. In particular, an erroneous management decision not to send notices to particular persons or groups is identified as outside what “accidental” or “non-receipt” would cover, so such failures may undermine reliance on the non-invalidation principle [#SRC:89ce33483e37159d] [#TGT:f23025bd819d81c5].
