question: If the society has to send meeting notices to people who become eligible after the notice date (like someone turning 18 or someone who becomes a shareholding or borrowing member), what happens if one of those people does not get a notice by accident—can the meeting still stand, and what mistakes are not treated as “accidental”?
gold_answer: The society’s duty to give notice is not limited to those already on the list at the notice date. It must also give notice to any person who will attain 18 after the notice date but by the meeting date, and to every person who becomes a shareholding or borrowing member after the notice date but before the final date for receipt of proxy voting forms, where they would be eligible to vote if they remained a member until then [#SRC:89ce33483e37159d]. If a notice is accidentally omitted to, or not received by, a person entitled to receive it, that does not invalidate the meeting proceedings, and the scrutineers report may properly take that principle into account when reviewing the notice position [#TGT:f23025bd819d81c5]. But the passages also draw a clear boundary: “accidental” does not cover systemic failures to send notices (for example, failing to send notices to new members, or omitting a group/class because of a computer-programme fault), and it does not cover all errors by management. In particular, an erroneous management decision not to send notices to particular persons or groups is highlighted as outside the accidental/non-receipt protection [#SRC:89ce33483e37159d] [#TGT:f23025bd819d81c5].

question: If a firm does not meet its combined buffer and has to work out its maximum distributable amount, how should it pick the right percentage for the product calculation, and what does each combined-buffer quartile mean for how much of the profits it can pay out?
gold_answer: If a firm does not meet its combined buffer, it will face restrictions on distributions and will be subject to a maximum distributable amount (MDA) [#SRC:f0d7eff2798e540b]. The MDA is not a general limit the firm can set itself; it must be calculated as the product of (i) a fixed percentage and (ii) a defined profits base [#SRC:f0d7eff2798e540b]. The percentage must be chosen from 60%, 40%, 20% or 0%, and the correct choice depends on which quartile of the firm’s combined buffer position it is in [#SRC:f0d7eff2798e540b]. The quartiles also define what share of the relevant profits can be distributed: in the first quartile (where the firm meets between 75% and 100% of its combined buffer), 60% of such profits can be distributed; in the second quartile, 40%; in the third, 20%; and in the fourth, 0% [#TGT:f7a8dbc40adc919d]. The profits base used in the product is the sum of the last four calendar quarter profits, net of any distribution of profits or any payment resulting from the items referenced in the MDA calculation requirement [#SRC:f0d7eff2798e540b].

question: Where a set of trades constitutes a group of transactions within a single netting set for which offsetting is permitted when determining potential future exposure, how shall Institutions reflect that grouping when calculating exposure at the netting set level?
gold_answer: When the relevant trades form a group of transactions within a single netting set and the framework permits full or partial offsetting for the purpose of determining potential future exposure, Institutions must treat that group as being assessed within the netting set construct rather than as isolated transactions. In that case, the required calculation is not multiple transaction-level exposure values but one consolidated exposure value at the netting set level, applying the method specified for that purpose. This aligns the definitional premise—offsetting being allowed within the single netting set for potential future exposure determination—with the operational obligation to produce a single exposure value for the netting set. Accordingly, Institutions shall calculate one exposure value at netting set level using the applicable method referenced for that calculation, while respecting any stated condition that the obligation is subject to the relevant paragraph. This ensures the exposure measure is consistent with the permitted offsetting treatment embedded in the definition of the grouped transactions within the netting set [#SRC:2d324df83e348f82] and with the explicit requirement to calculate a single exposure value at netting set level [#TGT:b16c73e93c0f2966].

question: If a firm wants to use assets backing TPs for an intragroup loan or participation, what must it show to meet the rule that investments should fit the nature and duration of its liabilities and be in policyholders’ best interests?
gold_answer: The firm must ensure that assets backing TPs are invested in a manner that matches the nature and duration of the firm’s insurance and reinsurance liabilities and is in the best interests of all policyholders, taking into account any disclosed policy objectives [#SRC:afb7633ef682266c]. When the proposed investment is an intragroup loan or participation, the policyholders’ best-interests requirement becomes especially important because such transactions can benefit shareholders without necessarily benefiting policyholders [#TGT:19e81bc332eae024]. The PRA expects it will be difficult for firms to prove that intragroup loans and participations meet the best-interests test and, for that reason, difficult to prove they are appropriate for covering TPs [#TGT:19e81bc332eae024]. The firm should therefore be prepared to justify both (1) why the intragroup exposure is suitable given the liabilities it backs (including duration) and (2) why policyholders are protected, bearing in mind the example risk that a loan issuer may be less willing or able to enforce repayment, particularly for upstream loans [#TGT:19e81bc332eae024].

question: How must a firm use mapping to support testing of its ability to deliver important business services within impact tolerances, and how must that testing be structured and focused when conducted regularly under severe but plausible disruption scenarios?
gold_answer: A firm must ensure its mapping work is built to enable and support testing of its ability to deliver important business services within impact tolerances, because the map of the relevant business service is needed to design scenarios and understand their full implications [#SRC:29629da2f8753b59]. In parallel, the firm must test regularly its ability to remain within those impact tolerances in severe but plausible disruption scenarios, treating impact tolerances as operating on the assumption that a disruption has already occurred [#TGT:2ff0a61603b1ca55]. Accordingly, the testing approach should be grounded in the mapped view of the business service so scenarios can be designed and interpreted in a way that reflects end-to-end delivery, while the test objectives should avoid concentrating on incident prevention and instead concentrate on whether recovery and response arrangements allow the firm to stay within the defined tolerances during disruption [#TGT:2ff0a61603b1ca55]. Taken together, the mapping provides the necessary foundation for scenario design and impact analysis, and the regular tests validate recovery and response capability against impact tolerances rather than controls intended to stop incidents [#SRC:29629da2f8753b59].

question: For societies that are not publicly quoted, what is the required governance standard they must take into account when establishing and reviewing corporate governance arrangements, and how should the relevant version of the Combined Code be identified by reference to its defined scope and timing?
gold_answer: Societies that are not publicly quoted are expected, when they establish and review their corporate governance arrangements, to take into account an appropriate governance code; specifically, they should have regard to the UK Corporate Governance Code or, where appropriate, the Combined Code [#SRC:1da93b3de3471f0b]. Determining when the Combined Code is the appropriate reference point requires using the definition of that term: it is the Combined Code on Corporate Governance developed by the Corporate Governance Committee of the Financial Reporting Council, and it is tied to accounting periods beginning before 29 June 2010 [#TGT:a3566db56919a9f0]. Read together, this means a society’s obligation to consider a governance code is not limited by its unquoted status, but the selection between the UK Corporate Governance Code and the Combined Code should be made by applying the defined temporal scope of the Combined Code (i.e., whether the relevant accounting period begins before the stated date) and recognising its provenance (the Financial Reporting Council’s Corporate Governance Committee). This supports consistent governance benchmarking when arrangements are created and periodically reassessed.

question: If societies are not publicly quoted, what code should they take into account when setting up and checking their corporate governance arrangements, and what does “the Combined Code” mean in terms of who developed it and which accounting periods it covers?
gold_answer: Even though societies are not publicly quoted, they are expected to take a recognised governance framework into account when they establish and review their corporate governance arrangements; in practice, they should have regard to the UK Corporate Governance Code or, where appropriate, the Combined Code [#SRC:1da93b3de3471f0b]. To apply that “as appropriate” choice, you need the definition of the Combined Code: it is the Combined Code on Corporate Governance that was developed by the Corporate Governance Committee of the Financial Reporting Council, and it applies to accounting periods beginning before 29 June 2010 [#TGT:a3566db56919a9f0]. Putting both points together, a society deciding whether to use the Combined Code should check whether the relevant accounting period begins before the stated date and understand that the code being referenced is the one produced through the Financial Reporting Council’s Corporate Governance Committee. If those definition conditions are not met, the society would instead look to having regard to the UK Corporate Governance Code when setting up and reassessing its governance arrangements.

question: When a firm experiences a material change in the firm’s systems affecting compliance with 11.1 and 11.2, what must the firm do to notify the PRA and FSCS within the required timeframe, and what accompanying signed confirmation must be provided on behalf of the firm’s governing body regarding the firm’s systems and related requirements?
gold_answer: Where there is a material change in the firm’s systems relevant to compliance with 11.1 and 11.2, the firm must notify the PRA and FSCS within 3 months of the change [#TGT:933dedc51e46fe4b]. In addition to making that notification, the firm must ensure the notification is accompanied by a statement signed on behalf of the firm’s governing body. That signed statement must confirm that the firm’s systems comply with 11.1 and 11.2 and also satisfy the requirements in 11.8 [#SRC:5b1ab5485cfeeb3f]. Read together, the obligations mean the firm’s notification is not complete unless it both (i) is delivered to the PRA and FSCS within the three‑month period following the material change and (ii) includes the governing-body-signed confirmation addressing the firm’s systems’ compliance with 11.1 and 11.2 and satisfaction of 11.8. The firm should therefore coordinate internal governance sign-off so the signed statement can be submitted as part of the same notification package sent to the PRA and FSCS within the deadline.

question: If a firm makes a material change to the firm’s systems that relates to compliance with 11.1 and 11.2, what must it send to the PRA and FSCS within 3 months, and what signed statement must be included with that notification?
gold_answer: If a firm makes a material change in the firm’s systems that is relevant to compliance with 11.1 and 11.2, the firm must notify the PRA and FSCS within 3 months of the change [#TGT:933dedc51e46fe4b]. That notification must not be sent on its own: it must be accompanied by a statement signed on behalf of the firm’s governing body [#SRC:5b1ab5485cfeeb3f]. The signed statement must confirm two things about the firm’s systems: first, that they comply with 11.1 and 11.2; and second, that they satisfy the requirements in 11.8 [#SRC:5b1ab5485cfeeb3f]. In practice, this means the firm needs to prepare a notification addressed to both the PRA and FSCS and ensure it is submitted within the three-month window, while also obtaining the required governing-body sign-off so the signed confirmation can be included as part of the same submission. Without the accompanying signed confirmation, the notification would not meet the stated accompanying requirement.

question: If a firm has client or trust accounts held for beneficiaries that might include eligible deposits, what must it do so those accounts can be spotted right away, and how quickly must it be able to send the PRA or FSCS the separated details of eligible versus ineligible accounts when asked?
gold_answer: The firm must mark the relevant accounts so they can be immediately identified—this includes client accounts and trust accounts held on behalf of beneficiaries that contain or may contain eligible deposits [#TGT:68113e9f6b9da4d1]. Beyond putting that marking in place, the firm must also have the ability to provide the PRA or the FSCS with the details of eligible and/or ineligible accounts, with eligible and ineligible accounts separately identified, in a format consistent with the relevant rule and the statement [#SRC:abfeb4bf0c334fbc]. The timing requirement is that the firm must be able to make those details available within twelve hours from the point when the PRA or the FSCS makes the request [#SRC:abfeb4bf0c334fbc]. In practice, this means the marking requirement supports immediate recognition of the accounts in scope, and the firm’s systems and processes must also support rapid production and delivery of the underlying account information, separated by eligibility status, to the PRA or FSCS on demand.

question: In a transfer to a specially formed successor company, what must the society build into the transfer terms to ensure it no longer holds shares by the time it dissolves, and how must the society manage vesting-date notification and any later dissolution date (including any restriction on post-vesting activities) to facilitate disposal of those shares?
gold_answer: The society must ensure the transfer documentation contains provisions that achieve a clear outcome: by the date the society is to dissolve, it no longer holds any shares in the specially formed successor company [#SRC:6b46a0ab65f37c08]. Operationally, this interacts with the society’s duties around the vesting date and dissolution. After the PRA has confirmed the transfer and notified the FCA and the society, the society must notify both the PRA and the FCA of the vesting date, and it must do so no later than seven days before that date [#TGT:44f3b2962ff383a8]. Unless the society gives notice of a later dissolution date in the vesting-date notice (where necessary to facilitate disposal of its shares in its successor), the society is dissolved on the vesting date; if a later dissolution date is notified for that facilitation purpose, dissolution occurs on that later date [#TGT:44f3b2962ff383a8]. Where the society uses the later-dissolution option, it must cease to transact any business from the vesting date except business necessary to dispose of its shares, aligning the timetable for disposal with the transfer-term requirement that shareholding ends by dissolution [#TGT:44f3b2962ff383a8] [#SRC:6b46a0ab65f37c08].

question: If the society is transferring to a specially formed successor company, what must the transfer terms do so the society stops holding shares by the time it dissolves, and what notices and timing must the society follow for the vesting date and any later dissolution date so it can dispose of those shares?
gold_answer: The transfer terms must include provisions that make sure the society stops holding any shares in the specially formed successor company by the date on which the society is to dissolve [#SRC:6b46a0ab65f37c08]. The society then has to follow the vesting-date and dissolution process that governs when dissolution happens and how share disposal can be completed. Once the PRA has confirmed the transfer, it will notify the FCA and the society, and the society must notify both the PRA and the FCA of the vesting date no later than seven days before that date [#TGT:44f3b2962ff383a8]. If the society does not give a notice of a later dissolution date, dissolution occurs on the vesting date; however, if it is necessary to help dispose of the society’s shares in its successor, the society may include in its vesting-date notice a later dissolution date, and dissolution will occur on that later date [#TGT:44f3b2962ff383a8]. If the society uses that later-dissolution option, it must stop transacting any business from the vesting date except what is necessary to dispose of its shares, supporting the requirement that it no longer holds shares by dissolution [#TGT:44f3b2962ff383a8] [#SRC:6b46a0ab65f37c08].

question: For a third country CRR firm, how should a firm determine whether the responsibilities described as “third country CRR firm prescribed responsibilities” are in scope, given that the scope provision states that such prescribed responsibilities do not apply? In your answer, explain what is captured by the definition of a “third country CRR firm prescribed responsibility” and how the stated non-application affects that category.
gold_answer: The definition establishes the category: subject to a stated condition, each responsibility set out in the relevant rule is treated as a “third country CRR firm prescribed responsibility” [#TGT:44007a11cde2c105]. Separately, the scope statement provides an explicit carve-out for a third country CRR firm by stating that the third country CRR firm prescribed responsibilities do not apply [#SRC:f648d10db474d8ec]. Read together, this means that even though the rule text may classify responsibilities as “third country CRR firm prescribed responsibilities” (i.e., they fall within the defined label when the definition’s condition is met), the scope provision removes their applicability to the third country CRR firm in question. Practically, the firm should (i) identify the responsibilities that would otherwise be captured by the definition as being “set out in this rule” and therefore within the defined category [#TGT:44007a11cde2c105], and then (ii) apply the scope carve-out confirming that those prescribed responsibilities are not applicable to the third country CRR firm [#SRC:f648d10db474d8ec].

question: If a rule says certain responsibilities are “third country CRR firm prescribed responsibilities,” but another provision says those prescribed responsibilities do not apply, what does that mean for a third country CRR firm? Please define what counts as a “third country CRR firm prescribed responsibility” and then explain the effect of the non-application statement.
gold_answer: A “third country CRR firm prescribed responsibility” is defined by reference to the responsibilities listed in the relevant rule: subject to a stated condition, each responsibility set out in that rule is treated as a third country CRR firm prescribed responsibility [#TGT:44007a11cde2c105]. However, the scope provision then states that the third country CRR firm prescribed responsibilities do not apply [#SRC:f648d10db474d8ec]. Putting these together, the responsibilities can still be identified and labelled under the definition (because they are “responsibilities set out in this rule” and therefore fall within the defined category when the definition’s condition is satisfied) [#TGT:44007a11cde2c105], but the separate scope statement removes any requirement for the third country CRR firm to comply with them because they are expressly stated not to apply [#SRC:f648d10db474d8ec]. In other words, the definition tells you what the category would include, while the scope statement tells you that, for the third country CRR firm, that category is switched off for applicability purposes.

question: When institutions handle derivative transactions that are mapped to the commodity risk category and the transaction has more than one material risk driver, how shall the transaction be mapped across risk categories and, within the commodity risk category, how shall it be assigned to a hedging set based on the relevant risk driver?
gold_answer: Institutions must first determine whether a derivative transaction has more than one material risk driver and, if so, apply the derogation requiring mapping to more than one risk category where relevant. If all material risk drivers fall within the same risk category, the transaction is mapped only once to that category using the most material risk driver; if the material risk drivers span different risk categories, the transaction is mapped once to each relevant risk category, using the most material risk driver within each category [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad]. Separately, for the portion of the analysis where the transaction is mapped to the commodity risk category, institutions must then assign that transaction to one of the specified hedging sets. That hedging set assignment must be made on the basis of the nature of the transaction’s primary risk driver, or (where applicable) the most material risk driver within the commodity risk category for the relevant transactions [#SRC:820ffbb74005c855]. In practice, this means multi-risk-driver transactions may require multiple category mappings, while the commodity hedging set selection is anchored to the primary or most material commodity risk driver.

question: If institutions have a derivative transaction with more than one important risk driver, what must they do about mapping it to risk categories, and if it is mapped to the commodity risk category, how must they choose the hedging set?
gold_answer: Institutions must check whether a derivative transaction has more than one material risk driver and then map it accordingly. If all the material risk drivers are in the same risk category, institutions only need to map the transaction once to that category, using the most material risk driver. If the material risk drivers are in different risk categories, institutions must map the transaction once to each risk category where it has at least one material risk driver, and for each such category they must use the most material risk driver in that category [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad]. In addition, whenever the transaction is mapped to the commodity risk category, institutions must assign it to one of the listed hedging sets. That assignment must be based on the nature of the primary risk driver, or (for the relevant transactions) the most material risk driver within the commodity risk category [#SRC:820ffbb74005c855]. So a single transaction can be mapped multiple times across categories, but its commodity hedging set is chosen by focusing on the primary or most material commodity-related driver.

question: If a managing agents is using an internal model to work out the notional syndicate SCR, what does “internal model” mean in that situation, and what must a firm with internal model permission make sure its risk-management function does as a result?
gold_answer: In the managing agents context, when the applied rules use the phrase “internal model,” it is not a special or limited term: it must be understood as referring to any internal model that a managing agents uses to calculate the notional syndicate SCR [#SRC:fcea9d1469b85659]. Separately, if a firm has received internal model permission, it must take a concrete governance step: it must ensure that its risk-management function covers additional tasks (i.e., tasks that are specifically extra because the firm has that permission) [#TGT:f3398a0e786dcdd5]. Putting these together, the interpretation tells you which models fall within scope for the managing agents’ notional syndicate SCR calculation, and the permission-based requirement tells you what the firm must do organisationally—make sure the risk-management function’s remit expands to cover the additional tasks associated with internal model permission. The combined effect is that the firm should not treat only one particular model as relevant; instead, the risk-management function’s expanded coverage must be set up with the understanding that “internal model” includes any model used for that notional syndicate SCR purpose.

question: When an institution acts as a clearing member and, in that capacity, intermediates between a client and a CCP, how must it combine its obligation to calculate own funds requirements for CCP-related transactions with that client with its obligation to assess—using scenario analysis and stress testing—whether own funds held against CCP exposures (including default fund and contingent exposures) are commensurate with the inherent risks?
gold_answer: Where an institution acts as a clearing member and, in that capacity, acts as a financial intermediary between a client and a CCP, it must first calculate the own funds requirements for its CCP-related transactions with that client in accordance with the applicable framework referenced for those calculations [#TGT:44da4c43fe9df94e]. In parallel, and as part of its broader prudential risk management, institutions must assess—through appropriate scenario analysis and stress testing—whether the level of own funds held against exposures to a CCP adequately relates to the inherent risks of those exposures [#SRC:a3a91a063d2c4fd0]. That assessment must explicitly cover not only current exposures but also potential future or contingent credit exposures, exposures arising from default fund contributions, and, where the institution is acting as a clearing member, exposures resulting from contractual arrangements. Taken together, the calculation obligation establishes the required own funds requirements for the relevant CCP-related client transactions, while the scenario and stress-testing obligation requires the institution to evaluate whether the own funds it holds against the full set of CCP exposures (including those linked to clearing-member contractual arrangements) remains risk-appropriate under adverse but plausible conditions.

question: In the context of the Prudential Regulator’s decision on whether to confirm a merger, how should a society understand the “Three Criteria” and when is the Prudential Regulator permitted to direct the society to remedy defects that would otherwise prevent confirmation, including what the direction may require and how the subsequent confirmation decision is determined?
gold_answer: The “Three Criteria” are the criteria the Prudential Regulator must consider when deciding whether to confirm a merger, and they are prescribed by the relevant statutory framework; they may also be varied in certain circumstances as noted in the definition. [#TGT:f876d164651d21b2] Where defects fall within those criteria such that the PRA would be precluded from confirming the merger, the PRA is permitted to direct a society to remedy the defects. [#SRC:8ba3cc430698d0ee] The direction may require practical remedial steps, including calling a further meeting to vote again after issuing a revised Schedule 16 Statement that includes material information previously omitted, or after correcting defects in systems for sending notices of meeting and Statements and validating votes. [#SRC:8ba3cc430698d0ee] After the society furnishes evidence, the Prudential Regulator’s confirmation outcome turns on whether it is satisfied the defects have been substantially remedied: if satisfied, it must confirm the merger; if not satisfied, confirmation must be refused. This links the definitional trigger (criteria governing confirmation) to the remedial permission (direction to cure defects that would otherwise block confirmation).

question: When institutions are determining exposure values for transactions under a contractual netting agreement, what is the required calculation sequence for using a single exposure value versus separate exposure values, and in that process when may two perfectly matching OTC derivative contracts in the same netting agreement be treated as one contract with a zero notional principal?
gold_answer: Institutions should first determine whether the transactions fall within a contractual netting agreement for which the applicable conditions are met; if so, they may calculate a single exposure value covering all transactions within that agreement, and if not, they must calculate an exposure value separately for each transaction, treating each as its own netting set [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c]. Within the scenario where institutions are calculating exposure value in accordance with the relevant methods, they are permitted to simplify the treatment of two OTC derivative contracts that are included in the same netting agreement and are perfectly matching by treating them as if they were a single contract with a notional principal equal to zero [#SRC:14f4743e51835715]. Practically, this means the procedural decision point is whether the contractual netting agreement qualifies for a single exposure value; once that approach is available, the institution can apply the permitted contract-level treatment for perfectly matching OTC derivative contracts inside the same netting agreement as part of its exposure value calculation methodology, while otherwise defaulting to transaction-by-transaction exposure values and separate netting sets as required [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c] and permitted [#SRC:14f4743e51835715].

question: If institutions have a contractual netting agreement, when can they use one exposure value for all transactions, and how can they handle two perfectly matching OTC derivative contracts in the same netting agreement during that calculation?
gold_answer: Institutions should start by checking whether the contractual netting agreement meets the relevant conditions for aggregation. If it does, institutions may calculate a single exposure value for all the transactions within that contractual netting agreement; if it does not, institutions must calculate an exposure value separately for each transaction and treat each transaction as its own netting set [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c]. When institutions are calculating the exposure value using the applicable calculation methods, they also have a specific permission for a narrow case inside a netting agreement: where two OTC derivative contracts are included in the same netting agreement and are perfectly matching, institutions may treat those two contracts as if they were a single contract, and the notional principal of that single contract is taken to be zero [#SRC:14f4743e51835715]. In other words, the procedure is (1) decide whether you can aggregate at the netting-agreement level, and then (2) within the netting agreement, apply the permitted “treat as one” approach for perfectly matching OTC derivative contracts as part of the exposure value calculation, while otherwise applying separate exposure values per transaction where aggregation is not available [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c].

question: When a firm identifies an economic downturn, what minimum historical period must it use to review economic indicators, and how does the Technical Standards (Economic Downturn) Instrument 2021 affect the application of that requirement, including any expectation to extend the period if the observed values are not sufficiently severe?
gold_answer: Where a firm identifies an economic downturn, it must examine relevant economic indicators over a historical time-span that yields values representative of the likely future range of variability, and that historical period must be at least 20 years [#SRC:c5c800b2b7424aab]. In addition, the PRA expects the firm to choose a time-span that enables identification of indicator values reflecting sufficiently severe downturn conditions; if the values observed over the minimum period are not sufficiently severe, the firm should extend the historical time-span beyond 20 years to capture more severe conditions [#SRC:c5c800b2b7424aab]. The Technical Standards (Economic Downturn) Instrument 2021 is the implementation vehicle for the relevant Technical Standards, so the firm should treat the above minimum-duration requirement and the PRA’s expectation on selecting (and, where needed, extending) the historical time-span as applying in the form implemented by that Instrument [#TGT:d2850b5b59c0e5dd]. Taken together, the obligation is to meet the minimum 20-year lookback while ensuring the chosen period is adequate to evidence sufficiently severe downturn indicator values, with extension beyond the minimum where necessary.

question: If a firm says it has identified an economic downturn, how far back does it need to look at economic indicators, and what does it need to do if that lookback does not show severe enough downturn values, given the Technical Standards (Economic Downturn) Instrument 2021?
gold_answer: If a firm identifies an economic downturn, it must review economic indicators over a historical time-span that produces values representative of the likely range of future variability, and that time-span must be at least 20 years [#SRC:c5c800b2b7424aab]. The PRA also expects the firm to pick a historical period that allows it to identify indicator values that are sufficiently severe for downturn conditions; the minimum period is not necessarily enough if it does not capture severe conditions [#SRC:c5c800b2b7424aab]. In that case, the firm should extend the historical time-span beyond the 20-year minimum so that the indicator values used reflect sufficiently severe downturn conditions [#SRC:c5c800b2b7424aab]. The Technical Standards (Economic Downturn) Instrument 2021 implements the relevant Technical Standards, so the firm should apply these requirements and expectations as they are implemented through that Instrument, rather than treating them as optional guidance [#TGT:d2850b5b59c0e5dd].

question: Before the Merger Notification Statement is issued to members, what must occur in relation to PRA approval, and how must the board address interim material changes to the society’s financial position given that the financial information may be out of date by the approval date?
gold_answer: Before the Merger Notification Statement is sent to the members, it must already have been approved by the PRA, and it must then be sent within the specified time limit [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc]. In parallel, because the financial information included in the Schedule 16 Statement will relate to a period ending before the date that statement is approved, the board must explicitly state whether there have been any material changes to the financial position in the interim [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1]. Where a change has been identified but cannot be quantified, the board must still describe the effect so that members understand it is relevant to their consideration of the proposed merger [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1]. These requirements work together to ensure that, at the point the PRA-approved member communication is issued, members are not relying on stale financial information without an accompanying statement about intervening developments. The target text also makes clear that failure to disclose such interim changes will be relevant to the PRA’s later consideration of the society’s application for confirmation of the merger [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1], reinforcing the importance of accurate, up-to-date disclosure alongside the PRA approval and timely dispatch obligations [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc].

question: What has to happen before the Merger Notification Statement is sent to members, and what does the board have to say about any important financial changes that happened after the financial period covered but before the statement is approved?
gold_answer: The Merger Notification Statement cannot be sent to the members unless it has first been approved by the PRA, and it must then be sent within the specified time limit [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc]. Separately, because the financial information in the Schedule 16 Statement will cover a period that ends before the date that statement is approved, the board must tell members whether there have been any material changes to the financial position in the meantime [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1]. If the board cannot put a number on the effect of a change, it still has to describe the change so members at least know it has been identified and is relevant to their decision on the proposed merger [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1]. The target text also warns that not disclosing these interim changes will matter to the PRA when it later considers the society’s application for confirmation of the merger [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1]. Taken together, the PRA-approval-before-sending requirement and the board’s interim-change disclosure obligation are intended to ensure members receive a PRA-approved communication that also addresses any significant developments since the financial period reported [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc] [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1].

question: When, at the relevant date, the firm is a party to an option and it is prudent to assume the option will be exercised, how must the firm reflect the resulting deemed acquisition or disposal of assets in the value ascribed to assets of each description?
gold_answer: Where the firm meets the definition that it must be deemed to have acquired or disposed of assets pursuant to an option—specifically, at the relevant date it is a party to an option and it is prudent to assume that the option will be exercised—the firm must treat the option as creating a deemed acquisition or disposal for valuation purposes [#SRC:bd531cb4e2558157]. Once that definitional trigger is met, the firm has a corresponding obligation to adjust the values it has ascribed to assets: the value ascribed in respect of assets of each description must be increased or decreased by the value of assets of that description that the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of pursuant to the option [#TGT:edaf68ec91a76124]. In practice, this means the firm must (i) identify the relevant asset description affected by the option, (ii) determine the value of the assets of that description that are treated as deemed acquired or disposed of under the option, and (iii) apply that value as an increase or decrease to the ascribed value for that asset description. The adjustment is required because the deemed transaction changes the firm’s position in those assets once the option is treated as effectively exercisable.

question: How must a firm align the requirement to have an appropriate actuary investigate the firm’s financial condition for its insurance business on a triennial basis with the obligation to ensure the first such investigation is completed for the first financial year ending on or after 1 January 2017?
gold_answer: A firm must operate a compliance timetable that satisfies both the ongoing cadence and the initial timing trigger. Specifically, the firm must ensure that an investigation is made by the appropriate actuary into the financial condition of the firm in respect of its insurance business every third financial year [#TGT:3caa12ffd3bf3daf]. In addition, the firm must ensure that the investigation referred to is completed in respect of the first financial year ending on or after 1 January 2017 [#SRC:fbe9526d072301c2]. Read together, this means the firm cannot treat the triennial requirement as purely prospective; it must identify the first financial year that ends on or after 1 January 2017 and ensure the actuary’s investigation for that year is completed, and then continue to ensure that the actuary performs the investigation at the required every-third-financial-year interval thereafter. The firm remains responsible for ensuring both that the investigation is made by the appropriate actuary and that the relevant investigation is completed for the specified first financial year and subsequent triennial cycles.

question: When applying the requirement that a credit union must ensure a member does not hold non-deferred shares above the applicable aggregate limit, how does the rule apply where the member’s percentage holding increases solely because the total non-deferred shares decrease after the member last acquired non-deferred shares?
gold_answer: A credit union’s core obligation is to ensure that a member does not have non-deferred shares in the credit union which, in aggregate, exceed the relevant limit [#SRC:20f46de0cd0e38dc]. The scope of that obligation is qualified for a specific post-acquisition scenario: where a member’s percentage of non-deferred shares increases not because the member acquired more, but because the total non-deferred shares are reduced after the time the member last acquired non-deferred shares. In that event, the rule addresses the situation in which the percentage increase would otherwise cause the member to breach the applicable limits, even though the member has not made a further acquisition [#TGT:2ad3af3cb41ab7f4]. Practically, the credit union should assess whether the apparent breach arises solely from the reduction in the total non-deferred shares occurring after the member’s last acquisition, and treat that circumstance as within the rule’s stated event, rather than as a straightforward failure to control member acquisitions. This preserves the general limit-enforcement duty while recognizing the defined exception-like circumstance tied to changes in the denominator rather than the member’s holdings.

question: A credit union must make sure a member does not end up with too many non-deferred shares in total. Does this still apply if the member’s percentage goes up only because the credit union’s total non-deferred shares go down after the member last bought any?
gold_answer: Yes, the starting point is that a credit union must ensure that a member does not have non-deferred shares in the credit union which, in aggregate, exceed the applicable limit [#SRC:20f46de0cd0e38dc]. But the scope of how that limit is applied is shaped by a specific situation: if the member’s percentage holding increases because the total non-deferred shares are reduced, and that reduction happens after the time the member last acquired non-deferred shares. The rule is aimed at the case where, without this provision, that percentage increase would result in a breach of the limits even though the member has not acquired additional non-deferred shares at that time [#TGT:2ad3af3cb41ab7f4]. In other words, the credit union should distinguish between (a) a member exceeding limits due to acquiring more shares (which the credit union must prevent) and (b) a member appearing to exceed limits due only to a later reduction in the total non-deferred shares. The latter is the defined event the rule addresses.

question: Can an institution use the Section 4 method to work out the exposure value of its derivative positions if it is using the methods in Sections 4 to 5, and what does it have to do to show its on- and off-balance-sheet derivative business is small enough?
gold_answer: Yes, but only if the institution meets the permission’s conditions and uses the right sizing basis. Where the institution is in the category of institutions using the methods set out in Sections 4 to 5 of Chapter 6 of Title II Part Three, the size of its on- and off-balance-sheet derivative business is the size calculated in accordance with Article 273a(1) or (2), as applicable [#SRC:afa72c2dcedc6ca1]. The institution may then calculate the exposure value of its derivative positions using the method set out in Section 4 only subject to the restriction referenced for that permission and provided that this size measure is equal to or less than both thresholds required for eligibility [#TGT:a1884bd4d42120b2]. It also has to keep checking this: the thresholds must be tested based on an assessment carried out monthly, using data as of the last day of each month, so the institution must monitor and evidence compliance on that recurring monthly basis rather than relying on a single point-in-time calculation [#TGT:a1884bd4d42120b2].

question: If a firm wants to report changes in close links every month, what must it send to the PRA, and what does that mean for the firm’s duties once it has made that election?
gold_answer: If a firm wants to report changes in close links on a monthly basis, it must send a written notice of election to the firm’s usual supervisory contact at the PRA [#TGT:ddb4ece0eb83434d]. Sending that written notice is the required step to make the election to use monthly reporting. After the firm has made that election, the source text explains that the firm then falls into the category of a firm that “has elected” monthly reporting and, in that situation, the firm must comply with the obligations that apply once the election has been made [#SRC:cbb18fb0e9c945fe]. In other words, the written notice is what the firm must do to put the monthly reporting approach in place, and the fact of having elected monthly reporting is what triggers the firm’s ongoing “must” requirements under the monthly reporting arrangement referenced in the source [#TGT:ddb4ece0eb83434d] [#SRC:cbb18fb0e9c945fe].

question: If an insurer is not a small non-Directive insurer, what must it do about contingency planning to ensure continuity and regularity, and how should that work be used to develop the insurer’s liquidity contingency plan?
gold_answer: An insurer, other than a small non-Directive insurer, must take reasonable steps to ensure continuity and regularity in the performance of its activities, and that requirement includes developing contingency plans; based on this obligation, the insurer is expected to develop a liquidity contingency plan [#TGT:eb3314818a8bad05]. The insurer should therefore treat the liquidity contingency plan as a specific contingency plan that is developed as part of its continuity and regularity arrangements, rather than as an optional add-on. In developing that liquidity contingency plan, the insurer should use the relevant material that is used to inform the development of the insurer’s liquidity contingency plan, so that the plan is grounded in the considerations intended to shape it and is developed in a deliberate, informed way [#SRC:3f58b3b215298de4]. This connects the general requirement to develop contingency plans for continuity with the specific expectation that the insurer develops a liquidity contingency plan, and ensures the liquidity plan is built using the inputs that are meant to inform its development [#TGT:eb3314818a8bad05] [#SRC:3f58b3b215298de4].

question: When a firm calibrates a residential mortgage rating system by uplifting internal observed default rates to a long-run average and uses an embedded calculation mechanism that changes the PD applied to exposures with a given set of characteristics, how must the firm treat that mechanism for recalibration purposes, and what cyclicality assumption must it apply when grade-level internal observed default rates are unavailable (including how the PRA may vary that expectation)?
gold_answer: A firm should treat any embedded calculation mechanism in its rating system that changes the PD applied to exposures with a given set of characteristics as a recalibration, rather than as an intended feature of rating system design, because the PRA expects such recalibrations to be rare and symptomatic of failures in the rating system’s assumptions [#SRC:5f859b5bac10db27]. In parallel, when calibrating residential mortgage rating systems by uplifting internal observed default rates to a long-run average, the firm should assume that the cyclicality of each rating system is no more than 30% in years where grade-level internal observed default rates are not available, as this cap is the PRA’s expectation for imputing missing historical default rates [#TGT:8705f442785054e1]. The firm should also reflect the PRA’s expectation that, when assigning long-run average default rates to each rating grade, at least 70% of the portfolio change in default rate is assumed to reflect grade-level changes in default rate (with the remaining portion attributable to grade migration) [#TGT:8705f442785054e1]. The PRA indicates this expectation may be adjusted if it judges the risk of under-calibration has changed [#TGT:8705f442785054e1].

question: If a firm’s residential mortgage rating system includes a built-in calculation that changes the PD for exposures with the same characteristics, what does the PRA say the firm must treat that as, and what cyclicality cap must the firm assume when it is filling in missing grade-level default-rate history while uplifting to a long-run average?
gold_answer: The PRA’s definition means that a built-in calculation mechanism in a rating system that changes the PD applied to exposures with a given set of characteristics should be treated as a recalibration, and the PRA expects recalibrations of rating systems applying the relevant cyclicality assumptions to be rare and to indicate failures of the rating system’s assumptions rather than being part of the system’s intended design [#SRC:5f859b5bac10db27]. Separately, to mitigate under-calibration risk when firms calibrate residential mortgage rating systems by uplifting internal observed default rates to a long-run average, the PRA expects firms to assume that cyclicality is no more than 30% in years where grade-level internal observed default rates are not available; this is the maximum cyclicality the PRA expects firms to assume when imputing missing historical default rates [#TGT:8705f442785054e1]. In setting long-run average default rates for each rating grade, the PRA also expects firms to assume that at least 70% of the portfolio change in default rate reflects changes in default rates within grades (rather than grade migration) [#TGT:8705f442785054e1]. The PRA notes it may adjust this expectation if it judges the risk of under-calibration has changed [#TGT:8705f442785054e1].

question: For institutions that are small CRR firms and are subject to the relevant disclosure framework, what remuneration-related information must they disclose, and how is that obligation framed for the staff categories in scope?
gold_answer: Where an institution is both subject to the applicable disclosure framework and qualifies as a small CRR firm, the scope condition in the source text clarifies that a specific disclosure approach applies notwithstanding other paragraphs, and it ties that approach to the information set associated with the remuneration disclosure framework [#SRC:47c62d3f801c6d13]. Within that scoped population, the institution’s concrete obligation is to make disclosures about its remuneration policy and practices, but only as they relate to those categories of staff whose professional activities have a material impact on the risk profile of the institutions [#TGT:d3efeb25748ccfe0]. Read together, the source establishes when the tailored disclosure treatment is triggered (i.e., for institutions subject to the Article that are small CRR firms and for the information referred to in the remuneration disclosure framework), while the target specifies the substantive content focus of what must be disclosed (remuneration policy and practices) and the personnel boundary that limits the disclosure to material risk-impacting staff categories. Accordingly, a small CRR firm that is in scope must ensure its remuneration disclosures are directed to those staff categories and cover the required policy-and-practices information.

question: If a firm is calculating the fundamental spread using the approach referenced in the matching adjustment rules, must it keep that fundamental spread out of the matching adjustment when it reflects risks the firm keeps?
gold_answer: Yes. The PRA Rulebook description explains that Chapter 4 of the Matching Adjustment Part restates the relevant IRPR provisions and includes a clear prohibition: the matching adjustment must not include the fundamental spread where that spread reflects risks retained by the firm [#SRC:9242ee9283fd69c0]. The matching adjustment requirement itself repeats the same prohibition and makes explicit that the excluded fundamental spread is the one calculated under the referenced calculation approach, while still being the spread that reflects risks retained by the firm [#TGT:9bbf6a9cc239d53c]. Taken together, this means the firm cannot treat the fundamental spread as an input to, or component of, the matching adjustment in those circumstances. The fact that the fundamental spread is calculated under the referenced approach does not create an exception; it identifies which fundamental spread is being referred to. So, if the spread reflects risks the firm retains, it must be excluded from the matching adjustment.

question: What does the PRA’s overall check of whether the home state supervisor is equivalent apply to, and what parts of the PRA’s work are outside that scope because they relate to advice to HM Treasury?
gold_answer: The PRA’s overall check of whether the home state supervisor is sufficiently equivalent applies to the PRA’s own purposes of authorisation and supervision, and it is based on the outcomes achieved [#TGT:b4c97c646d738581]. In carrying out that assessment, the PRA looks at whether the home state supervisor’s regime is consistent with the UK regulatory framework in delivering appropriate outcomes that meet the PRA’s objectives, and it assesses the relevant factors in their totality [#SRC:8e5451c44f63e11a]. As part of the PRA’s process, it places considerable weight on the extent and quality of co-operation with the home state supervisor, and it also takes into account the supervision of individual firms (including branches) and their consolidated group, as well as the nature and scale of a firm’s activities in the UK [#SRC:8e5451c44f63e11a]. Outside that scope, the PRA may separately provide advice to HM Treasury, where HM Treasury may make determinations of equivalence for other purposes; that advisory activity is distinct from the PRA’s equivalence assessment for PRA authorisation and supervision [#TGT:b4c97c646d738581].

question: When making an application for an insurance business transfer scheme, what must the firm(s) do to (i) send notice to the required recipients unless the court directs otherwise, and (ii) ensure that the scheme report, the notice, and an accompanying statement are available to anyone who requests them, including via an appropriate internet method?
gold_answer: The firm(s) must ensure that notice of the application is sent, unless the court directs otherwise, to all policyholders of the parties and to reinsurers (or a person acting on its behalf) whose contracts of reinsurance are proposed to be transferred as part of the insurance business transfer scheme [#TGT:c99af11004d99259]. In parallel, the Business Transfers Regulations require the scheme report, the notice, and the statement to be made available to anyone requesting them, and the internet may be used to provide access where it is suitable for the person making the request [#SRC:763120bb6b209201]. The statement included with the notice would normally set out the terms of the scheme and contain a summary of the scheme report, drafted so recipients can understand in broad terms how the scheme is likely to affect them; it should be clear and concise, with sufficient detail, and should not be lengthy or hard to understand [#SRC:763120bb6b209201]. The notice and related communications should also explain how and when affected parties can make representations for the court to consider [#TGT:c99af11004d99259].

question: A notice says you may refer the matter to the Tribunal and explains how to do it. What does “Tribunal” mean here, and what happens if the Tribunal has been replaced by another body?
gold_answer: If a notice tells you that you have a right to have the matter referred and it also explains the procedure for making that referral, you need to understand what “Tribunal” means in that context. The definition makes clear that “Tribunal” is the Upper Tribunal (Tax and Chancery Chamber). It also includes any successor body, meaning that if the Upper Tribunal (Tax and Chancery Chamber) is replaced or its role is taken over by another body, the term “Tribunal” covers that replacement. Putting the two together, the notice’s statement about your right to refer and the steps it gives for doing so should be treated as pointing you to the Upper Tribunal (Tax and Chancery Chamber) as the place to send the reference, unless there is a successor body, in which case the reference should go to that successor instead. This links the notice’s procedural guidance to the correct forum identified by the definition. [#SRC:a967680a6134e470] [#TGT:f7f54d793dfe546b]

question: When a firm uses internal credit assessments for Matching Adjustment purposes, what must it do to validate its internal credit assessment methodology and criteria (including identification and allowance for all sources of credit risk), and how must it demonstrate that the resulting internal credit assessment outcomes are comparable to CRA issue ratings in terms of plausibility, consistency, and absence of bias?
gold_answer: A firm must operate an internal credit assessment process that is subject to appropriate validation, and that validation must cover the firm’s internal credit assessment methodology and criteria, including how the firm has identified and allowed for all sources of credit risk on either a qualitative or quantitative basis [#SRC:4f0228446ac0d767]. In addition, the firm’s validation work must ensure that the internal credit assessment outcomes meet the relevant points referenced in the source passage, so that the outputs are not only produced but also checked against the required standards [#SRC:4f0228446ac0d767]. Alongside this, the firm must demonstrate that its internal credit assessments are of a comparable standard to a credit rating by ensuring outcomes lie within the plausible range of issue ratings that could have resulted from a CRA, and by meeting requirements for broad consistency and no bias within that plausible range when comparing internal outcomes to CRA issue ratings at both asset-type and portfolio levels [#TGT:5fd5739308652721]. Using sample assets assessed by a CRA can further support demonstrating broad consistency, but the firm should not rely solely or mechanistically on credit ratings when assessing creditworthiness [#TGT:5fd5739308652721].

question: When a new DGS member is required to calculate its class A tariff base, what calculation approach must it follow, including when a projected valuation of the relevant business is used and how any stated exceptions affect that approach?
gold_answer: A new DGS member has a mandatory obligation to calculate its class A tariff base, and it must do so by applying the calculation method set out for that purpose [#SRC:f441f3fa763671cd]. The applicable procedure for that calculation is that, unless an exception applies, A’s class A tariff base is calculated (where the calculation is necessary) using a projected valuation of the business to which the tariff relates [#TGT:7eeca38c43f8e855]. In practice, this means the new DGS member should treat the projected valuation method as the default basis for the class A tariff base whenever the tariff base needs to be determined, and it should only depart from that default if the specified carve-out (“unless otherwise provided”) applies. Accordingly, the compliance step is twofold: first, confirm that the tariff base calculation is required in the circumstances (“where necessary”); and second, apply the projected valuation of the relevant business as the calculation input unless the referenced exception displaces that method. This aligns the member’s obligation to calculate with the prescribed procedural basis for how the calculation is performed.

question: If a new DGS member has to work out its class A tariff base, how should it do the calculation, and when does it use a projected valuation of the business instead of something else?
gold_answer: A new DGS member is required to calculate its class A tariff base, so it must take an active step to determine that figure rather than leaving it unspecified [#SRC:f441f3fa763671cd]. The way the calculation is to be done is set by the procedural rule that, as the default position, A’s class A tariff base is calculated—when the calculation is needed—using a projected valuation of the business to which the tariff relates [#TGT:7eeca38c43f8e855]. So, the member should start by checking whether the tariff base needs to be calculated in the particular situation (“where necessary”). If it does, the member should then base the tariff base on a projected valuation of the relevant business. The only time the member should not follow that projected-valuation approach is when the stated exception applies (“unless otherwise provided”), in which case the member would follow whatever alternative is provided for that exception. This ties the member’s obligation to calculate the tariff base to the specific method used to compute it.

question: After a liability is first recorded, must a firm (and an insurance or reinsurance undertaking) avoid changing the valuation just because its own credit standing changes?
gold_answer: Yes. The TARGET sets a two-step requirement for a firm: it must value financial liabilities (as referred to in UK-adopted international accounting standards) in the required way when the liability is first recognised, and then it must not make any later adjustment that takes account of a change in the firm’s own credit standing after that initial recognition [#TGT:f26605efb3832de6]. The SOURCE expresses the same type of restriction for a different actor and in a “subsequently” context: it states that there shall be no valuation adjustment to take account of the change in own credit standing of the insurance or reinsurance undertaking [#SRC:d6c3553c96db7f71]. Taken together, the practical rule is consistent across both texts: once the liability valuation is established at the relevant recognition point, later movements in the entity’s own credit standing are not a permitted reason to adjust the valuation. The main difference is only who is being addressed (a firm versus an insurance or reinsurance undertaking) and the explicit linkage in the TARGET to initial recognition and subsequent adjustments.

question: When a firm maintains the required up-to-date record of the statement of responsibilities for each key function holder, what signatures must be obtained on that record and on any updated version, and who must provide them?
gold_answer: A firm must maintain an up-to-date record of the statement of responsibilities for each key function holder, meaning the firm is responsible for ensuring the record remains current for every key function holder [#TGT:1d05aec0b357c9ba]. In addition to keeping that record current, the firm must ensure that the record and each updated version is signed by two parties: (1) the relevant key function holder, and (2) an appropriate representative of the firm [#SRC:8e03ecfaf3ea1715]. Practically, this means that whenever the firm creates the record for a key function holder or updates it to reflect changes, the firm must obtain fresh signatures from both the key function holder and an appropriate representative of the firm on the updated version, not only on the initial record. The obligation therefore combines ongoing maintenance (keeping the record up to date for each key function holder) with a formal sign-off requirement that applies to the record itself and every subsequent updated version, ensuring both the individual and the firm acknowledge the current statement of responsibilities [#TGT:1d05aec0b357c9ba] [#SRC:8e03ecfaf3ea1715].

question: If a firm updates the statement of responsibilities record for a key function holder to keep it current, what must the firm do to ensure the updated record is properly executed, and which persons must sign?
gold_answer: The firm’s obligation has two linked components: it must keep an up-to-date record of the statement of responsibilities of each key function holder, and it must ensure that the record is properly signed when created and whenever it is updated [#TGT:1d05aec0b357c9ba]. Specifically, the record and each updated version must be signed by the key function holder and an appropriate representative of the firm [#SRC:8e03ecfaf3ea1715]. Accordingly, when the firm updates the record to keep it current, it is not sufficient merely to revise the content; the firm must also obtain signatures on the updated version from both required signatories. This ensures that the key function holder confirms the updated statement of responsibilities and that an appropriate representative of the firm also attests to the updated record. The requirement applies to each updated version, so the firm should treat every update as requiring renewed execution by the key function holder and the firm’s appropriate representative, aligning the ongoing “up-to-date” maintenance duty with a continuing sign-off control [#TGT:1d05aec0b357c9ba] [#SRC:8e03ecfaf3ea1715].

question: A firm must keep the statement of responsibilities record for each key function holder up to date. When the firm creates or updates that record, who must sign it?
gold_answer: The firm must keep an up-to-date record of the statement of responsibilities of each key function holder, so the firm needs to maintain a current record for every key function holder [#TGT:1d05aec0b357c9ba]. Alongside that ongoing maintenance duty, the record must be formally signed: the record itself and each updated version must be signed by the key function holder and an appropriate representative of the firm [#SRC:8e03ecfaf3ea1715]. This means that whenever the firm first prepares the record, it must obtain both signatures, and whenever the firm updates the record to keep it current, it must again ensure the updated version is signed by both the key function holder and an appropriate representative of the firm. The combined effect is that the firm is responsible not only for keeping the content current for each key function holder, but also for ensuring that every version that is current has the required sign-off from the individual key function holder and the firm’s representative [#TGT:1d05aec0b357c9ba] [#SRC:8e03ecfaf3ea1715].

question: When implementing an adjustment to the deposit protection limit, must a firm treat that implementation as a material change in its systems and therefore notify the PRA and FSCS within three months, or is it excluded from the material-change trigger?
gold_answer: A firm’s notification duty is triggered only where there is a “material change in the firm’s systems” made to comply with the relevant deposit protection requirements, in which case the firm must notify both the PRA and FSCS within three months of the change [#TGT:933dedc51e46fe4b]. However, the PRA’s stated position is that the implementation of an adjustment to the deposit protection limit is not a material change for the purposes of the referenced depositor protection provisions [#SRC:6d78c60f7fc6d076]. Read together, this means that, where the only change is implementing an adjustment to the deposit protection limit, the firm should not treat that implementation itself as meeting the “material change” threshold that would otherwise require notification to the PRA and FSCS within three months [#SRC:6d78c60f7fc6d076] [#TGT:933dedc51e46fe4b]. Conversely, if the firm makes additional systems changes beyond implementing the limit adjustment, the firm must assess whether those changes are material; if they are, the notification obligation and three-month timeframe apply [#TGT:933dedc51e46fe4b].

question: If the PRA asks a firm to run a test based on EVT in stress, what does the firm have to do to make it part of its regular internal model validation cycle, including showing the PRA the capital requirements are appropriate and checking how sensitive results are to key assumptions?
gold_answer: The firm should build the EVT-in-stress test into its regular internal model validation cycle as one of the tools it uses to validate the model on an ongoing basis, because the PRA says it will ask firms to apply a test based on EVT in stress when assessing internal model applications and continued compliance, to help assure that the amount of MA in stress is not overstated [#SRC:197d09dc7abf48b4]. To fit the required validation cycle, the firm should connect the test to routine monitoring of internal model performance, periodic review of whether the model specification remains appropriate, and testing of results against experience, so the EVT-in-stress output is evaluated alongside other evidence about model performance [#TGT:5b30ae70a80bf3bb]. The firm must also ensure the test is supported by an effective statistical validation process that enables it to demonstrate to the PRA that the resulting capital requirements are appropriate, using the EVT-in-stress results as part of that demonstration [#TGT:5b30ae70a80bf3bb]. In addition, the firm should use the EVT-in-stress work to inform required stability and sensitivity testing to changes in key underlying assumptions, and ensure the data used for the test is accurate, complete, and appropriate [#TGT:5b30ae70a80bf3bb].

question: When competent authorities request information on hedging sets by risk category, how must institutions present the requested counts and risk-driver identifiers in a way that is consistent with the obligation to map derivative transactions with more than one material risk driver across risk categories, including the rule for mapping only once when all material risk drivers fall within the same risk category?
gold_answer: Institutions must be able to provide competent authorities, upon request, a risk-category breakdown of the hedging sets they have established, including (i) the number of hedging sets per risk category, (ii) the relevant risk-driver identifier for each hedging set (either the primary/most material risk driver in that risk category, or the pair of risk drivers, as applicable), and (iii) the number of transactions in each hedging set [#SRC:83d0ae2a5dfdf3ce]. To ensure that this information is coherent with the mapping obligation for derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver, institutions must reflect that such transactions are mapped to more than one risk category where their material risk drivers span different risk categories, using the most material risk driver within each relevant risk category as the basis for mapping [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad]. Conversely, where all material risk drivers of a transaction fall within the same risk category, institutions should map that transaction only once to that risk category, based on the most material of those risk drivers, so that the transaction counts reported per hedging set and risk category are not duplicated inappropriately [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] while still meeting the requested hedging-set reporting granularity [#SRC:83d0ae2a5dfdf3ce].

question: If competent authorities ask for details on hedging sets, what exactly must institutions make available, and how should that information reflect the requirement to map a derivative transaction to multiple risk categories when it has material risk drivers in different categories?
gold_answer: When competent authorities request it, institutions must make available a structured summary of hedging sets by risk category: the number of hedging sets for each risk category, the identifying risk driver information for each hedging set (the primary or most material risk driver in that risk category, or the pair of risk drivers, as relevant), and the number of transactions in each hedging set [#SRC:83d0ae2a5dfdf3ce]. That reporting must align with how institutions are required to map derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver. Specifically, if a transaction’s material risk drivers fall into different risk categories, the transaction must be mapped once to each such risk category, using the most material risk driver within each risk category as the basis for that mapping [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad]. If all material risk drivers are within the same risk category, the transaction is mapped only once to that category, based on the most material risk driver, which helps ensure the transaction counts institutions provide per hedging set and risk category are consistent and not overstated [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] while still meeting the requested disclosure items [#SRC:83d0ae2a5dfdf3ce].

question: What does a firm have to produce to show it is prepared for an orderly solvent exit in BAU, even if solvent exit seems very unlikely, and what extra plan is required if execution later becomes a reasonable prospect?
gold_answer: A firm should build preparation for an orderly solvent exit into its BAU activities and produce a solvent exit analysis to meet the PRA’s expectations for that preparation stage [#SRC:005f99bdd705abe3]. The preparation expectation is intended to apply broadly and is not limited to firms that think a solvent exit is imminent; it applies even where the prospect of solvent exit seems unlikely or distant to the firm, so the firm should still complete the analysis as part of its BAU preparation [#TGT:ce7365f82f898e3e]. Separately, the materials distinguish preparation from execution: if and when execution of a solvent exit becomes a reasonable prospect, the firm should produce a solvent exit execution plan, aligning with the PRA’s expectations for execution planning and for how the firm manages and monitors the execution of a solvent exit [#SRC:005f99bdd705abe3]. In practice, this means the firm maintains an up-to-date preparation analysis in BAU, and then adds the execution plan when the execution condition is met.

question: How must a managing agent structure its management of syndicates to ensure general insurance business and long-term insurance business are kept separately managed, given the prohibition on allowing both classes to be carried on together through any syndicate it manages (subject to limited exceptions)?
gold_answer: Composites 2.2 requires composite firms to maintain separate management of general insurance business and long-term insurance business, and explains that, in practice, this means managing agents must separately manage syndicates that carry on general insurance business from syndicates that carry on long-term insurance business [#SRC:112b43b1150a4cf8]. This obligation aligns with the prohibition that a managing agent must not permit both general insurance business and long-term insurance business to be carried on together through any syndicate managed by it, except where an exception applies [#TGT:022fa162b8d30cb6]. Accordingly, the default compliance approach is to avoid any single syndicate carrying on both classes and instead allocate each class to different syndicates under separate management arrangements. Where a single syndicate does carry on both general insurance business and long-term insurance business pursuant to the exceptions referenced in the Composites material, the source notes that paragraphs 3.1–3.3 of SS8/15 on Composites are intended to assist in determining how the requirements of the Composites Part apply to managing agents in that scenario [#SRC:112b43b1150a4cf8], consistent with the target’s “except where” carve-out [#TGT:022fa162b8d30cb6].

question: If a managing agent manages syndicates, what must it do to keep general insurance business and long-term insurance business separate, and what is it prohibited from allowing within a single syndicate unless an exception applies?
gold_answer: The source states that Composites 2.2 requires composite firms to maintain separate management of general insurance business and long-term insurance business, and clarifies that, in practical terms, managing agents should separately manage syndicates that carry on general insurance business from syndicates that carry on long-term insurance business [#SRC:112b43b1150a4cf8]. The target reinforces the separation outcome by prohibiting a managing agent from permitting both general insurance business and long-term insurance business to be carried on together through any syndicate managed by it, unless an exception applies [#TGT:022fa162b8d30cb6]. Put together, the normal expectation is that the managing agent structures its syndicate portfolio so each syndicate is dedicated to one class of business and is managed accordingly, rather than combining both classes in one syndicate. The source also anticipates that there may be limited cases where a single syndicate carries on both classes under referenced exceptions, and notes that paragraphs 3.1–3.3 of SS8/15 on Composites are intended to help determine how the Composites Part requirements apply to managing agents in those circumstances [#SRC:112b43b1150a4cf8], which corresponds to the target’s “except where” qualification [#TGT:022fa162b8d30cb6].

question: When applying the expectation to treat an outsourcing or third party arrangement as material where a defect or failure could materially impair the firm, how must a firm interpret the scope of “material outsourcing” given the PRA’s clarification that it is used for clarity and is intended to cover arrangements that would otherwise be treated as “critical or important outsourcing” under relevant retained EU legislation or PRA rules?
gold_answer: A firm should apply the materiality expectation to outsourcing and third party arrangements by using the PRA’s clarified meaning of “material outsourcing” as the operative scope for assessment. The PRA explains that it uses “material outsourcing” for clarity and to avoid confusion with other overlapping regulatory terms, and that, for all intents and purposes, a “material outsourcing” arrangement encompasses a “critical or important outsourcing” arrangement in relevant retained EU legislation or PRA rules [#SRC:c6da983dfd07933b]. Therefore, when the firm follows the expectation to generally consider an arrangement as material where a defect or failure in performance could materially impair the firm, it should not treat “material” as a narrower category than “critical or important”; rather, it should treat the categories as effectively covered within the PRA’s “material outsourcing” framing [#TGT:52624254f79512d2]. In doing so, the firm should also align its identification approach to the criteria that are substantively aligned to the EBA Outsourcing GL criteria (where applicable), recognising that the PRA notes there are a few justified exceptions, including references to the PRA’s operational resilience requirements [#SRC:c6da983dfd07933b].

question: When applying the rule that sets the boundary for whether a deposit qualifies as an eligible deposit, what reasonable steps must a firm take to establish a local authority’s annual budget, and how must the firm treat the local authority if it cannot determine eligibility after taking those steps?
