gold_answer: A firm that has not completed a full financial year by the start of the fee year should use projected valuations in the specified second-fee-year scenario, and this aligns conceptually with the first-fee-year approach of paying periodic fees using a projected valuation for the first twelve months of new business. [#SRC:d75ff793a1100dc6] [#TGT:bc923fb7c74a4666] Specifically, if the firm is in its second fee year and it received its new or extended permission relevant to the activity during the window from 1 January in its first fee year to 1 April in its second fee year, it should apply projected valuations in the manner referenced (as set out in 3.7). [#SRC:d75ff793a1100dc6] This second-fee-year instruction is particularly relevant because the firm has not yet completed a full financial year by the start of the fee year, so a projected valuation is used rather than a completed-year measure. [#SRC:d75ff793a1100dc6] In parallel, the first-fee-year rule states that a firm in its first fee year pays periodic fees based on its projected valuation for the first twelve months of its new business. [#TGT:bc923fb7c74a4666] Taken together, the passages indicate that projected valuation is the valuation basis both for first-fee-year periodic fees (covering the first twelve months of new business) and, for firms meeting the stated timing and permission conditions, for periodic fees in the second fee year as well. [#SRC:d75ff793a1100dc6] [#TGT:bc923fb7c74a4666]

question: If a firm is new and hasn’t finished a full financial year yet, what valuation should it use to pay periodic fees in its first fee year, and what should it use in its second fee year if it got its new or extended permission between 1 January (in its first fee year) and 1 April (in its second fee year)?
gold_answer: The firm should use projected valuation in both situations described, but the trigger conditions differ between the first and second fee years. [#TGT:bc923fb7c74a4666] [#SRC:d75ff793a1100dc6] In the first fee year, the periodic fees are paid based on the firm’s projected valuation for the first twelve months of its new business. [#TGT:bc923fb7c74a4666] For the second fee year, the projected-valuation approach applies only where the firm has not completed a full financial year by the start of the fee year and it is in its second fee year, and it received its new or extended permission relevant to the activity during the period from 1 January in its first fee year to 1 April in its second fee year. [#SRC:d75ff793a1100dc6] When those second-fee-year conditions are met, the firm should apply projected valuations in the way referenced (as set out in 3.7). [#SRC:d75ff793a1100dc6] Linking the two passages, the first-fee-year rule establishes projected valuation as the basis for periodic fees for the first twelve months of new business, and the second-fee-year rule extends the use of projected valuations into the second fee year for firms that are still without a completed full financial year and that obtained the relevant permission within the stated date window. [#TGT:bc923fb7c74a4666] [#SRC:d75ff793a1100dc6]

question: If the C17.01/C17.02 reporting instructions tell you to use supervisory disclosures from the EBA website, what UK document should you use instead, and where do you find it online?
gold_answer: You should treat the instruction to use supervisory disclosures from the EBA website as meaning you must use the corresponding disclosure produced by the PRA for those COREP templates. [#SRC:40ad42a86de28e1d] The online location for that PRA disclosure is the “Regulatory reporting – banking sector” page in the prudential regulation section of the Bank of England website, using the specific web address provided. [#TGT:91473ca52a070954] This linkage matters because the COREP instructions for C17.01 and C17.02 explicitly redirect certain non-UK references (including the EBA supervisory disclosure reference) to UK equivalents, so your reporting should be based on the PRA-produced disclosure rather than the EBA publication. [#SRC:40ad42a86de28e1d] In other words, when you see the EBA supervisory disclosure reference in those instructions, you should navigate to the Bank of England prudential regulation area and retrieve the PRA disclosure from the Regulatory reporting – banking sector page, ensuring your template completion uses the UK-referenced source. [#TGT:91473ca52a070954]

question: When setting the absolute minimum level of financial resources for a solvent exit, how should a firm treat the possibility of using the Bank of England’s lending facilities (eg the Discount Window Facility), and what cost categories must be considered alongside any asset-sale losses below book value?
gold_answer: In setting its absolute minimum level of financial resources for a solvent exit, the firm should treat the anticipated use of the Bank of England’s lending facilities (for example, the Discount Window Facility) as a relevant planning assumption that triggers consultation of the Bank of England Market Operations Guide for further detail on those facilities. [#TGT:0bca7830398dd073] At the same time, the firm must still identify a minimum financial-resources level below which there is no reasonable prospect of successfully executing the solvent exit, and it should do so by recognising that the solvent exit itself is likely to generate additional costs beyond any funding considerations. [#SRC:34d82b030223f2b2] In particular, the firm should account for potential losses (or “haircuts”) arising from selling assets or portfolios below book value, and it should also include other exit-related cost categories such as fees for specialist services, redundancy and retention payments, contract termination penalties, and pension fund deficits. [#SRC:34d82b030223f2b2] The practical implication is that even if the firm expects to access a Bank of England facility, the minimum resources threshold should be calibrated to cover these identified exit costs and not be set so low that a solvent exit would no longer be reasonably achievable. [#SRC:34d82b030223f2b2] [#TGT:0bca7830398dd073]

question: If a firm thinks it might use the Bank of England’s lending facilities (like the Discount Window Facility) during a solvent exit, what document should it look at, and what kinds of extra costs should it build into its minimum financial resources level (including any losses from selling below book value)?
gold_answer: If the firm anticipates using the Bank of England’s lending facilities (for example, the Discount Window Facility), it should look to the Bank of England Market Operations Guide for more detail on those facilities. [#TGT:0bca7830398dd073] Separately, when planning a solvent exit, the firm should assume the exit itself is likely to create additional costs and should reflect those costs when identifying the absolute minimum level of financial resources needed to have a reasonable prospect of completing the solvent exit. [#SRC:34d82b030223f2b2] That minimum should take into account potential losses (or “haircuts”) from selling assets or portfolios for less than their book value. [#SRC:34d82b030223f2b2] It should also include other cost types that may arise in a solvent exit, including fees for specialist services, redundancy and retention payments, contract termination penalties, and pension fund deficits. [#SRC:34d82b030223f2b2] Bringing these together, the firm’s planning should not treat anticipated Bank of England facility use as a substitute for recognising and sizing these exit costs; instead, it should use the Guide for facility details while still setting a minimum resources level that covers the identified cost drivers. [#TGT:0bca7830398dd073] [#SRC:34d82b030223f2b2]

question: When a firm has received a Part 4A permission to accept deposits and must provide the FSCS with single customer views and exclusions views, what is the FSCS required to do after it receives the information required by 12.2 or 12.5, and what are the relevant timeframes for both the firm’s submission and the FSCS’s response (including the purpose tied to compensation time limits in 9.2)?
gold_answer: A firm that has received a Part 4A permission to accept deposits is required to deliver single customer views and exclusions views to the FSCS within three months of receiving that permission. [#TGT:01013ac4ba4ac357] Once the FSCS has received the information required by 12.2 or 12.5 (which would include the information the firm provides from its SCV system), the FSCS must, within six months of receiving that required information, advise the PRA on two specific points: first, whether the information produced by the firm’s SCV system is capable of being submitted to the FSCS; and second, whether that information is compatible with the FSCS’s systems. [#SRC:615a56bb461bcd74] The FSCS’s assessment is explicitly linked to operational readiness to enable the FSCS to pay compensation within the time limits set out in 9.2, so the advice to the PRA must address capability and compatibility in that context. [#SRC:615a56bb461bcd74] In practical terms, the combined timing framework is that the firm’s three-month delivery obligation starts from receipt of the Part 4A permission, while the FSCS’s six-month period starts from its receipt of the information required by 12.2 or 12.5, and culminates in a formal communication to the PRA. [#TGT:01013ac4ba4ac357] [#SRC:615a56bb461bcd74]

question: If a firm gets a Part 4A permission to accept deposits, how quickly does it have to send the FSCS the single customer views and exclusions views, and after the FSCS receives the information required by 12.2 or 12.5 what must the FSCS tell the PRA and by when (including how this links to paying compensation within the 9.2 time limits)?
gold_answer: After a firm receives a Part 4A permission to accept deposits, it must provide the FSCS with single customer views and exclusions views within three months of receiving that permission. [#TGT:01013ac4ba4ac357] After the FSCS receives the information required by 12.2 or 12.5, the FSCS then has a separate deadline: it must, within six months of receiving that required information, advise the PRA about whether the information coming from the firm’s SCV system can be submitted to the FSCS and whether it will work with (i.e., be compatible with) the FSCS’s systems. [#SRC:615a56bb461bcd74] This FSCS advice is not just a general data-quality check; it is specifically framed around whether the FSCS’s systems can use the SCV information so that the FSCS can pay compensation within the time limits referred to in 9.2. [#SRC:615a56bb461bcd74] Put together, the firm’s obligation is a three-month delivery requirement triggered by the permission event, while the FSCS’s obligation is a six-month assessment-and-notification requirement triggered by receipt of the information required by 12.2 or 12.5 and directed to the PRA. [#TGT:01013ac4ba4ac357] [#SRC:615a56bb461bcd74]

question: When implementing Operational Continuity 3.1(2), how should a firm plan for continuity of critical services during restructuring related to recovery or resolution, and how may the firm use its implementation of the Bank of England Statement of Policy ‘Restructuring Planning’ in doing so?
gold_answer: A firm implementing Operational Continuity 3.1(2) should ensure it has the capability to maintain continuity of critical services through potential changes in service provision that arise from restructuring connected to recovery or resolution, and it may leverage its implementation of the Bank of England Statement of Policy ‘Restructuring Planning’ as a supporting resource for that work. [#SRC:59c21b8c65ce33a6] [#TGT:2adfa31e81fef236] The continuity capability is expected to be robust across whatever restructuring scenarios the firm might face, meaning the firm should not plan for only a single outcome but should consider multiple scenarios when designing its continuity approach. [#SRC:59c21b8c65ce33a6] In practical terms, the firm can treat its existing work under the ‘Restructuring Planning’ Statement of Policy as an input to its Operational Continuity 3.1(2) implementation, using that implementation to inform how it anticipates and manages changes to service provision during restructuring. [#TGT:2adfa31e81fef236] [#SRC:59c21b8c65ce33a6] The key compliance outcome is that, regardless of which restructuring scenario materialises, the firm remains capable of keeping critical services running while service provision changes are occurring. [#SRC:59c21b8c65ce33a6]

question: If a firm is planning for continuity under Operational Continuity 3.1(2), what does it need to be able to do during restructuring for recovery or resolution, and what Bank of England document can it draw on to help with that planning?
gold_answer: For Operational Continuity 3.1(2), the firm needs to be able to keep critical services running even if restructuring for recovery or resolution causes changes in how services are provided, and it can draw on its implementation of the Bank of England Statement of Policy ‘Restructuring Planning’ to support that planning. [#SRC:59c21b8c65ce33a6] [#TGT:2adfa31e81fef236] The capability expectation is not limited to one anticipated event: the firm should be able to ensure continuity regardless of the restructuring scenarios it may encounter, and it should factor different scenarios into its continuity planning. [#SRC:59c21b8c65ce33a6] Using the ‘Restructuring Planning’ Statement of Policy as an input can help the firm structure or inform its approach to preparing for those restructuring-driven changes to service provision while still meeting the continuity objective for critical services. [#TGT:2adfa31e81fef236] [#SRC:59c21b8c65ce33a6] The overall result should be a continuity plan and capability that remains effective across multiple possible restructuring situations, rather than being tailored to a single assumed path. [#SRC:59c21b8c65ce33a6]

question: When a firm lacks the capability within the firm or the firm’s group to comply with Conditions Governing Business 6 and therefore must appoint an external actuary, what due diligence must the firm perform before making that appointment, and how must that assessment be calibrated to the firm’s business and applicable regulatory standards?
gold_answer: Where a firm does not have the capability within the firm or the firm’s group to comply with Conditions Governing Business 6, it is required to appoint an external actuary. [#TGT:bb5e586ce2dcc1ab] Before making that appointment, the firm must carry out reasonable due diligence to satisfy itself that the actuary it selects has the skill and experience needed to perform the actuary’s functions under the regulatory system. [#SRC:dcc349f7a298ef71] That pre-appointment assessment is not generic: the firm must calibrate its evaluation of the actuary’s competence to (i) the nature, scale, and complexity of the firm’s business and (ii) the specific requirements and standards under the regulatory system that apply to the firm. [#SRC:dcc349f7a298ef71] In practice, this means the firm should treat the external appointment triggered by the Conditions Governing Business 6 capability gap as the point at which it must verify the actuary’s suitability, rather than assuming that “external” status alone is sufficient. [#TGT:bb5e586ce2dcc1ab] The firm’s obligation is therefore twofold: ensure an external actuary is appointed when internal/group capability is lacking, and ensure—before appointment—that the chosen actuary’s qualifications match the firm’s regulatory functions and business profile. [#SRC:dcc349f7a298ef71]

question: If a firm can’t meet Conditions Governing Business 6 using people in the firm or the firm’s group and has to hire an external actuary, what checks does it need to do before hiring, and what should those checks take into account?
gold_answer: If a firm does not have the capability within the firm or the firm’s group to comply with Conditions Governing Business 6, it must appoint an external actuary. [#TGT:bb5e586ce2dcc1ab] Before it makes that appointment, the firm must take reasonable steps to make sure the actuary has the skill and experience required to carry out the actuary’s functions under the regulatory system. [#SRC:dcc349f7a298ef71] The firm’s checks must be tailored: it needs to judge the actuary’s skill and experience in a way that matches the nature, scale, and complexity of the firm’s business. [#SRC:dcc349f7a298ef71] The firm must also align its assessment with the requirements and standards under the regulatory system that apply to the firm, so the actuary’s capabilities fit what the firm is actually subject to. [#SRC:dcc349f7a298ef71] Put together, the rule is that the capability gap under Conditions Governing Business 6 drives the need for an external actuary, and the firm must then verify—before hiring—that the chosen actuary is suitably qualified for the firm’s regulatory functions and context. [#TGT:bb5e586ce2dcc1ab]

question: For a firm that is a member of a group covered by 2.1(3), how should the firm determine whether it must ensure group-level strategies, processes and systems support assessing impact tolerance for important group business services during a severe but plausible disruption, given the condition under which 22.2, 22.3 and 22.4 do not apply?
gold_answer: A firm that is a member of a group covered by 2.1(3) must ensure that group-level strategies, processes and systems allow the firm to assess whether important group business services could stay within the impact tolerance during a severe but plausible disruption to the firm’s operations. [#SRC:43a647fe4cce5cd9] However, when determining the overall rule set that applies to that same 2.1(3) group context, the firm must also check whether the group’s parent undertaking has its head office in a third country that is an overseas jurisdiction designated under regulation 11 in relation to regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations for insurance group supervision, and whether paragraph (3) of regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations applies. [#TGT:b6b6500b2b9939c8] If those conditions are met, then 22.2, 22.3 and 22.4 do not apply to the firm in that scenario, even though the firm remains within the population described as a member of a group covered by 2.1(3). [#TGT:b6b6500b2b9939c8] Practically, the firm should (i) confirm it is in scope as a member of a group covered by 2.1(3), and (ii) separately evaluate the third-country/overseas-jurisdiction designation and regulation 14(3) condition to determine whether the 22.2–22.4 provisions are disapplied while still maintaining the group-level capability to assess impact tolerance for important group business services. [#SRC:43a647fe4cce5cd9] [#TGT:b6b6500b2b9939c8]

question: If a firm is in a group covered by 2.1(3), what does it need to have in place at group level to check whether important group business services can stay within impact tolerance during a severe but plausible disruption, and when would 22.2, 22.3 and 22.4 not apply because of where the parent undertaking’s head office is?
gold_answer: For a firm in a group covered by 2.1(3), the firm must make sure the group’s strategies, processes and systems let the firm assess whether important group business services could remain within the impact tolerance if there is a severe but plausible disruption to the firm’s operations. [#SRC:43a647fe4cce5cd9] In the same 2.1(3) setting, the firm also needs to identify whether a specific disapplication condition is met: 22.2, 22.3 and 22.4 do not apply if the group’s parent undertaking has its head office in a third country that is an overseas jurisdiction designated under regulation 11 in relation to regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations for insurance group supervision, and paragraph (3) of regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations applies. [#TGT:b6b6500b2b9939c8] This means the firm’s operational resilience assessment capability at group level (focused on impact tolerance for important group business services under severe but plausible disruption) is a required capability for the firm as a group member, while the applicability of 22.2–22.4 depends on the parent undertaking’s head-office jurisdiction and the stated IRPR regulation conditions. [#SRC:43a647fe4cce5cd9] [#TGT:b6b6500b2b9939c8]

question: If a firm has big exposures to companies in its own group, what is the normal rule for how those exposures are treated, and what does the firm need to apply for if it wants a higher limit—plus which named document (with month and year) is pointed to for “Large Exposures”?
gold_answer: Normally, a firm’s exposures to entities in its own group are not treated as a special category; they are generally treated like exposures to a third party and therefore are subject to the large exposure limits. [#SRC:27a742d1f4627dc1] If the firm wants to use a higher large exposure limit for certain entities within its group, it can do so only by applying to the PRA for a non-core large exposures group permission, and the higher limit is available only where those group entities meet the relevant conditions tied to that permission. [#SRC:27a742d1f4627dc1] The text also points to a specific supervisory statement for the large exposures topic: SS16/13, called ‘Large Exposures’, dated June 2018. [#TGT:998aae35b45397cf] Putting these points together, the compliance approach is to treat intra-group exposures as if they were to an outside counterparty unless the PRA grants the non-core large exposures group permission, and to use the referenced SS16/13 ‘Large Exposures’ (June 2018) as the named supervisory statement associated with this large exposures framework. [#SRC:27a742d1f4627dc1] [#TGT:998aae35b45397cf]

question: For a firm that is subject to the PRA’s recovery planning rules and is considering the TWD option as part of its recovery plan, what expectations apply to that option and where is the interaction between those expectations, other relevant PRA policies, and this SS described?
gold_answer: A firm subject to the PRA’s recovery planning rules must maintain a recovery plan that includes a range of executable recovery options, and the TWD option is treated as one of those recovery options. [#SRC:79cc8d3f5662f4d8] Because the TWD option is a recovery option, the expectations in SS9/17 apply to it. [#TGT:cdec50384b35267e] In practical terms, this means the firm should align the TWD option within its recovery plan to the SS9/17 expectations that cover areas such as governance, information and reporting requirements, and the use of fire drills and playbooks, as part of the overall recovery planning framework. [#SRC:79cc8d3f5662f4d8] To ensure the TWD option is implemented consistently with the broader policy framework, the firm should also use the document that explains how SS9/17 expectations interact with other relevant PRA policies and with this SS. [#TGT:cdec50384b35267e] That interaction is described in the PRA’s Trading activity wind-down Statement of Policy (SoP), which sets out how the SS9/17 expectations, other relevant PRA policies, and this SS fit together for the TWD option. [#TGT:cdec50384b35267e]

question: If a firm has to follow the PRA’s recovery planning rules and wants to use the TWD option, what does it need to include in its recovery plan and which document explains how SS9/17 links with other PRA policies and this SS for that option?
gold_answer: The firm needs a recovery plan that contains a range of executable options, and the TWD option can be one of those options because it is a recovery option. [#SRC:79cc8d3f5662f4d8] Since the TWD option is a recovery option, the expectations in SS9/17 apply to it. [#TGT:cdec50384b35267e] When building or updating the recovery plan, the firm should therefore ensure the TWD option is developed in a way that reflects SS9/17’s recovery planning expectations, including expectations covering governance, information and reporting requirements, and the use of fire drills and playbooks. [#SRC:79cc8d3f5662f4d8] To understand how those SS9/17 expectations should be read alongside other relevant PRA policies and alongside this SS specifically for the TWD option, the firm should look to the document that sets out that interaction. [#TGT:cdec50384b35267e] The interaction between SS9/17, other relevant PRA policies, and this SS is described in the PRA’s Trading activity wind-down Statement of Policy (SoP). [#TGT:cdec50384b35267e]

question: If the PRA or FSCS asks for the SCV and exclusions file, what does the bank have to do within 24 hours, and what kinds of deposits (not in the SCV) should be listed in the exclusions file?
gold_answer: If the PRA or FSCS requests it, the bank must provide its single customer view (SCV) and exclusions file within 24 hours, and it must maintain these files to support orderly resolution. [#SRC:85d027c5ae493740] To make that possible, the bank’s systems must automatically work out the amount of covered deposits payable to each depositor and must also identify any part of an eligible deposit that is above the specified coverage level. [#SRC:85d027c5ae493740] Alongside those automated identifications, the exclusions file should include data on deposits that are not in the SCV, so that the information provided is not limited only to what appears in the SCV. [#TGT:a5f45339915181b6] The text gives examples of deposits that are not in the SCV and therefore should appear in the exclusions file, including deposits held in client accounts and deposits held in deposit aggregators. [#TGT:a5f45339915181b6] In practice, when responding to the PRA or FSCS request within the 24-hour window, the bank should ensure both that its systems produce the depositor-level covered amounts and over-coverage indicators and that the exclusions file contains the specified non-SCV deposit categories. [#SRC:85d027c5ae493740] [#TGT:a5f45339915181b6]

question: For a firm using an internal model, what must be included in template AoC.01 and how must it be submitted to the PRA, taking into account both the PRA’s description of AoC.01 and the annual submission requirement and instructions referenced for internal models?
gold_answer: A firm using an internal model is required to provide the PRA with template AoC.01 on an annual basis, and that submission must follow the specific instructions identified for AoC.01. [#TGT:13a55e684b224a20] AoC.01 is the PRA’s analysis of change template that firms complete with key information about movements in the SCR, and it is to be submitted in line with the relevant provisions cited for submission in the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook. [#SRC:282806b2f50a9291] In terms of content, the annual AoC.01 submission must set out the analysis of change referenced in Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 13A and include both quantitative information and a supporting qualitative analysis. [#TGT:13a55e684b224a20] Operationally, the firm should (i) complete AoC.01 with the key information regarding movement in SCR, (ii) ensure the template includes the quantitative elements and the accompanying qualitative analysis required for internal model reporting, and (iii) submit it to the PRA annually using the instructions in section AoC.01 of Chapter 10. [#SRC:282806b2f50a9291] [#TGT:13a55e684b224a20] The submission should also be made in accordance with Articles 19 and 35 of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook, as referenced for AoC.01. [#SRC:282806b2f50a9291]

question: For a PRA-authorised bank or designated investment firm that is headquartered in the UK (or part of a UK-based group) and conducts investment banking or sales and trading activities in both the UK and overseas, how should it determine whether the PRA’s high-level expectations for managing booking arrangements for trading activity apply to it, and what is the stated purpose of those expectations?
gold_answer: A firm that is a PRA-authorised bank or designated investment firm should first assess whether it falls within the category described as ‘UK trading banks’, which covers firms headquartered in the UK or in a UK-based group that have investment banking or sales and trading activities in both the UK and overseas; for those firms, the sections in Chapter 4 on the PRA’s expectations of booking arrangements apply. [#SRC:a3ab5e4ef313b90a] Once within scope, the firm should treat the Chapter 4 expectations as the PRA’s high-level expectations for how booking arrangements for trading activity should be managed. [#TGT:99aa362d479338d6] The purpose of these high-level expectations is to ensure that the firm’s booking arrangements are transparent and well-controlled. [#TGT:99aa362d479338d6] In applying this, the firm should use the statement’s delineation of which Chapter 4 paragraphs and related materials comprise the relevant expectations for UK trading banks (including the specified paragraph ranges and the Annex on Context and definitions), and note that the statement indicates it will specify in the relevant sections when expectations apply only to international banks versus when they apply to both international banks and UK trading banks. [#SRC:a3ab5e4ef313b90a] For terminology describing the scope of application for the booking expectations, the firm is directed to the summary referenced in paragraph 4.24B. [#SRC:a3ab5e4ef313b90a]

question: If you work at a third-country branch undertaking in the UK, where do you look for (1) the PRA rules that apply to you and (2) the extra PRA expectations you’re expected to refer to, and how does this connect to the PRA’s focus on ‘supervisability’?
gold_answer: You should use two complementary sources: the PRA Rulebook for the applicable rules, and the Prudential and Resolution Policy Index for the additional rules and expectations the PRA expects third country branches to refer to, and you should organise your compliance work so it supports the PRA’s assessment of ‘supervisability’ and regulatory equivalence. [#SRC:b3cd6bbde42a8501] First, because third-country branch undertakings operating in the UK are subject to the PRA’s rules that are relevant to third-country branches and third-country branch undertakings, you should identify and track those requirements in the PRA Rulebook. [#SRC:b3cd6bbde42a8501] Second, for further details of PRA rules and expectations the PRA expects third country branches to refer to, you should consult the listed sections of the Prudential and Resolution Policy Index, specifically the pages covering third-country branches of international insurers, Cross-cutting policies, Run Off and Undertakings in Difficulty, and Policyholder Protection. [#TGT:3b54c4e703c83d05] Linking these sources matters because the PRA’s authorisation and supervision approach for third-country branches is anchored in its statutory objectives and is underpinned by the PRA’s assessment of regulatory equivalence and its ability to effectively supervise a branch insurer (its ‘supervisability’). [#SRC:b3cd6bbde42a8501]

question: When setting priorities for investment and designing recovery and response arrangements using impact tolerances, how should a firm align its regular testing in severe but plausible disruption scenarios so that the testing approach matches what impact tolerances are intended to measure (including what the testing should not concentrate on)?
gold_answer: A firm should treat impact tolerances as the board and senior management’s benchmark for prioritising investment and for shaping recovery and response arrangements, and then design its regular testing to demonstrate it can stay within those tolerances during severe but plausible disruption scenarios. [#SRC:51a4e8e33523d5d5] [#TGT:2ff0a61603b1ca55] Because impact tolerances are framed on the assumption that a disruption has already happened, the firm’s testing should be oriented to operating within the tolerance during an incident rather than being built around incident-prevention objectives. [#TGT:2ff0a61603b1ca55] In practice, this means the firm should use the same tolerance standard that guides investment prioritisation and recovery/response planning as the yardstick for scenario tests, so the tests evidence whether the planned recovery and response arrangements are sufficient to keep the firm within tolerance when disruption occurs. [#SRC:51a4e8e33523d5d5] [#TGT:2ff0a61603b1ca55] During real operational disruptions, impact tolerances can also inform decision-making alongside other incident-management information; the testing approach should therefore support that decision-use by focusing on recovery and response performance under disruption conditions. [#SRC:51a4e8e33523d5d5] The PRA’s expectation to focus on recovery and response arrangements reinforces this alignment between how tolerances are used for planning and what scenario testing is intended to validate. [#TGT:2ff0a61603b1ca55]

question: If a disruption has already happened, what should impact tolerances be used for by boards and senior management, and what should regular testing in severe but plausible scenarios focus on (and not focus on) to match that use?
gold_answer: Impact tolerances should be used as a standard for boards and senior management to help decide where to prioritise investment and how to set up recovery and response arrangements, and they can also help guide decisions during an operational disruption alongside other incident information. [#SRC:51a4e8e33523d5d5] Regular testing should then be designed to show the firm can remain within those impact tolerances in severe but plausible disruption scenarios, reflecting that the tolerance framework assumes a disruption has occurred. [#TGT:2ff0a61603b1ca55] As a result, the testing should not be aimed at proving the firm can stop incidents from happening; instead it should concentrate on whether the firm’s recovery and response arrangements are effective enough to keep performance within the tolerance once disruption is underway. [#TGT:2ff0a61603b1ca55] This creates a direct link between how impact tolerances drive investment and planning decisions and what the tests are meant to validate: the firm is checking that its planned recovery and response actions are sufficient to manage disruption within the tolerance standard that leadership uses for prioritisation. [#SRC:51a4e8e33523d5d5] [#TGT:2ff0a61603b1ca55] The PRA’s expectation to focus on recovery and response arrangements supports keeping both planning and testing centred on managing incidents effectively after they occur. [#TGT:2ff0a61603b1ca55]

question: When drafting outsourcing terms for a material outsourced function, how should a firm address (i) the rights of firms and the PRA to inspect and audit the service provider, and (ii) the PRA’s expectation that service providers are made aware of the Bank and PRA’s statutory information-gathering and investigatory powers (including the effect of any failure to provide that awareness)?
gold_answer: A firm should treat the contractual inspection and audit rights for a material outsourced function as a distinct requirement, while also ensuring the service provider is informed about the Bank and PRA’s statutory powers that may apply directly to the provider. The outsourcing arrangement should include the rights of firms and the PRA to inspect and audit the service provider in relation to the material outsourced function. [#SRC:c8d1fead98534aaa] In parallel, and explicitly independent of later chapter expectations on access, audit, and information rights, the firm should make the service provider aware that the Bank and PRA have statutory information-gathering and investigatory powers, some of which may apply to outsourced service providers as well as firms. [#TGT:a387300e34c8188b] The PRA expects firms to communicate the powers and requirements described in Tables 6 and 7 (noting those tables are not exhaustive), so the provider understands the potential direct reach of those powers beyond the contract’s audit/inspection clauses. [#TGT:a387300e34c8188b] Importantly, even if the firm does not make the provider aware of these powers and requirements, that failure does not change whether the powers apply. [#TGT:a387300e34c8188b]

question: If a firm outsources a material function, what needs to be in the contract about inspections/audits, and what extra message does the PRA expect the firm to give the service provider about the Bank and PRA’s statutory powers (including what happens if the firm forgets to tell them)?
gold_answer: For a material outsourced function, the firm should ensure the outsourcing terms cover both contractual oversight and regulatory awareness. The contract should provide for the rights of firms and the PRA to inspect and audit the service provider in relation to the material outsourced function. [#SRC:c8d1fead98534aaa] Separately, the PRA expects the firm to tell the service provider that, beyond the chapter’s later expectations on access, audit, and information rights, the Bank and PRA also have statutory information-gathering and investigatory powers. [#TGT:a387300e34c8188b] The firm should explain that some of these statutory powers may apply directly to outsourced service providers as well as firms, and it should use the powers and requirements described in Tables 6 and 7 as the basis for that awareness (while recognising those tables are not exhaustive). [#TGT:a387300e34c8188b] The firm should also make clear that if it fails to provide this awareness, that does not affect whether the statutory powers and requirements apply in practice. [#TGT:a387300e34c8188b]

question: When forming the opinion required by Rules 2.1 and 4.1 of the External Audit Part of the PRA Rulebook, what is the auditor’s responsibility regarding (i) assessing whether a firm meets the eligibility conditions for use of the MA and (ii) opining on the validity of approvals, waivers, or other supervisory determinations, and how should those determinations be treated in the audit framework (including in the context of transitional measures on technical provisions)?
gold_answer: In forming the opinion required by Rules 2.1 and 4.1 of the External Audit Part of the PRA Rulebook, the auditor does not have to test whether the firm satisfies the eligibility conditions for use of the MA, and the auditor is also not expected to validate the correctness of any approval, waiver, or other supervisory determination. [#SRC:7bd251a3e64bccff] Instead, approvals, waivers, and supervisory determinations issued by the competent authority are inputs to the basis on which the audit opinion is formed, rather than matters the auditor re-adjudicates. [#TGT:15d29d4311dd73f6] This means the auditor’s work is framed around applying the audit opinion to the relevant reporting framework while accepting those supervisory outcomes as given. [#TGT:15d29d4311dd73f6] For transitional measures on technical provisions specifically, the framework the auditor uses should also incorporate Pillar 1 and 2 assets, liabilities, and capital that are calculated under the previous regime, treating those amounts as part of the same framework against which the audit opinion is provided. [#TGT:15d29d4311dd73f6] Taken together, the auditor’s role is to deliver the required Rules 2.1 and 4.1 opinion without reassessing MA eligibility or second-guessing supervisory decisions, while still reflecting those decisions (and relevant transitional-measure elements) in the framework used for the opinion. [#SRC:7bd251a3e64bccff] [#TGT:15d29d4311dd73f6]

question: If an auditor is giving the opinion required by Rules 2.1 and 4.1, do they need to check whether the firm qualifies to use the MA, and do they need to judge whether an approval or waiver is valid? If not, how should those approvals/waivers be used when the audit also involves transitional measures on technical provisions?
gold_answer: When giving the opinion required by Rules 2.1 and 4.1 of the External Audit Part of the PRA Rulebook, the auditor does not need to evaluate whether the firm meets the eligibility conditions to use the MA. [#SRC:7bd251a3e64bccff] The auditor is also not expected to give a view on whether an approval, waiver, or other supervisory determination is valid. [#SRC:7bd251a3e64bccff] Rather than being re-tested by the auditor, approvals, waivers, and supervisory determinations from the competent authority are treated as part of the framework the auditor uses to form the audit opinion. [#TGT:15d29d4311dd73f6] In practical terms for transitional measures on technical provisions, the auditor should also treat Pillar 1 and 2 assets, liabilities, and capital that are calculated under the previous regime as part of that same framework for the audit opinion. [#TGT:15d29d4311dd73f6] So, the auditor’s job is to apply the audit work to the framework that already includes those supervisory outcomes and transitional-measure elements, without separately deciding MA eligibility or re-validating supervisory decisions. [#SRC:7bd251a3e64bccff] [#TGT:15d29d4311dd73f6]

question: When an entity falls within the scope of “large subsidiaries of UK parent institutions, UK parent financial holding companies or UK parent mixed financial holding companies” (or a large subsidiary of a parent undertaking established in a third country), how should it determine whether it must make an individual or sub-consolidated disclosure specifically about remuneration policy and practices for staff whose activities materially affect the institution’s risk profile, and what is the minimum content anchor for that remuneration disclosure?
gold_answer: A large subsidiary that is within the scope described (i.e., a large subsidiary of UK parent institutions, UK parent financial holding companies or UK parent mixed financial holding companies, or a large subsidiary of a parent undertaking established in a third country) must make the required disclosures either on an individual basis or on a sub-consolidated basis, and that basis choice governs how it presents any remuneration-related disclosure that is required within the specified disclosure set. [#SRC:d6dd201508b9a673] In parallel, where the disclosure set includes remuneration information, the institution’s remuneration disclosure must address its remuneration policy and practices for the categories of staff whose professional activities have a material impact on the institution’s risk profile, meaning the content must be framed around those staff categories and their risk relevance. [#TGT:d3efeb25748ccfe0] Practically, this means the entity should (i) confirm it is a “large subsidiary” in one of the listed parent-structure situations and therefore is subject to the specified-Articles disclosure obligation, and (ii) ensure that, whichever reporting basis it uses (individual or sub-consolidated), the remuneration section is organized to cover the relevant staff categories defined by material impact on risk profile. [#SRC:d6dd201508b9a673] The minimum content anchor for the remuneration portion is that it must be “regarding” remuneration policy and practices and must be scoped to those risk-material staff categories, rather than to all staff generally. [#TGT:d3efeb25748ccfe0]

question: If a company is a large subsidiary under a UK parent group (or under a parent undertaking in a third country), does it have to publish remuneration policy information, and if so, should it do it on its own or at a sub-group level and which staff does the remuneration part need to cover?
gold_answer: If the company is a large subsidiary in one of the covered structures (under UK parent institutions, UK parent financial holding companies, UK parent mixed financial holding companies, or under a parent undertaking established in a third country), it is required to disclose the information specified in the listed Articles, and it must do so either on an individual basis or on a sub-consolidated basis. [#SRC:d6dd201508b9a673] Where the disclosure includes remuneration information, the remuneration part must cover the institution’s remuneration policy and practices for the categories of staff whose professional activities have a material impact on the institution’s risk profile, so the scope is tied to risk-material staff categories rather than the entire workforce. [#TGT:d3efeb25748ccfe0] To comply, the company should first determine that it is within the “large subsidiary” scope described and then choose whether it will report at the individual entity level or at the sub-consolidated level for the required disclosures. [#SRC:d6dd201508b9a673] It should then ensure the remuneration disclosure is written to address the relevant categories of staff identified by their material impact on risk profile, because that is the defined audience for the remuneration policy and practices information. [#TGT:d3efeb25748ccfe0] The key linkage is that the reporting basis (individual vs sub-consolidated) comes from the large-subsidiary disclosure rule, while the staff coverage for the remuneration content comes from the remuneration disclosure requirement. [#SRC:d6dd201508b9a673] [#TGT:d3efeb25748ccfe0]

question: When determining the amount of the long-term insurance liability for each contract, under what circumstances may a retrospective calculation be used instead of the default prospective calculation, and what demonstration (if any) is required to justify that choice?
gold_answer: The default position is that the amount of the long-term insurance liability is to be calculated prospectively for each contract, meaning the starting assumption is a prospective calculation on a contract-by-contract basis. [#SRC:72c3af495575a5fb] A retrospective calculation is permitted only as an exception to that default, and only in limited circumstances tied to the feasibility and prudence of the prospective approach. [#TGT:30f622a929df3844] Specifically, a retrospective calculation may be used where a prospective method cannot be applied to a particular type of contract or benefit, which links the contract-level determination requirement to a contract/benefit-type limitation on method selection. [#SRC:72c3af495575a5fb] [#TGT:30f622a929df3844] Alternatively, even if a prospective method could be applied, a retrospective calculation may be used where it can be demonstrated that the liabilities produced would be no lower than the amount that would be required by a prudent prospective calculation; in that case, the justification hinges on demonstrating a non-lower outcome relative to a prudent prospective benchmark. [#TGT:30f622a929df3844] In all cases, the prospective calculation remains the baseline method for determining the long-term insurance liability for each contract, and the retrospective approach is only available within the stated exception conditions. [#SRC:72c3af495575a5fb] [#TGT:30f622a929df3844]

question: If you normally have to work out the long-term insurance liability using a forward-looking (prospective) calculation for each contract, when are you allowed to use a backward-looking (retrospective) calculation instead, and what do you need to show?
gold_answer: You generally must determine the amount of the long-term insurance liability for each contract using a prospective calculation, so the standard method is forward-looking and applied at the individual contract level. [#SRC:72c3af495575a5fb] You may switch to a retrospective calculation only in specific situations that relate to whether a prospective method can be used and whether the retrospective result is at least as conservative as a prudent prospective result. [#TGT:30f622a929df3844] First, a retrospective calculation is allowed where a prospective method cannot be applied to a particular type of contract or benefit; this is an exception that depends on the nature of the contract or benefit, even though the liability is still being determined for each contract. [#TGT:30f622a929df3844] [#SRC:72c3af495575a5fb] Second, even if a prospective method could be applied, you may use a retrospective calculation if you can demonstrate that the liabilities it produces would be no lower than what would be required by a prudent prospective calculation; the key requirement is the demonstration of a non-lower outcome against that prudent prospective benchmark. [#TGT:30f622a929df3844] Outside these conditions, the prospective calculation remains the required approach for determining the long-term insurance liability for each contract. [#SRC:72c3af495575a5fb] [#TGT:30f622a929df3844]

question: When documenting the risks that must be addressed for SCR purposes, how should a firm align the requirement to cover both (i) the risks included in the SCR calculation and (ii) the risks not, or not fully, included, with the calibration expectation that all quantifiable risks to which the firm is exposed are taken into account (including at least the listed underwriting, market, credit, and operational risks)?
gold_answer: A firm should structure its SCR risk documentation so it both maps what is captured by the SCR calculation and explicitly identifies any exposures that are outside, or only partially inside, that calculation, while ensuring the overall calibration approach is designed to capture all quantifiable risks the firm faces. [#SRC:c2d9c82eaebd8586] [#TGT:f261181a95a3ca51] In practice, this means the firm should (i) list the risks that are included in the SCR calculation as required, and (ii) separately describe the risks that are not, or not fully, included in that calculation, rather than treating the SCR calculation as exhaustive. [#SRC:c2d9c82eaebd8586] At the same time, the firm’s calibration must be set so that all quantifiable risks to which it is exposed are taken into account, and this includes at least non-life underwriting risk, life underwriting risk, health underwriting risk, market risk, credit risk, and operational risk. [#TGT:f261181a95a3ca51] The linkage is that the “not, or not fully, included” category should be used to highlight any quantifiable exposures that the calibration objective would otherwise require the firm to consider, even if they are not fully reflected in the SCR calculation itself. [#SRC:c2d9c82eaebd8586] [#TGT:f261181a95a3ca51]

question: If a firm is listing risks for its SCR work, what should it write down about risks that are not (or not fully) in the SCR calculation, and how does that fit with the rule that calibration must take in all quantifiable risks (including the named underwriting, market, credit, and operational risks)?
gold_answer: The firm should document two things side by side: the risks that are part of the SCR calculation and the risks that are missing from it or only partly captured, and it should do this in a way that supports a calibration designed to include all quantifiable risks the firm is exposed to. [#SRC:c2d9c82eaebd8586] [#TGT:f261181a95a3ca51] Specifically, the firm’s write-up must cover the risks that are included in the SCR calculation and also call out the risks that are not, or not fully, included in that calculation. [#SRC:c2d9c82eaebd8586] Separately, the calibration requirement sets the expectation that all quantifiable risks to which the firm is exposed are taken into account, and it gives a minimum set that must be included: non-life underwriting risk, life underwriting risk, health underwriting risk, market risk, credit risk, and operational risk. [#TGT:f261181a95a3ca51] Putting these together, the firm should not assume the SCR calculation list is complete; instead, it should use the “not, or not fully, included” section to identify any quantifiable exposures that still need to be considered to meet the calibration expectation, even if they are not fully reflected in the SCR calculation. [#SRC:c2d9c82eaebd8586] [#TGT:f261181a95a3ca51]

question: If a firm gets a notice from the Bank of England saying it is (or is likely to be) subject to external or internal MREL above regulatory capital requirements, what MREL details does the PRA expect it to give, and how can the PRA change or update what it asks for in Phase 2?
gold_answer: If the Bank of England has notified a firm that it is, or is likely to be, subject to external or internal MREL in excess of regulatory capital requirements, the PRA expects the firm to provide specific MREL information. [#TGT:de6e936130cf1aef] That expected package covers MREL resources, projected resources, and individual instrument characteristics. [#TGT:de6e936130cf1aef] This information is provided in the context of the PRA’s Phase 2 information-gathering, which is shaped after the PRA reviews Phase 1 submissions and, working with the Bank of England, determines a preferred resolution strategy that defines what should be requested in Phase 2. [#SRC:f6b88f60c0da27f9] The PRA applies supervisory judgement to decide how broad and detailed the Phase 2 request will be and may integrate the request with other scheduled supervisory initiatives to avoid duplicating effort. [#SRC:f6b88f60c0da27f9] The PRA also notes that it may require information beyond what is otherwise outlined, and it will notify firms when Phase 2 information needs to be updated, including potentially asking for refreshed data as the firm moves closer to resolution. [#SRC:f6b88f60c0da27f9]

question: In calibrating the PRA buffer for a new bank, when does the PRA’s time-limited approach cease to apply and what supervisory-judgement basis allows the PRA to move earlier to an established-bank stress-testing calibration, including the type of circumstances that could justify diverging from the stated approach?
gold_answer: The PRA’s time-limited approach for setting the PRA buffer for new banks ends once either of the relevant conditions referenced in the prior material (paragraph 4.8) no longer applies; at that point, the bank’s PRA buffer is calibrated using the bank’s stress testing assessments in the same manner as for established banks. [#SRC:786185f23d84f194] Separately, the PRA may bring forward that transition: the text indicates that an earlier move to the established-bank, stress-testing-based calibration can be introduced where the PRA identifies heightened risks to its objectives. [#SRC:786185f23d84f194] In addition, when exercising supervisory judgement, the PRA may—only in exceptional circumstances—diverge from the stated approach to calculating the PRA buffer for new and growing banks, including where the stated approach would fail to avoid a disproportionate level of capital relative to financial stability risks. [#TGT:7cb7aa7ed1a3d55a] That divergence power explicitly includes cases where the PRA identifies heightened risks to its objectives that justify an earlier transition to the PRA buffer approach used for established banks. [#TGT:7cb7aa7ed1a3d55a] Accordingly, the default trigger for ending the time-limited approach is the cessation of the referenced conditions, but supervisory judgement can justify an earlier shift (or other divergence) in exceptional circumstances, including heightened-risks scenarios and outcomes that would otherwise be disproportionate to financial stability risks. [#SRC:786185f23d84f194] [#TGT:7cb7aa7ed1a3d55a]

question: If a new bank is under the PRA’s time-limited buffer approach, what happens when the earlier conditions stop applying, and when could the PRA still change course sooner—especially if the usual method would lead to too much capital compared with financial stability risks?
gold_answer: When the time-limited approach for new banks no longer applies—because either of the earlier conditions referenced in the prior material (paragraph 4.8) has ceased—the PRA buffer is then set using the bank’s stress testing assessments, consistent with how established banks are treated. [#SRC:786185f23d84f194] The same source also indicates that the PRA can introduce this established-bank, stress-testing-based approach earlier if it identifies heightened risks to its objectives. [#SRC:786185f23d84f194] Beyond that, the PRA may use supervisory judgement to depart from the stated approach in exceptional circumstances, including where following the stated approach would not achieve the intended outcome of avoiding a disproportionate level of capital relative to financial stability risks. [#TGT:7cb7aa7ed1a3d55a] This exceptional-circumstances divergence can also cover situations where the PRA identifies heightened risks to its objectives and considers that those risks justify an earlier transition to the PRA buffer approach used for established banks. [#TGT:7cb7aa7ed1a3d55a] In practice, that means there is a normal “end point” tied to the earlier conditions, but there is also an explicit ability to move earlier (or otherwise diverge) when exceptional circumstances or heightened risks make the standard approach inappropriate. [#SRC:786185f23d84f194] [#TGT:7cb7aa7ed1a3d55a]

question: When a scheme involves a book of non-life insurance business in run-off, how should the parties determine whether the PRA’s stated s166 commissioning approach is triggered if they disagree on the valuation of the technical provisions being transferred, and at what point relative to the independent expert nomination would the assessment be commissioned?
gold_answer: To determine whether the PRA’s described approach to commissioning an assessment under s166 of FSMA applies, the parties should apply the threshold tests using the higher of any differing valuations of the technical provisions being transferred, and then align the timing of any resulting assessment with the PRA’s stated sequencing. [#TGT:6859654d7bfc4b42] Specifically, where the scheme involves a book of non-life insurance business in run-off and the gross technical provisions exceed £100 million, and the scheme would increase the transferee’s technical provisions by more than 10%, the PRA indicates it intends in most cases to use its s166 powers to assess the transferee’s operational readiness to accept the scheme. [#SRC:5ae53f838b30c1a8] In applying those quantitative conditions when valuations differ, the higher valuation is the one used to decide whether the relevant threshold is met. [#TGT:6859654d7bfc4b42] If the thresholds are met on that basis, the PRA’s stated process is that the operational-readiness assessment would be commissioned before the independent expert is nominated. [#SRC:5ae53f838b30c1a8] The PRA also describes an exception: it may refrain from commissioning a new s166 assessment where it can satisfy itself by other means, such as a recent s166 assessment in the same area or an equivalent assessment by an independent body or regulator. [#SRC:5ae53f838b30c1a8]

question: When assessing the total amount of the PRA buffer at consolidated group level for group risk, how should the PRA treat any excess of a buffer applicable to an entity established outside the United Kingdom over that entity’s share of the consolidated group buffer for the same risk, and in what circumstance would that difference not be reflected in the consolidated group PRA buffer?
gold_answer: In assessing the total amount of the PRA buffer at consolidated group level for group risk, the PRA’s assessment is informed by the extent to which any buffer applicable to an entity established outside the United Kingdom is higher than that entity’s share of the buffer applied at consolidated group level for the same risk. [#SRC:fe2dce1c22203901] This means the PRA looks at the size of the “difference” between (i) the outside‑UK entity’s own applicable buffer and (ii) the portion of the consolidated group buffer allocated to that entity for the same risk, and uses that difference as an input to its consolidated group buffer assessment. [#SRC:fe2dce1c22203901] However, the PRA would not carry that difference through into (ie, would not reflect it in) the consolidated group PRA buffer where the underlying risk of the entity established outside the United Kingdom is otherwise mitigated in the consolidated group requirements. [#TGT:78474634e148d6b8] Accordingly, the excess can inform the assessment in general, but it is not reflected in the consolidated group PRA buffer when consolidated group requirements already mitigate the relevant underlying risk. [#TGT:78474634e148d6b8]

question: If an entity established outside the United Kingdom has its own buffer that is bigger than its share of the consolidated group buffer for the same risk, how does that difference affect the PRA’s consolidated group PRA buffer, and when would the PRA ignore the difference?
gold_answer: Where an entity established outside the United Kingdom has a buffer that exceeds that entity’s share of the buffer applied at consolidated group level for the same risk, the PRA uses the amount of that excess as an input when it assesses the total amount of the PRA buffer at consolidated group level for group risk. [#SRC:fe2dce1c22203901] In other words, the PRA’s consolidated group assessment is informed by comparing the outside‑UK entity’s applicable buffer with the entity’s allocated share of the consolidated group buffer covering the same risk, and considering how much higher the entity-level buffer is. [#SRC:fe2dce1c22203901] But the PRA would not reflect that difference in the consolidated group PRA buffer if the underlying risk of the entity established outside the United Kingdom is otherwise mitigated in the consolidated group requirements. [#TGT:78474634e148d6b8] So the difference matters for the assessment generally, yet it is not carried into the consolidated group PRA buffer outcome when consolidated group requirements already address and mitigate the underlying risk that drives the outside‑UK entity’s buffer. [#TGT:78474634e148d6b8]

question: If someone is claiming compensation for a temporary high balance, when should the FSCS pay, and what happens if the depositor’s written application or evidence has a material mistake or leaves something important out (including when the FSCS thinks it was wholly unintentional)?
gold_answer: For a temporary high balance claim, the FSCS is required to pay compensation within three months of the compensation date, unless an exception in 10.9 to 10.11 applies. [#SRC:620668f3ab20c44f] However, that payment outcome depends on the claim not being rejected based on what the depositor submitted. [#TGT:044561de7cc92e8c] If the depositor’s written application or evidence contains a material inaccuracy or omission, the FSCS is allowed to reject the claim for compensation, which would mean no payment is made (including within the three-month period). [#TGT:044561de7cc92e8c] There is an important carve-out: even where there is a material inaccuracy or omission, the FSCS may still accept the claim if it considers the problem to be wholly unintentional. [#TGT:044561de7cc92e8c] So, the practical sequence is: first, the FSCS assesses whether the depositor’s written application/evidence has a material error or missing information and whether any such issue is wholly unintentional; then, if the claim is not rejected on that basis, the FSCS must pay the temporary high balance compensation within three months of the compensation date (subject to the 10.9 to 10.11 exceptions). [#SRC:620668f3ab20c44f] [#TGT:044561de7cc92e8c]

question: When deriving the basic FS for senior notes using an internal credit assessment and an assigned CQS, how should a firm treat qualitative and quantitative retained risks, including interactions and combinations of risks, given that the FS assumes the eligible asset is held to maturity except for sales needed for MA portfolio rebalancing to restore the overall matching position after material cash-flow changes?
gold_answer: A firm should derive the basic FS by identifying and reflecting the retained risks on the assumption the eligible asset is held until maturity, while recognising the limited circumstance where sale may be necessary as part of rebalancing the MA portfolio to restore the overall matching position after material changes in asset and/or liability cash flows. [#TGT:5ef1d5a9b4e454c2] In doing so, the firm’s internal credit assessment for the senior notes must consider both qualitative and quantitative sources of risk, and it must also assess how those risks may interact or combine, because the PRA expects all risks to which the senior notes are exposed (including combinations) to be captured through the internal credit assessment, the assigned CQS, and therefore the derivation of the basic FS. [#SRC:baebcddb0c257a4e] Retained risks explicitly include qualitative and quantitative risks, and qualitative risks can include matters such as the strength of terms and conditions in the loan agreement or a lack of default data, while quantitative risks can include economic or market stresses. [#TGT:5ef1d5a9b4e454c2] Where the firm adjusts the basic FS to reflect differences in credit quality by rating notch, those adjustments should still be grounded in the same comprehensive internal credit assessment and assigned CQS that incorporate the full set of relevant risks and their interactions. [#SRC:baebcddb0c257a4e]

question: If a firm is working out the basic FS for senior notes, what risks does it need to look at in its internal credit assessment, and how does that connect to the FS idea that the asset is held to maturity (except when selling is needed to rebalance the MA portfolio after big cash-flow changes)?
gold_answer: To work out the basic FS for senior notes, the firm should treat the FS as a measure of how much of the spread on an eligible asset reflects the risks the firm keeps, using an assumption that the asset is held until maturity, except where selling is needed for MA portfolio rebalancing to restore the overall matching position after material changes in asset and/or liability cash flows. [#TGT:5ef1d5a9b4e454c2] Within that framework, the internal credit assessment must cover both qualitative and quantitative sources of risk, and it must also consider how those risks can interact or combine, because retained risks include both types and the interaction point is explicitly called out. [#TGT:5ef1d5a9b4e454c2] The PRA expects that all risks to which the senior notes are exposed—including combinations of risks—feed through the internal credit assessment into the assigned CQS and therefore into the derivation of the basic FS. [#SRC:baebcddb0c257a4e] Examples of qualitative risks include the strength of the terms and conditions in the loan agreement or a lack of default data, and examples of quantitative risks include economic or market stresses; these examples are not exhaustive. [#TGT:5ef1d5a9b4e454c2] Any adjustments to the basic FS to reflect differences in credit quality by rating notch should still be based on that same comprehensive assessment and CQS linkage. [#SRC:baebcddb0c257a4e]

question: When a firm (and, where applicable, a UK holding company) reports group information that includes more than one firm using an internal model, what must be submitted to the PRA, how often, what must it contain, and under which rulebook provisions and instructions must it be submitted?
gold_answer: In the scenario where firms and, where applicable, UK holding companies report information on a group that includes more than one firm using an internal model, they must submit template AoC.01 to the PRA on an annual basis. [#TGT:d0d445db94d0c556] The submission must set out the analysis of change referenced in Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 13A and must include both quantitative information and a supporting qualitative analysis. [#TGT:d0d445db94d0c556] AoC.01 is the PRA’s analysis of change template that firms complete with key information about movements in SCR, so the content should address the movement in SCR in the format of that template. [#SRC:282806b2f50a9291] The submission must be made in line with the instructions in section AoC.01 of Chapter 10, and it must also be submitted in accordance with Articles 19 and 35 of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook. [#TGT:d0d445db94d0c556] [#SRC:282806b2f50a9291]

question: If a group report covers more than one firm using an internal model, what is the AoC.01 template for, what information has to be in it, and what timing and rulebook/instruction references apply when sending it to the PRA?
gold_answer: For a group report that includes more than one firm using an internal model, the required submission is the PRA’s AoC.01 analysis of change template, which firms complete with key information about the movement in SCR. [#SRC:282806b2f50a9291] This AoC.01 submission must be made to the PRA every year. [#TGT:d0d445db94d0c556] The template must set out the analysis of change referred to in Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 13A and must include both quantitative information and a supporting qualitative analysis, so it is not limited to numbers alone. [#TGT:d0d445db94d0c556] In addition to using the AoC.01 template for SCR movement information, the submission must follow the instructions in section AoC.01 of Chapter 10. [#TGT:d0d445db94d0c556] It must also be submitted in accordance with Articles 19 and 35 of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook, which are the rulebook provisions tied to how the PRA expects AoC.01 to be submitted. [#SRC:282806b2f50a9291]

question: When a controller or proposed controller that is an investment manager is following the directions in 2.1 and 2.3 for an acquisition or disposal of listed shares in the course of its fund management activity, how should the content and accompanying documents of the section 178 notice be determined, and which form may be used for that notice?
gold_answer: In this scenario, the section 178 notice must be prepared by reference to the Controller’s Form requirements, and the investment manager may use the specific Controller’s form identified by the PRA for this context. [#TGT:6dd8365d28ebc407] Where the controller or proposed controller is an investment manager and is complying with the directions in 2.1 and 2.3 in connection with acquiring or disposing of listed shares as part of its fund management activity, the PRA directs that it may use the Controller’s form at 6.5. [#SRC:3d54441b14fbefda] Consistently, the PRA directs that a section 178 notice submitted in accordance with section 178(1) of FSMA must contain the information and be accompanied by the documents required by the Controller’s Form approved for the relevant application. [#TGT:6dd8365d28ebc407] Accordingly, for an investment manager in the listed-shares fund management context described, the notice’s information content and supporting documents should be those required by the Controller’s Form applicable to the application, and the form that may be used is the Controller’s form at 6.5. [#SRC:3d54441b14fbefda] [#TGT:6dd8365d28ebc407]

question: When a firm is estimating PDs as long-run averages of one-year default rates for obligor grades or pools, how should it choose and use a data series of appropriate length so that the estimate reflects a representative mix of good and bad economic periods, and in what circumstances should the firm change (or not automatically update) that long-run estimate as additional years of experience become available?
gold_answer: A firm should build its long-run PD estimate using a data series that is long enough to support a reasonable estimate of the long-run default rate, and it should use that series in a way that captures a representative mix of both good and bad economic periods rather than relying only on the firm’s realised historic average. [#SRC:bbb89e949553ef1a] [#TGT:13e5135f24e80eea] In practice, this means the “appropriate length” is not just about adding more years mechanically; it is about ensuring the observation window and any adjustments produce expected default rates for each obligor grade or pool that reflect conditions across the cycle. [#SRC:bbb89e949553ef1a] [#TGT:13e5135f24e80eea] The firm should change the long-run estimate when there is a reason to believe the existing long-run estimate is no longer accurate, because the objective is a reasonable long-run default rate estimate rather than a static figure. [#TGT:13e5135f24e80eea] However, the firm should not automatically update the long-run estimate simply to incorporate additional years of experience, since those extra years may not be representative of the long-run average even if they extend the data series. [#TGT:13e5135f24e80eea] This approach aligns the requirement for an appropriately long data series with the expectation that the estimate be cycle-representative and only revised when accuracy is in doubt. [#SRC:bbb89e949553ef1a] [#TGT:13e5135f24e80eea]

question: If a firm is trying to set a long-run PD for a grade or pool, what does it mean to use a data series of “appropriate length,” and why can’t the firm just take its own historic average and update it every year?
gold_answer: Using a data series of “appropriate length” means the firm should select enough data to support a reasonable estimate of the long-run default rate, not merely the shortest or most convenient history. [#SRC:bbb89e949553ef1a] For long-run PDs that are meant to be averages of one-year default rates for obligor grades or pools, the firm is expected to estimate expected default rates over a representative mix of good and bad economic periods, rather than simply averaging the default rates it actually experienced over some past years. [#TGT:13e5135f24e80eea] Put together, this implies the length and composition of the data series should help the firm reflect different economic conditions so the estimate is a reasonable long-run measure. [#SRC:bbb89e949553ef1a] [#TGT:13e5135f24e80eea] The firm should change the long-run estimate when there is reason to think the current long-run estimate is no longer accurate. [#TGT:13e5135f24e80eea] But it should not automatically update the estimate just because another year of defaults has occurred, since those extra years may not be representative of the long-run average even though they extend the data series. [#TGT:13e5135f24e80eea] This keeps the estimate focused on long-run representativeness and reasonableness, not year-by-year drift. [#SRC:bbb89e949553ef1a] [#TGT:13e5135f24e80eea]

question: Where a firm excludes exposures under the resolution exemption in the Large Exposures Part of the PRA Rulebook, and those exposures are not included in MREL reporting as specified in Supervisory Statement (SS) 19/13 ‘Resolution planning’, what notification is required and which June 2018 Bank of England webpage is identified for SS 19/13?
gold_answer: A firm that has excluded exposures using the resolution exemption in the Large Exposures Part of the PRA Rulebook must notify the PRA when those excluded exposures are not included in MREL reporting in the manner specified in Supervisory Statement (SS) 19/13 ‘Resolution planning’. [#SRC:5ef0f6dbfa3bd3bb] This notification trigger is tied specifically to the combination of (i) use of the resolution exemption for Large Exposures and (ii) the fact that the exposures are not captured in MREL reporting as SS 19/13 sets out, so the firm should treat the absence from MREL reporting (as specified in SS 19/13) as the condition that makes the PRA notification necessary. [#SRC:5ef0f6dbfa3bd3bb] The referenced SS 19/13 ‘Resolution planning’ is identified with a June 2018 link on the Bank of England website at www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/publication/2013/resolution-planning-ss. [#TGT:695e320d362f1655] Accordingly, the firm’s compliance action is to notify the PRA in the stated circumstances, and the SS 19/13 reference point for the MREL reporting specification is the June 2018 Bank of England webpage provided. [#SRC:5ef0f6dbfa3bd3bb] [#TGT:695e320d362f1655]

question: If the rules don’t say how to value a certain type of asset, what value should be used, and how should that value be changed if the firm is treated as having bought or sold that asset type because of an option when working out its exposure using the 19 to 23 adjustments?
gold_answer: If there is no specific valuation provision for a particular description of assets, the firm must still ascribe a value, using the amount that would reasonably be paid as consideration for an immediate assignment or transfer of those assets. [#TGT:596695fe437c2dff] That ascribed value is the basis for calculating exposure, because the firm’s exposure to assets of each description is determined by adjusting the value of the assets in accordance with 19 to 23. [#TGT:596695fe437c2dff] When the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of assets of a given description pursuant to an option, the value ascribed for assets of that description (under 18 to 19) must be increased or decreased by the value of the assets the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of. [#SRC:edaf68ec91a76124] So, even where the initial valuation is based on a reasonable immediate transfer price (because the rules are silent for that asset type), the firm must still apply the option-driven increase or decrease to the ascribed value for that asset description as part of the overall adjustment process used to determine exposure under 19 to 23. [#SRC:edaf68ec91a76124] [#TGT:596695fe437c2dff]

question: If an insurance contract lets the premium be paid as one upfront amount and then smaller instalments, can a firm split the contract into parts to put some of it in an MA portfolio? What extra checks does Matching Adjustment 2.3 require for a with-profits annuity “component,” including how it must be managed under regulation 4(6)?
gold_answer: A firm generally should not use an upfront-plus-instalments premium pattern as a reason to split one insurance contract into separate parts for Matching Adjustment purposes, except in the limited cases referenced in the SOURCE. [#SRC:4d0f75998fee0e4e] Matching Adjustment 2.3 instead permits inclusion only of a “component” of a with-profits annuity contract where that component is legally established and clearly identifiable as guaranteed within the contract and can be organised and managed separately in accordance with regulation 4(6) of the IRPR regulations. [#TGT:0bace533be32cdc7] So, even if the premium is paid over time, the firm must avoid a notional split that would undermine separate management of the MA portfolio from the rest of the business, which the PRA links to regulation 4(6)(b). [#SRC:4d0f75998fee0e4e] To support inclusion, the PRA expects the firm to provide a detailed assessment demonstrating that the liabilities included are limited to contractually guaranteed elements and are not dependent on future premiums or future investment performance. [#TGT:0bace533be32cdc7] The firm is also expected to set out a clear policy on whether future attaching bonuses will be added within the MA portfolio or outside it, which helps define what is (and is not) part of the guaranteed component being managed separately. [#TGT:0bace533be32cdc7]

question: What does the text say non-executive directors must do (including what “independence of mind” looks like in board decisions), and where is the related EU law reference shown (Article 91(8) of the Capital Requirements Directive 2013/36/EU)?
gold_answer: The text says that all non-executive directors who are members of the management body—whether independent or not—have a binding obligation to act with honesty, integrity, and independence of mind. [#SRC:8e63907640d17c50] It also clarifies that “independence of mind” is not just a label but a pattern of behaviour that shows up especially during board discussions and decision-making, where each board member should be able to reach sound, objective, and independent decisions and judgements.
