[#SRC:8e63907640d17c50] Alongside that, the same passage ties these expectations to specified internal conduct requirements by stating that non-executive directors are required under Rules 2.1–2.3 and 3.4 in the Conduct Rules Part of the Rulebook to act with integrity, due skill, care and diligence, and to be open and co-operative with regulators. [#SRC:8e63907640d17c50] The related EU law reference is shown separately as a citation to “Article 91(8) Capital Requirements Directive (2013/36/EU),” including a link to the legislation source, which is the explicit place where the EU provision is identified in the provided materials. [#TGT:f668b599884eb746]

question: When a firm outsources a critical or important operational function or activity to a service provider that is in the same group, how must the firm reflect its control or influence over the service provider in the written agreement referred to in 7.5(3), given the requirement that the agreement’s terms and conditions align with the firm’s obligations in 7.1, 7.2 and 7.2A?
gold_answer: The firm must structure the written agreement referred to in 7.5(3) so that its terms and conditions remain aligned with the firm’s obligations under 7.1, 7.2 and 7.2A, and it must do so in a way that reflects the group relationship when the service provider is in the same group. [#SRC:21f32c39e40bb35a] In practice, where the firm and the service provider are members of the same group and the firm is outsourcing a critical or important operational function or activity, the firm must explicitly consider how much it controls the service provider or can influence the service provider’s actions, and ensure the agreement is consistent with that assessment. [#TGT:0ed38a7a991d91b5] This means the agreement should not be drafted in isolation from the firm’s actual ability to direct or shape the service provider’s conduct within the group, because the firm is required to take that control/influence into account for this type of outsourcing. [#TGT:0ed38a7a991d91b5] At the same time, the agreement’s terms and conditions must remain consistent with the firm’s obligations as provided for in 7.1, 7.2 and 7.2A, so the firm should check that any provisions addressing the intra-group control or influence do not conflict with those obligations. [#SRC:21f32c39e40bb35a]

question: If the firm is outsourcing a critical or important operational function or activity to a service provider in the same group, what does the firm need to think about regarding control or influence, and how should that show up in the written agreement mentioned in 7.5(3) so it matches the firm’s obligations in 7.1, 7.2 and 7.2A?
gold_answer: When the firm outsources a critical or important operational function or activity to a service provider that is in the same group, the firm must consider how much it controls the service provider or how much it can influence the service provider’s actions. [#TGT:0ed38a7a991d91b5] That consideration should then be reflected in how the firm prepares the written agreement referred to in 7.5(3), because the firm must ensure the agreement’s terms and conditions are consistent with the firm’s obligations under 7.1, 7.2 and 7.2A. [#SRC:21f32c39e40bb35a] Put simply, the firm cannot treat the agreement as a generic outsourcing contract: for intra-group outsourcing of critical or important functions, the firm must build the agreement in a way that aligns with (i) the firm’s required assessment of its control or influence over the service provider and (ii) the firm’s obligations in 7.1, 7.2 and 7.2A. [#TGT:0ed38a7a991d91b5] [#SRC:21f32c39e40bb35a] The compliance check is therefore twofold: confirm the agreement is consistent with the obligations referenced in 7.1, 7.2 and 7.2A, and confirm that, because the provider is in the same group, the firm has taken its control/influence into account when setting the agreement’s terms. [#SRC:21f32c39e40bb35a] [#TGT:0ed38a7a991d91b5]

question: How should a firm operationalise its record-keeping for outsourcing arrangements so that it can meet the PRA’s expectation to provide information the PRA would reasonably expect notice of, and how does Fundamental Rule 7 shape what must be disclosed to the PRA?
gold_answer: A firm should maintain records of its outsourcing arrangements at a level that supports timely, appropriate disclosure to the PRA of matters the PRA would reasonably expect to be told about, because the PRA expects both robust record-keeping and proactive availability of relevant information. [#SRC:ff27a2b6ca15a12d] Fundamental Rule 7 frames the disclosure standard by requiring the firm to deal with regulators openly and cooperatively and to disclose to the PRA appropriately anything relating to the firm of which the PRA would reasonably expect notice. [#TGT:ab86212dc24973dd] In practice, the firm should (i) keep appropriate records of outsourcing arrangements, including records of material outsourcing arrangements that it would likely already hold when complying with 2.3(1)(e) of the Notifications Part of the PRA Rulebook; and (ii) ensure those records are sufficient to enable the firm to fulfil the PRA’s expectations concerning concentration risk referenced in 5.24. [#SRC:ff27a2b6ca15a12d] The firm should then make information on its outsourcing and third party arrangements available to the PRA where the PRA would reasonably expect notice, aligning the content and timing of what is provided with the Fundamental Rule 7 obligation to disclose appropriately and cooperate. [#SRC:ff27a2b6ca15a12d] [#TGT:ab86212dc24973dd] Separately, the firm should be prepared that the PRA may request data on outsourcing arrangements under section 165 of FSMA where appropriate and justified, which reinforces the need for well-organised records. [#SRC:ff27a2b6ca15a12d]

question: When submitting an application to the PRA for confirmation of an amalgamation or a transfer of engagements, what must be included with the application regarding the scrutineers report, and what additional commentary does the PRA indicate would be helpful in that report where invalid votes are significant?
gold_answer: For either an amalgamation (submitted as a joint application) or a transfer of engagements (submitted as separate applications), the application package must include the scrutineers report and a certified copy of the minutes of the general meeting at which the Merger Resolutions were moved. [#SRC:05dcadd91554d83e] In addition to enclosing the report as part of the application, the PRA indicates it would be helpful for the scrutineers report to go beyond the core reporting and also address process quality where relevant—specifically, it should note any procedural difficulties encountered and provide an analysis explaining why votes were treated as invalid when the number of invalid votes appears significant. [#TGT:2c0f6dd7f7e57586] This means the applicant(s) should treat the scrutineers report as both a required enclosure for the confirmation application and, where invalid votes are notably high, a vehicle for explaining the mechanics and causes of invalidity so the PRA can better understand the voting outcome in context. [#SRC:05dcadd91554d83e] [#TGT:2c0f6dd7f7e57586]

question: If a firm wants to stop quarterly reporting because its submission period is under a year, what is the relief actually called (even if the document uses a different word), and which PRA categories can apply normally versus only in special cases?
gold_answer: For a firm trying to limit quarterly supervisory reporting because the predefined submission period is less than one year, the relief should be understood as being granted through a modification by consent, even though the document uses the word “waiver” throughout. [#TGT:0eac4043346185e2] Under the PRA’s stated eligibility approach, firms designated as Category 3 or 4 under the potential impact framework can apply for this exemption from quarterly reporting, whether they are solo firms or part of a group. [#SRC:5d517e892ad5235c] Category 1 and 2 firms are treated differently: the PRA may consider limitations for them only on an exceptional basis rather than as a standard eligibility route. [#SRC:5d517e892ad5235c] The text indicates that one type of exceptional case could involve small firms that sit within groups where the group is designated as Category 1 or 2 by the PRA. [#SRC:5d517e892ad5235c] So, the firm should use the modification-by-consent framing (despite the “waiver” label) and then assess whether it fits the normal Category 3/4 eligibility or needs to justify an exceptional Category 1/2 case. [#TGT:0eac4043346185e2] [#SRC:5d517e892ad5235c]

question: When a firm seeks the PRA’s permission to apply the MA to the relevant risk-free rate term structure for calculating best estimate liabilities, what must the firm submit under the SoP, and how does that submission requirement interact with the chapter’s description of the PRA’s approach to considering, granting, and varying that permission (including any indication of streamlined treatment in certain circumstances)?
gold_answer: A firm applying for the PRA’s permission to apply the MA to the relevant risk-free rate term structure for calculating its best estimate liabilities should expect the PRA to assess the request under the chapter that describes the PRA’s approach to considering, granting, and varying that permission, while still meeting the SoP’s application submission requirements. [#TGT:c07c55d3c6994e3a] Specifically, the PRA will require the firm to submit a written application in the form set out in Chapter 2 of the SoP, and that application must be accompanied by documentary evidence. [#SRC:974d2778f8f27567] If the request is a change in scope application, the firm must also include the changes that are signposted in the manner described in paragraph 2.18 of the SoP. [#SRC:974d2778f8f27567] In terms of process expectations, the chapter frames the PRA’s handling of these requests as covering consideration, granting, and variation of permission to apply the MA to the relevant risk-free rate term structure for best estimate liabilities, and it also indicates that Chapter 3 discusses how the same approach could be applied more flexibly and in a streamlined way in certain circumstances. [#TGT:c07c55d3c6994e3a] Accordingly, even where a streamlined approach may be discussed for certain circumstances, the baseline submission package remains a written application with supporting evidence, plus the paragraph 2.18 signposting for change in scope cases. [#SRC:974d2778f8f27567]

question: If a firm has to work out deferred taxes for every asset and liability it recognises for solvency or tax purposes (including technical provisions), can it follow IFRS, and what extra valuation rules still have to be followed?
gold_answer: Yes. For the deferred tax task that covers all assets and liabilities recognised for solvency or tax purposes (and that explicitly includes technical provisions), the firm can follow IFRS because the deferred tax provisions are described as consistent with IFRS in relation to Valuation 11.1, and using IFRS is not expected to be disproportionately costly. [#TGT:d84bdc975f6ad72f] [#SRC:ce67e40da8a3c610] But using IFRS does not mean the firm can ignore the rest of the valuation framework: Valuation 11.2 and Valuation 11.3 still apply and must be complied with as well. [#SRC:ce67e40da8a3c610] So the firm’s approach should combine (1) the required scope—deferred taxes must be recognised and valued in relation to all assets and liabilities recognised for solvency or tax purposes, including technical provisions, [#TGT:d84bdc975f6ad72f] with (2) the method—IFRS can be used for the part aligned to Valuation 11.1, while continuing to apply Valuation 11.2 and 11.3. [#SRC:ce67e40da8a3c610] This linkage matters because the scope requirement tells you what items must be covered, while the valuation note clarifies how IFRS can be used without removing the ongoing application of the other Valuation provisions. [#TGT:d84bdc975f6ad72f] [#SRC:ce67e40da8a3c610]

question: When applying the PRA’s expectations on a firm’s risk management and governance of algorithmic trading, how should a firm treat Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2017/565 in terms of its subject-matter scope and its relationship to the supervisory statement, including any applicability qualifier?
gold_answer: A firm should treat Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2017/565 as an external instrument that the PRA expects the supervisory statement on algorithmic trading risk management and governance to be read alongside, but only where it is relevant to the firm. [#SRC:c69125ba4b5fdbc2] In doing so, the firm should understand that the Regulation’s subject-matter is organisational requirements and operating conditions for investment firms, and that it also addresses defined terms for the purposes of the Directive it supplements. [#TGT:e332b1004b0a62b3] The practical linkage is that the supervisory statement frames PRA expectations specifically for algorithmic trading risk management and governance, while the Regulation provides a broader organisational and operating-conditions context for investment firms that may inform how those expectations are interpreted and implemented. [#SRC:c69125ba4b5fdbc2] [#TGT:e332b1004b0a62b3] Accordingly, a firm should (i) identify whether the Regulation is applicable to it (as indicated by the supervisory statement’s qualifier), and then (ii) align its algorithmic trading governance and risk management approach with the organisational and operating-conditions concepts addressed in the Regulation when reading the documents together. [#SRC:c69125ba4b5fdbc2] [#TGT:e332b1004b0a62b3]

question: If you are using the PRA supervisory statement on algorithmic trading, what does it tell you to read alongside it, and what does that other document cover (in plain terms), including when it applies?
gold_answer: You should use the PRA supervisory statement as the document that sets the PRA’s expectations for a firm’s risk management and governance of algorithmic trading, and you should read it together with Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2017/565 where that Regulation is relevant to your firm. [#SRC:c69125ba4b5fdbc2] The Regulation you are asked to read alongside it is about organisational requirements and operating conditions for investment firms, and it also deals with defined terms for the purposes of the Directive it supplements. [#TGT:e332b1004b0a62b3] Put together, this means the supervisory statement provides the PRA’s algorithmic-trading governance and risk-management expectations, while the Regulation provides a broader organisational and operating framework for investment firms that can help you interpret and structure those expectations. [#SRC:c69125ba4b5fdbc2] [#TGT:e332b1004b0a62b3] The key practical step is to confirm whether the Regulation is applicable in your situation (as indicated by the supervisory statement), and then use its organisational and operating-conditions focus as part of the context when applying the PRA’s expectations to algorithmic trading. [#SRC:c69125ba4b5fdbc2] [#TGT:e332b1004b0a62b3]

question: When a G-SII uses the derogation that permits Article 441 information to be disclosed separately from the standalone document referenced in Article 434(1), how does that interact with the general requirement that Titles II and III disclosures be provided in electronic format and in a single medium or location, and what form must that single medium or location take?
gold_answer: A G-SII that relies on the derogation may place the information required under Article 441 in a different medium or location than the standalone document referenced in Article 434(1), even though institutions generally must publish required disclosures in one place. [#SRC:f339ea4b3db2ad76] The baseline rule is that institutions must disclose all information required under Titles II and III electronically and in a single medium or location. [#TGT:8422ed9edcda5caa] That single medium or location must be either (i) a standalone document that serves as a readily accessible source of prudential information for users, or (ii) a distinctive section included in or appended to the institutions' financial statements or financial reports that contains the required disclosures and is easily identifiable to those users. [#TGT:8422ed9edcda5caa] In applying the derogation, the institution can therefore keep the Titles II and III disclosures organized in the required single electronic medium or location meeting the specified form, while allowing the Article 441 information to be disclosed separately from the standalone document mentioned in Article 434(1). [#SRC:f339ea4b3db2ad76] [#TGT:8422ed9edcda5caa]

question: If a G-SII decides to use the option to publish the Article 441 information somewhere different from the standalone document in Article 434(1), what is the normal “one place, electronic” rule for Titles II and III disclosures, and what can count as that one place?
gold_answer: If a G-SII uses the derogation, it is allowed to put the information required under Article 441 in a separate medium or location rather than in the standalone document referred to in Article 434(1). [#SRC:f339ea4b3db2ad76] Normally, institutions must publish all information required under Titles II and III electronically and in a single medium or location. [#TGT:8422ed9edcda5caa] That single place must be set up in one of two ways: it can be a standalone document that gives users a readily accessible source of prudential information, or it can be a clearly identifiable distinctive section that is included in or appended to the institutions’ financial statements or financial reports and that contains the required disclosures. [#TGT:8422ed9edcda5caa] Putting these together, the G-SII can follow the general approach of having Titles II and III disclosures in one electronic location that meets the required format, while still using the derogation to locate the Article 441 information separately from the Article 434(1) standalone document. [#SRC:f339ea4b3db2ad76] [#TGT:8422ed9edcda5caa]

question: When an institution that acts as a clearing member is calculating its own funds requirements for CVA risk under Title VI using the reduced exposure at default from the calculations in paragraphs 3, 4 and 5, and it also applies the Section 5 method to determine the own funds requirement for its exposures to a client, what maturity factor may it apply in that client-exposure calculation, and how does that fit within the overall CVA own-funds computation?
gold_answer: An institution that acts as a clearing member may integrate two specific calculation features when determining its own funds requirements for CVA risk under Title VI: it may base the CVA calculation on a reduced exposure at default derived from the calculations in paragraphs 3, 4 and 5, and—when separately calculating the own funds requirement for exposures to a client using the Section 5 method—it may apply a maturity factor of 0.21 within that Section 5 calculation. [#SRC:e0f6e3ca4abbfbea] [#TGT:f6e5657c2d3e0f5e] This combination is available only where the institution is acting as a clearing member, because both the reduced exposure-at-default permission and the maturity-factor permission are framed for an institution in that role. [#SRC:e0f6e3ca4abbfbea] [#TGT:f6e5657c2d3e0f5e] Operationally, the institution can (i) use the reduced exposure at default produced by the specified paragraph 3–5 calculations for purposes of its Title VI CVA own-funds requirement, and (ii) in the distinct context of applying the Section 5 method to compute the own funds requirement for its exposures to a client, use the 0.21 maturity factor as part of that computation. [#SRC:e0f6e3ca4abbfbea] [#TGT:f6e5657c2d3e0f5e] The maturity factor of 0.21 is expressly permitted as a derogation from point (d) of Article 282(4) for that Section 5 client-exposure calculation. [#TGT:f6e5657c2d3e0f5e]

question: If an institution that acts as a clearing member is working out its CVA own-funds requirement under Title VI using the reduced exposure at default from paragraphs 3–5, and it also uses the Section 5 method for its exposures to a client, what maturity factor can it use for that client calculation?
gold_answer: In that situation, the institution that acts as a clearing member can use a maturity factor of 0.21 when it applies the Section 5 method to calculate the own funds requirement for its exposures to a client. [#TGT:f6e5657c2d3e0f5e] This sits alongside (and does not replace) the separate permission for a clearing member to use a reduced exposure at default—specifically, the reduced exposure at default that results from the calculations in paragraphs 3, 4 and 5—when calculating its own funds requirements for CVA risk under Title VI. [#SRC:e0f6e3ca4abbfbea] So, the combined approach is: use the reduced exposure at default from paragraphs 3–5 for the Title VI CVA own-funds calculation, and, when the calculation step concerns exposures to a client under the Section 5 method, apply the 0.21 maturity factor within that Section 5 computation. [#SRC:e0f6e3ca4abbfbea] [#TGT:f6e5657c2d3e0f5e] The 0.21 maturity factor is explicitly allowed as a derogation from point (d) of Article 282(4) for that Section 5 client-exposure calculation. [#TGT:f6e5657c2d3e0f5e]

question: When calculating the risk-weighted exposure amounts for trade exposures with CCPs for Article 92(3), how should an institution treat assets posted as collateral to a CCP or a clearing member that are bankruptcy remote upon insolvency of the CCP, the clearing member, or other clients—specifically, can those assets be assigned a zero exposure value and, if so, how does that affect the sum of exposure values that is multiplied by the applicable risk weight?
gold_answer: In calculating risk-weighted exposure amounts for trade exposures with CCPs for Article 92(3), the institution’s baseline method is to add up the exposure values of its trade exposures with CCPs (as calculated under the relevant paragraphs) and then apply the risk weight determined under the relevant paragraph to that summed amount. [#SRC:99cd1305ee2e0e40] However, a specific derogation allows the institution, in defined circumstances, to set the exposure value to zero for certain counterparty credit risk exposures tied to collateral assets posted to a CCP or a clearing member. [#TGT:3efc66c18754eca4] This zero-exposure treatment is available only where the posted collateral assets are bankruptcy remote if the CCP, the clearing member, or one or more other clients of the clearing member becomes insolvent. [#TGT:3efc66c18754eca4] When the derogation applies and the institution attributes an exposure value of zero to those counterparty credit risk exposures, those zero-valued exposures would not increase the summed exposure values that form the basis for the subsequent multiplication by the applicable risk weight in the CCP trade exposure calculation. [#SRC:99cd1305ee2e0e40] The institution should therefore reflect the derogation at the exposure-value stage before performing the sum-and-multiply step used to arrive at the risk-weighted exposure amount for its trade exposures with CCPs. [#SRC:99cd1305ee2e0e40]

question: Where this Part applies to Article 109 undertakings and references to a firm in Chapters 2–4 are to be read as including those undertakings, what capital buffer calculation must be performed and on what basis must it be measured?
gold_answer: Because this Part applies to Article 109 undertakings and provides that references to a firm in Chapters 2–4 should, as appropriate, be read to include all Article 109 undertakings [#SRC:bb2dd76c55650361], the obligation that applies to “a firm” in those chapters is to be treated as applying to those undertakings within the scope of this Part. Accordingly, the relevant entity must calculate a capital conservation buffer, and that buffer must be composed of common equity tier 1 capital and set at a level equal to 2.5% of the entity’s total risk exposure amount [#TGT:1fa5af1842dbec2d]. In practical compliance terms, the scope provision determines who is captured (Article 109 undertakings, via the interpretive reading of “firm”), while the obligation specifies what must be done (perform the buffer calculation) and the quantitative basis for the calculation (a percentage applied to total risk exposure amount).

question: If this Part covers Article 109 undertakings and says that mentions of a firm in Chapters 2–4 should be read to include them, what must they do about the capital conservation buffer and how is it calculated?
gold_answer: This Part is stated to apply to Article 109 undertakings, and it also explains that references to a firm in Chapters 2–4 should, where appropriate, be read as including all Article 109 undertakings [#SRC:bb2dd76c55650361]. That scope and interpretation means the duty placed on “a firm” in those chapters is not limited to firms in the narrow sense; it extends to the Article 109 undertakings that fall within this Part. As a result, the covered entity must calculate a capital conservation buffer, and the buffer must be made up of common equity tier 1 capital and set at 2.5% of its total risk exposure amount [#TGT:1fa5af1842dbec2d]. Put simply, the source text tells you who the rule is meant to capture (Article 109 undertakings by reading “firm” to include them), and the target text tells you the required action and the exact measurement basis for the calculation.

question: For which applicants and related parties does the PRA’s obligation to consult the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) in advance of certain transfer decisions apply, when they are proposing to apply for or accept an insurance business transfer scheme?
gold_answer: The PRA’s stated approach to insurance business transfers includes an obligation that, before making certain decisions in respect of a transfer, it will consult with the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) in advance and will seek to avoid inadvertently introducing incompatible requirements. This obligation is relevant in the context of Chapter 2’s scope, which is aimed at any firm, one or more underwriting members of the Society of Lloyd’s, or one or more persons who have ceased to be such a member, where they are proposing to make an application to transfer the whole or part of its business by an insurance business transfer scheme or to accept such a transfer [#TGT:c07f687cc71ea64f]. In practice, this means that when those in-scope applicants (or transferees) are engaging with the PRA on a transfer, they should expect the PRA to coordinate with the FCA ahead of certain PRA decisions, reflecting the FCA’s own approach and expectations on insurance business transfers referenced by the PRA [#SRC:8bd54938895a298a]. The same overall framework also encompasses the independent expert approved by the PRA to make the scheme report, who operates within the Chapter 2 process in which this PRA–FCA coordination is part of the regulatory backdrop [#TGT:c07f687cc71ea64f].

question: Where Chapter 2 applies to a proposed insurance business transfer scheme, how should a firm or underwriting member of the Society of Lloyd’s factor in the PRA’s requirement to consult the FCA in advance of certain decisions, including in relation to the independent expert’s role?
gold_answer: Chapter 2 applies to any firm, or one or more underwriting members of the Society of Lloyd’s, or one or more persons who have ceased to be such a member, that is proposing to apply to transfer the whole or part of its business by an insurance business transfer scheme or to accept such a transfer; it also applies to the independent expert approved by the PRA to make the scheme report [#TGT:c07f687cc71ea64f]. Within that in-scope process, the PRA indicates that, while it sets out its expectations for insurance business transfers, it will consult with the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) in advance of making certain decisions in respect of a transfer and will seek to avoid inadvertently introducing incompatible requirements [#SRC:8bd54938895a298a]. Accordingly, an in-scope firm or relevant Lloyd’s member should plan on the basis that some PRA decision points will involve prior FCA consultation, and that the PRA is actively trying to align outcomes so that requirements are not incompatible across regulators [#SRC:8bd54938895a298a]. Because Chapter 2 also targets the independent expert approved by the PRA, the parties should anticipate that the independent expert’s work sits within a regulatory process where the PRA’s decision-making is coordinated with the FCA’s stated approach and expectations for such transfers [#TGT:c07f687cc71ea64f].

question: If a firm (or an underwriting member of the Society of Lloyd’s, or someone who used to be one) is planning to apply to transfer insurance business or accept a transfer, does the PRA have to talk to the FCA before making some decisions, and who else is covered by the same Chapter 2 process?
gold_answer: Yes. In the context of insurance business transfers, the PRA explains that it sets out its expectations but will consult with the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) in advance of making certain decisions about a transfer, and it will try to avoid accidentally creating incompatible requirements [#SRC:8bd54938895a298a]. This matters for the scope of Chapter 2, because Chapter 2 is aimed at any firm, or one or more underwriting members of the Society of Lloyd’s, or one or more persons who have ceased to be such a member, when they are proposing to make an application to transfer the whole or part of its business by an insurance business transfer scheme or to accept such a transfer [#TGT:c07f687cc71ea64f]. So, if you fall into that group and are planning a transfer or acceptance, you should expect that some PRA decision steps will involve prior FCA consultation as part of the overall regulatory handling of the transfer [#SRC:8bd54938895a298a]. Chapter 2 also covers the independent expert approved by the PRA to make the scheme report, meaning that the independent expert’s work is part of the same in-scope process in which the PRA’s coordination with the FCA is a stated feature [#TGT:c07f687cc71ea64f].

question: If a firm is a small CRR firm or a small third country CRR firm, which remuneration provisions are stated not to apply, and what information must institutions give when they rely on a derogation (including who benefits and how much they are paid)?
gold_answer: The scope statement says that the listed remuneration provisions do not apply to a firm that is a small CRR firm or a small third country CRR firm [#TGT:a4ec0f032fd53c03]. Separately, when institutions benefit from a derogation for the relevant purposes, they have to clearly state that they benefit from the derogation and explain the basis for that reliance, including whether it is on the basis of the Remuneration Part of the PRA Rulebook at the specified locations (including the one referenced in the source) [#SRC:709d7a650b1d24f6]. They also must describe how they are using the derogation(s) by identifying which remuneration principles the derogation(s) are applied to, and they must provide quantitative details: the number of staff members who benefit from the derogation(s) and those staff members’ total remuneration, broken down into fixed and variable remuneration [#SRC:709d7a650b1d24f6]. In practice, you use the scope rule to determine whether the listed provisions apply to the firm at all, and the derogation rule to determine what must be disclosed when a derogation is used.

question: When determining whether the total gross cost of proposed bonus(es) is within the prescribed limit for purposes of where members’ approval must be included in the Merger Resolutions, how must a society calculate the relevant limit by reference to a sum tied to its reserves after deducting fixed assets, including any required pro rata apportionment, and what is the resulting procedural consequence if the cost exceeds that limit?
gold_answer: To apply the procedure for members’ approval of bonus payments through the Merger Resolutions, the society must first determine the prescribed limit by using the defined calculation that refers to “a sum equal to the society’s reserves after deducting its fixed assets,” with the fixed assets apportioned pro rata for the relevant context, and then taking the lesser amount where the definition requires that comparison [#SRC:fa83aff840ed1f2b]. Once that limit is established, the society compares it to the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es) (calculated without any adjustment for prospective corporation tax recovery) to decide how widely the approval must be embedded in the Merger Resolutions [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8]. If the total gross cost is within the prescribed limit, approval need only be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of the society whose funds are to be distributed; however, if the total gross cost exceeds the prescribed limit, then the approval must be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of each participating society [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8].

question: How do you work out the limit using the society’s reserves after taking off fixed assets (including the pro rata split), and then decide which societies’ Merger Resolutions must include members’ approval for the bonus payments if the bonus cost is over that limit?
gold_answer: You start by calculating the relevant limit using the definition that ties it to a sum based on the society’s reserves after deducting its fixed assets, with the fixed assets apportioned pro rata for the relevant context, and then applying the definition’s instruction to use whichever resulting amount is the less; the source also notes that the Regulations should be consulted for full calculation detail [#SRC:fa83aff840ed1f2b]. Next, you compare that limit to the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es), which is assessed without any adjustment for prospective corporation tax recovery, because that is the cost measure used to test whether the limit is exceeded [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8]. This comparison drives the approval-routing step: if the cost is within the prescribed limit, members’ approval only needs to be included in the Merger Resolutions of the society whose funds are being distributed; but if the cost exceeds the limit, the approval must be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of each participating society [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8].

question: For annual reports and accounts within the Chapter’s application dates, may an auditor treat the reporting obligation concerning the audited annual report and accounts of the firm’s ultimate parent undertaking as inapplicable where the auditor is not also the auditor of that ultimate parent undertaking?
gold_answer: The Chapter’s requirements apply in relation to annual reports and accounts by reference to the accounting reference date: it applies for accounting reference dates on or after 1 November 2016, but the specific provisions that include the relevant reporting framework apply only for accounting reference dates on or after 31 December 2018 [#SRC:857a0e15a398cd88]. Within that applicable population of annual reports and accounts, the auditor’s position on reporting about the audited annual report and accounts of the firm’s ultimate parent undertaking is qualified by an express exception: an auditor is not required to report in relation to those audited annual report and accounts if the auditor is not also the auditor of the ultimate parent undertaking [#TGT:f18969dc0a4b1513]. Accordingly, even where the Chapter (and, where relevant, the later-applying provisions) would otherwise govern the annual reports and accounts based on the accounting reference date, the auditor may rely on this condition to conclude that no reporting is required in respect of the ultimate parent undertaking’s audited annual report and accounts when the auditor does not hold that ultimate parent undertaking audit role [#SRC:857a0e15a398cd88] [#TGT:f18969dc0a4b1513].

question: Where a firm has achieved SRT for a transaction involving unfunded credit protection, what must the firm do on an ongoing basis to assess the risk that the protection provider is downgraded, and how must that assessment be incorporated into the firm’s monitoring, stress testing, and capital planning for residual exposures?
gold_answer: The PRA expects the firm to continue monitoring the transaction for any risks to which it may still be exposed even after achieving SRT, and to run regular stress testing over its securitisation activities and relevant off balance sheet exposures, including existing securitisations and pipeline transactions, with procedures to assess and respond to the results and take them into account under Pillar 2 [#TGT:a1f555dbe3d2d607]. Within that ongoing monitoring and stress-testing framework, the PRA also expects originators to assess the risk that the protection provider could be downgraded and to evaluate what that would mean for the effectiveness of the unfunded credit protection and whether the provider would remain eligible to continue providing that protection, and to reflect those implications in capital planning [#SRC:e7a6b6de3819019b]. Read together, this means the downgrade assessment should not be treated as a one-off due diligence step: it should be embedded in the firm’s continuing risk monitoring and stress testing for the transaction and should feed through to capital planning, including consideration of the capital impact if securitised assets were to return to the balance sheet and any broader firm-wide impacts on other sources of risk.

question: When preparing the Statement for a merger, what must it include about any bonus to be paid to members, and how must the Merger Resolutions address member approval of that bonus depending on whether the total gross cost is within or exceeds the prescribed limit?
gold_answer: The Statement must set out whether a bonus is to be paid to members as consideration for the merger and, if so, it must specify that bonus so members can understand what is being proposed and voted on [#SRC:3c15426a910415a8]. Separately, the payment of any such bonus requires members’ approval through the Merger Resolutions, and the placement of that approval within the resolutions depends on the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es) (calculated without adjustment for prospective corporation tax recovery) [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8]. If the total gross cost is within the prescribed limit, the approval need only appear in each of the Merger Resolutions of the society whose funds are to be distributed; however, if the total gross cost exceeds the prescribed limit, the approval must be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of each participating society [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8]. Read together, the Statement’s required specification of the bonus supports the members’ approval process that must be reflected in the relevant Merger Resolutions [#SRC:3c15426a910415a8] [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8].

question: When a TWD firm uses the TWD option, what should be documented about the actions, arrangements and measures intended to reduce risk and leverage and to restructure trading activities, and how should that documentation be aligned with the Recovery Plans Part of the PRA Rulebook and the related cross-references?
gold_answer: Under the TWD option, the TWD firm should set out a coherent package of actions, arrangements and measures that are specifically designed to enable it to reduce risk and leverage and to restructure its trading activities, rather than describing the option at a high level only [#SRC:f125cff5511a454b]. That description should be prepared in a way that is consistent with the Recovery Plans Part of the PRA Rulebook, and it should be read alongside the additional materials that are explicitly cross-referenced for context and supporting detail, including the cited paragraphs in SS9/17 and the referenced Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2016/1075 as it forms part of UK law [#TGT:da63c97283a5093f]. Practically, this means the firm’s recovery planning documentation should clearly connect each proposed action, arrangement, or measure to the intended outcomes (risk and leverage reduction and trading-activity restructuring) while ensuring the overall presentation and supporting references align with the Recovery Plans framework and its linked guidance and legal materials.

question: In preparing recovery planning materials, how should a TWD firm evidence that its TWD option includes concrete actions, arrangements and measures to reduce risk and leverage and restructure trading activities, given the requirement to consider the PRA Rulebook Recovery Plans provisions and the specified related references?
gold_answer: A TWD firm should evidence its TWD option by explicitly setting out the actions, arrangements and measures that would allow it to reduce risk and leverage and to restructure its trading activities, making clear that these are integral components of the option rather than ancillary considerations [#SRC:f125cff5511a454b]. That evidence should be positioned within the Recovery Plans Part of the PRA Rulebook framework, taking account of the specific rule reference and the further materials signposted for interpretation and completeness, namely the referenced paragraphs in SS9/17 and the referenced Article in Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2016/1075 as it forms part of UK law [#TGT:da63c97283a5093f]. In effect, the firm should ensure its documentation both (i) describes the concrete content of the TWD option (actions/arrangements/measures and their intended effects) and (ii) is structured and supported in a way that is consistent with the Recovery Plans rule context and its linked guidance and legal cross-references.

question: When a firm must reduce its basic own funds by participations in a financial and credit institution that exceed the 10% threshold, how must the firm proceed if a straightforward application of the relevant own-funds deduction approach is not possible, and what step must it take to determine which tier of own-funds the adjustment applies to?
gold_answer: A firm must reduce its basic own funds by the full value of participations in a financial and credit institution to the extent those participations exceed 10% of the items included in 3A.1(1)(a), 3A.1(1)(b), 3A.1(1)(d) and 3A.1(1)(f), for the purpose of determining its basic own funds [#TGT:0627964a494e4b18]. In carrying out the calculations that support this own-funds determination, firms should observe Guidelines 4 and 5, which are described as supporting the required calculations under Own Funds 3K [#SRC:f70061d7218c187e]. Where implementing the deduction requires an adjustment and a straightforward application of Own Funds 3K.5 is not possible, the firm should follow Guideline 6 to identify the tier of own-funds to which the adjustment should apply [#SRC:f70061d7218c187e]. In practice, this means the firm applies the mandatory reduction for participations above the 10% threshold, and, if the normal deduction method cannot be applied straightforwardly, it uses Guideline 6 as the procedural step to allocate the resulting adjustment to the correct own-funds tier while still completing the underlying calculations supported by Guidelines 4 and 5.

question: If a firm must cut its basic own funds because its participations in a financial and credit institution are over the 10% limit, what should it do if it cannot apply the usual deduction method in a straightforward way, and how does it work out which own-funds tier the adjustment belongs to?
gold_answer: The firm must, for the purpose of determining its basic own funds, reduce its basic own funds by the full value of participations in a financial and credit institution that exceeds 10% of the items included in 3A.1(1)(a), 3A.1(1)(b), 3A.1(1)(d) and 3A.1(1)(f) [#TGT:0627964a494e4b18]. To support doing the calculations needed for this own-funds determination, firms should observe Guidelines 4 and 5, which are described as supporting the carrying out of the calculations required by Own Funds 3K [#SRC:f70061d7218c187e]. If the firm needs to make a deduction from own-funds and it cannot apply Own Funds 3K.5 in a straightforward way, it should follow Guideline 6 to identify the tier of own-funds to which the adjustment should apply [#SRC:f70061d7218c187e]. So the required action is the reduction for participations above the 10% threshold, and the procedural step—when the normal approach is not straightforward—is to use Guideline 6 to decide which tier receives the adjustment while still relying on the calculation support in Guidelines 4 and 5.

question: When meeting the expectations for its indicator approach, how must a firm satisfy the obligation to monitor indicators for a solvent exit while relying on, and tailoring, its existing management information and recovery-planning indicator frameworks rather than creating a separate new set?
gold_answer: A firm is permitted to meet the relevant expectations by drawing on and adapting its existing management information framework and any indicator framework developed under the PRA’s recovery planning expectations, without necessarily creating and monitoring a wholly new set of indicators [#SRC:123f8b7afeb33b32]. However, that flexibility does not remove the firm’s monitoring obligation: the firm should monitor both the projected and actual levels of the indicators it uses, and also monitor their trend over time [#TGT:30201d932e512926]. In practice, the firm should ensure that whichever indicators it selects from, or builds upon within, its existing frameworks are tracked in a way that captures forward-looking projections and realised outcomes, and that trend information is maintained so changes can be identified promptly [#TGT:30201d932e512926]. The monitored indicators, together with other relevant information, should be used to support clear and timely decision-making regarding a solvent exit, meaning the firm should be able to use the adapted framework to inform decisions without delay or ambiguity [#TGT:30201d932e512926], while still leveraging existing structures as permitted [#SRC:123f8b7afeb33b32].

question: If a firm uses and tweaks its existing management information and recovery-planning indicator frameworks instead of building a new indicator set, what does it still need to do to meet its monitoring duties for a solvent exit?
gold_answer: A firm may meet the relevant expectations by drawing on and adapting its existing management information framework and the indicator framework it developed under the PRA’s recovery planning expectations, and it does not necessarily have to create and monitor a brand-new set of indicators to do so [#SRC:123f8b7afeb33b32]. Even when using that approach, the firm still has a monitoring duty for the indicators it relies on: it should monitor the projected levels and the actual levels of those indicators, and it should also monitor their trend so it can see how they are moving over time [#TGT:30201d932e512926]. The point of this monitoring is not just record-keeping; the indicators, together with other relevant information, should support clear and timely decision-making regarding a solvent exit [#TGT:30201d932e512926]. So, if the firm reuses existing reporting and recovery-planning metrics, it should ensure they are tracked in a way that provides projections, actual outcomes, and trend information that can be used quickly for solvent-exit decisions [#TGT:30201d932e512926], while taking advantage of the flexibility to adapt existing frameworks [#SRC:123f8b7afeb33b32].

question: When an Institution is required to make the disclosures corresponding to point (j) of the relevant disclosure provision, how must it structure those disclosures between trading and non-trading book activities, and what templates and instructions must it follow to complete the disclosure process?
gold_answer: Where an Institution is calculating risk-weighted exposure amounts under the specified framework for trading activities or is calculating own funds requirements under the specified approaches, it has an obligation to disclose the required information separately for its trading book and non-trading book activities [#TGT:c436a14243ca6883]. For the specific set of disclosures corresponding to point (j) of the relevant disclosure provision, the disclosure process must be carried out using the prescribed reporting format: the Institution should prepare the disclosures in accordance with Templates UK-SEC1 and UK-SEC2, and it must apply the relevant instructions set out in Annex XXVIII when completing those templates [#SRC:faa958a16f11e0e7]. Read together, this means the Institution should not present a single combined disclosure across books for these items; instead, it should populate the required templates in a way that preserves the separate presentation for trading and non-trading book activities, following the associated instructions to ensure the disclosures are completed consistently with the required template structure and completion guidance [#TGT:c436a14243ca6883] [#SRC:faa958a16f11e0e7].

question: If a firm triggers an SPF for restructuring by engaging, or preparing to engage, in the restructuring activity, does it have to include third‑party fees and disbursements that are billed to the PRA for help with the PRA’s related regulatory work?
gold_answer: Yes. Once an SPF for restructuring becomes payable because a firm engages, or prepares to engage, in activity that involves it undertaking or making arrangements with a view to the specified outcomes, the payable amount must be calculated in a way that also captures certain external costs incurred by the PRA. The procedure says to add any fees and disbursements that a third party provider invoices to the PRA, but only where those charges are for services performed for the PRA and are connected to assisting the PRA in carrying out the relevant regulatory work. In other words, the trigger for payment is the firm’s engagement (or preparation to engage) in the restructuring activity [#TGT:28f11ba870345a3b], and the calculation step requires including third‑party invoiced fees and disbursements to the PRA that relate to supporting the PRA’s performance of that regulatory work [#SRC:f9e22b9441fa0c58].

question: If a firm is using the PRA supervisory statement on algorithmic trading, what does it mean that it should be read alongside Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2017/565, and what is that Regulation about?
gold_answer: It means the firm should not rely only on the PRA supervisory statement when shaping its approach to algorithmic trading. The supervisory statement explains that it sets out the PRA’s expectations for a firm’s risk management and governance of algorithmic trading, and it explicitly says it should be read alongside Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2017/565 where that is applicable [#SRC:c69125ba4b5fdbc2]. The Regulation itself is described as an EU measure that supplements Directive 2014/65/EU and deals with organisational requirements and operating conditions for investment firms, as well as defined terms used for the purposes of that Directive [#TGT:e332b1004b0a62b3]. So, in practice, the firm should use the supervisory statement to understand what the PRA expects for algorithmic trading risk management and governance, and also consider the Regulation’s organisational and operating conditions framework for investment firms to ensure its approach is consistent with both documents when the cross-reference applies [#SRC:c69125ba4b5fdbc2] [#TGT:e332b1004b0a62b3].

question: When identity verification has not been completed under the relevant anti-money laundering requirements before the firm’s compensation date, how should insolvency practitioners align their required consideration of their objectives and responsibilities with the ability for the relevant insolvency practitioner appointed by the court to facilitate identity verification to determine eligibility for FSCS protection?
gold_answer: Where identity verification has not been carried out in accordance with the relevant anti-money laundering requirements ahead of the firm’s compensation date, the PRA’s view is that the relevant insolvency practitioner appointed by the court is permitted to facilitate the identity verification specifically for the purpose of determining eligibility for FSCS (Financial Services Compensation Scheme) protection [#SRC:eb355065b8865baf]. In parallel, insolvency practitioners are expected to consider matters in line with the insolvency practitioner’s objectives and responsibilities under Section 99 of the Banking Act 2009 [#TGT:02363a43a51fdf7b]. Read together, this means the insolvency practitioner’s decision-making should not treat facilitation of identity verification as a standalone discretionary step; rather, it should be approached as an action that may be used to support the eligibility determination where the pre-compensation-date verification gap exists, while ensuring the practitioner’s overall approach remains consistent with their statutory objectives and responsibilities. The practical linkage is that the permitted facilitation addresses the missing verification needed to assess FSCS eligibility, and the required consideration frames how and why the practitioner proceeds in that context, given their role and responsibilities.

question: If identity checks were not done under the anti-money laundering requirements before the firm’s compensation date, what must insolvency practitioners consider about their objectives and responsibilities, and how can the relevant insolvency practitioner appointed by the court help complete identity verification to decide FSCS protection eligibility?
gold_answer: If identity verification has not been carried out in line with the relevant anti-money laundering requirements before the firm’s compensation date, the PRA indicates that the relevant insolvency practitioner appointed by the court is allowed to facilitate identity verification for the purpose of determining whether someone is eligible for FSCS (Financial Services Compensation Scheme) protection [#SRC:eb355065b8865baf]. At the same time, insolvency practitioners should consider their actions in line with the insolvency practitioner’s objectives and responsibilities under Section 99 of the Banking Act 2009 [#TGT:02363a43a51fdf7b]. Putting these together, the practitioner should not ignore the missing identity checks: they can use the permitted facilitation route to complete verification needed for the eligibility decision, but they must do so while keeping their broader objectives and responsibilities in view. In other words, the permission explains what the court-appointed insolvency practitioner can do to address a verification gap, and the obligation explains the lens through which insolvency practitioners should evaluate and carry out that step as part of their role.

question: In the PRA’s process for assessing whether minimum requirements applied to an entity established outside the United Kingdom exceed that entity’s portion of consolidated group requirements for the same risk type, how must the entity’s portion of the consolidated group capital requirement be determined, and which categories of requirements or risks would the PRA generally exclude from that assessment?
gold_answer: The assessment compares, for a given risk type, the minimum requirements applied to an entity established outside the United Kingdom (on an individual or sub-consolidated basis) against that entity’s share of the consolidated group requirements for the same risk [#SRC:ef9de1e6e4142317]. To determine the entity’s share of a particular consolidated group capital requirement, the consolidated group capital requirement is multiplied by the proportion of the consolidated group’s Pillar 1 RWAs attributable to that entity [#TGT:0b98872ee0444604]. The RWAs attributable to the entity are calculated as the entity’s Pillar 1 RWAs (calculated on the same basis as the group RWAs) minus the entity’s risk-weighted exposures to other group entities, so intragroup exposures are removed in the attribution step [#TGT:0b98872ee0444604]. When making the overall assessment, the PRA would not generally take into account requirements attributable to risks that are already mitigated through the risk based capital framework or by other means, or risks that net off in consolidation (with intragroup risks and offsetting positions given as examples) [#SRC:ef9de1e6e4142317].

question: When the PRA checks whether an overseas entity’s minimum requirements are higher than its part of the group requirement for the same risk, how do you work out the entity’s part using Pillar 1 RWAs, and what kinds of risks does the PRA usually leave out of that check?
gold_answer: To run the PRA’s comparison for a given risk type, you look at how the minimum requirements applied to an entity established outside the United Kingdom (on an individual or sub-consolidated basis) stack up against that entity’s share of the consolidated group requirements for the same risk [#SRC:ef9de1e6e4142317]. The entity’s share of a particular consolidated group capital requirement is calculated by taking the consolidated group capital requirement and multiplying it by the proportion of the consolidated group’s Pillar 1 RWAs that are attributable to that entity [#TGT:0b98872ee0444604]. To get the RWAs attributable to the entity, start with the entity’s Pillar 1 RWAs (calculated on the same basis as the group RWAs) and subtract the entity’s risk-weighted exposures to other group entities, which removes intragroup exposures from the attribution [#TGT:0b98872ee0444604]. In doing the assessment, the PRA would not generally count requirements linked to risks already mitigated through the risk based capital framework or by other means, and it would also generally exclude risks that net off in consolidation, such as intragroup risks and offsetting positions [#SRC:ef9de1e6e4142317].

question: When Institutions are required to publish prudential disclosures in electronic format in a single medium or location, under what circumstances may a G-SII instead place the information required under Article 441 in a separate medium or location, and how should that be reconciled with the standalone-document or distinctive-section requirement?
gold_answer: Institutions have a general obligation to make all information required under Titles II and III available electronically in a single medium or location, structured either as a standalone document providing a readily accessible source of prudential information for users, or as a distinctive, easily identifiable section included in or appended to the institutions' financial statements or financial reports [#TGT:8422ed9edcda5caa]. Against that baseline, a specific permission applies by way of derogation: where a G-SII relies on the derogation in paragraph 1, it may disclose the information required under Article 441 in a separate medium or location from the standalone document referenced in the single-medium framework [#SRC:f339ea4b3db2ad76]. Read together, the G-SII’s ability to separate the Article 441 information is conditional (it must be relying on the derogation) and limited in scope (it concerns the information required under Article 441), while the broader single-medium presentation remains the default for the overall set of required prudential disclosures. Accordingly, the compliance approach is to maintain the required single medium or location for Titles II and III disclosures, while using the permitted separation only for the specified Article 441 content when the derogation conditions are met.

question: Institutions must put required prudential disclosures online in one place. If the Institution is a G-SII, when can it put the information required under Article 441 somewhere else, and what still has to be true about the main disclosure document or section?
gold_answer: Institutions are required to disclose all information required under Titles II and III in electronic format and in a single medium or location, and that single location must take a defined form: either a standalone document that is readily accessible for users of prudential information, or a distinctive section included in or appended to the institutions’ financial statements or financial reports that contains the required disclosures and is easily identifiable to those users [#TGT:8422ed9edcda5caa]. For a G-SII, there is a limited permission that departs from that single-location approach: by way of derogation, where the G-SII relies on the derogation in paragraph 1, it may disclose the information required under Article 441 in a separate medium or location from the standalone document used for the single-medium framework [#SRC:f339ea4b3db2ad76]. This means the “somewhere else” option is not automatic; it depends on the G-SII relying on the derogation, and it applies only to the Article 441 information. The main single medium or location requirement, and the need for a readily accessible standalone document or clearly identifiable section, still frames how the overall disclosures are presented.

question: For Supervisory Statement 2/19 on the PRA approach to interpreting reporting and disclosure requirements and regulatory transactions forms after EU withdrawal, how should a firm reconcile the Supervisory Statement reference in the source listing with the dated Bank of England publication entry, including the applicable timing indicated?
gold_answer: A firm should treat the two entries as referring to the same Supervisory Statement and use them together to identify both the instrument and its publication timing in the context of the PRA’s approach to interpreting reporting and disclosure requirements and regulatory transactions forms after withdrawal from the EU. The source provides the core identification of the document as “Supervisory Statement (SS) 2/19” and its subject matter—how the PRA approaches interpretation of reporting and disclosure requirements and regulatory transactions forms after EU withdrawal—so it anchors what the material is and the regulatory topic it addresses [#SRC:4cab36a7d094e1aa]. The target then adds the concrete timing detail by listing “December 2020” alongside “Supervisory Statement 2/19” and associates it with a Bank of England publication page, which supports locating the relevant publication entry for that same Supervisory Statement and confirms the date to be used for internal tracking and referencing [#TGT:6be01175d4277214]. Read together, the firm can cite SS 2/19 for the interpretive approach and record December 2020 as the dated publication entry for governance, audit trails, and document control.

question: When you are documenting the PRA approach to interpreting reporting and disclosure requirements and regulatory transactions forms after EU withdrawal, how do you link the Supervisory Statement (SS) 2/19 mention in the source to the Bank of England entry that includes a date, and what date should you record?
gold_answer: You should link the two references by matching the Supervisory Statement identifier and topic, then use the target entry to capture the date for your records. The source names the document as Supervisory Statement (SS) 2/19 and describes its purpose as the PRA approach to interpreting reporting and disclosure requirements and regulatory transactions forms after EU withdrawal, which tells you exactly which Supervisory Statement your documentation should point to [#SRC:4cab36a7d094e1aa]. The target repeats the same Supervisory Statement 2/19 title and frames it as a Bank of England publication entry, but crucially it adds the specific timing detail “December 2020,” which is the date you should record in your compliance inventory or policy cross-reference [#TGT:6be01175d4277214]. Using both together ensures your documentation is consistent: SS 2/19 is the referenced interpretive statement, and December 2020 is the dated publication entry you can use for version control and evidence of the relevant publication listing.

question: When an institution that acts as a clearing member calculates the own funds requirement for its exposures to a client using the specified method, is it permitted to apply the fixed maturity factor in that calculation and, in parallel, to rely on the reduced exposure at default produced by the relevant calculation steps when determining its own funds requirements for CVA risk?
gold_answer: Yes. Where an institution that acts as a clearing member uses the method set out in Section 5 to calculate the own funds requirement for its exposures to a client, it is permitted to apply a maturity factor of 0.21 within that client-exposure own-funds calculation [#TGT:f6e5657c2d3e0f5e]. Separately, for the purposes of calculating its own funds requirements for CVA risk, an institution that acts as a clearing member may use the reduced exposure at default that results from the calculations set out in the relevant paragraphs, provided it is using that reduced exposure at default specifically for its CVA own-funds requirement determination [#SRC:e0f6e3ca4abbfbea]. Read together, the permissions operate on two linked but distinct inputs to own-funds computations: the TARGET permits a particular maturity factor when the clearing member is calculating the own-funds requirement for exposures to a client using the stated method, while the SOURCE permits the clearing member to carry forward a reduced exposure at default (as calculated under the referenced steps) into its CVA risk own-funds requirement calculation. Both permissions are framed for the same actor and are conditional on using the specified calculation approaches for the respective purposes.

question: If an institution that acts as a clearing member is working out its own funds requirement for exposures to a client using the stated method, can it use the set maturity factor, and can it also use the reduced exposure at default from the relevant calculation steps when it later calculates its own funds requirements for CVA risk?
gold_answer: It can, provided the conditions in each permission are met. For the client-exposure calculation, where an institution that acts as a clearing member uses the method set out in Section 5 to calculate the own funds requirement for its exposures to a client, that institution may use a maturity factor of 0.21 in that calculation [#TGT:f6e5657c2d3e0f5e]. For CVA risk, an institution that acts as a clearing member may use the reduced exposure at default that results from the calculations set out in the referenced paragraphs, but only for the purpose of calculating its own funds requirements for CVA risk [#SRC:e0f6e3ca4abbfbea]. In other words, the TARGET permission is about a specific parameter (the maturity factor) inside the own-funds calculation for exposures to a client when the stated method is used, while the SOURCE permission is about using a reduced exposure at default (as produced by the specified calculation steps) as an input when calculating own funds requirements for CVA risk. Both apply to the same type of institution acting as a clearing member, but each applies in its own calculation context.

question: If a firm outsources a function or any insurance or reinsurance activity, what must it do with the terms and conditions in the written agreement to make sure it still meets all of its obligations?
gold_answer: If a firm outsources a function or any insurance or reinsurance activity, it must not assume that the outsourcing provider takes over regulatory accountability. The firm remains fully responsible for discharging all of its obligations under the PRA rules, FSMA, and any other laws, rules, regulations and administrative provisions deriving from FSMA that apply to UK Solvency II firms [#TGT:c0c1ed2e69073245]. Because that responsibility continues, the firm must ensure the terms and conditions of the written agreement are consistent with the firm’s obligations as set out in the obligations framework referenced by the source requirement [#SRC:21f32c39e40bb35a]. Put simply, the written agreement must be written and agreed in a way that supports—rather than conflicts with—the firm’s ability to comply with its obligations while the outsourced work is carried out. The firm should review the agreement’s terms and conditions with this in mind so that the outsourcing arrangement does not create contractual barriers to meeting those continuing obligations.

question: If an institution has to work out risk-weighted exposure amounts for its trade exposures with CCPs, can it set the exposure value to zero for some collateral exposures, and when does that apply if a CCP or clearing member becomes insolvent?
gold_answer: The institution must calculate the risk-weighted exposure amounts for its trade exposures with CCPs by summing the exposure values of its trade exposures with CCPs (calculated under the specified paragraphs) and then multiplying that total by the risk weight determined under the specified paragraph [#SRC:99cd1305ee2e0e40]. Separately, the institution may, as a derogation, assign an exposure value of zero to the counterparty credit risk exposures for assets it has posted as collateral to a CCP or to a clearing member, but only if those collateral assets are bankruptcy remote when insolvency occurs [#TGT:3efc66c18754eca4]. The insolvency trigger is not limited to the CCP itself: the condition is met if the CCP, the clearing member, or one or more other clients of the clearing member becomes insolvent, provided the posted collateral remains bankruptcy remote in that scenario. In effect, the required CCP trade-exposure calculation uses exposure values, and the permission allows certain qualifying collateral-related exposure values to be reduced to zero before they feed into the summed amount.

question: What does the PRA say its statement is adding to its insurance supervision approach, and what is the named document it points to as the baseline for that approach?
gold_answer: The PRA explains that its statement is meant to add detail to its existing insurance supervision approach by expanding on the PRA’s general approach and then setting out the PRA’s expectations of firms in a clear and consistent way for the specific areas covered by the statement [#SRC:679004eaf3c19064]. In other words, the statement is not presented as a standalone approach; it is positioned as building on an already-published framework for how the PRA supervises insurance. The baseline document the PRA points to for that general approach is explicitly identified as “The Prudential Regulation Authority’s approach to insurance supervision, June 2014,” with a link to the publication [#TGT:ca54d7921f57df42]. The PRA also explains why it is providing this additional clarity: it seeks to advance its statutory objectives by supporting the safety and soundness of the firms it regulates and contributing to an appropriate degree of protection for policyholders [#SRC:679004eaf3c19064]. Finally, the PRA notes that it has considered matters it is required to have regard to and considers the statement compatible with the Regulatory Principles and relevant provisions of the Legislative and Regulatory Reform Act 2006 [#SRC:679004eaf3c19064].

question: In documenting the calculation workflow, what linkage must be shown between the defined meaning of the multiplier as a formula-based multiplication factor and the mandatory calculation steps that apply for the stated purpose?
gold_answer: The workflow documentation should explicitly connect the term’s definition to the calculation procedure so that an auditor can see that the firm is computing the correct concept in the required way. The definition fixes the meaning of “multiplier” as the multiplication factor that is calculated in accordance with the formula that the definition points to, so the documentation must identify that the multiplier is not merely any scaling number but the specific factor produced by that referenced formula [#SRC:9f9ce1a7bc7b7a33]. The procedural text then imposes a mandatory requirement that, for the relevant purpose, the multiplier “shall be calculated as follows,” which means the firm must follow the prescribed calculation steps rather than an informal or approximate method [#TGT:bd4335a117dddc31]. Therefore, the linkage to show is: the procedure’s step-by-step computation is the mechanism used to generate the defined multiplication factor, and the output of those steps is recorded and labeled as the “multiplier” only because it is derived in accordance with the referenced formula and calculated under the mandatory procedural instruction [#SRC:9f9ce1a7bc7b7a33] [#TGT:bd4335a117dddc31].

question: When a firm is investing in assets covering technical provisions for linked long-term contracts of insurance, in what circumstances must it still apply the PRA’s expectation to limit its investment where there is insufficient data to quantify asset risks, and when is that expectation outside scope?
gold_answer: The PRA’s expectation that a firm should limit its investment appropriately where there is insufficient data to quantify the risks arises when the firm is considering the nature and quantification of risks for each category of asset and for individual assets [#TGT:f36a81ef70fe60e8]. However, the scope of the relevant part of the chapter is restricted for firms investing in assets that cover technical provisions (TPs) for linked long-term contracts of insurance: those provisions do not apply to such firms, except in a specific carve-in [#SRC:e5c80b0f218c00c6]. The carve-in is where the assets are held to cover the additional TPs in respect of policyholder liabilities, including liabilities for any guarantee of investment performance or other guaranteed benefit provided under those linked long-term contracts [#SRC:e5c80b0f218c00c6]. Accordingly, the firm should treat the expectation to limit investment due to insufficient risk data as applicable when the assets fall within that exception (ie, held for additional TPs tied to policyholder liabilities and guarantees), and as not applicable under this chapter where the assets merely cover TPs for linked long-term contracts without meeting the exception [#SRC:e5c80b0f218c00c6] [#TGT:f36a81ef70fe60e8].

question: If a firm is investing in assets for linked long-term insurance contracts, does it still have to limit investments when it cannot quantify the risks due to insufficient data, and what is the key exception that changes the scope?
gold_answer: A firm is expected by the PRA to limit its investment appropriately where there is insufficient data to quantify the risks, as part of its consideration of the nature and quantification of risks for each category of asset and for individual assets [#TGT:f36a81ef70fe60e8]. But the chapter material that frames this expectation has a scope exclusion for firms investing in assets covering technical provisions (TPs) for linked long-term contracts of insurance [#SRC:e5c80b0f218c00c6]. That means, for assets that simply cover TPs for linked long-term contracts, the relevant paragraphs do not apply to the firm [#SRC:e5c80b0f218c00c6]. The key exception is where the assets are held to cover the additional TPs in respect of policyholder liabilities, including liabilities for any guarantee of investment performance or other guaranteed benefit under those linked long-term contracts [#SRC:e5c80b0f218c00c6]. In that exception case, the scope exclusion does not apply, so the firm should treat the PRA’s expectation to limit investment when risk data is insufficient as applying to those assets and the related risk assessment activity [#TGT:f36a81ef70fe60e8] [#SRC:e5c80b0f218c00c6].

question: When this Part is applied on a group basis, how should the scope of the group be determined across all undertakings within the relevant group, and how is that scope affected if the PRA grants a waiver or if a supervisory authority acting as the group supervisor decides not to include an undertaking in group supervision?
gold_answer: When this Part applies at the level of a group, the starting point for scope is that the group is defined to consist of all undertakings within the relevant group, subject to the stated qualifications and conditions attached to that group-level application [#SRC:5b84eae896bfe57f]. However, that baseline “all undertakings” composition is not absolute: the scope can be narrowed where the PRA has granted a waiver, or where a supervisory authority which is the group supervisor has decided—using the Solvency II EEA implementing measures implementing Article 214 of the Solvency II Directive—not to include a particular undertaking in the group supervision that is being applied on that group basis [#TGT:835e743b1b5b8d84]. Read together, the provisions mean you should first identify the relevant group and the undertakings within it for purposes of applying this Part at group level, and then check whether any undertaking is carved out from inclusion in group supervision due to either a PRA waiver or a group supervisor decision under the referenced Solvency II implementing framework, in which case that undertaking is not included for the group supervision in question.

question: If this Part applies to a group, does it cover every undertaking in the relevant group, or can an undertaking be left out when the PRA gives a waiver or when the group supervisor decides not to include it in group supervision?
gold_answer: If this Part applies at the level of a group, the default scope is broad: the group is treated as consisting of all undertakings within the relevant group, subject to the stated limitations and conditions that qualify that group-level application [#SRC:5b84eae896bfe57f]. But the target text makes clear that an undertaking can be excluded from the group supervision that applies on that group basis in specific situations: either the PRA has granted a waiver, or a supervisory authority which is the group supervisor has decided—following Solvency II EEA implementing measures implementing Article 214 of the Solvency II Directive—not to include that undertaking in the group supervision [#TGT:835e743b1b5b8d84]. Putting both together, you should assume all undertakings in the relevant group are in scope when applying this Part at group level, and then confirm whether any undertaking is removed from that scope because a waiver or a group supervisor decision has been made to exclude it from group supervision. This approach reconciles the general “all undertakings” group definition with the explicit exclusion mechanism described for group supervision.

question: If a firm needs to appoint an external auditor to carry out the required functions, what must the firm do before it appoints the auditor, and how does that fit with the requirement to appoint the external auditor in accordance with the auditor provisions?
gold_answer: The firm has to meet both requirements as part of one compliant appointment process. On the one hand, it must appoint an external auditor in accordance with the specified auditor provisions, and the appointment must be to perform the relevant functions referred to in that obligation [#SRC:6499d8de81f4da18].
