The target further indicates that, when considering whether an arrangement with a third party falls within the outsourcing definition, firms should consider whether the third party will perform the relevant function or service (or part of it) on a recurrent or ongoing basis [#TGT:b7ac6dbd1a20206b]. If the arrangement does not meet that outsourcing definition, the source text states that existing outsourcing requirements only apply to “outsourcing” as defined and do not apply to other arrangements between firms and third parties that fall outside the definition [#SRC:ae60277c11940928].

question: If a firm has a contract with an organisation to provide a product or service, when does that relationship count as “outsourcing” instead of just a third‑party arrangement, and what does the firm need to check about what the provider does and how often they do it?
gold_answer: First, confirm the provider fits the “third party” concept used in the source text: it is an organisation that has entered into a business relationship or contract with the firm to provide a product or service [#SRC:ae60277c11940928]. Next, decide whether the arrangement is “outsourcing” under the PRA Rulebook definition. It is outsourcing where the service provider (whether a supervised entity or not) performs a process, service, or activity—either directly or through sub-outsourcing—that the firm would otherwise carry out itself [#TGT:b7ac6dbd1a20206b]. The target also explains that, when judging whether an arrangement with a third party falls within the outsourcing definition, firms should consider whether the third party will perform the relevant function or service (or part of it) on a recurrent or ongoing basis [#TGT:b7ac6dbd1a20206b]. If the arrangement does not meet the outsourcing definition, the source text states that existing outsourcing requirements only apply to “outsourcing” and do not apply to other arrangements between firms and third parties that fall outside that definition [#SRC:ae60277c11940928].

question: When a credit union provides a subordinated loan, what must it do before providing the loan regarding assessing the financial implications, and what record-retention obligation applies to the written record of that assessment, including the retention period and when it starts?
gold_answer: A credit union must complete an assessment of the financial implications of making a subordinated loan before it provides that subordinated loan, so the assessment is a pre-condition to provision rather than a post-event formality [#TGT:070e1e95885eea3e]. In addition, once the subordinated loan has been made, the credit union must keep documentary evidence of that pre-loan assessment: it must retain a written record of the assessment for five years, with the retention clock running from the date of the subordinated loan [#SRC:33b846227c3ca9b2]. Read together, these obligations require both (i) timely completion of the financial-implications assessment prior to provision and (ii) ongoing governance and auditability through preservation of the written record for the full five-year period following the loan date. Practically, the credit union should ensure the assessment is documented in writing at the time it is carried out (so it can be retained) and that its recordkeeping controls can demonstrate continuous retention for the entire five-year period after the subordinated loan date, since the retention duty is explicitly tied to that date [#SRC:33b846227c3ca9b2] and the assessment duty is explicitly tied to the period prior to provision [#TGT:070e1e95885eea3e].

question: Before a credit union provides a subordinated loan, what assessment must it do, and after the loan date how long must it keep the written record of that assessment?
gold_answer: Before providing a subordinated loan, a credit union must carry out an assessment of the financial implications of making the loan; this is required to happen prior to provision, not after the fact [#TGT:070e1e95885eea3e]. Once the subordinated loan has been made, the credit union must also keep evidence that it performed that assessment by retaining a written record of it. The retention obligation is time-bound and event-triggered: the written record must be retained for five years, and the five-year period runs following the date of the subordinated loan [#SRC:33b846227c3ca9b2]. Taken together, the requirements mean the credit union needs both (1) a completed financial-implications assessment before it provides the subordinated loan and (2) a written record of that assessment that is preserved for the full five-year period after the loan date. This pairing ensures the assessment is done at the correct time and that the credit union can later demonstrate, through retained documentation, that it complied with the pre-provision assessment requirement [#TGT:070e1e95885eea3e] and the post-loan record-retention requirement [#SRC:33b846227c3ca9b2].

question: When you assess a model’s complexity, what risk factors should you look at across the modelling process, and what does “designer or data bias” mean so you can decide whether it needs to be considered as part of that complexity assessment?
gold_answer: When assessing a model’s complexity, you should consider the risk factors that impact the model’s inherent risk within each component of the modelling process. This includes reviewing the nature and quality of the input data, the choice of methodology (including assumptions), the requirements and integrity of implementation, and how frequently and/or extensively the model is used [#SRC:81ef096859a0c253]. If it is necessary—especially where newly advanced approaches or technologies are involved—the complexity assessment may also take into account additional risk factors, including the use of alternative and unstructured data and measures of interpretability, explainability, transparency, and whether designer or data bias could be present [#SRC:81ef096859a0c253]. “Designer or data bias” means that elements of a dataset (or, alternatively, aspects of model design) are more heavily weighted and/or represented than others, and that this can produce results with ethical and/or social implications [#TGT:330cb726532ca174]. Using that definition, you should treat any disproportionate weighting or representation—whether coming from the data or the model design—as a specific risk factor to be considered within the overall complexity assessment, alongside the other modelling-process factors [#SRC:81ef096859a0c253] [#TGT:330cb726532ca174].

question: How must Institutions handle publication of the disclosures required under Titles II and III when they are not subject to the provisions that otherwise set the manner of publication, and what does that imply for the frequency of disclosing the information outlined below?
gold_answer: Institutions have a baseline obligation to publish the disclosures required under Titles II and III, and that publication is to be done in the manner set out in the referenced publication framework [#SRC:a2135b9576433803]. Where Institutions are not subject to the specific provisions that would otherwise govern that framework, they are still required to disclose the information outlined below, but the applicable obligation is framed in terms of doing so with a specified frequency [#TGT:8b9c1538e39a6dc4]. Read together, this means the actor remains “Institutions” in both cases, and the compliance outcome remains disclosure/publication of the required information; however, the operational emphasis shifts depending on whether the Institution is subject to the relevant publication provisions. If it is not subject to them, the Institution must follow the frequency requirement attached to the outlined information, rather than relying on those provisions to determine how the disclosures are delivered. In practice, Institutions should ensure that their Titles II and III disclosures are produced and made available, and that the timing of the disclosures aligns with the frequency specified for the outlined information when the Institution falls outside the scope of those provisions [#SRC:a2135b9576433803] [#TGT:8b9c1538e39a6dc4].

question: Where a firm acts as an originator, original lender, and/or sponsor in a securitisation, how must the firm’s internal audit function provide assurance that the firm’s involvement is compliant, including confirming that the securitisation’s underlying exposures must not include securitisation positions?
gold_answer: Where a firm acts as an originator, original lender, and/or sponsor in a transaction that is subject to the requirements of the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook, the PRA expects the firm’s internal audit function to provide assurance that the firm’s involvement in the securitisation is compliant with the applicable requirements referenced for that framework [#SRC:cecc17757525a70b]. As part of providing that assurance, the internal audit function should explicitly test and evidence that the securitisation structure and asset pool respects the prohibition on the composition of underlying exposures—specifically, that the underlying exposures used in the securitisation do not include securitisation positions [#TGT:d7fccee9ffee99cb]. In practice, this means the internal audit function’s assurance work should cover both (i) the firm’s role-based involvement in the transaction (as originator, original lender, and/or sponsor) and (ii) the transaction’s compliance with the prohibition on including securitisation positions within the underlying exposures, so that the firm can demonstrate that its involvement is compliant with the relevant requirements as expected by the PRA [#SRC:cecc17757525a70b] and that the prohibited exposure composition is avoided [#TGT:d7fccee9ffee99cb].

question: If a firm is an originator, original lender, or sponsor in a securitisation, what does the PRA expect the internal audit function to check, and how should it make sure the deal does not use underlying exposures that include securitisation positions?
gold_answer: When a firm acts as an originator, original lender, and/or sponsor in a transaction that is subject to the requirements of the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook, the PRA expects the firm’s internal audit function to provide assurance that the firm’s involvement in the securitisation complies with the relevant requirements in that framework [#SRC:cecc17757525a70b]. A key part of that assurance should be confirming that the securitisation’s underlying exposures meet the prohibition on what can be included in the pool: the underlying exposures used in a securitisation must not include securitisation positions [#TGT:d7fccee9ffee99cb]. To satisfy the PRA’s expectation, the internal audit function should therefore review how the firm is involved in the transaction (in its capacity as originator, original lender, and/or sponsor) and also verify, based on the transaction’s underlying exposures, that no securitisation positions are included. This links the internal audit assurance obligation about the firm’s compliant involvement [#SRC:cecc17757525a70b] with the specific prohibited feature of the securitisation’s exposure composition [#TGT:d7fccee9ffee99cb].

question: How must a firm align its interest rate risk governance for non-trading activities so that the systems it implements to identify, evaluate and manage that risk also support the institution-level obligation to disclose quantitative and qualitative information on the resulting impacts on economic value of equity and net interest income?
gold_answer: A firm must put in place systems that identify, evaluate and manage the risk from potential changes in interest rates affecting its non-trading activities, including where those changes impact one or both relevant outcomes for those activities [#TGT:70fc9e8a73e07e79]. In parallel, institutions must disclose quantitative and qualitative information about the risks from potential interest rate changes as they affect both the economic value of equity and the net interest income of their non-trading book activities [#SRC:c4b6e2c4dc5015d9]. Read together, the systems requirement should be implemented in a way that produces and maintains the risk identification, evaluation and management outputs needed to underpin the required disclosures, covering both dimensions (economic value of equity and net interest income) for the non-trading book. This means the firm’s systems should be capable of capturing and assessing interest rate change risk across non-trading activities and translating that assessment into information suitable for institution disclosures that are both quantitative (measurable impacts) and qualitative (descriptive risk information), ensuring consistency between internal risk management and external disclosure.

question: What does a firm need to do to manage interest rate change risk in its non-trading activities, and how does that connect to what institutions must disclose about the effects on economic value of equity and net interest income?
gold_answer: A firm must implement systems that identify, evaluate and manage the risk from potential changes in interest rates that affect the firm’s non-trading activities, including where those changes impact one or both relevant effects for those activities [#TGT:70fc9e8a73e07e79]. Separately, institutions must disclose both quantitative and qualitative information about the risks from potential interest rate changes as they affect both the economic value of equity and the net interest income of their non-trading book activities [#SRC:c4b6e2c4dc5015d9]. Taken together, the firm’s systems should be designed and operated so they generate the information needed for those disclosures: they should enable the firm to spot and assess interest rate risk in non-trading activities and to manage it, while also producing outputs that can be reported as numbers and narrative. The disclosures must cover both economic value of equity and net interest income for the non-trading book, so the systems should support analysis and reporting across both of those impact measures.

question: If the financial conglomerate is a third country financial conglomerate, do the rules still require a firm to keep enough capital resources at all times to make the financial conglomerate’s capital resources adequate, or are those rules switched off for that situation?
gold_answer: The requirement on its face is continuous: a firm must at all times have capital resources of the right amount and type so that the capital resources of the financial conglomerate are adequate [#TGT:bb825e3fc5dd5d17]. But the scope text adds an important boundary: the rules in the listed provisions, including Chapter 7, do not apply with respect to a third country financial conglomerate [#SRC:326d068c15dba31a]. Putting these together, you need to classify the financial conglomerate first. If it is a third country financial conglomerate, then the identified rules are stated not to apply “with respect to” that conglomerate, which means the obligations contained in those rules are not intended to operate for that third country case [#SRC:326d068c15dba31a]. If the financial conglomerate is not a third country financial conglomerate, the scope carve-out does not apply, and the firm remains subject to the ongoing obligation to maintain capital resources that make the financial conglomerate’s capital resources adequate [#TGT:bb825e3fc5dd5d17].

question: If a TWD firm needs to update the TWD option within weeks, how should it decide what counts as a “material component,” and what must it set up so it can consistently refresh assumptions, modelling/methodology, and scenario factors when changes could affect decisions?
gold_answer: A TWD firm must be able to refresh the material components of the TWD option within weeks through a “full plan refresh,” which includes updating the assumptions and approximations that inform the TWD option, updating the modelling or methodology used for information provision and decision-making, and updating the factors that make up the TWD scenario [#SRC:76a8dbf9e47fc1dd]. To decide what is in scope for that refresh, material components are those where the impact of a change could influence decision-making, and TWD firms must define what they mean by “material component” and set thresholds for what level of change is treated as material [#TGT:8d564dede4742c2a]. In practice, the firm’s definitions and thresholds provide the consistent trigger points for identifying decision-relevant changes and ensuring they are captured in the full plan refresh within the required weeks-long timeframe, rather than being handled ad hoc or inconsistently across different assumptions, methods, or scenario drivers.

question: For purposes of the Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) supervisory statement setting expectations on banks’ model risk management, which types of firms fall within scope, and which categories are expressly outside scope despite the use of the term “banks” in the title?
gold_answer: The Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) supervisory statement is framed as setting out the PRA’s expectations for banks’ model risk management (MRM), and it also makes clear that the PRA considers model risk to be a risk in its own right [#SRC:af03f7cbf472c97d]. Read together with the scope clarification, the expectations are not limited only to entities commonly described as “banks” in ordinary language: the scope includes banks, building societies, and designated investment firms [#TGT:c120c182f73a34aa]. At the same time, the use of “banks” in the title is specifically intended to signal an exclusion: the expectations do not apply to insurers or reinsurers [#TGT:c120c182f73a34aa]. Accordingly, when applying the PRA’s MRM expectations, firms should determine applicability by reference to the stated scope categories (banks, building societies, and designated investment firms) and should treat insurers and reinsurers as out of scope, even though the statement’s title uses the term “banks” [#SRC:af03f7cbf472c97d] [#TGT:c120c182f73a34aa].

question: When updating the insurer’s liquidity risk management strategy and relevant policies, what governance and prudential risk management elements must an insurer have in place to ensure the update is aligned with its required system of governance and information flows to management or the board?
gold_answer: When an insurer updates its liquidity risk management strategy and relevant policies, it should do so within the framework of the effective system of governance and prudential risk management systems it is required to establish [#TGT:e007010cf752bc53]. Practically, the update should be anchored to the insurer’s risk appetite or tolerance for risk, and supported by a defined process to identify, measure, and monitor risk so that liquidity-related risks are assessed consistently and the strategy and policies remain coherent with the insurer’s overall risk approach [#TGT:e007010cf752bc53]. The insurer must also ensure it has appropriate systems to convey relevant information arising from the liquidity strategy and policy update to management or the board, so that decision-makers receive the necessary inputs and oversight can be exercised effectively [#TGT:e007010cf752bc53]. In this context, the liquidity risk management strategy and relevant policies are specifically described as being used for update purposes, reinforcing that the insurer should treat liquidity strategy and policy maintenance as an ongoing governance activity rather than a one-off exercise [#SRC:8cda5a0f7fa9c1dd].

question: Before providing any attestation, what must a firm do to demonstrate that the fundamental spread reflects compensation for all retained risks and that the matching adjustment can be earned with a high degree of confidence, and how must the firm then address any risks identified when it applies the matching adjustment?
gold_answer: Before providing any attestation, a firm must carry out an analysis and justification showing two linked points: first, that the fundamental spread it uses reflects compensation for all retained risks; and second, that the matching adjustment can be earned with a high degree of confidence from the assets held in the relevant portfolio of assets [#TGT:4d06c3de64a9c9ce]. Where the firm applies the matching adjustment, it must also manage any risks that are identified in the analysis undertaken for that purpose [#SRC:afd68bad9897c2bc]. Read together, this means the firm’s pre-attestation work is not limited to a narrative justification; it must be sufficiently risk-focused to identify the retained risks relevant to the fundamental spread and the confidence in earning the matching adjustment, and it must then translate those identified risks into active risk management when the matching adjustment is applied. The firm should ensure the analysis and justification are aligned with the relevant portfolio of assets and that the resulting risk management actions address the specific risks surfaced by that analysis, so the attestation is supported by both the documented assessment and the firm’s ongoing management of the identified risks.

question: Before a firm gives an attestation, what analysis and justification must it do about retained risks and earning the matching adjustment, and what must it do with any risks that analysis identifies when it applies the matching adjustment?
gold_answer: Before giving an attestation, a firm must analyse and justify that the fundamental spread it uses reflects compensation for all retained risks, and that the matching adjustment can be earned with a high degree of confidence from the assets held in the relevant portfolio of assets [#TGT:4d06c3de64a9c9ce]. Separately, when the firm applies the matching adjustment, it must manage any risks that are identified in the analysis undertaken for that purpose [#SRC:afd68bad9897c2bc]. Putting these together, the firm’s work before the attestation should be structured to identify the retained risks that matter to the fundamental spread and to support the conclusion about earning the matching adjustment from the relevant portfolio. Then, the firm must not leave those identified risks as theoretical findings: it must actively manage them as part of applying the matching adjustment. In practice, the analysis and justification should be consistent with the assets in the relevant portfolio and should clearly surface the risks that are being retained, because those are the risks the firm must be prepared to manage once it applies the matching adjustment.

question: When Institutions calculate replacement cost for a single netting set that is subject to a margin agreement (and is not within the separate treatment referenced for certain cases), what margin factor must be applied for the transactions that fall within the netting sets cross-referred to in the relevant provision, and how does that requirement integrate into the replacement cost calculation obligation?
gold_answer: Institutions must calculate the replacement cost for single netting sets that are subject to margin agreements, except where the netting set falls under the separate treatment referenced for certain cases, and they must do so using the prescribed formula-based approach for that replacement cost calculation [#TGT:19512cdca8e04e88]. Within that calculation framework, where the replacement cost computation concerns transactions that are included in the specific netting sets that are cross-referred to in the relevant provision, Institutions must apply a margin factor (MF) equal to 0.42 for those transactions [#SRC:465c803c2a417476]. Read together, the obligation is twofold: (1) Institutions are required to perform a replacement cost calculation for each qualifying single netting set subject to a margin agreement using the stated formula approach, and (2) in populating that formula for the subset of transactions that are included in the cross-referred netting sets, Institutions must use MF = 0.42 as the applicable factor. This ensures consistent parameterisation of the replacement cost calculation for those transactions under the margin agreement context.

question: If Institutions are working out replacement cost for a single netting set under a margin agreement (and it is not in the separate treatment mentioned), what MF value must they use for transactions that sit in the cross-referred netting sets, and where does that MF fit into what they must calculate?
gold_answer: Institutions have to calculate the replacement cost for each single netting set that is subject to a margin agreement, except for those netting sets that fall under the separate treatment mentioned, and they must do this using the required formula-based method for replacement cost [#TGT:19512cdca8e04e88]. For the part of that calculation that relates to transactions included in the specific netting sets that are cross-referred to in the relevant provision, Institutions must set the margin factor (MF) to 0.42 [#SRC:465c803c2a417476]. In practice, this means the replacement cost calculation obligation tells Institutions what they must compute (replacement cost for the qualifying single netting set using the formula), while the MF requirement tells them the exact parameter value they must plug in when the transactions being captured are those included in the cross-referred netting sets. The two requirements operate together: the formula-based replacement cost calculation is mandatory, and MF = 0.42 is mandatory for that defined subset of transactions.

question: When a firm is justifying that commensurate risk has been transferred for a portfolio of Standardised Approach exposures, what must it do to align with the PRA’s approach to assessing commensurate risk transfer for SA portfolios, specifically regarding tranche thickness and the comparison of detachment points to the portfolio’s K SA?
gold_answer: For portfolios of Standardised Approach (SA) exposures, a firm must apply the PRA’s approach to assessing commensurate risk transfer (CRT) for SA portfolios by addressing both the structure of the tranches used for transfer and the quantitative support for its CRT justification. In practice, the PRA expects the firm to consider, prudently, the thickness of any tranches sold to third parties and any tranches on which protection is purchased, as these are the instruments through which risk transfer is being asserted [#TGT:0d7fe241ffc2c78c]. In addition, when the firm is justifying that commensurate risk has been transferred, it must compare the detachment point (D) of the relevant tranches (sold or protected) against the portfolio’s K SA, which is defined using the risk-weighted exposure amount for the underlying exposures as if they had not been securitised, scaled by 8% and divided by the value of the underlying exposures [#TGT:0d7fe241ffc2c78c]. These expectations operationalise the PRA’s stated approach to assessing CRT for SA portfolios [#SRC:621804de98de0e6a] by linking prudent tranche design considerations to an explicit D-versus-K SA comparison in the firm’s CRT justification.

question: If a firm says it has transferred enough risk on a Standardised Approach exposure portfolio, what does it have to do under the PRA’s approach to assessing CRT for SA portfolios, including how it should look at tranche thickness and what it must compare the detachment point to?
gold_answer: Where a firm is seeking to justify that commensurate risk has been transferred for a portfolio of Standardised Approach (SA) exposures, it must follow the PRA’s approach to assessing CRT for SA portfolios by doing two connected things. First, the PRA expects the firm to take a prudent view of the thickness of the tranches that are actually used to transfer risk—meaning tranches sold to third parties and/or tranches on which protection is purchased—because those tranche features are part of how the firm is demonstrating CRT [#TGT:0d7fe241ffc2c78c]. Second, when making the CRT justification, the PRA expects the firm to compare the detachment point (D) of the tranches sold or protected against the portfolio’s K SA, which is calculated using the risk-weighted exposure amount of the underlying exposures as if they had not been securitised, multiplied by 8% and divided by the value of the underlying exposures [#TGT:0d7fe241ffc2c78c]. Together, these steps reflect and implement the PRA’s stated approach to assessing commensurate risk transfer for SA portfolios [#SRC:621804de98de0e6a].

question: When a firm is unable to evidence that its operational arrangements support recovery and resolution, what minimum description must it be able to provide about the effect on critical services if recovery options are executed or if the Bank exercises its stabilisation powers, and how should the stabilisation powers be understood for this purpose?
gold_answer: Where a firm cannot demonstrate that its operational arrangements facilitate recovery and resolution, the PRA expects the firm to make changes so that they do facilitate that outcome, with supervisory judgement applied in assessing adequacy [#SRC:69a8d0afb1f8c2dd]. As a minimum expectation, the firm must be able to describe what would happen to its critical services in two scenarios: (i) if its recovery options were executed, and (ii) if the Bank were to apply one or more of its stabilisation powers [#SRC:69a8d0afb1f8c2dd]. For the second scenario, the stabilisation powers should be understood as the Bank’s stabilisation powers as set out in s.1(4) of the Banking Act 2009 [#TGT:784dbf1f736c397d]. In practical terms, the firm’s description should connect its operational arrangements to the continuity or disruption of critical services under those recovery and stabilisation scenarios, so the PRA can judge whether changes are needed to ensure the arrangements facilitate recovery and resolution [#SRC:69a8d0afb1f8c2dd] while referencing the correct legal basis for the Bank’s stabilisation powers [#TGT:784dbf1f736c397d].

question: If a firm cannot show that its operational arrangements help recovery and resolution, what does the PRA expect the firm to be able to explain about what happens to critical services if recovery options are used or if the Bank uses its stabilisation powers, and what are those stabilisation powers?
gold_answer: If a firm cannot demonstrate how its operational arrangements facilitate recovery and resolution, the PRA expects the firm to make changes to achieve that outcome, and supervisory judgement is used to assess whether the firm has met the expectation [#SRC:69a8d0afb1f8c2dd]. At a minimum, the PRA expects firms to be able to describe what would happen to critical services in two situations: first, if the firm’s recovery options were executed; and second, if the Bank were to apply one or more of its stabilisation powers [#SRC:69a8d0afb1f8c2dd]. The stabilisation powers in this context are specifically the Bank’s stabilisation powers set out in s.1(4) of the Banking Act 2009 [#TGT:784dbf1f736c397d]. So the firm’s explanation should link its operational arrangements to the expected outcome for critical services under both recovery actions and the Bank’s use of those stabilisation powers, enabling the PRA to decide whether the firm must change its arrangements to better support recovery and resolution [#SRC:69a8d0afb1f8c2dd] while using the correct definition of the stabilisation powers [#TGT:784dbf1f736c397d].

question: Given that the reiterated valuation requirement is stated to be non-derogable, is a firm prohibited from departing from the prescribed initial-recognition valuation of financial liabilities and from later remeasuring those liabilities to reflect changes in the firm’s own credit standing?
gold_answer: Yes. The SOURCE establishes that the reiterated valuation requirement “cannot be derogated,” meaning a firm is not permitted to depart from that reiterated requirement in practice [#SRC:66ac6b27bb56a949]. Read together with the TARGET, this non-derogable status reinforces two prohibitive constraints on a firm’s treatment of financial liabilities: first, the firm must apply the specified valuation approach at initial recognition for financial liabilities referred to in UK-adopted international accounting standards, rather than using an alternative approach; and second, after initial recognition the firm is expressly prohibited from making any subsequent adjustment that takes account of changes in the firm’s own credit standing [#TGT:f26605efb3832de6]. In combination, the passages indicate there is no permissible carve-out or discretionary departure from the initial-recognition valuation requirement, and the prohibition on subsequent own-credit adjustments operates as an additional, specific restriction on later measurement. Accordingly, a firm must not attempt to derogate from the reiterated valuation requirement by either substituting a different initial-recognition method or by indirectly revising the liability’s carrying amount later to reflect its own credit standing.

question: Where a firm holds accounts on behalf of beneficiaries that contain or may contain eligible deposits, what must the firm do to ensure those accounts can be immediately identified, and what further capability and timeframe must it meet to provide separately identified details of eligible and/or ineligible accounts to the PRA or FSCS upon request?
gold_answer: A firm must implement an account-marking approach that enables immediate identification of accounts (including client accounts and trust accounts) held on behalf of beneficiaries that contain or may contain eligible deposits, so that such accounts can be promptly distinguished when needed [#TGT:68113e9f6b9da4d1]. In addition, the firm must be able to make available the details of eligible and/or ineligible accounts, with those categories separately identified, to the PRA or the FSCS in a format consistent with the relevant rule and the statement, and it must do so within twelve hours from the point of a request by the PRA or the FSCS [#SRC:abfeb4bf0c334fbc]. Taken together, the obligations require both (i) operational marking that supports immediate identification of the relevant beneficiary-held accounts and (ii) a supporting data-extraction and delivery capability that can produce the required account details, separated by eligibility status, in the specified format and within the stated response window when the PRA or FSCS requests it.

question: Where a firm has a material outsourcing arrangement, what must it do to ensure business continuity and exit strategies are in place and operationally validated, consistent with the PRA’s expectations?
gold_answer: Taken together, the SOURCE frames the relevant control objective as “business continuity and exit strategies,” while the TARGET sets out the PRA’s expectation that, for each material outsourcing arrangement, firms take specific lifecycle actions. In practice, a firm should treat business continuity and exit strategies as the required focus area [#SRC:cbf91fe709000f41] and then, for every outsourcing arrangement that is material, develop an appropriate plan or framework addressing that focus, keep it current over time, and validate it through testing, because the PRA expects firms to “develop, maintain, and test” the relevant artefact for each such arrangement [#TGT:20dec419321d50d1]. This means the obligation is not satisfied by a one-off document: the firm should (i) create the continuity and exit approach for the specific material arrangement, (ii) maintain it so it remains fit for purpose as the arrangement evolves, and (iii) test it to demonstrate it can be executed in practice. The scope trigger is materiality of the outsourcing arrangement, and the subject matter is continuity and exit.

question: If an outsourcing arrangement is material, what does the PRA expect firms to do so that business continuity and exit strategies are actually ready to use?
gold_answer: The SOURCE identifies the topic that needs to be addressed—business continuity and exit strategies [#SRC:cbf91fe709000f41]. The TARGET then explains what the PRA expects firms to do for each material outsourcing arrangement: they should develop something that covers that topic, keep it up to date, and test it [#TGT:20dec419321d50d1]. So, when a firm decides an outsourcing arrangement is material, it should ensure there is a continuity-and-exit plan (or equivalent) specifically for that arrangement, not just a general statement. The firm should also maintain it over time, meaning it should be reviewed and updated as the outsourcing arrangement, the service, or the firm’s needs change. Finally, the firm should test it so it can show the continuity and exit approach works in practice, rather than assuming it would work. The key link is: material outsourcing is the trigger, and continuity/exit is the content that must be developed, maintained, and tested.

question: Where 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies and the listed requirements are applied at the level of the group with any necessary changes, how must a firm implement its obligation to establish, implement, and maintain an effective risk-management system, and what does that imply for identifying and reporting risks on both an individual and aggregated basis across the group?
gold_answer: When 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies, the scope provision requires that the specified requirements apply “with any necessary changes” at the level of the group [#SRC:bb599b0cccb14552]. In that context, a firm’s obligation to establish, implement, and maintain an effective risk-management system must be carried out in a way that functions at group level, not only for the firm viewed in isolation [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca]. Practically, this means the firm’s strategies, processes, and reporting procedures must be capable of identifying, measuring, monitoring, managing, and reporting risks on a continuous basis in a manner that captures both (i) risks at an individual level and (ii) risks at an aggregated level, including the interdependencies among those risks, across the group as relevant [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca]. The “necessary changes” concept in the scope provision supports adapting the application of the listed requirements so the risk-management system’s design and reporting lines operate effectively at group level while still meeting the continuous, multi-level risk coverage required of a firm [#SRC:bb599b0cccb14552] [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca].

question: If 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies and the requirements must be applied at the level of the group with any needed adjustments, what does a firm have to do to make sure its risk-management system works for the group as well as for the firm itself?
gold_answer: If 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies, the scope text says the listed requirements apply at the level of the group, with any necessary changes [#SRC:bb599b0cccb14552]. In that situation, a firm must ensure its risk-management obligation is implemented in a way that is effective at group level, not just within a single entity boundary [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca]. Specifically, the firm must establish, implement, and maintain an effective risk-management system that includes strategies, processes, and reporting procedures that operate continuously and can identify, measure, monitor, manage, and report risks both at an individual level and at an aggregated level, including how those risks depend on each other [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca]. Applying the requirements “with any necessary changes” at group level means the firm should adapt how it structures and runs those strategies, processes, and reporting procedures so they can capture and communicate risk information across the group, while still meeting the continuous and multi-level risk coverage required of a firm [#SRC:bb599b0cccb14552] [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca].

question: When preparing the independent expert’s opinion on the likely effects of a scheme, what must Independent experts assess at both the firm and policyholder levels, and what specific policyholder-level prudential differentiation must they consider across different types of policyholders?
gold_answer: Independent experts must ensure their opinion on the likely effects of the scheme is assessed at two distinct levels: the firm level and the policyholder level, so that the overall impact on the firm is considered alongside the consequences for policyholders as a group and in relevant sub-groups [#SRC:64aec45ad5138f67]. When forming the policyholder-level assessment, Independent experts should also have regard to whether the scheme may create different prudential impacts for different types of policyholders, meaning the analysis should not treat all policyholders as homogeneous if the scheme could affect categories differently [#TGT:87ffe13fc26ddb10]. In practice, this requires Independent experts to structure their assessment so that the policyholder-level conclusions explicitly address potential differences between types of policyholders, including (as examples) unit-linked policyholders and with-profit policyholders, and to integrate that differentiated view into the overall opinion of likely effects [#TGT:87ffe13fc26ddb10]. This combined approach aligns the required dual-level assessment with a targeted consideration of prudential variation across policyholder types [#SRC:64aec45ad5138f67].

question: What do Independent experts need to do when they write an opinion on the likely effects of a scheme, and how should they check whether different kinds of policyholders could be affected differently at the policyholder level?
gold_answer: Independent experts need to assess the likely effects of the scheme at both the firm level and the policyholder level, so their opinion covers impacts on the firm as well as impacts on policyholders [#SRC:64aec45ad5138f67]. When they focus on the policyholder level, Independent experts should also consider whether the scheme may lead to different prudential impacts for different types of policyholders, rather than assuming the effect is the same for everyone [#TGT:87ffe13fc26ddb10]. This means the policyholder-level assessment should be framed to identify and address any prudential differences that could arise between policyholder types, including the examples of unit-linked policyholders and with-profit policyholders, if those distinctions are relevant to how the scheme operates [#TGT:87ffe13fc26ddb10]. By combining the dual-level assessment with this check for differentiated prudential impacts, Independent experts can present an opinion that reflects both the overall position and any meaningful variation within the policyholder population [#SRC:64aec45ad5138f67].

question: When setting a quantitative limit for the aggregate of debts of the relevant descriptions, how should the 5% cap be reconciled with the separate 1% cap that applies to all unsecured debts (excluding debts under the terms of debt securities and debts from a regulated institution) that are due or to become due from any one counterparty other than an individual, body corporate or group?
gold_answer: The framework presents two percentage-based constraints that must be applied in tandem when assessing exposures. First, there is a 5% limit that applies specifically “for the aggregate of debts of the descriptions” referenced in the source text, i.e., the aggregate of the debts falling within the described categories tied to 28.5, 28.6 and 28.7 [#SRC:49457b0134191ba3]. Separately, there is a 1% limit that applies to “all unsecured debts” that are due or to become due from any one counterparty, but only where those unsecured debts are not (i) debts arising under the terms of debt securities and not (ii) debts from a regulated institution; additionally, the counterparty must be “other than an individual, body corporate or group” [#TGT:cd6a8143565de2fd]. Practically, this means an unsecured-debt exposure to a single qualifying counterparty must respect the 1% cap, while the overall aggregation of debts of the specified descriptions must also remain within 5%. Both limits can be simultaneously relevant where the unsecured debts to that counterparty also fall within the described aggregate categories.

question: If you are checking limits on debts, how do you apply the 5% limit for the aggregate of debts of the relevant descriptions alongside the 1% limit for unsecured debts due or to become due from one counterparty (excluding debt securities terms and regulated institution debts, and excluding an individual, body corporate or group)?
gold_answer: You need to apply two separate percentage limits that address different scopes, and both can matter for the same set of exposures. One limit is 5% and it applies to “the aggregate of debts of the descriptions” identified in the source text, meaning you total up the debts that fall within those described categories (linked to 28.5, 28.6 and 28.7) and ensure the aggregate stays within 5% [#SRC:49457b0134191ba3]. The other limit is 1% and it applies to “all unsecured debts” that are due or to become due from any one counterparty, but only after excluding unsecured debts that arise under the terms of debt securities and excluding debts from a regulated institution; it also only applies where the counterparty is “other than an individual, body corporate or group” [#TGT:cd6a8143565de2fd]. So, for a qualifying counterparty, you must keep that counterparty’s unsecured-debt exposure within 1%, while also ensuring that the relevant described debts, in aggregate, do not exceed 5%.

question: After receiving a Part 4A permission to accept deposits, what must a firm do within three months to evidence to the PRA that its systems will support the required identification of eligible deposits, and what operational outcome must those systems achieve for deposit marking?
gold_answer: Following receipt of a Part 4A permission to accept deposits, a firm has a time-bound reporting obligation to the PRA and a related operational obligation concerning how deposits are handled. Specifically, the firm must provide the PRA with a report on its systems within three months of receiving that permission, and the report must address the firm’s systems for compliance with the relevant requirements [#SRC:e1ca6e2e43062558]. In parallel, the firm’s systems and processes must ensure that eligible deposits are marked in a manner that enables immediate identification of those deposits, meaning the marking approach must support prompt recognition without delay in practice [#TGT:60b306349873ce31]. Read together, the report to the PRA should therefore cover how the firm’s systems are designed and operated to deliver this immediate-identification outcome for eligible deposits, including the mechanisms by which deposits are marked and how that marking is relied upon to distinguish eligible deposits as soon as needed [#SRC:e1ca6e2e43062558] [#TGT:60b306349873ce31].

question: If a firm has just received a Part 4A permission to accept deposits, what must it send to the PRA within three months, and what must its deposit-marking method allow staff or systems to do for eligible deposits?
gold_answer: A firm that has received a Part 4A permission to accept deposits must meet both a reporting requirement and an operational requirement that the report should address. Within three months of receiving the permission, the firm must provide the PRA with a report describing its systems for complying with the applicable requirements, so the PRA can understand how the firm intends to meet those obligations in practice [#SRC:e1ca6e2e43062558]. At the same time, the firm must ensure that eligible deposits are marked in a way that allows those deposits to be identified immediately, which means the marking must be set up so eligible deposits can be recognised straight away when needed [#TGT:60b306349873ce31]. In practical terms, the systems described in the report should therefore explain how the firm will implement and maintain the marking of eligible deposits so that immediate identification is possible, and how that marking capability forms part of the firm’s overall compliance systems that are being reported to the PRA within the three-month deadline [#SRC:e1ca6e2e43062558] [#TGT:60b306349873ce31].

question: When an institution acts as a clearing member for its own purposes or as a financial intermediary between a client and a CCP, what must it do to determine the own funds requirements for its exposures to a CCP, and how must the resulting sum of own funds requirements for exposures to a QCCP arising from trade exposures and default fund contributions be constrained?
gold_answer: Where an institution acts as a clearing member, either for its own purposes or as a financial intermediary between a client and a CCP, it is required to calculate the own funds requirements for its exposures to a CCP in accordance with the prescribed approach for that calculation [#TGT:90f89b9de841e0ff]. In addition, for the purposes of the relevant calculation context, the institution must apply a limiting constraint to the aggregate outcome for certain QCCP-related components: specifically, the sum of the institution’s own funds requirements for its exposures to a QCCP that are due to trade exposures and default fund contributions is not permitted to exceed a cap. That cap is defined by reference to a counterfactual calculation—namely, the sum of own funds requirements that would be applied to those same exposures if the CCP were treated as a non-qualifying CCP [#SRC:61d9b5a70f557f6d]. Taken together, the institution must both perform the required clearing-member calculation for CCP exposures and ensure that, for the specified QCCP exposure categories, the aggregate own funds requirement is bounded by the non-qualifying CCP benchmark cap.

question: If an institution is a clearing member (for itself or between a client and a CCP), what does it have to do to work out its own funds requirements for CCP exposures, and what cap applies to the total own funds requirements for QCCP trade exposures and default fund contributions?
gold_answer: If an institution acts as a clearing member, whether for its own purposes or as a financial intermediary between a client and a CCP, it must calculate the own funds requirements for its exposures to a CCP using the required calculation approach that applies to clearing members [#TGT:90f89b9de841e0ff]. After doing that calculation, the institution must also check a specific limit that applies in the stated context: the total (sum) of the institution’s own funds requirements for its exposures to a QCCP that arise from trade exposures and default fund contributions cannot be higher than a defined cap [#SRC:61d9b5a70f557f6d]. The cap is set by comparing to what the own funds requirements would have been for those same exposures if the CCP were instead treated as a non-qualifying CCP, and using that sum as the maximum allowed amount [#SRC:61d9b5a70f557f6d]. In practice, the institution must both perform the clearing-member CCP exposure calculation and ensure the QCCP-related total stays within the non-qualifying CCP benchmark cap.

question: For purposes of applying the permitted asset exposure limits, how should an Authorised Person determine whether a land holding falls within the defined 5% land exposure category, particularly where a proper valuation assigns an aggregate value to a piece of land or multiple pieces of land (or interests in them) that exceeds the sum of separate valuations?
gold_answer: The permitted asset exposure limits are defined by reference to the limits that are set out elsewhere, and an Authorised Person should treat those limits as the governing framework for what is permitted in relation to asset exposure [#SRC:4a2c6b4a1519f187]. Within that framework, a specific land-related exposure category is defined as 5% for a piece of land or a number of pieces of land (including one or more interests in such pieces of land) where, in the most recent proper valuation, an aggregate value is ascribed to the relevant pieces of land that is greater than the aggregate of the value of each piece of land or interest valued separately [#TGT:e0fdde5fe1fac33a]. Practically, this means the compliance assessment must (i) identify whether the asset exposure is to a “piece of land” (or multiple pieces, or interests), (ii) confirm that the valuation used is the most recent proper valuation, and (iii) test whether the valuation methodology produces an aggregate value that exceeds the sum of separate valuations. If those definitional conditions are met, the relevant quantitative limit to apply for that land exposure category is 5%, and it must be applied as part of the permitted asset exposure limits framework [#SRC:4a2c6b4a1519f187] [#TGT:e0fdde5fe1fac33a].

question: When checking permitted asset exposure limits, when does the 5% limit apply to land, and what valuation test must be met for a piece of land (or interests in land) to fit that definition?
gold_answer: To check compliance, you first need to treat the permitted asset exposure limits as the limits that are set out in the referenced range, because that is what defines which exposure limits are “permitted” [#SRC:4a2c6b4a1519f187]. Then, for land, a specific definition sets a 5% limit for a piece of land or a number of pieces of land, including one or more interests in such pieces of land, but only where a particular valuation condition is satisfied [#TGT:e0fdde5fe1fac33a]. The condition is that, in the most recent proper valuation of the relevant pieces of land, an aggregate value is ascribed to those pieces of land that is greater than the aggregate of the value of each piece of land or interest valued separately [#TGT:e0fdde5fe1fac33a]. So the steps are: identify the exposure as land (a “piece of land” or multiple pieces, or interests), confirm you are using the most recent proper valuation, and compare the aggregate valuation against the sum of separate valuations. If the aggregate is higher, the land exposure fits the defined category and the applicable quantitative limit is 5%, applied within the permitted asset exposure limits framework [#SRC:4a2c6b4a1519f187] [#TGT:e0fdde5fe1fac33a].

question: When a firm acts as an originator, sponsor, and/or original lender in a securitisation subject to the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook, what must it be able to evidence to the PRA on request regarding its internal compliance arrangements, and how must those arrangements ensure the required ongoing retention of a material net economic interest (including how that interest is measured and determined)?
gold_answer: A firm that acts as an originator, original lender, and/or sponsor in a securitisation subject to the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook must be able to demonstrate to the PRA, if asked, that it has adequate arrangements, processes and mechanisms in place to comply with the relevant requirements referenced in the PRA’s expectation [#SRC:82ecd83bdfb2b614]. Those arrangements should be capable of evidencing that the originator, sponsor or original lender retains, on an ongoing basis, a material net economic interest in the securitisation of at least 5% [#TGT:faa1ca2e4ad51012]. In practice, the firm’s processes should also support how it measures and substantiates that retained interest: it must be measured at origination and determined by notional value for off-balance-sheet items [#TGT:faa1ca2e4ad51012]. Accordingly, to meet the PRA’s request-for-evidence expectation, the firm should be able to show documentation and controls that track the retention level over time, demonstrate the origination-time measurement, and explain the notional-value determination for any off-balance-sheet components, as part of its overall compliance mechanisms [#SRC:82ecd83bdfb2b614].

question: If a firm acts as an originator, original lender, or sponsor in a securitisation, what does it need to be able to show the PRA on request about its compliance setup, and what does it have to do to keep the required economic interest (including when and how it is measured)?
gold_answer: Where a firm acts as an originator, original lender, and/or sponsor in a securitisation that is subject to the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook, it needs to be able to demonstrate to the PRA, if asked, that it has adequate arrangements, processes and mechanisms to comply with the relevant requirements the PRA points to [#SRC:82ecd83bdfb2b614]. Those arrangements must be sufficient to support and evidence the specific retention obligation: the originator, sponsor or original lender must retain, on an ongoing basis, a material net economic interest in the securitisation of not less than 5% [#TGT:faa1ca2e4ad51012]. The firm also needs to be able to show how it measures and calculates that interest, because the interest must be measured at the origination and determined by the notional value for off-balance-sheet items [#TGT:faa1ca2e4ad51012]. So, the compliance setup the PRA expects should include clear records and controls that demonstrate the 5% minimum is met continuously, and that the origination-time measurement and notional-value approach for off-balance-sheet items are applied and can be explained to the PRA on request [#SRC:82ecd83bdfb2b614].

question: Where a credit union proposes to offer shares within an Individual Savings Account (ISA) tax-free wrapper and also intends to issue fixed-rate shares or deposits, what must it do to ensure it is referring to the relevant regulations and meeting all statutory mandatory requirements before commencing the fixed-rate activity, and how should it treat any HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) approval in its compliance assessment?
gold_answer: A credit union that wishes to offer shares in an Individual Savings Account (ISA) tax-free wrapper is expected to refer to the relevant regulations issued by HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC), and it must not treat HMRC approval as reducing or displacing its need to comply with statutory requirements [#SRC:39468cc7f2d4556d]. In parallel, where the same credit union intends to issue fixed-rate shares or deposits, the PRA expects it to comply with the statutory mandatory requirements that must be satisfied before beginning that activity [#TGT:bb34e94b2a68af4b]. Read together, the obligations require the credit union to (i) consult and follow the applicable HMRC regulatory framework for the ISA wrapper, (ii) recognise that obtaining HMRC approval does not provide any exemption from statutory compliance duties, and (iii) ensure that all statutory mandatory preconditions for issuing fixed-rate shares or deposits are met before it starts offering or issuing those products. The compliance approach should therefore treat HMRC approval as separate from, and not a substitute for, satisfying the statutory mandatory requirements expected by the PRA prior to commencement.

question: If a credit union wants to offer shares in an ISA tax-free wrapper and also plans to issue fixed-rate shares or deposits, what must it do before it starts, and does HMRC approval change its duty to meet statutory requirements?
gold_answer: The credit union is expected to look to the relevant regulations issued by HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) when it wishes to offer shares in an Individual Savings Account (ISA) tax-free wrapper, and it should not assume that HMRC approval changes its underlying legal compliance position [#SRC:39468cc7f2d4556d]. Separately, if it intends to issue fixed-rate shares or deposits, the PRA expects the credit union to comply with the statutory mandatory requirements that must be satisfied before it begins that activity [#TGT:bb34e94b2a68af4b]. Putting both requirements together, the credit union must (1) refer to and follow the HMRC regulations relevant to the ISA wrapper, (2) treat HMRC approval as not providing any exemption from statutory requirements, and (3) ensure it has satisfied the statutory mandatory requirements that apply before starting to issue fixed-rate shares or deposits. In practice, this means the credit union should complete its statutory readiness checks for the fixed-rate activity even if it has already obtained HMRC approval for the ISA-related offering.

question: Who counts as a ring-fenced body (RFB) for this material, and what does an RFB need to do when setting up arrangements to meet the Operational Continuity Part and this supervisory statement?
gold_answer: A ring-fenced body (RFB) is determined by the definition that is set out in Section 142A of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 [#TGT:34a32bd7af0986f7]. That definition is important here because the expectation described applies to RFBs specifically, so you first need to confirm that the firm is an RFB under Section 142A before treating the expectation as applicable. If the firm is an RFB, then when it is implementing arrangements to comply with the Operational Continuity Part and this supervisory statement, it should have regard to the Ring-fenced Bodies Part of the PRA Rulebook [#SRC:b0a1aa8def7f8a7f]. In practical terms, this means the RFB should actively consider the Ring-fenced Bodies Part as part of its implementation work for Operational Continuity and the supervisory statement, using it as a relevant reference point when designing and putting in place the arrangements needed for compliance, rather than focusing only on Operational Continuity requirements.

question: This supervisory statement says it matters to banks, building societies and Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) designated investment firms and explains the PRA’s expectations and Pillar 2 reporting clarity. How does the note that it was updated in 2016 and 2017, with details in an annex, affect how you should use it?
gold_answer: You should use the supervisory statement as guidance aimed at banks, building societies and Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) designated investment firms, because it is presented as being of interest to those firms and as setting out the PRA’s expectations while giving further clarity on Pillar 2 reporting [#SRC:0438216f78dc5eb1]. At the same time, you should factor in that the statement has been revised before: it was previously updated in 2016 and 2017, and you are directed to the annex for the details of those updates [#TGT:266a62be9029c8b7]. Putting these together, the practical effect is that you should read the current expectations and reporting clarifications with an awareness that the document has a change history, and you should consult the annex to understand what was updated in those earlier versions. That helps ensure you are relying on the statement as it currently stands, while also understanding the context of prior updates that may explain how the expectations and Pillar 2 reporting clarity have been refined over time.

question: If a third country branch has someone acting as head of risk, what approval do they need, and which PRA Supervisory Statement (with date and link) is pointed to for the explanation?
gold_answer: If a third country branch has an individual performing the head of risk role, that person needs to be pre-approved as the Head of Risk function (SMF4). The source also indicates this can cover people doing the head of risk role across multiple UK legal entities, such as a regional CRO responsible for the firm’s UK subsidiaries as well as the branch, so the pre-approval expectation is not limited to a single entity when the role spans the group’s UK footprint [#SRC:b3f688a3830f743b]. The source says this is explained in PRA Supervisory Statement 28/15, “Strengthening individual accountability in banking.” The target provides the publication details needed to find it: PRA Supervisory Statement 28/15, dated July 2015, and the specific Bank of England/PRA webpage URL where it is referenced [#TGT:fe2f4b4552a1cd37].

question: If an institution is a clearing member and acts between a client and a CCP, what must it do to (1) work out the own funds needed for the client’s CCP-related transactions and (2) check, using scenario analysis and stress testing, that the own funds it holds for CCP exposures are enough for the risks involved?
gold_answer: If an institution acts as a clearing member and, in that role, is a financial intermediary between a client and a CCP, it must calculate the own funds requirements for its CCP-related transactions with that client using the applicable calculation framework referenced for those requirements [#TGT:44da4c43fe9df94e]. Separately, institutions must also assess, through appropriate scenario analysis and stress testing, whether the level of own funds they hold against exposures to a CCP adequately matches the inherent risks of those exposures [#SRC:a3a91a063d2c4fd0]. This risk-based assessment is not limited to current exposures: it must include potential future or contingent credit exposures and exposures from default fund contributions. In addition, where the institution is acting as a clearing member, the assessment must also cover exposures that result from the relevant contractual arrangements connected to that clearing activity. In practice, the institution therefore needs both: a compliant calculation of own funds requirements for the client-facing CCP-related transactions, and a scenario- and stress-based evaluation that the own funds held against the broader set of CCP exposures remains appropriate given the risks.

question: When a firm is required to apply the calculation methodology described in the relevant range of provisions, how must it complete the multiplication step that follows arriving at the applicable sum or sums under the specified alternatives?
gold_answer: Where the process requires applying the calculation methodology described across the relevant provisions, the firm must use that methodology as the procedural basis for determining the figures to be carried forward into the next step [#SRC:7e5e070c1512b49a]. Once the firm has arrived at the appropriate figure(s) under the alternative routes—either the sum produced under one route, the sum produced under the other route, or (where applicable) the aggregate of both sums—the firm is then required to perform the multiplication step on that resulting amount [#TGT:6ea8868a81121c4f]. In practice, this means the firm should (i) apply the referenced calculation framework to ensure the underlying sums are determined consistently with the prescribed method, and then (ii) identify whether it is operating on a single sum or an aggregate of sums, depending on which alternative applies, before carrying out the required multiplication. The obligation is to multiply the relevant resulting amount, and the procedural cross-reference clarifies that the multiplication is not standalone but follows from applying the specified calculation set.

question: In addition to PRA rules, what other supervisory materials does the PRA issue, and where is the PRA’s page for its approach documents made available online?
gold_answer: The SOURCE establishes that, alongside PRA rules, the PRA also issues supervisory approach documents and identifies these as including SoPs and SSs, indicating that these materials sit in addition to the PRA’s rules-based framework [#SRC:e2d2b8440b248841]. The TARGET complements this by specifying where the PRA’s approach documents are made available online, providing a direct Bank of England web address for the PRA approach documents page [#TGT:e887f801375d7abb]. Read together, the passages support a compliance conclusion that firms should look beyond PRA rules to the PRA’s supervisory approach documents (including SoPs and SSs) and that the PRA maintains an accessible online location for these approach documents via the referenced Bank of England URL. This pairing is useful for governance and regulatory change management because it links the existence and types of supervisory approach documents the PRA issues with a concrete source location where those documents can be accessed and monitored for updates [#SRC:e2d2b8440b248841] [#TGT:e887f801375d7abb].

question: Besides PRA rules, what kinds of supervisory documents does the PRA issue, and where can you find the PRA approach documents online?
gold_answer: The SOURCE explains that the PRA does more than publish PRA rules: it also issues supervisory approach documents, and it indicates that these include SoPs and SSs [#SRC:e2d2b8440b248841]. The TARGET then tells you where those PRA approach documents are available online by giving a specific Bank of England link to the PRA approach documents page [#TGT:e887f801375d7abb]. Putting both together, you can describe the PRA’s non-rules supervisory materials as supervisory approach documents (including SoPs and SSs) and you can point to the exact online location where the PRA makes its approach documents available. This combined view supports a practical compliance step: when tracking PRA expectations, you should monitor not only PRA rules but also the PRA’s supervisory approach documents, and you can use the provided URL as the reference point for accessing those materials [#SRC:e2d2b8440b248841] [#TGT:e887f801375d7abb].

question: When a Solvency II Firms Sector provision is stated to apply to the Society on an “in accordance with” basis under this Chapter, how must the Society treat that application in light of the reference to managing agents being “in accordance with” Insurance General Application 3?
gold_answer: If a provision in the Solvency II Firms Sector of the PRA Rulebook is framed so that it applies to the Society only on an “in accordance with” basis under this Chapter, the Society is under a mandatory obligation to follow the Chapter’s “in accordance with” mechanism when giving effect to that provision [#TGT:a0364be43454855a]. The cross-reference in the materials indicates that, for the relevant context, the “in accordance with” approach is tied to Insurance General Application 3 and specifically to managing agents [#SRC:fed9ff0568e8a36e]. Read together, this means the Society must not treat the Solvency II Firms Sector provision as applying in isolation; instead, it must apply it through the Chapter’s “in accordance with” condition, and where the Chapter’s condition points to Insurance General Application 3 in relation to managing agents, the Society must align its implementation with that referenced framework. In practice, the Society’s compliance analysis should therefore confirm (i) that the triggering wording (“in accordance with” this Chapter) is present, and (ii) that the relevant “in accordance with” linkage includes the managing agents reference to Insurance General Application 3, so the Society’s application of the provision reflects that linkage [#TGT:a0364be43454855a] [#SRC:fed9ff0568e8a36e].

question: How shall Institutions determine when they must calculate replacement cost using the formula for (i) single netting sets that are subject to margin agreements and (ii) netting sets that are not subject to a margin agreement or are subject to a one way margin agreement where the institution must post but is not entitled to receive variation margin, and how should these categories be kept distinct for compliance purposes?
gold_answer: Institutions must apply a formula-based replacement cost calculation in two distinct situations that are defined by whether, and how, a margin agreement applies to the relevant netting set. First, where the exposure is a single netting set that is subject to a margin agreement, Institutions shall calculate the replacement cost for that single netting set in accordance with the specified formula, except for those margin-agreement cases carved out from that treatment in the SOURCE provision [#SRC:19512cdca8e04e88]. Second, for netting sets that are not subject to a margin agreement, or that are subject to a one way margin agreement under which the institution is required to post but is not entitled to receive variation margin, Institutions shall calculate the replacement cost RC in accordance with the specified formula in the TARGET provision [#TGT:8928616d2b66e35d]. Compliance requires classifying each netting set into the correct bucket—margin agreement (single netting set) versus no margin agreement/one-way posting-only variation margin—so that the appropriate formula obligation is applied to the correct population and the exception in the SOURCE is not inadvertently applied to the TARGET category.

question: When do Institutions have to calculate replacement cost using the formula for a single netting set under a margin agreement, and when do they have to calculate replacement cost RC using the formula for netting sets with no margin agreement or a one way margin agreement where they must post but cannot receive variation margin?
gold_answer: Institutions have two related but separate formula obligations, and the trigger depends on the margin agreement status of the netting set. If the position is a single netting set that is subject to a margin agreement, Institutions shall calculate the replacement cost for that single netting set using the formula specified for that category, while observing that the SOURCE text excludes certain margin-agreement cases from that treatment [#SRC:19512cdca8e04e88]. Separately, if the netting set is not subject to a margin agreement at all, or if it is subject to a one way margin agreement where the institution is required to post but is not entitled to receive variation margin, Institutions shall calculate the replacement cost RC using the formula specified for that category [#TGT:8928616d2b66e35d]. In practice, Institutions should first determine whether there is a margin agreement and, if so, whether it is one way with posting-only variation margin; that classification determines which formula-based replacement cost requirement applies and helps ensure the single-netting-set margin-agreement rule is not mixed with the no-margin/one-way posting-only rule.

question: How must a firm’s obligation to establish, implement and maintain robust governance arrangements and decision-making procedures be operationalised so that relevant persons are made aware of, and follow, the procedures required for the proper discharge of their responsibilities?
gold_answer: A firm must translate its duty to establish, implement and maintain robust governance arrangements and decision-making procedures into practical internal measures that ensure relevant persons are aware of the procedures that must be followed to properly discharge their responsibilities. This requires the firm not only to design governance and decision-making procedures as part of its overall arrangements, but also to implement them in a way that makes them known to the relevant persons who need to apply them in practice, and to maintain them so awareness and adherence are sustained over time. In effect, the governance and decision-making framework must include an embedded communication and awareness component: relevant persons should be informed of the applicable procedures and understand that those procedures must be followed when carrying out their responsibilities. The firm’s governance arrangements and decision-making procedures therefore need to be established and implemented with sufficient clarity and accessibility to support proper discharge of responsibilities, and maintained so that awareness does not lapse as roles or circumstances change. These expectations arise from the requirement to ensure awareness and following of procedures by relevant persons [#SRC:87f186d46471481e] and the obligation on a firm to establish, implement and maintain robust governance arrangements and decision-making procedures [#TGT:51b5542d9eb513b2].

question: For SEC-SA and SEC-IRBA, define what “non-neutrality” means in terms of the relationship between tranche RWAs and the RWAs of the underlying portfolio absent securitisation, and explain how the framework’s reliance on pre-defined inputs (such as STS status) affects the level of that non-neutrality, including the mechanisms by which it is introduced.
gold_answer: In SEC-SA and SEC-IRBA, “non-neutrality” refers to the typical outcome that the total RWAs calculated for the tranches of a securitisation are higher than the RWAs that would have been calculated for the underlying portfolio if it had not been securitised [#TGT:dbb9be39416dec17]. This feature matters because the SEC-SA and SEC-IRBA methods can only recognise a defined number of items in their capital requirement calculations and are primarily focused on credit risk, so they may fail to recognise the presence of non-credit risks; the framework reflects some additional non-credit risks arising from securitisation through this non-neutrality [#SRC:b660733416fb3965]. The level of non-neutrality is not open-ended; it is driven by pre-defined inputs, such as STS status [#SRC:b660733416fb3965]. In practice, the framework introduces non-neutrality primarily through applying a risk weight floor that differs by STS versus non-STS positions and through the supervisory “p” factor, which together push tranche RWAs above the underlying portfolio benchmark [#TGT:dbb9be39416dec17].

question: In SEC-SA and SEC-IRBA, what does “non-neutrality” mean, and how do pre-defined inputs like STS status drive how much non-neutrality the securitisation capital framework applies, given that these methods mainly focus on credit risk and may miss non-credit risks?
gold_answer: “Non-neutrality” in SEC-SA and SEC-IRBA means that, in typical cases, the total RWAs calculated for the tranches of a securitisation will be higher than the RWAs that would have been calculated for the underlying portfolio if it had not been securitised [#TGT:dbb9be39416dec17]. This concept is relevant because the SEC-SA and SEC-IRBA methods can only recognise a defined number of items in their capital calculations and are primarily focused on credit risk, so they may fail to recognise non-credit risks; the framework reflects some additional non-credit risks that can arise from securitisation through the “non-neutrality” built into the capital framework [#SRC:b660733416fb3965]. The amount of non-neutrality applied is not discretionary; it is driven by pre-defined inputs, such as whether a position has STS status [#SRC:b660733416fb3965]. The definition explains that this non-neutrality is introduced primarily through a risk weight floor that differs for STS and non-STS positions and through the supervisory “p” factor, which are the key mechanisms that increase tranche RWAs relative to the underlying portfolio baseline [#TGT:dbb9be39416dec17].

question: For purposes of calculating RoA as a two-year average ratio, how must the “net income” input be identified and sourced, and how does that definition interact with the requirement to use total assets as the denominator?
gold_answer: RoA is defined as a metric computed by taking net income divided by total assets and then averaging that ratio over a two-year period, so the calculation requires a consistent identification of both the numerator and denominator across the relevant years [#SRC:005b0d8588b51505]. The “net income” component used as the numerator is not left to general interpretation; it is specifically tied to a FINREP data point, meaning net income must be taken from row 355, column 01 of template F02.00 (FINREP) [#TGT:faed71864e571bf4]. Read together, this means the RoA numerator must be sourced from that precise FINREP location for each year included in the two-year averaging window, while the denominator remains total assets as required by the RoA calculation construct [#SRC:005b0d8588b51505].
