Under the definition, an exit cost is not simply any expense of winding down; it is specifically the gap between (i) the expected exit value under the TWD scenario and (ii) the accounting book value, and it applies to positions that, under the actions, arrangements and measures for the TWD scenario, are to be novated, terminated or liquidated [#TGT:de5e0b682bbd3308]. Accordingly, when projecting exit costs over the wind-down period, the firm should (a) identify the relevant positions subject to novation, termination, or liquidation under its TWD actions and measures, (b) estimate the expected exit value for those positions under the TWD scenario, and (c) compare that expected exit value to the accounting book value to calculate the gap that constitutes the exit cost. This defined gap then forms the basis of the firm’s exit cost projections across the relevant timeframe [#SRC:80164e310f0e8310] [#TGT:de5e0b682bbd3308].

question: In a TWD scenario, what exactly counts as an “exit cost,” and how should a TWD firm use that definition when it needs to project its exit costs from the assumed reference date through the wind-down period?
gold_answer: An “exit cost” in a TWD scenario has a specific meaning that a TWD firm should use when meeting the expectation that it can project its exit costs from the assumed reference date of the TWD option through the wind-down period [#SRC:80164e310f0e8310]. The definition ties exit cost to certain positions and to a particular calculation: it is the gap between the expected exit value under the TWD scenario and the accounting book value, and it applies to positions that will be novated, terminated, or liquidated under the actions, arrangements and measures for the TWD scenario [#TGT:de5e0b682bbd3308]. So, when the firm projects “exit costs” over time, it should not treat the term as a general label for all wind-down spending. Instead, it should focus on the relevant positions that its TWD actions and measures would novate, terminate, or liquidate, estimate what those positions are expected to exit for under the TWD scenario, and then compare that expected exit value to the accounting book value to determine the gap. That gap is what the firm should project as its exit costs across the wind-down period [#SRC:80164e310f0e8310] [#TGT:de5e0b682bbd3308].

question: For variable interest investments that are equity shares in bodies corporate drawing up accounts under the Accounts Directives framework, International Accounting Standards Committee accounting standards, or US generally accepted accounting practice, how must the yield be determined when the undertaking’s accounting period is longer or shorter than a year, and what profit-or-loss figure must be used in the yield ratio?
gold_answer: Where the yield is being determined for variable interest investments that are equity shares in bodies corporate that draw up accounts in accordance with legislation implementing the Accounts Directives, or in accordance with International Accounting Standards Committee accounting standards, or US generally accepted accounting practice, the yield on an asset is defined as a ratio to the value of the asset [#TGT:19634e1dc744e91d]. In that context, if the undertaking’s accounting period is not exactly one year (i.e., it is longer or shorter than a year) and the relevant rule applies, the undertaking must annualise the amount of profits or losses for that accounting period. The annualised profit-or-loss figure is then the figure that must be used when calculating the yield under the ratio-based definition, rather than the unadjusted profits or losses for the non‑annual period [#SRC:f994473a44562eb1]. This ensures the numerator used in the yield ratio reflects a one‑year equivalent amount whenever the accounting period length differs from a year, while still applying the yield definition that ties the calculation to the asset’s value [#TGT:19634e1dc744e91d].

question: If a firm mentions the FS, what does FS mean in terms of how many parts it has, and what does the PRA expect the firm to do with those parts unless the text says otherwise?
gold_answer: FS is defined as having three elements, so it is a three-part concept rather than a single item [#TGT:f2e9197797a590a2]. Because of that definition, the PRA’s expectation is that when a firm makes a reference to the FS, the firm should consider all three elements of the FS together, not just one element, unless the relevant context clearly states otherwise [#SRC:74244d08f74c3214]. In practical terms, the firm should read any mention of “FS” as pointing to the full three-element structure and should ensure its work (for example, an internal assessment or an external explanation) reflects consideration of each element. The only time the firm should narrow its focus is when the reference itself includes an explicit statement that changes what is being covered. This approach keeps the firm aligned with both what FS is (three elements) and how the PRA expects firms to treat references to it (consider all three unless an exception is stated).

question: What are the key parts of the FS, and when a firm refers to the FS, does the PRA expect the firm to look at every part or only some of them?
gold_answer: The FS is described as having three elements, so the term “FS” refers to a set made up of three parts [#TGT:f2e9197797a590a2]. Based on that, the PRA expects that where a firm makes a reference to the FS, the firm should consider all three elements of the FS, meaning the firm should not treat the FS as if it were only one element or an incomplete subset [#SRC:74244d08f74c3214]. The default position is therefore comprehensive: a reference to the FS should trigger consideration of every element that forms the FS. The only exception is where it is stated otherwise—i.e., where the context of the reference clearly indicates that the firm is not expected to apply all three elements. So, to comply with the PRA’s expectation, the firm should first recognize that FS is a three-element concept and then ensure that any reference to it is handled in a way that addresses all three elements unless an explicit limitation is stated.

question: What must institutions do first for a netting set so they can properly calculate the equity risk category add-on, and which section is named for the calculation step?
gold_answer: Before institutions can carry out the required calculation for a netting set, they must ensure the netting set has been set up with the right equity reference information. Specifically, for the purposes of paragraph 2, institutions shall establish the relevant equity reference entities of the netting set in accordance with the approach that follows [#SRC:a43b7a94ebe76894]. Separately, for the purposes of Article 278, institutions shall calculate the equity risk category add-on for a given netting set as set out in that provision [#TGT:0ebfaf3bc04a9c8f]. These obligations fit together because both are about the same unit of analysis (the netting set): establishing the relevant equity reference entities is a required preparatory step tied to the netting set, and calculating the equity risk category add-on is the required computation performed for that netting set. The named section for the calculation step is Article 278, and institutions are the actor that must perform both the establishment and the calculation.

question: For compliance referencing purposes, how should an Authorised Person identify and locate the specific joint Bank / Financial Services Authority (FSA) publication that is cross-referenced as the first item in the list of joint publications, including where it is made available?
gold_answer: The SOURCE identifies a set of joint Bank / Financial Services Authority (FSA) publications and indicates that the first listed publication is “A review of requirements for banks entering into or expanding in the banking sector (the 2013 report)”, followed by a cross-reference marker that distinguishes it from the subsequent “one year on” publication [#SRC:af42f23c6a6fad15]. The TARGET then provides the availability information for that same first cross-referenced item by specifying that it is available at a particular FCA web address, which functions as the retrieval location for the referenced publication [#TGT:f7d87ccbb522927b]. Read together, the SOURCE supplies the correct identification of the joint Bank / Financial Services Authority (FSA) publication within the list (i.e., the 2013 report as the first item), while the TARGET supplies the practical access point (the URL) for that specific cross-referenced entry. This combined approach supports accurate citation and document control by ensuring the correct joint publication is both named and locatable.

question: Which joint Bank / Financial Services Authority (FSA) publication is the first one listed, and where can you find it online?
gold_answer: The SOURCE lists joint Bank / Financial Services Authority (FSA) publications and shows that the first one is “A review of requirements for banks entering into or expanding in the banking sector (the 2013 report)”, before it moves on to a separate “one year on” publication [#SRC:af42f23c6a6fad15]. The TARGET then tells you where the first listed item can be accessed by stating that it is available at a specific FCA webpage address [#TGT:f7d87ccbb522927b]. Using both passages together, you can (1) pick the correct document from the list—i.e., the initial 2013 report rather than the later follow-up—and (2) retrieve it using the online location provided. This pairing matters for basic compliance work because the SOURCE alone gives the titles but not the access details, while the TARGET alone gives the access link but not the full context of which joint publication in the list it corresponds to.

question: In the context of an RFTS application, how should the term “applicant” be defined, and what procedural timetable must the court set for that applicant at a Directions hearing regarding public notification and the handling of written submissions from potentially adversely affected persons?
gold_answer: For an RFTS application, the “applicant” is defined as the transferor, the transferee, or both, where that party (or those parties) submits the RFTS application to the court in order to effect the transfer [#TGT:3c51f46b31ac10e8]. In procedural terms, a Directions hearing is the point at which the court sets out a timetable specifically for that applicant to carry out two linked steps: first, to notify the public of the RFTS application, and second, to receive any written submissions from persons alleging they would be adversely affected by the scheme [#SRC:350ef7c8985b9d8e]. Read together, the definition identifies which entity is responsible for complying with the court-directed timetable, and the Directions hearing procedure clarifies the scope of what the timetable must cover—public notification and the receipt of written submissions from those claiming adverse impact. This means the applicant (as transferor/transferee/both) must be prepared to follow the court’s sequencing and timing for these communications and submissions as part of progressing the application to effect the transfer [#TGT:3c51f46b31ac10e8] [#SRC:350ef7c8985b9d8e].

question: Who counts as the “applicant” for an RFTS application, and what does the court set a timetable for the applicant to do at a Directions hearing about telling the public and collecting written submissions from people who say they would be adversely affected?
gold_answer: The “applicant” for an RFTS application is usually the transferor, the transferee, or both, where that party (or those parties) is submitting the RFTS application to the court in order to effect the transfer [#TGT:3c51f46b31ac10e8]. When a Directions hearing takes place, the court sets out a timetable for that applicant to complete key steps connected to the application: the applicant must notify the public of the RFTS application and must receive any written submissions from persons alleging they would be adversely affected by the scheme [#SRC:350ef7c8985b9d8e]. Putting these together, the definition tells you which party is responsible for acting (transferor/transferee/both), and the Directions hearing procedure tells you what the court’s timetable will cover (public notice and receiving written submissions) [#TGT:3c51f46b31ac10e8] [#SRC:350ef7c8985b9d8e]. In practice, the applicant should expect the court to sequence and time these actions so that public notification occurs and written submissions can be gathered from those who claim adverse effects before the application proceeds further [#SRC:350ef7c8985b9d8e].

question: A TWD firm must be able to run sensitivity analysis on key assumptions. How should it use that analysis to show the range of impacts on capital and liquidity while still building its TWD capabilities on a full wind-down of its trading activities?
gold_answer: A TWD firm should be able to conduct sensitivity analysis that measures how changing key assumptions (compared with those used in the TWD scenario) affects outcomes, and it should use that capability to set out upper and lower bounds for those assumptions so senior management can see the range of plausible impacts on the firm’s capital and liquidity projections after the TWD option is executed [#SRC:b6ce98b0d799fd2f]. At the same time, the firm should treat this sensitivity analysis as supporting work that sits within, and does not alter, the expectation that the firm’s TWD capabilities are built on the basis of the full wind-down of its trading activities [#TGT:67153071a209f68a]. The sensitivity analysis capability should include the ability to analyse the minimum baseline set of factors that form part of the TWD scenario, and then vary assumptions around that baseline to quantify how projections move under different plausible conditions [#SRC:b6ce98b0d799fd2f]. In other words, the firm uses sensitivity analysis to stress and bound its wind-down planning assumptions, while keeping the overall capability design grounded in a full trading wind-down [#TGT:67153071a209f68a].

question: If the Merger Document includes the Schedule 16 Statement, what does the board have to say about any material financial changes since the period covered by the financial information, and what should it do if it cannot put a number on the impact?
gold_answer: When the Merger Document is being provided and it includes the Schedule 16 Statement (along with the related explanations of change, comparability and commitments), the board must deal with the fact that the financial information will cover a period ending before the Schedule 16 Statement is approved [#SRC:f1c8b930cd8f5ee1] [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1]. Specifically, the board is required to state whether or not there have been any material changes to the financial position in the interim, so members have a clear, direct statement rather than assumptions [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1]. If there has been a change but the effect cannot be quantified, the board must still describe the change so that members at least know it has been identified and that it matters to their consideration of the proposed merger [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1]. This obligation sits within the broader requirement to provide the Merger Document including the Schedule 16 Statement, unless consent to proceed by way of board resolution is being sought in respect of the transferee society [#SRC:f1c8b930cd8f5ee1].

question: If K is meant to be the loan principal plus expected interest built up by time T, what do firms need to do for ERM loans when a borrower’s actions can change that K amount through principal or interest?
gold_answer: K is defined as the loan principal plus the expected accrued interest at time T, and it is to be calculated using the relevant principles referenced for that calculation [#SRC:f62ad92b67a510fd]. For ERM loans, if the value of K at time T depends on borrower behaviour that affects principal or interest, the PRA expects firms to follow the applicable principles for how K should be determined in that situation [#TGT:3683522dee3bbc3a]. Putting these together, firms should (1) identify K’s components at time T (principal and expected accrued interest), and (2) treat borrower-behaviour dependency as the condition that requires applying the PRA’s expected approach. The obligation is not just to label K correctly, but to calculate it in line with the principles when borrower behaviour can influence the principal or interest that make up K. This ensures the K figure used at time T reflects both the defined elements and the PRA’s expectation for ERM loans where borrower behaviour is relevant [#SRC:f62ad92b67a510fd] [#TGT:3683522dee3bbc3a].

question: For a firm with a TMTP permission, how must the firm determine the permissible range for the transitional deduction it applies, and how is the “maximum amount” defined for that purpose? Where the firm elects to apply less than that maximum, what disclosure and supervisory-sharing steps does the PRA expect, and how must the firm ensure consistency of this approach across its Solvency II reporting and governance materials?
gold_answer: For all firms with a TMTP permission, the firm must ensure the amount of the transitional deduction it applies sits within a defined range: it must be no less than zero and no more than the maximum amount [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c]. The “maximum amount” for this purpose is defined as the maximum number derived either from the TMTP method in Transitional Measures on Technical Provisions or from the legacy approach set out in the relevant firm’s permission [#TGT:f321e44c98b40d33]. If the firm decides to apply less than that maximum, the PRA expects the firm to include both the maximum amount and the actual TMTP amount in the notes to market disclosures and to share the same information with its supervision team [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c]. In addition, the firm should maintain a transparent approach to determining the TMTP benefit it is applying, and the PRA expects that approach to be followed consistently across all Solvency II reporting, including Quarterly Reporting Templates (QRTs), and to be reflected within the firm’s ORSA and risk management framework [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c].

question: If a firm has a TMTP permission, what does “maximum amount” mean when setting the transitional deduction, and what range must the firm stay within? If the firm uses less than the maximum, what does the PRA expect the firm to disclose and share, and where must the firm apply the same approach consistently?
gold_answer: A firm with a TMTP permission must apply a transitional deduction amount that is within a required range: it must be between zero and a maximum amount [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c]. The “maximum amount” is defined as the maximum number derived from the TMTP method in Transitional Measures on Technical Provisions or from the legacy approach described in the relevant firm’s permission [#TGT:f321e44c98b40d33]. If the firm chooses to apply less than that maximum, the PRA expects the firm to (i) include both the maximum amount and the actual TMTP amount in the notes to market disclosures and (ii) share this information with its supervision team [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c]. Beyond disclosure, the firm should keep its method for deciding the TMTP benefit transparent, and the PRA expects the firm to follow that method consistently across all Solvency II reporting, including Quarterly Reporting Templates (QRTs) [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c]. The same approach should also be reflected in the firm’s ORSA and its risk management framework, so the firm’s reporting and governance materials align with how it determines and applies the deduction [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c].

question: When you calculate the CET1 ratio, what goes on top and what goes on the bottom, and what does the rule mean when it says the exposure amount is the CRR ‘total risk exposure amount’?
gold_answer: Using both passages, the CET1 ratio is a simple ratio with a specified numerator and a denominator whose meaning is fixed by a separate definition. The SOURCE says the CET1 ratio is calculated as CET1 capital divided by risk-weighted assets [#SRC:4751cd1c8d385d48]. The TARGET adds that the relevant exposure amount is defined as the “total risk exposure amount,” and that this term must be understood as it is defined in the CRR [#TGT:5ef87f6cdf1558a3]. Put together, you calculate the ratio by placing CET1 capital in the numerator and using the risk/exposure measure in the denominator, but you should not interpret that denominator loosely: the exposure concept is anchored to the CRR’s definition of total risk exposure amount. This combined reading matters because it links the denominator used in the CET1 ratio calculation to a specific, externally defined exposure amount, rather than leaving it to a general description. The result is a CET1-capital-to-exposure calculation where the exposure side is tied to the CRR-defined total risk exposure amount.

question: Where one or more of the specified circumstances arise, is the FSCS permitted to postpone paying compensation beyond the standard time period, and is that permission limited to cases where those circumstances are present?
gold_answer: Yes. The scope trigger is that one or more of the specified circumstances must arise; that condition defines when the relevant framework applies and therefore when any related timing flexibility can be engaged [#SRC:815814104eb16d96]. In that same situation, the permission granted to the FSCS is that it may decide to defer the payment of compensation beyond the otherwise applicable time period, but only where the deferral condition is met—namely, where the relevant circumstances arise [#TGT:e7ff6bd16d34a149]. Read together, the SOURCE establishes the applicability boundary (the occurrence of one or more of the listed circumstances), and the TARGET provides the operational consequence within that boundary (a discretionary decision by the FSCS to defer payment beyond the standard period). Accordingly, absent the arising of at least one of those circumstances, the SOURCE does not indicate that the deferral condition is satisfied, and the TARGET’s permission to defer is not engaged; conversely, once the condition is met, the FSCS has discretion to defer rather than an obligation to do so.

question: If a derivative transaction has more than one important risk driver, and one of those drivers is linked to climatic conditions, what must institutions do to map the transaction to the right risk category or categories?
gold_answer: Institutions must map the transaction in a way that captures both the climatic-conditions rule and the rule for transactions with multiple material risk drivers. If the primary risk driver is a climatic conditions variable, institutions shall map the transaction to the commodity risk category [#SRC:d444b5b1871ca35e]. Also, because the transaction has more than one material risk driver, institutions shall map it to more than one risk category when the drivers belong to different risk categories, mapping it once to each relevant risk category based on the most material risk driver within that category [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad]. If, instead, all material risk drivers belong to the same risk category, institutions only need to map the transaction once to that single category, using the most material driver as the basis [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad]. Putting these together: the presence of a climatic conditions variable as the primary driver (or as the most material driver within a risk category used for mapping) requires commodity mapping, and the multi-driver framework then determines whether additional mappings are required to other risk categories as well [#SRC:d444b5b1871ca35e] [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad].

question: For transactions within scope, how should a firm determine who falls within its relevant senior management population, and what external supervisory material should it consult to support its approach to individual accountability in banking?
gold_answer: For the purposes of the transactions in question, a firm should treat “relevant senior management” as a defined population that includes (a) any individuals performing Senior Management Functions (SMFs) who have oversight of those transactions and (b) any employees who are subject to the Certification Regime and are involved in the transactions, including relevant Material Risk Takers (MRTs) under the Remuneration rules. This means the identification exercise is not limited to SMF holders; it must also capture certified staff who participate in the transactions, with particular attention to those whose roles align with MRT status under remuneration requirements. To support and evidence its approach to strengthening individual accountability in banking, the firm should also refer to the Bank of England Prudential Regulation Authority’s Supervisory Statement SS 28/15, “Strengthening Individual Accountability in Banking,” as the cited supervisory material available online [#TGT:b4a4d930ae66ef1e], alongside applying the transaction-specific definition of relevant senior management described in the source definition [#SRC:3035bf91c8e1c057].

question: When your firm is working on these transactions, who counts as relevant senior management, and which Bank of England supervisory statement should you look at for guidance on individual accountability in banking?
gold_answer: For these transactions, your firm should treat “relevant senior management” as a practical list of people that includes two groups: first, any individuals performing Senior Management Functions (SMFs) who have oversight of the transactions; and second, any employees who are subject to the Certification Regime and are involved in the transactions, including relevant Material Risk Takers (MRTs) under the Remuneration rules. In other words, you should not stop at identifying only the SMF holders—your scope must also include certified staff who take part in the transactions, and you should consider whether any of those individuals are MRTs for remuneration purposes. To anchor this identification and accountability approach in supervisory material, you should consult the Bank of England Prudential Regulation Authority’s Supervisory Statement SS 28/15, “Strengthening Individual Accountability in Banking,” which is referenced as being available online [#TGT:b4a4d930ae66ef1e]. Apply that supervisory reference together with the definition of relevant senior management provided for these transactions [#SRC:3035bf91c8e1c057].

question: When responding to a request from the PRA or any other relevant competent authority for information needed to supervise compliance of outsourced activities, how must a third country branch meet that obligation where the branch and the service provider are members of the same group and the branch may assess the degree of control or influence it has over the service provider’s actions?
gold_answer: A third country branch must be able to provide, on request, all information necessary for the PRA and any other relevant competent authority to supervise whether the performance of outsourced activities complies with the requirements of the regulatory system [#TGT:5c89c9f008f3d8f1]. Where the third country branch and the service provider are members of the same group, the branch is permitted, for the relevant purposes, to take into account the extent to which it controls the service provider or has the ability to influence the service provider’s actions [#SRC:ba066540a6b4af47]. In practice, this means the branch should not treat group membership as reducing the information it must be able to make available; rather, it may use its control or influence assessment to inform how it ensures the requested information can be obtained and provided. The branch should therefore be prepared to explain, consistently with its control/influence position, how it can access and deliver the information needed for supervisory review of outsourced activities, including where the service provider’s actions are shaped by the branch’s control or influence within the group structure.

question: For compliance documentation, how should an institution identify the EBA guidance that sets a minimum list of qualitative and quantitative recovery plan indicators, and where should it direct readers to access the authoritative version online?
gold_answer: An institution should identify the relevant guidance by naming it as the EBA “Guidelines on the minimum list of qualitative and quantitative recovery plan indicators,” ensuring the reference clearly ties the document to recovery plan indicators and the minimum qualitative and quantitative set expected under that guidance [#SRC:190ad124a87642f9]. In the same compliance documentation (e.g., a recovery planning policy, indicator framework, or internal governance memo), it should also provide an access point to the authoritative online location by directing readers to the EBA webpage where the guidelines are made available, using the provided “Available at” link to the EBA site [#TGT:ee3e5f11faa9443d]. Taken together, this approach both (i) specifies the exact EBA guidelines being relied upon for the minimum list of recovery plan indicators and (ii) enables reviewers, auditors, and supervisors to retrieve the current official version from the EBA’s published source. This pairing supports traceability between the named guidelines and the official online publication location, reducing ambiguity about which EBA recovery indicator guidance is being applied.

question: If you need to cite the EBA document about the minimum qualitative and quantitative recovery plan indicators, what is the document called and where can someone find it online?
gold_answer: You should cite the document by its name as the EBA “Guidelines on the minimum list of qualitative and quantitative recovery plan indicators,” which makes clear that it covers both qualitative and quantitative indicators and that it is focused on recovery plan indicators and a minimum list [#SRC:190ad124a87642f9]. To help someone actually locate the official text, you should also include the online location where it is available by pointing to the EBA webpage indicated as the access source, i.e., the “Available at” link to the EBA site hosting the guidelines [#TGT:ee3e5f11faa9443d]. Using both elements together in your citation or internal reference note ensures that readers understand exactly which EBA guidelines you mean and have a direct route to retrieve the authoritative version from the EBA’s own publication page. This is especially useful when sharing recovery planning materials internally or with reviewers, because it links the named guidelines to the official online source.

question: When a firm is a member of a group whose parent undertaking has its head office in a third country that is treated as an overseas jurisdiction for insurance group supervision, how does that affect whether the firm must ensure group-level strategies, processes and systems comply with the Operational Resilience obligations, and are any group provisions disapplied in that scenario?
gold_answer: If the firm is a member of a group that falls within the group categories that trigger the requirement, the firm must ensure that the strategies, processes and systems at the level of the group of which it is a member comply with the obligations in Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 3 (noting the stated exception for Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 3.1(3)) [#TGT:df26169200bb5c19]. However, the scope text also creates a conditional disapplication: where the firm is a member of a group covered by the specified group coverage condition, certain provisions (22.2, 22.3 and 22.4) do not apply if the third country in which the group’s parent undertaking has its head office is an overseas jurisdiction designated for insurance group supervision and the stated condition about the IRPR regulations applies [#SRC:b6b6500b2b9939c8]. Read together, the firm should treat the overseas-jurisdiction/third-country condition as narrowing which group-related provisions apply, while still meeting the group-level operational resilience compliance duty where the target obligation applies to the firm’s group category [#TGT:df26169200bb5c19] and the source condition does not remove that duty [#SRC:b6b6500b2b9939c8].

question: If a firm is in a group and the group’s parent undertaking is based in a third country that is treated as an overseas jurisdiction for insurance group supervision, does the firm still have to make sure the group’s strategies, processes and systems meet the Operational Resilience obligations, or do some group rules stop applying?
gold_answer: The target obligation says that, where a firm is a member of a group within the listed group coverage conditions (including one category that is subject to a stated limitation), the firm must ensure that the strategies, processes and systems at the level of the group comply with the obligations in Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 3, while also recognising the stated exception for Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 3.1(3) [#TGT:df26169200bb5c19]. The source scope text then adds an important boundary: where a firm is a member of a group covered by the specified group coverage condition, certain provisions (22.2, 22.3 and 22.4) do not apply if the third country where the group’s parent undertaking has its head office is an overseas jurisdiction designated for insurance group supervision and the stated IRPR condition applies [#SRC:b6b6500b2b9939c8]. Putting both together, the firm should (i) identify whether it is in a group that triggers the group-level operational resilience duty [#TGT:df26169200bb5c19], and (ii) check whether the third-country/overseas-jurisdiction condition switches off the specified group provisions, which may change the set of group requirements that apply in that situation [#SRC:b6b6500b2b9939c8].

question: Where the PRA cannot obtain adequate assurance that the home resolution authority’s regime will achieve outcomes aligned with the PRA’s and the Bank’s objectives, may the firm be required to move toward UK structures and supervision that enable the Bank to resolve the UK branch on a standalone basis in certain circumstances?
gold_answer: Yes. The SOURCE explains that the PRA’s preferred approach is to gain assurance that the home resolution authority’s resolution regime will deliver appropriate outcomes for the PRA’s and the Bank’s objectives as UK resolution authority, and that without adequate assurance the PRA will likely not be prepared to host a branch from that jurisdiction; for an international bank operating through an existing branch, it may be required to establish a UK subsidiary [#SRC:aed1e5a5beeec125]. The SOURCE further indicates that if there is insufficient assurance over home state resolution arrangements, it may be necessary for the firm to be supervised on a more standalone basis consistent with an MPE approach to resolution [#SRC:aed1e5a5beeec125]. The TARGET complements this by stating that the Bank has certain resolution powers over branches, including the power to resolve branches on a standalone basis in certain circumstances [#TGT:5b8d0f16006f4c55]. Read together, the PRA’s willingness to host and its potential requirement for a UK subsidiary and more standalone supervision align with enabling the Bank’s branch resolution powers to be exercised on a standalone basis when the relevant circumstances arise.

question: How must a firm with a matching adjustment permission ensure that its SCR captures all material and quantifiable risks by (i) identifying uncertainties in the timing and amount of cash-flows from assets with highly predictable cash-flows in the relevant portfolio and (ii) reflecting, under stress, resulting changes to the fundamental spread, matching adjustment, and any additions made to the fundamental spread used to calculate technical provisions?
gold_answer: A firm with a matching adjustment permission must start by identifying all sources of uncertainty in the timing and amount of cash-flows for any asset in the relevant portfolio whose cash-flows are highly predictable, so that the firm has a complete view of where cash-flow outcomes could deviate from expectation [#TGT:e9d53c2edcdb5a35]. Building on that identification, the firm’s SCR should capture all material and quantifiable risks to which it is exposed, and the SCR calculation should allow for changes to the fundamental spread and matching adjustment following a stress event [#SRC:c6705600c498e9a1]. To do so, firms should determine the risks to which the matching adjustment portfolio is exposed, evaluate how those risks could affect the fundamental spread and matching adjustment, and assess how the resulting impact is captured within the SCR calculation [#SRC:c6705600c498e9a1]. In stress conditions, changes to the fundamental spread should include changes to any additions made to the fundamental spread used to calculate technical provisions, including additions made as part of the attestation process, and for assets with highly predictable cash flows the SCR should specifically allow for changes to the expected cash-flow pattern and related fundamental spread additions [#SRC:c6705600c498e9a1].

question: If a firm has a matching adjustment permission, what must it do to (1) find all uncertainties in the timing and amount of cash-flows for highly predictable cash-flow assets in the relevant portfolio, and (2) make sure the SCR calculation reflects how those uncertainties could change the fundamental spread, matching adjustment, and expected cash-flow patterns under stress?
gold_answer: A firm with a matching adjustment permission must identify all sources of uncertainty about the timing and amount of cash-flows from any asset in the relevant portfolio where cash-flows are highly predictable, so the firm can understand what could cause cash-flows to differ from expectations [#TGT:e9d53c2edcdb5a35]. The firm must then ensure its SCR captures all material and quantifiable risks it is exposed to, and that the SCR calculation allows for changes to the fundamental spread and matching adjustment after a stress event [#SRC:c6705600c498e9a1]. This means the firm should determine the risks affecting the matching adjustment portfolio, consider how those risks could affect the fundamental spread and matching adjustment, and assess how that effect is captured within the SCR calculation [#SRC:c6705600c498e9a1]. In stress conditions, the firm should include changes to additions made to the fundamental spread used to calculate technical provisions, including additions made through the attestation process, and for assets with highly predictable cash flows the SCR should specifically allow for changes to the expected cash-flow pattern and any related fundamental spread additions [#SRC:c6705600c498e9a1].

question: Who does this Chapter apply to, and if an insurer is covered, what does it have to put in place to run an effective system of governance and manage risk?
gold_answer: This Chapter is limited in scope: it only applies to a large non-directive insurer and a Swiss general insurer [#TGT:5d1441b4dce1a2f4]. If an insurer falls into one of those categories, it must establish an effective system of governance and prudential risk management systems as described in the source passage [#SRC:e007010cf752bc53]. That means the insurer must set a risk appetite or tolerance for risk, and it must have a process to identify, measure, and monitor risk so that risks are understood and tracked over time [#SRC:e007010cf752bc53]. It also must have appropriate systems to convey information to management or the board, ensuring that the people responsible for oversight receive the information needed to govern the business and respond to risk exposures [#SRC:e007010cf752bc53]. In short, the target text defines which insurers are covered, and the source text defines what those covered insurers must implement to meet the governance and risk-management expectation.

question: If a firm plans to issue an instrument with new or complex features, what should it do early with its usual supervisory contact, and who is responsible for making sure the PRA notifications are high quality even if someone else submits the form?
gold_answer: If a firm is planning an issuance with new or complex features—especially where those features could affect eligibility—the PRA expects the firm to engage with its usual supervisory contact as early as possible, for example once the key terms and conditions (including any side agreements) are drafted, and to give a clear explanation of how the proposed features meet the letter and objective of PRA rules and supervisory expectations; the PRA also expects these potentially eligibility-affecting features to be discussed in advance even where the instrument is otherwise subject to post-notification [#SRC:cd48a3e0ac792741]. At the same time, the PRA expects the relevant Senior Management Function (SMF) to take responsibility for the quality of the capital structure overall and to be accountable for the quality of notifications to the PRA, while acknowledging that the act of signing and submitting a notification form may be delegated [#TGT:acd7b7086471f868]. Practically, this means early engagement should be supported by a well-prepared compliance explanation, and the relevant SMF must ensure appropriate oversight so that delegated submission does not reduce accountability for notification quality.

question: When a firm calculates the aggregate value of its assets and is required to reduce that value, how must it treat assets whose valuation was carried out using the approach that has been applied when valuing the assets selected, and within what applicability boundary does that valuation approach operate notwithstanding another valuation provision?
gold_answer: In calculating the aggregate value of the assets of a firm, the firm is under an obligation to reduce that aggregate value by an amount representing the aggregate of specified items, but this obligation operates within a framework that is expressly made subject to a set of related provisions [#TGT:f960c6353f214378]. Separately, the scope condition in the paired text identifies a category of assets for which a particular valuation approach has been applied when valuing the assets selected, and it clarifies that this application occurs notwithstanding another valuation provision referenced in that scope statement [#SRC:478093f2219facc5]. Read together, the firm’s reduction calculation must be performed on the aggregate value figure that reflects (for the relevant selected assets) the fact that the specified valuation approach has been applied, even where that approach overrides the otherwise applicable valuation rule mentioned in the scope condition. Accordingly, the firm should ensure that the assets included in the aggregate value—and therefore the base to which the reduction is applied—properly incorporates the valuation treatment for those selected assets that fall within the scope condition, while still applying the reduction requirement subject to the stated related provisions.

question: If a firm has valued certain selected assets using the valuation approach that has been applied (even though another valuation rule would normally apply), how must the firm handle the required reduction to the aggregate value of its assets when it does its calculation?
gold_answer: The firm must start from the aggregate value of its assets and then reduce that aggregate value by an amount representing the aggregate of the required components, but it must do so within the limits of the provisions that the reduction rule is expressly subject to [#TGT:f960c6353f214378]. At the same time, the paired scope text describes a situation where a particular valuation approach has been applied when valuing the assets selected, and it makes clear that this application happens notwithstanding another valuation provision that would otherwise govern that valuation step [#SRC:478093f2219facc5]. Putting these together, the firm’s reduction calculation should be based on an aggregate asset value that already reflects the correct valuation treatment for those selected assets that fall within the scope condition—i.e., the valuation approach that has been applied for those assets, even where it displaces the other valuation rule referenced. The firm should therefore ensure it identifies which assets are in that category, values them using the specified applied approach, includes them in the aggregate value on that basis, and then applies the required reduction to that aggregate value in the manner required and subject to the stated related provisions.

question: Where the PRA applies the MREL buffer policy and Threshold Conditions policy to MREL set by the Bank for interim and end-state requirements, what is a firm prohibited from doing with CET1 when demonstrating compliance with both MREL and its risk-weighted capital and leverage buffers?
gold_answer: When the PRA applies the MREL buffer policy and the Threshold Conditions policy in respect of MREL set by the Bank for both interim and end-state MREL requirements, firms are expected to manage compliance on a basis that keeps the MREL requirement and the firm’s risk-weighted capital and leverage buffers conceptually distinct [#SRC:140f409993eca2fe]. In that context, the PRA’s prohibition is that firms should not double count CET1 to satisfy both (i) MREL and (ii) the amount of CET1 that reflects the firm’s risk-weighted capital and leverage buffers [#TGT:cf350995c5d698e1]. The PRA expects firms to meet both obligations, but the same CET1 resources should not be used to meet each simultaneously. At the same time, the PRA recognises that firms can meet MREL with CET1, but they are not required to meet MREL with CET1; this flexibility does not remove the expectation that any CET1 held to reflect buffers remains separately maintained and not counted again toward MREL [#TGT:cf350995c5d698e1].

question: If the PRA is applying its MREL buffer policy and Threshold Conditions policy to MREL set by the Bank for interim and end-state MREL, what must a firm not do with CET1 when it is trying to show it meets both MREL and its capital and leverage buffers?
gold_answer: Where the PRA applies the MREL buffer policy and the Threshold Conditions policy in respect of MREL set by the Bank for both interim and end-state MREL requirements, firms should treat the MREL requirement and their buffer-related CET1 as separate expectations that must both be met [#SRC:140f409993eca2fe]. The key prohibition is that the PRA expects firms not to double count CET1 toward both MREL and the amount of CET1 that reflects the firm’s risk-weighted capital and leverage buffers [#TGT:cf350995c5d698e1]. In practice, this means a firm should not point to the same CET1 resources as simultaneously satisfying the MREL requirement and also being the CET1 maintained to reflect its risk-weighted capital and leverage buffers. The PRA also indicates that, while firms can meet MREL with CET1, they do not have to meet MREL with CET1; however, whichever resources are used to meet MREL, the firm must still maintain CET1 that reflects its buffers and must avoid counting that CET1 twice [#TGT:cf350995c5d698e1].

question: Within the Chapter’s applicability to valuation of investments, when the issuer is not permitted to be compelled to purchase units or other beneficial interests, what valuation basis must be used and under what stated condition does this Chapter apply?
gold_answer: The Chapter’s scope is limited to the valuation of investments that comprise securities and beneficial interests in limited partnerships, and it applies only on the stated condition “Subject to 12.2” [#TGT:15680800125ff112]. Within that scoped valuation context, where the issuer cannot be required to purchase the units or other beneficial interests, the valuation basis that must be used is “a value determined in accordance with 12” [#SRC:4e4b8ca3297e05fe]. Read together, the Target establishes that the relevant rules are about valuation (not purchase mechanics) and that their application is expressly conditioned by the Section label “Subject to 12.2,” while the Source specifies the required valuation approach in the particular circumstance that compulsion to purchase units or other beneficial interests is not available. Accordingly, for investments within the Chapter’s defined subject matter, the issuer’s inability to be required to purchase triggers use of the value determined under “12,” but the overall applicability remains constrained by the “Subject to 12.2” condition.

question: If this Chapter covers valuing investments in securities and beneficial interests in limited partnerships, what value should be used when the issuer cannot be forced to buy the units or other beneficial interests, and what condition limits when the Chapter applies?
gold_answer: This Chapter applies to the valuation of investments that comprise securities and beneficial interests in limited partnerships, but its application is expressly limited by the condition “Subject to 12.2” [#TGT:15680800125ff112]. In that valuation setting, if the issuer cannot be required to purchase the units or other beneficial interests, the value to use is “a value determined in accordance with 12” [#SRC:4e4b8ca3297e05fe]. Putting the two together: the Target tells you when the Chapter is in scope (valuation of those types of investments) and flags a specific limiting Section label (“Subject to 12.2”), while the Source tells you what valuation basis applies in the specific case where the issuer cannot be compelled to purchase the relevant units or other beneficial interests. So, for in-scope investments, you use the value determined under “12” in that circumstance, but only insofar as the Chapter applies subject to “12.2.”

question: How must the firm’s governing body make sure it stays confident that the firm’s systems meet the requirement to clearly mark beneficiary accounts (including client and trust accounts) so they can be identified immediately when they contain or may contain eligible deposits?
gold_answer: The firm needs a clear governance procedure explaining how the firm’s governing body will ensure it remains satisfied that the firm’s systems comply with the applicable requirements over time [#SRC:d11985b37b3a54b1]. That ongoing assurance must cover the concrete obligation placed on the firm’s systems and processes: the firm must mark accounts held on behalf of beneficiaries—specifically including client accounts and trust accounts—where those accounts contain or may contain eligible deposits, and the marking must be done in a way that allows those accounts to be identified immediately [#TGT:68113e9f6b9da4d1]. So, the governing body’s procedure should be designed to check that the marking is actually applied to all relevant accounts, that it captures both “contain” and “may contain” situations, and that the result is immediate identifiability. The procedure should also set out how the governing body will keep monitoring this (not just at one point in time) so it can continue to be satisfied that the systems are operating as required and that the account-marking outcome remains in place.

question: When payments are treated as deferred for levy-related calculations, may the PRA permit a class A2 member to defer paying its share of a recapitalisation payment levy, and what limits and renewal conditions apply to that deferral?
gold_answer: Yes. Where the framework contemplates “payments deferred” as a relevant input to levy-related calculations (including how levies are calculated after an assumption of liability and other specified calculations) [#SRC:ce527b7017646a7a], the PRA is permitted to defer, in whole or in part, a class A2 member’s obligation to pay its share of a recapitalisation payment levy, but only where the PRA considers that making the contribution would jeopardise the liquidity or solvency of the firm [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b]. The deferral is time-limited: it cannot be granted for more than six months at a time [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b]. However, the deferral may be renewed, and the renewal is conditional on the firm making a request for renewal [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b]. In practice, this means the PRA’s permission to defer payment operates as a temporary relief mechanism tied to the firm’s liquidity/solvency risk, while the broader levy-calculation context recognises that deferred payments can affect how levies are handled in related calculation scenarios [#SRC:ce527b7017646a7a].

question: When the firm is treated as having acquired or disposed of assets because it has achieved the effect of a contract by entering into appropriate futures contracts or options, how must the firm adjust the value ascribed under the relevant valuation provisions, and how must those deemed asset movements be handled for subsequent treatment?
gold_answer: Where the firm is deemed to have achieved the effect of a contract by entering into appropriate futures contracts or options, it follows that the firm is also deemed to have acquired or disposed of certain assets. In that situation, the firm must reflect those deemed asset movements in two linked ways. First, the firm must adjust the value ascribed under the applicable valuation range by increasing or decreasing it by an amount that represents the value of the assets the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of under the relevant deeming basis [#TGT:490d874efaa81343]. Second, the assets that are deemed to be acquired or disposed of are not left unaddressed: they must be dealt with in accordance with the provisions that apply to deemed acquisitions and deemed disposals respectively, ensuring the firm applies the correct treatment depending on whether the deemed movement is an acquisition or a disposal [#SRC:83c9a3a543a7d699]. Taken together, the obligation is to translate the deemed economic effect created through futures contracts or options into a corresponding valuation adjustment, and then to process the resulting deemed assets under the appropriate acquisition/disposal handling provisions.

question: Where the PRA has consented to a transferee society proceeding by board resolution (so the transferee society is exempt from putting Merger Resolutions and sending a Schedule 16 Statement to its members), what must the societies concerned still do to ensure members are properly informed about the confirmation hearing and completion timing, and how does this link to the requirement to agree a provisional timetable with the PRA’s staff?
gold_answer: When the PRA has consented to a transferee society proceeding by board resolution, the transferee society is permitted to proceed without putting Merger Resolutions to its members and without sending a Schedule 16 Statement to its members [#SRC:98fdd2a7fe5b0420]. However, the societies concerned still have an essential obligation to support good and orderly management of the merger by meeting with the PRA’s staff as soon as their boards have resolved to seek a merger and agreeing a provisional timetable, which can then be fixed by the time the Schedule 16 Statement is approved [#TGT:513958170c8d776a]. Building on that timetable, members must be notified in the Merger Document of (i) the date provisionally set for the confirmation hearing and (ii) the proposed date of completion of the merger [#TGT:513958170c8d776a]. In practice, the permission affecting Merger Resolutions and the Schedule 16 Statement does not remove the need for early engagement with the PRA’s staff and timely member notification of key dates; it changes certain member-approval and document-sending steps for the transferee society while leaving intact the broader timetable-setting and member-notification requirements.

question: When calculating and disclosing changes in the economic value of equity under six supervisory shock scenarios for the current and previous disclosure periods, how must a firm apply the prescribed interest rate scenarios across currencies, and what determines the scope of currencies to which those scenarios must be applied?
gold_answer: A firm’s obligation to calculate and disclose the changes in the economic value of equity under six supervisory shock scenarios for the current and previous disclosure periods must be carried out using the prescribed interest rate scenarios that the firm is required to apply for the relevant evaluation. Specifically, the firm must apply the prescribed interest rate scenarios to all material currencies, with materiality determined as specified for that purpose, so that the economic value of equity changes produced under the six supervisory shock scenarios are generated on a currency-complete basis for all currencies that meet the materiality determination. This links the disclosure of economic value of equity changes under the six supervisory shock scenarios for the current and previous disclosure periods [#SRC:c83e5203dad7e1bc] to the requirement that, for the purposes of the evaluation, the firm must apply the prescribed interest rate scenarios to all material currencies as determined [#TGT:e1e527ecb87d369a]. In practice, the firm should ensure its calculations and resulting disclosures reflect scenario application consistently across the set of material currencies, rather than limiting scenario application to a subset that would omit required currency exposures.

question: If a firm is reporting the change in the economic value of equity under six supervisory shock scenarios for the current and previous disclosure periods, what does it have to do with the prescribed interest rate scenarios, and which currencies must be covered?
gold_answer: When a firm reports the changes in the economic value of equity calculated under six supervisory shock scenarios for the current and previous disclosure periods, it must ensure those calculations are produced using the prescribed interest rate scenarios that apply for the evaluation. The prescribed interest rate scenarios are not optional or limited to a single currency: the firm must apply them to all material currencies, with materiality determined under the relevant determination referenced for that purpose. This means the firm’s economic value of equity change figures under the six supervisory shock scenarios should reflect scenario impacts across every currency that qualifies as material, so the disclosure for both the current and previous disclosure periods is based on scenario application that is complete for the firm’s material currency set. The disclosure element—changes in economic value of equity under six supervisory shock scenarios for the current and previous disclosure periods [#SRC:c83e5203dad7e1bc]—therefore depends on meeting the evaluation requirement to apply prescribed interest rate scenarios to all material currencies as determined [#TGT:e1e527ecb87d369a].

question: If the rules say a firm must have an audit committee and the text refers to a “governing body,” what does “governing body” mean when the rule is applied to the Society, and who does that make responsible for having the audit committee in place?
gold_answer: When the provisions are applied to the Society, the term “governing body” is not read in a generic way; it must be interpreted as referring to the Council [#SRC:f9ba2c73cf9c8afc]. That interpretation then feeds directly into the obligation that a firm must have an audit committee that meets the stated criteria and is responsible for performing the stated functions [#TGT:19455d2a9ac4ced6]. In other words, in the Society context, the Council is the body that should be treated as the “governing body” for purposes of understanding where governance-level responsibility sits in relation to the audit committee requirement. The requirement itself is that the firm has an audit committee meeting the criteria and with responsibility for the functions described, but the definitional instruction clarifies which body is meant by “governing body” when applying the text to the Society, so responsibility and oversight should be mapped to the Council in that applied scenario [#SRC:f9ba2c73cf9c8afc] [#TGT:19455d2a9ac4ced6].

question: For a subsidiary, what qualifies as a Statement of Responsibilities for purposes of ensuring it is kept current, and what must the subsidiary do to maintain those Statements of Responsibilities as up to date alongside its Management Responsibilities Map?
gold_answer: A subsidiary should treat “Statements of Responsibilities” as the specific Statements of Responsibilities that are required by section 60(2A) of FSMA, rather than any informal internal role descriptions, because the definition in scope is tied to that statutory requirement [#TGT:9de8b5441f652d6e]. On that basis, the subsidiary must focus its governance controls on keeping those FSMA-required Statements of Responsibilities current: it should particularly ensure that its Management Responsibilities Map and its Statements of Responsibilities (SoR) are up to date, and that responsibilities are allocated in accordance with the Allocation of Responsibilities Part of the PRA Rulebook and SS28/15 [#SRC:f199857a7c43ed1d]. Practically, this means the subsidiary should maintain an appropriate number of SMFs for its size, complexity, and governance structure, and then ensure the documented responsibilities for those SMFs are reflected accurately and kept current in both the Map and the SoR, so that the allocation of responsibilities remains aligned with the relevant PRA framework and the principles referenced.

question: When the text says a subsidiary must keep Statements of Responsibilities up to date, which Statements of Responsibilities does it mean, and what does the subsidiary need to do with them (and the Management Responsibilities Map) to meet the requirement?
gold_answer: Here, “Statements of Responsibilities” means the Statements of Responsibilities that are required by section 60(2A) of FSMA, not just any internal job description or organisation chart [#TGT:9de8b5441f652d6e]. Using that definition, the subsidiary should particularly ensure two key documents stay current: its Management Responsibilities Map and its Statements of Responsibilities (SoR) [#SRC:f199857a7c43ed1d]. The subsidiary is also expected to make sure responsibilities are allocated in line with the Allocation of Responsibilities Part of the PRA Rulebook and SS28/15, so “up to date” is not only about refreshing dates or formatting but about keeping the recorded responsibilities accurate as the business changes [#SRC:f199857a7c43ed1d]. In the same context, the subsidiary should ensure it has an appropriate number of SMFs for its size, complexity, and governance structure, because changes in SMFs or governance will affect what must be reflected in the SoR and the Map.

question: When performing the required validation of technical provisions, how must a firm determine whether the assumptions used in the calculation are sufficiently adequate and realistic, and in what circumstances are those assumptions treated as realistic for the relevant technical provisions purpose?
gold_answer: In validating technical provisions, the firm must ensure its validation work explicitly covers the adequacy and realism of the assumptions used in the calculation, as part of the broader validation scope that also includes checks on the appropriateness, completeness and accuracy of data, the appropriateness of any grouping of policies, remedies for data limitations, and the appropriateness of approximations used to calculate the best estimate [#SRC:146ec8f0b2f81994]. However, the firm cannot treat assumptions as “realistic” merely by internal judgement; the scope of when assumptions may be considered realistic is constrained by the Technical Provisions Part, which states that assumptions are only considered realistic for the relevant purpose where they meet all specified conditions [#TGT:61fa99eb8c5cced6]. Practically, this means the firm’s validation must (i) assess adequacy and realism as a required validation topic and (ii) apply the Technical Provisions Part’s conditional test for realism as the boundary for that assessment, so that any conclusion that assumptions are realistic is supported by meeting all of the conditions set for that purpose [#SRC:146ec8f0b2f81994] [#TGT:61fa99eb8c5cced6].

question: For a firm validating its technical provisions, what must it check about the assumptions used in the calculation, and when can those assumptions be treated as realistic under the Technical Provisions Part?
gold_answer: A firm’s validation of technical provisions must include a specific check on the adequacy and realism of the assumptions used in the calculation, alongside other required validation areas such as the appropriateness, completeness and accuracy of the data, the appropriateness of any grouping of policies, remedies for data limitations, and the appropriateness of approximations used for calculating the best estimate [#SRC:146ec8f0b2f81994]. But the firm’s ability to label assumptions as “realistic” is not open-ended. The Technical Provisions Part limits that label by stating that assumptions shall only be considered realistic for the relevant purpose where they meet all of the listed conditions [#TGT:61fa99eb8c5cced6]. So, in practice, the firm must do two linked things: first, include adequacy and realism of assumptions as a mandatory validation topic; second, apply the Technical Provisions Part’s “meet all conditions” test as the scope boundary for concluding that assumptions are realistic for that purpose [#SRC:146ec8f0b2f81994] [#TGT:61fa99eb8c5cced6].

question: If a society is merging product lines, when do updates count as changes to the terms and conditions for PIBS 26, and what exactly are Permanent interest-bearing shares in that context?
gold_answer: Updates count as changes to the terms and conditions when they affect any of the listed instruments or accounts, including “PIBS 26” and “share and deposit accounts,” and this expressly includes changes made as part of integrating the product lines of the transferor society(ies) into those of the transferee or successor society [#SRC:3bbbda00879e9203]. To apply that scope correctly, you need to identify what the instrument is: “Permanent interest-bearing shares” are defined as “a type of deferred share” [#TGT:91aeec4ad31299e3]. That definition matters because it tells you that Permanent interest-bearing shares are a share type (deferred share) and therefore sit naturally within the “share” side of the listed scope, rather than being treated as CCDS or PPDS [#SRC:3bbbda00879e9203]. So, if the integration work changes the product terms attached to Permanent interest-bearing shares (as deferred shares), those changes should be treated as changes to the terms and conditions in the same way as changes to CCDS, PPDS, “PIBS 26,” and other share and deposit account terms [#SRC:3bbbda00879e9203] [#TGT:91aeec4ad31299e3].

question: If you need the Bank’s indicative thresholds for setting preferred resolution strategies and MREL requirements, what documents or webpages should you use, and where on the Bank of England site is the right link?
gold_answer: Use the SOURCE to identify what content you need and the TARGET to find where to access it. The SOURCE explains that the detail on the Bank’s indicative thresholds used to set preferred resolution strategies and MREL requirements is in the Bank’s approach to resolution, and it separately notes that thresholds for reporting under the Resolvability Assessment Framework are in the PRA RAF SS 4/19 document on resolution assessment and public disclosure by firms [#SRC:5423b3916f47b476]. The TARGET then tells you how to reach the Bank’s approach to resolution online: it points to the Bank of England’s resolution page and indicates that you should use the link to the “framework for resolution” located under “Why we need a resolution regime” [#TGT:001a06cd5d5a94ac]. Putting both together, you would go to the Bank of England resolution webpage to access the framework material that supports the Bank’s approach to resolution for the indicative thresholds, and you would consult the PRA RAF SS 4/19 for RAF reporting thresholds.

question: For model governance documentation, how should a firm define and evidence the model’s operating boundaries when describing the purpose and intended use of a model for a relevant product or portfolio, including how the intended use compares to actual use and when use conditions would be treated as outside those boundaries?
gold_answer: When documenting the purpose and use of a model, the firm should set out the relevant product or portfolio and clearly describe the intended use of the model alongside a comparison to its actual use, and then specify the model operating boundaries under which performance is expected to be acceptable [#SRC:eee778735c44195f]. The operating boundaries should be defined in terms of the sample data range used to measure model performance, including (where applicable) the empirical variance-covariance relationships in multivariate settings [#TGT:67bcc3ea827b033b]. In practice, this means the firm should identify the data domain and conditions represented in the performance measurement dataset and treat model application outside that domain as a boundary breach. Where actual use extends beyond the sample data range (for example, applying the model under shock or stressed economic conditions such as extreme macroeconomic indices), the firm should assume increased model risk and reflect that in its governance narrative and controls, because extrapolation beyond operating boundaries is explicitly associated with increased model risk [#TGT:67bcc3ea827b033b]. This linkage ensures the stated purpose/use and the acceptable-performance conditions are consistent and testable [#SRC:eee778735c44195f].

question: When you write up what a model is for and how it is used on a product or portfolio, what does “operating boundaries” mean, and how do you tell if the model is being used outside those boundaries compared with its intended use?
gold_answer: In the model description, you should explain the purpose and use of the model, identify the relevant product or portfolio, and state the intended use with a comparison to the model’s actual use; you must also describe the model operating boundaries under which performance is expected to be acceptable [#SRC:eee778735c44195f]. “Operating boundaries” means the sample data range used to measure model performance, including the empirical variance-covariance relationships if the model is multivariate [#TGT:67bcc3ea827b033b]. To tell whether the model is being used outside those boundaries, compare the conditions and data characteristics of the actual use case to the sample data range and relationships that were used for performance measurement. If actual use requires extrapolating beyond that range—such as applying the model when macroeconomic indices reflect shock or stressed economic conditions—then it should be treated as outside the operating boundaries and assumed to involve increased model risk [#TGT:67bcc3ea827b033b]. This check ties the “intended vs actual use” comparison to a concrete, data-based boundary definition [#SRC:eee778735c44195f].

question: Where the PRA has deferred, in whole or in part, a class A2 member’s obligation to pay its share of a recapitalisation payment levy because payment would jeopardise the liquidity or solvency of the firm, when must the deferred amount be paid, and what limits apply to the duration and renewal of the deferral?
gold_answer: If the PRA defers, in whole or in part, a class A2 member’s obligation to pay a share of a recapitalisation payment levy because the PRA considers the contribution would jeopardise the liquidity or solvency of the firm, the deferred contribution must be paid once making the payment no longer jeopardises the liquidity and solvency of the firm [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b] [#SRC:f026573295165d20]. The deferral is time-limited: it must not be granted for longer than six months at a time, but it may be renewed if the firm requests renewal [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b]. Accordingly, the compliance expectation is that the firm monitors whether the original jeopardy condition has ceased and, when it has, ensures payment is made without waiting for the end of any deferral period, while also tracking the six‑month cap and submitting a renewal request if the PRA’s deferral needs to continue because the jeopardy condition persists [#SRC:f026573295165d20] [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b].

question: When a derivative is included only unless an exception applies, when do you have to use the rule for valuing rights under that derivative, and what two main pieces make up that value?
gold_answer: You have to use the valuation rule only when the item is treated as “a derivative” within the scope and is not taken out by the stated exception condition (“except as provided …”) [#SRC:80829761ce022abc]. Once that scope test is met for a derivative—or for a contract or asset that has the effect of a derivative—the required value is not open-ended; it is defined by the rights you can enforce. Specifically, the value of the rights arising under the derivative must be the value of your right to recover assets that were transferred by way of initial margin, together with the value of any other unconditional right to receive a specified amount [#TGT:5f3ef81aedf2a03b]. So the “when” comes from the source’s exception-based inclusion of derivatives, and the “how” comes from the target’s instruction to build the value from (1) initial margin recovery rights and (2) other unconditional specified-amount receivables.

question: For purposes of member communications in a transfer process, how should a society distinguish the document it is permitted to send to members in place of the full Transfer Statement from the full Transfer Statement itself, including when and to whom that substitute document may be sent and how this relates to the PRA’s role in approving the Transfer Statement?
gold_answer: The substitute document is the Transfer Summary: it is defined as a summary of the Transfer Statement that may be sent instead of the Transfer Statement, and it is specifically tied to the notice of the meeting at which the Transfer Resolutions are to be considered. Under the definition, the Transfer Summary may, in accordance with Schedule 17 to the 1986 Act, be sent in or with that meeting notice to every member entitled to receive the notice, rather than sending the full Transfer Statement itself [#TGT:a14772d46835cf4f]. In the broader transfer process context, the chapter explains that the PRA has a role in approving the Transfer Statement that must be sent to the members, and also has a role in the confirmation procedure and ongoing prudential supervision during the transfer process [#SRC:bc1b187c93910ab0]. Read together, this means the society’s permission to use the Transfer Summary operates as an alternative method of member communication in the meeting-notice context, while the PRA’s approval role remains anchored to the Transfer Statement that is otherwise required to be sent to members [#SRC:bc1b187c93910ab0] and the Transfer Summary’s defined use-case [#TGT:a14772d46835cf4f].

question: What is the Transfer Summary, and when can a society send it to members instead of the Transfer Statement, given that the PRA approves the Transfer Statement that must be sent to members?
gold_answer: The Transfer Summary is defined as the summary of the Transfer Statement that may be sent instead of the Transfer Statement, and it is linked to the notice for the meeting where the Transfer Resolutions will be considered. Specifically, it may (in accordance with Schedule 17 to the 1986 Act) be sent in or with the notice of that meeting to every member who is entitled to receive the notice [#TGT:a14772d46835cf4f]. The source context explains that the PRA’s role includes approving the Transfer Statement, which must be sent to the members, and that the chapter also covers the PRA’s role in the confirmation procedure and its ongoing prudential supervision during the transfer process [#SRC:bc1b187c93910ab0]. Putting these together, the society’s ability to send the Transfer Summary is a permitted alternative to sending the full Transfer Statement in the specific meeting-notice setting, while the PRA’s approval role remains tied to the Transfer Statement that is otherwise required to be sent to members during the transfer process [#SRC:bc1b187c93910ab0] and the defined scope of the Transfer Summary [#TGT:a14772d46835cf4f].

question: How must the credit union determine and maintain, over time, the quantity and quality of its liquid assets, and how does that ongoing approach interact with the requirement to hold liquid assets at a minimum percentage of total relevant liabilities?
gold_answer: The credit union must manage liquidity on an ongoing basis by determining and maintaining, over time, both the quantity and the quality of liquid assets it holds, and it must do so in a way that takes account of the applicable minimum liquidity requirement [#SRC:f2622a90a592c4ce]. In practical terms, this means the credit union’s liquidity framework cannot focus only on the amount of liquid assets at a single point in time; it must also consider the suitability (quality) of those assets and ensure the position is maintained over time, while still meeting the minimum quantitative floor. The minimum floor is that a credit union must hold liquid assets equal to at least 10% of its total relevant liabilities [#TGT:738a19e25819dedf]. Accordingly, the credit union should treat the 10% threshold as a baseline within its broader, continuing assessment of how much liquidity it needs and what form that liquidity should take, ensuring that its maintained liquid asset position remains at or above the minimum relative to total relevant liabilities while also addressing the quality dimension referenced in its ongoing maintenance obligation [#SRC:f2622a90a592c4ce] and the specific percentage requirement [#TGT:738a19e25819dedf].

question: When setting internal expectations for liquidity, what must the credit union do to ensure the maintained quantity and quality of liquid assets over time does not fall below the minimum level tied to total relevant liabilities?
gold_answer: The credit union must establish and operate an approach to liquidity that addresses both the quantity and the quality of liquid assets it maintains over time, explicitly taking into account the minimum liquidity requirements that apply to it [#SRC:f2622a90a592c4ce]. This obligation requires the credit union to look beyond a one-off calculation and instead ensure that its liquid asset holdings remain appropriate and sustainable as conditions change, while still meeting the minimum quantitative requirement. The minimum quantitative requirement is clear: a credit union must hold liquid assets equal to at least 10% of its total relevant liabilities [#TGT:738a19e25819dedf]. Therefore, internal expectations and monitoring should be calibrated so that, at all times, the maintained stock of liquid assets is not only of sufficient quality and managed over time, but also remains at or above the 10% of total relevant liabilities threshold.
